Nov. 6: Lewis pleads guilty in a plea bargain to two counts of conspiring to distribute cocaine and names Barry as a person for whom he bought crack cocaine while staying at the hotel where Barry visited him in 1988. Nov. 27, 1989: A local television station reports that the 1983 hernia episode was reported to police as a drug overdose; police say they investigated at the time but found no substantiation. Dec. 12: Published report says FBI report includes evidence the agency believes could support allegations that Barry used drugs. Jan. 7, 1990: Los Angeles Times publishes interview in which Barry ridicules potential mayoral challenger Jesse Jackson. Jan. 18, 1990: Barry is arrested on a drug charge in a downtown hotel. Jan. 21, 1990: Barry announces he will seek assistance ``to heal my body, mind and soul,'' but makes no mention of drug abuse. Jan. 22, 1990: Barry checks into Hanley-Hazelden Treatment Center in West Palm Beach, Fla. His spokeswoman says the mayor will be treated for alcoholism. Feb. 15, 1990: A federal grand jury indicts Barry on eight counts of perjury and possession of a controlled substance.

DOC.HEAD: With PM-Barry, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Here is the text of the statement issued by Washington Mayor Marion S. Barry Jr.

Today's indictment does not surprise me at all, because it represents a continuation of the political lynching and excesses of the Justice Department in this multi-year, multimillion-dollar effort to investigate me and the Barry administration. I am not surprised; in fact, if it has to happen, I'm glad it's now rather than later, and I am relieved that the indictment has finally been issued and the suspense has ended. All of the calculated, carefully orchestrated rumors and leaks by the federal government have put a damper on the city and its people. But now that we will be moving into the courtroom _ which is where this case should be tried, not in the press _ I am relieved. I know that when a trial is held, I will be exonerated. Until that time, I urge the public to hold fast to our democratic principle that presumes a person to be innocent until proven guilty in a court of law. I further ask that members of the media exercise restraint and professionalism in not seeking to interview me or my family about this matter that now clearly will be in the hands of the court. I will have nothing to say about this case outside the courtroom. As I continue to undergo the healing of my mind, body and soul, I want to assure the residents of Washington D.C. that I am not considering resignation. An indictment is not a finding of guilty _ it is simply a formal charge based on the presentation of only one side of the evidence. Now, I have the right to defend myself against that charge. I also want to tell you that I am firmly committed to continuing to focus on my recovery from the disease of alcoholism and its attendant problems _ a disease that affects millions of Americans, including such notable and courageous individuals as former first lady Betty Ford. I have derived great benefit from my stay here at the alcohol rehabilitation center in Florida, and I know that recovery is a lifelong process to which I have dedicated myself. But for now, as I go through this healing process, I want to make sure that my wife and our son are psychologically and emotionally comfortable, after all that we have through and will be going through, as a family. I do not want them badgered and dogged at every turn. They do not suffer from the disease, I do. Any consequences should be mine to bear, not theirs. I am extremely proud of the way my management team, headed by City Administrator Carol Thompson, has handled the affairs of government in my absence. I know this budget period is a tough time for Carol; my staff director, Maudine Cooper; Deputy Mayors Bob Pohlman and Wylie Williams; Director of Special Services, Tina Smith; and the agency directors who must explain the serious realities of the city's financial picture during an election year. I know citizens need assurance that their needs will be met, and that the same high quality government services will continue uninterrupted in spite of the mean-spirited and calculating people who would like to see us fail as a local government. I put a strong management team in place, and I can reassure you that government is operating smoothly, efficiently and effectively _ and under the Barry philosophy of quality, compassionate, competent and caring service. I want to say to all that when I decided to go away to deal with my health concerns, my political decisions were placed on hold and will be determined within the next 60 days. Anita Bonds is the only person designated and authorized by me to speak on political matters. My lawyer, Kenneth Mundy, and I are now preparing to go to court and win this case. I will have no announcement about my political future at this point. I hope the media will respect my right to continue my recovery, in private, and allow me to obtain the full benefit of treatment for this disease. During my absence, I urge you to respect the rights of my wife and my son to lead private lives as we go forward during this highly political legal procedure. I ask that you confine your questions about the legal case to my attorney. Any other questions about me should be directed to my press secretary, Lurma Rackley. To all of you who continue to remember me, my family, and this city in your prayers, I sincerely thank you.

DOC.HEAD: EPA Adds 71 Sites to Cleanup List
With PM-Superfund List
DOC.TEXT: The Environmental Protection Agency is adding 71 hazardous waste sites, including 14 Defense Department installations, to its national priority cleanup list. The action on Thursday brings the total number of sites on the list to 1,081. The 71 sites previously had been proposed for listing and had undergone a final review before being placed on the cleanup list. Another 137 sites have been proposed for cleanup under the federal Superfund law, but still await final reviews, officials said. The action brings the total number of defense facilities on the priority cleanup list to 75. One site was dropped from the list, the Keyser Avenue Borehole in Scranton, Pa. Officials said it did not pose a big enough health threat for listing. Placement on the list makes non-federal sites eligible for federal cleanup aid.

DOC.HEAD: Highlights of Drug Summit Communique
DOC.TEXT: Following are highlights of the 13-page communique signed by the presidents of the United States, Colombia, Peru and Bolivia to fight illicit drugs. The nations pledged to work together toward ``dynamic programs'' to fight the flow of drugs from the Andean nations to the United States. The statement broke no new ground, but sounded a strong theme of cooperation. ``The parties recognize that trafficking in illicit drugs has a negative, long-term impact on their economies,'' it asserted. Specifically, the presidents agreed: _They would cooperate in exchanging information and intelligence. But, in an apparent foreclosure of the use of U.S. military forces in the region, the communique asserted ``each country may involve its armed forces in this fight within its own national territory.'' Still the United States agreed ``to provide increased equipment and training to the law enforcement agencies and the militaries of the Andean parties.'' _They will call for a ``world conference against illicit drug trafficking in 1991'' and hold a high-level followup to Thursday's four-nation session ``within six months.'' _The United States would help train Andean farmers on how to switch to other crops to substitute for the lucrative coca harvest. _Bush will request an economic aid package of an unspecified amount from Congress for fiscal 1991 to 1994 to help offset ``significant, immediate and long-term costs'' caused by the loss of the coca crop in the three Andean countries. The president has earlier pledged a total of $2.2 billion in economic and military anti-drug assistance for the Andean nations over five years. _The United States will try to open its markets more to South American goods and to provide balance-of-payments assistance to help stabilize the economies of the drug-production countries, which have rampant inflation. _The Bush administration will work for more private investment in the Andean nations. _The four countries will sponsor programs to strengthen public awareness of drug problems. ``The parties reaffirm their will to fight drug trafficking in a comprehensive manner attacking all facets of the trade: production, transportation and consumption,'' the statement said. On the sensitive issue of military involvement, the communique said ``the control of illegal trafficking is essentially a law enforcement matter'' rather than a military one. However, it says that because of the ``magnitude'' of the problem, ``the armed forces in each of these countries, within their own territory and national jurisdictions, may also participate.'' The statement also calls for better intelligence-gathering cooperation, stepped up enforcement, more control of chemicals used to manufacture drugs, tighter restrictions on ``weapons, planes, ships, explosives and communications equipment'' used in drug trafficking. All the parties agreed to ``strengthen controls over the movement of illegal weapons.'' The Andean nations have complained that semi-automatic weapons made in the United States are finding their way into the hands of drug traffickers. However, Bush thus far has resisted proposals to change U.S. laws to further restrict the manufacture and export of such firearms. In addition to the multilateral communique, the United States reached six bilateral agreements with the other countries. Those incorporate: _An agreement with Bolivia in which the State Department will ``help diminish that flow of U.S. light arms and other arms to drug traffickers in the Andean countries'' by requiring weapons exporters to obtain an import certificate from the importing government before the United States will issue an export license. The administration also committed to further discussions to determine what weapons are covered by the directive, and to ``pursuing discussion'' with other governments concerned about limiting the flow of U.S. weapons to illegitimate end users in the Andean countries. _An extradition agreement with Peru, asserting that narcotics traffickers are extraditable under Peru's 1889 extradition treaty with the United States. _An agreement with Peru to exchange tax records, bank statements and other information to uncover drug profiteering and money laundering. It also calls for prosecution of tax evasion to catch drug dealers, and exchanges of technical information to improve tax compliance. _An agreement with Bolivia pledging cooperation and information-sharing to crack down on illegal U.S. exports of chemicals used to manufacture cocaine. The countries vowed to promptly investigate the destination of such chemicals and seize those destined for illicit points. The agreement requires domestic legislation if needed to provide for such seizure. _Public awareness agreements with Peru and Bolivia to build public support against narcotics production, distribution and use. They also call for establishment of a computerized data base on anti-drug activities, and joint sponsorship of mass media projects to promote information-sharing about drug problems and solutions.

DOC.HEAD: Government May Borrow Up to $44 Billion More for Thrift Bailout
DOC.TEXT: The Bush administration is moving forward with plans to borrow as much as $44 billion more this year to finance its savings and loan bailout, but it's leaving unresolved the politically touchy question of how the borrowing will affect the budget deficit. A Treasury Department-led board overseeing the Resolution Trust Corp. is expected to formally approve the plan as soon as today. Oversight board staff members on Thursday told congressional aides the borrowing could start at the end of this month, total as much as $11 billion by the end of March and $44 billion by the end of the year. The private briefings on Capitol Hill followed a ruling from the Justice Department that the RTC, created to dispose of failed thrifts, may legally borrow from the Federal Financing Bank, a conduit for funneling Treasury money to government agencies. S&L bailout legislation enacted in August provided $50 billion through next year to cover the losses in failed thrift institutions. But the RTC needs to temporarily borrow as much as $100 billion more. The borrowing, called ``working capital,'' would be repaid as the government sold loans, real estate and other assets inherited from failed thrifts. However, the politically sensitive issue of what impact the borrowing will have on the budget deficit remains up in the air. The Office of Management and Budget has the authority to decide how to account for the borrowing, but it plans to consult with Congress before making the decision, according to OMB spokeswoman Barbara Clay. Rep. Charles Schumer, D-N.Y., a member of the Banking and Budget committees, and other congressional Democrats say they are worried the administration will allow the deficit to balloon for the current fiscal year, now that it's too late to trigger automatic spending cuts under the Gramm-Rudman Law. Later, when S&L assets are sold and the working capital is repaid, it would cut the budget deficit number and hide the true scope of government spending, the Democrats maintain. ``It's the worst type of budget gimmickry,'' Schumer said. But ``it is a juicy morsel in the eyes of any person trying to make it look like the budget was balanced.'' Meanwhile, economists said the extra Treasury borrowing could, at least temporarily, drive up short-term interest rates. Economist David Jones of Aubrey G. Lanston & Co., a government securities dealer in New York, said consumers with adjustable-rate home mortgages or home equity loans tied to the one-year Treasury bill may see their payments take a jump. However, economist Elliott Platt of Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Securities Corp. said any upset in interest rates would be short-lived. ``Apart from a little short-term friction ... there's probably going to be relatively little effect on interest rates overall,'' he said. Meanwhile, RTC oversight staff members said, at least for now, two other more expensive methods of raising working capital won't be used. In one, the government would solicit large, government-guaranteed deposits for failed thrifts from institutional investors such as pension funds. In the other, the administration would borrow through the Federal Home Loan Bank System, the quasi-governmental financing arm of the S&L industry. Also, they said, the $44 billion estimate for working capital in 1990 does not include additional funds that could be used to pay off high-cost deposits in failed thrifts controlled by the government. The $11 billion estimate for this quarter includes about $3 billion to pay off high-cost deposits, they said.

DOC.HEAD: Coast Guard Chief `Delighted' With California Spill Cleanup
DOC.TEXT: The head of the Coast Guard says he's satisfied with the cleanup of an oil spill off the California coast despite a congressman's contention the service overstated its readiness. ``I'm delighted with the cleanup,'' Adm. Paul A. Yost said Thursday in an interview. ``I'll stand by the cleanup.'' Yost made the comment after Rep. George Miller, D-Calif., charged that Yost last August said the Coast Guard was capable of cleaning up far more than it actually did at the California spill. Miller said Yost told him in a letter that under ideal conditions, 161,500 barrels of oil would have been recovered within 72 hours of a spill off Southern California. Miller said the cleanup of the Feb. 7 spill by the American Trader, although much smaller than that of the Exxon Valdez in Alaska last March, reached only 2,762 barrels four days later _ 2 percent of what the Coast Guard had estimated. The American Trader spilled 400,000 gallons _ about 9,500 barrels _ of crude oil as it tried to moor about two miles offshore. The Exxon Valdez spilled more than 10 million gallons of crude when it went aground. ``I think everything that could be mobilized was mobilized here to deal with it,'' Miller said of the California spill, adding that weather and other conditions were as close to ideal for a cleanup as could be expected. ``All evidence would suggest that if you had a spill the size of the Exxon Valdez off the Huntington Beach we'd probably be lynching the executives of British Petroleum at this time,'' Miller said, referring to the company that chartered the American Trader. Miller had asked the Coast Guard for its appraisal of the cleanup capabilities off the California coast as a result of the Exxon Valdez disaster, the nation's worst oil spill. Yost said that model cannot be applied to the current spill. ``He asked for a benchmark,'' Yost said. ``I said in my answer this was an unrealistic situation.'' Yost said the two situations can't be compared because skimming would be much easier with a larger spill, since the oil lies on the ocean in much thicker layers. He added that in an ideal situation the water would be placid, while in the California situation there was a ``slight chop.'' ``We picked up 30 percent,'' he said. ``That's a higher percentage of oil slick than in any large spill in history.'' Miller, chairman of the House Interior subcommittee on water, power and offshore energy resources, is trying to win passage of oil spill liability legislation. House and Senate negotiators are working on a compromise measure. The Coast Guard participates in and supervises oil spill cleanups, but state and local governments and private industry provide most of the capability. Resources include skimmers, barges, helicopters, airplanes, fire booms and pumps.

DOC.HEAD: Bush, Latin Leaders Avoid Controversial Issues During Summit
LaserColor CART2, LaserPhotos CART1,3,4,6
DOC.TEXT: President Bush and three Latin American leaders agreed on a new drug-fighting strategy but steered away from a disputed U.S. initiative during a tightly guarded one-day summit. Bush said he and the leaders of the three largest cocaine-producing nations formed the first ``anti-drug cartel,'' but a joint communique vowing closer coordination on the war on drugs apparently ruled out expanding the use of U.S. military force in Bolivia, Colombia and Peru to combat cocaine traffickers. ``Each country may involve its armed forces in this fight in its own territory,'' said the communique, signed by Bush, Bolivia's Jaime Paz Zamora, Colombia's Virgilio Barco and Peru's Alan Garcia. Latin leaders had opposed a U.S. plan to send a naval force to interdict cocaine shipments in the international waters off Colombia's coast. At the summit, Bush promised to step up the fight against U.S. drug use and outlined emergency programs to help offset the weakening of Peru's and Bolivia's economies as they fight to reduce and eventually eliminate cultivation of coca, used to make cocaine. But Garcia later questioned if the United States could come up with the money to pay for such expensive programs. ``Where's the beef?'' he asked at the concluding news conference. Zamora, with a nod to Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's sweeping reforms, said a new openness had been attained at the summit. ``A perestroika has begun,'' he said. Extraordinary security precautions were taken to protect Bush and his three summit partners, with about 5,000 uniformed troops watching over the proceedings. Battleships presented an imposing force off shore and helicopter gunships hovered nearby. Bush returned to Washington late Thursday without incident. But Colombian guerrillas made their own point, one of defiance. They kidnapped an American priest in Cali, the third U.S. citizen taken prisoner by rebels this week. Also, a small bomb exploded Thursday morning, 4{ miles from Barranquilla Airport, damaging a voltage regulator of a line that fed the air conditioning of the airport where Bush landed two hours later. At the summit, Bush met a key Latin American demand by promising in the communique to fight cocaine consumption in his country. ``I owe it to the children of America, the United States ... to these three presidents to guarantee them that we will do everything we can to cut demand for narcotics in the United States,'' Bush said. The four nations also promised to hold a follow-up meeting within six months to review progress in the batttle against cocaine and called for a 1991 world conference to address illegal drug trafficking. The document proposed ``broad-based rural development'' to help prevent the economic hardship that it admitted will inevitably result from programs to substitute other crops for coca. The communique indicated that the United States was willing to help finance programs to replenish the country's foreign exchange and to help create jobs for farmers no longer able to grow the illegal crop. ``The great result of the anti-drug summit for our countries is the realization of the necessity of substituting a legal economy for the current coca economy,'' Zamora said. In Bolivia's central Chapare region, an estimated 300,000 peasants make a living by growing the bush. Garcia has said repeatedly that many of the estimated 200,000 Peruvian peasants who survive by growing coca could be driven into the camp of leftist rebels if their livelihood is taken away from them. Colombia has frequently complained that while it is spilling its blood fighting drug traffickers, the U.S. is discriminating against its legal exports such as coffee and flowers with high tariffs and other protective measures. Bush on Thursday tried to address those complaints by saying he would work to open U.S. markets more. Bush did not promise any more aid to the Latin American countries other than the $2.2 billion over the next five years he had already pledged. However, the president, perhaps realizing the programs called for in the communique would require additional funding, said he would try to get Western European and other developed nations to help foot the bill. He added that at the economic summit of developed nations July 9-11 in Houston he would try to place economic assistance for Latin American drug producers high on the agenda.

DOC.HEAD: Stocks Down in Tokyo
DOC.TEXT: The Nikkei Stock Average closed at 37,460.32, down 11.67 points or 0.03 percent, on the Tokyo Stock Exchange Friday.

DOC.HEAD: Tsunami, Landslides and Fish Banquet Hit Monterey Bay After Quake
DOC.TEXT: The earthquake that walloped Northern California in October triggered a four-foot-high tsunami, a huge undersea landslide and a feeding frenzy by fish in Monterey Bay, scientists say. Towns along the bay were lucky the the tsunami, or quake-caused sea wave, occurred near low tide because if the jolt had come at high tide, ``there could have been problems,'' oceanographer Frank Schwing said Thursday in a telephone interview. The tsunami, which measured as much as four feet from crest to trough, moved through the bay at 67 mph just after the quake struck Oct. 17, said Schwing, of the National Marine Fisheries Service in Monterey. Submarine landslides _ including one two-by-five-miles in size _ suddenly exposed buried worms, tiny crustaceans and other creatures, attracting flatfish, rockfish and deep-sea perch, he said. A small unmanned submarine placed in the bay two weeks after the quake found the fish ``appeared to be engaging in a `feeding frenzy' on the newly exposed ... organisms,'' Schwing and others wrote in a study published in the current issue of Eos, an American Geophysical Union publication. The 7.1 magnitude earthquake was centered on the San Andreas Fault about 10 miles northeast of Santa Cruz, on the north side of Monterey Bay, which is about 70 miles south of San Francisco. The U.S. Geological Survey said the quake killed 62 people, injured 3,757, left 12,053 homeless and caused more than $6 billion in damage in the greater San Francisco Bay region. Other estimates reported greater damage. Tsunamis, which are often incorrectly called tidal waves, are sudden rises and drops in sea level that sometimes make giant waves crash onto a coastline. As the earthquake was unleashed, the sea level in Santa Cruz Harbor dropped about three feet as water rushed out of the harbor, probably because the tremor lifted underlying ground upward by about four to eight inches, Schwing said. ``People standing there actually saw the water go out,'' he said. ``There was some evidence boats actually hit bottom.'' After the sea levels dropped, they rose again by about three to four feet, Schwing said. Sea levels at Monterey, on the bay's south side, dropped about one foot, then rose by 1.5 feet, he said. The tsunami took about 20 minutes to travel the approximate 24 miles from Santa Cruz to Monterey, he said. Water sloshed back and forth across the bay every half hour for 24 hours after the jolt, rising and falling about one foot, he added. ``It's analogous to having a tub of water, and if you strike the side of the tub, the water is going to bounce back and forth,'' Schwing said. He said the tsunami and sloshing were much smaller than the normal tidal variation in Monterey Bay, but the tsunami could have caused damage if it had happened at high tide. Ground failure, or liquefaction, on the bay floor caused numerous underwater landslides, including the two-by-five-mile slide about 1.5 miles west of Moss Landing. The ground slid into Monterey Submarine Canyon, an underwater canyon about as deep and wide as the Grand Canyon, Schwing said. Schwing co-authored the study with Jerry Norton, also at the National Marine Fisheries Service, and Cindy Pilskaln, of the Monterey Bay Aquarium Research Institute in Pacific Grove.

DOC.HEAD: On the Light Side
DOC.TEXT: Worried that his constituents might lick or kiss a South American toad to get at the hallucinogenic toxin it secretes, a legislator has introduced a bill making it illegal to get high on cane toads. ``It's the latest wave'' in hallucinating, said Rep. Pat Harris, citing the Drug Enforcement Administration's recent toad-licking alert. Harris said Thursday he has not heard of instances of cane toad-licking in South Carolina, although he said it was potentially an explosive phenomenon. ``Crack could pale'' in significance, he joked. ``They say these frogs grow to the size of a dinner plate. I don't want to see somebody walk across the Statehouse grounds with a frog on a leash and pick him up and lick him.'' Harris admitted his bill was good for nothing more than a laugh. ``It's a kind of tongue-in-cheek deal,'' the 78-year-old real estate executive said. ``Kind of tongue-on-the-frog deal.'' Cane toads, endemic to South America, produce a toxin called bufotenine to ward off predators. When licked raw, or cooked, the toxin acts as a hallucinogen. Asked if he would consider kissing a cane toad to hallucinate, Harris replied, ``Oh no, no. No. I'd rather drink a lot of liquor.''

A full-time policeman, part-time inventor has invented a tweezer-like gadget that puts the pinch on crime. The tiny aluminum pincers invented by Officer Robert Mika can be squeezed against an earlobe or finger, especially the pinky, to inflict pain without causing permanent injury. Dubbed the ``Mika Come-Along,'' the badged creator sees it as a public relations-conscious alternative to clubs, stun guns and martial arts weapons. The pincers can be held discreetly in the palm of the hand. They are being evaluated for use by the police department, officials said. ``Image is important in police work,'' said Mika, a 16-year department veteran. ``You don't want something that looks too militaristic or has high visibility,'' he said. ``You don't want something that gives the image of overkill.'' The pincers are the latest gadget Mika has produced in the workshop at his suburban Woodland Hills home. About 6,000 officers have a ``Mika Pocket Holster,'' which prevents guns from snagging on pants pockets when drawn. About 3,000 have ordered the ``Mika Pocket Mirror,'' which has a fold-out handle that can be used to peek around street and corridor corners during pursuits and searches.

DOC.HEAD: Mouse Model for Human Leukemia May Help Fight Killer Disease, Experts Say
DOC.TEXT: Researchers report today they have succeeded in giving a form of human leukemia to laboratory mice, producing an animal that now can be used to test therapies against the disease. ``With this new animal model, experimental therapies that might otherwise be tried in human patients can now be tested in these mice,'' said George Daley, lead researcher in the study conducted at the Whitehead Institute for Biomedical Research in Cambridge, Mass. ``You obviously can do more with the mice than you could with human patients,'' he said. The study, published today in Science, says the Whitehead researchers used intricate genetic engineering to inject into the bone marrow of laboratory mice the human gene linked to chronic myelogenous leukemia (CML), a form of a blood cancer that usually attacks adults and is only rarely cured. Daley said the study also proves CML is initiated by the fusion of parts from two broken chromosomes, a finding that was suggested by earlier studies in other laboratories. Those parts have been identified as the so-called ABL gene from chromosome 9 and a gene called BCR from chromosome 22. Cells containing this hybrid gene produce a protein, called P210, that changes healthy cells into cancer cells. Daley said his study showed that transferring the BCR@ABL gene into mouse bone marrow and then putting these infected cells into healthy mice could produce CML in those mice. ``It answers a question of basic science, that is, what causes the disease,'' said Daley. ``We now know that the BCR@ABL gene is sufficient to induce the leukemia.'' He said it is still not known precisely what causes the two chromosomes to break and create the hybrid gene, but a high exposure to radiation is thought to be a factor. Dr. George Canellos, chief of medical oncology at the Dana-Farber Institute in Boston, said the Whitehead finding is ``an important advance in understanding the disease.'' He said the new animal model of the disease may help scientists find ways to block the action of the P210 protein produced by the BCR@ABL gene, thus preventing the disease. ``In screening biological substances, it will make a very nice model,'' said Canellos. Daley said the mouse can be used to test ``biological inhibitors'' that would prevent the P210 protein from transforming normal cells into cancers. Such inhibitors formally could only be tested on human patients, a process that could take years. With a mouse model of the disease, experiments can be sped up and can be more extensive. To create the mouse model, Daley said he and his colleagues inserted the human BCR@ABL gene into a virus. Normal mouse bone marrow cells were then exposed to the virus, which transferred the gene into the marrow cells. Thirty healthy mice were then irradiated to kill their bone marrow cells. Next, the bone marrow carrying the BCR@ABL gene was transplanted into the 30 mice. Within five months, 13 of the 30 mice developed a blood disease that mimicked human chronic myelogenous leukemia. CML in humans can be controlled by chemotherapy for 3 to 5 years. This remission period usually ends with the sudden increase in abnormal cells, a disease phase called ``blast crisis'' that usually results in death. The only successful therapy used now is to kill the diseased bone marrow in the patient and replace it with healthy bone marrow from a compatible donor, but even this treatment often fails. Daley said that continued studies of the CML mice show that many of the laboratory animals develop the ``blast crisis'' phase of the disease. This, he said, is further verification that the course of the disease in the mice mimics CML in humans. Richard A. Van Etten and David Baltimore, both of the Whitehead Institute, were coauthors of the study with Daley. Science, which published the study, is the journal of the American Association for the Advancement of Science.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Rises, Stocks Down in Tokyo
DOC.TEXT: The dollar rose slightly against the yen Friday, while the key index on the Tokyo Stock Exchange edged down. The dollar finished the week in Tokyo at 144.55 yen, up 0.10 yen from Thursday's close of 144.45 yen. After opening at 144.80 yen, it ranged between 144.55 yen and 144.95 yen during the day. On the stock market, the Nikkei Stock Average of 225 selected issues, which rose 316.10 points Thursday, shed 11.67 points, or 0.03 percent, closing the week at 37,460.32. Currency dealers said the dollar-yen exchange rate remained in a narrow range ahead of the release of U.S. trade figures for December, due out later Friday. They also said market players were taking a wait-and-see stance before Sunday's general election for Japan's lower house of Parliament. ``It's a see-saw game,'' said Shinji Tanaka, a dealer with Mitsui Bank. Japanese news media predicted this week the governing Liberal Democratic Party will retain a majority in the 512-member House of Representatives. An unpopular sales tax and a series of scandals have kindled discontent with the Liberal Democrats, leading some to forecast that they might lose their majority in parliament.

DOC.HEAD: Behavior Changes Needed to Stem AIDS Spread, Federal Panel Told
DOC.TEXT: Even the best advances in the laboratory won't stem the AIDS epidemic unless people infected with the HIV virus change their sexual behavior, researchers told a federal commission on the disease. ``Behavior is always the problem,'' said Dr. John W. Ward of the national Centers for Disease Control in Atlanta. ``Look at smoking. People still smoke, in spite of peer pressure and such. It always comes down to the individual, to what benefit there is to the individual to change the behavior.'' On Thursday, Ward and other AIDS experts in academia, government and medicine addressed a working group of the National Commission on AIDS, a panel appointed by President Bush and Congress to make national policy recommendations. The group was meeting for a two-day conference focusing on testing for HIV, the virus that causes AIDS, and early intervention. The group is to present its findings to the full commission next month in Washington, D.C. Paul Cleary, a Harvard associate professor of health care, said AIDS testing may improve steadily and at first may seem to be a way to address the epidemic because it identifies the afflicted. But the emotional costs to those who test positive for HIV and the social costs of some forms of testing make testing a policy the nation should approach cautiously, Cleary said. Counseling, which can help people absorb the implications of their HIV infection and take steps to stop its spread, is too often excluded altogether from AIDS testing, speakers at the conference agreed. Panel members said patients react in dramatic and often tragic ways when they learn their blood contains the HIV virus. They spoke of patients who refused to change their behavior or tell their sexual partners, and of others who killed themselves. Others suppress the news, Cleary said. ``We all work with persons with whom the information is not used,'' he said. Adequate counseling can inform people who test positive of the possibility of false results, tell them of the treatments available that often delay the onset of complications, and help them understand the potential consequences of their infection, the speakers said. In addition, however, support services can help patients take steps to alter the behavior that may have got them the infection, to ensure that its spread ends there. ``The first step is giving people information, saying `If you care about people, about the people you love, your family, you don't want to spread the deadly infection to them,'' said Ward, the special assistant for science in the deputy director's office at the CDC. About 1 million Americans are believed to be infected with the HIV virus, said Dr. Alan R. Hinman of the CDC. About 200,000 of those have been tested and are aware of their infection, he said.

DOC.HEAD: New Study Shows No Racial Bias In California Criminal Sentencing
DOC.TEXT: The authors of a study published today say California is succeeding in eliminating racial bias in the sentencing of felons to prison. Joan Petersilia, a Rand Corp. researcher who co-wrote the report appearing today in the journal Science, said it shows race plays no role in determining how long a convicted felon goes to prison in California. She said the study shows California's Determinate Sentencing Act ``almost means sentencing by computer.'' Various factors, such as the type and seriousness of the crime and the defendant's prior record, are used to determine a sentencing score, she said. ``If you get a certain score, then you go to prison unless the judge can give a very good explanation of why you will be an exception,'' she said. This has ``worked to the advantage of racial minorities,'' Ms. Petersilia said. ``The system just doesn't have the discretion that it once had and as the discretion went away, so did the opportunity for racial prejudice in the sentencing decision.'' Ms. Petersilia wrote a 1983 study that found racial bias in the California sentencing system. But she says now that conclusion was in error. She said judges told her the earlier study was flawed because it didn't take into account all the factors judges must consider in sentencing decisions. She said the earlier study looked at 15 factors affecting the sentence, but the new report was the result of studying 60 factors. When those 60 factors were studied, ``the addition of the individual's race made no difference,'' she said. Factors considered included such things as whether a weapon was used, how badly the victim was hurt, whether an accomplice was involved, and the precise role of the offender in the crime. Ms. Petersilia said the new study analyzed the records of 11,553 California offenders who were convicted in 1980 of assault, robbery, burglary, theft, forgery or drug crimes. Probation usually is not a possibility in more serious crimes, such as murder, so that type of offense was not analyzed, she said. The racial distribution in California's prisons is significantly out of balance when compared to the general population, but the researcher said the criminal justice system is not to blame. Blacks make up about 34 percent of the California prison population and about 7 percent of the general population in the state. Hispanics are 19 percent of the state population and are 23 percent of the prison population. Whites are 74 percent of the general population and 33 percent of those in prison. ``What this study shows is that it is not a racist criminal justice system,'' said Ms. Petersilia. She said the solution to the racial imbalance in the prisons must be found in the communities. Coauthors of the study with Ms. Petersilia were Stephen Klein and Susan Turner. All are researchers in the criminal justice program of the Rand Corporation, a Santa Monica, Calif., firm. Science, which published the study, is the journal of the American Association for the Advancement of Science.

DOC.HEAD: Withdrawal Of Soviet Troops To Start By Feb. 26
With PM-Eastern Europe, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Soviet troops will begin leaving Czechoslovakia in 10 days and an agreement on complete withdrawal from Hungary may come within a month, officials say. Soviet soldiers arrived in Hungary to suppress the 1956 anti-Stalinist uprising and in Czechoslovakia to crush the ``Prague Spring'' political liberalization of 1968. With the first free general elections in more than 40 years nearing, Hungary and Czechoslovakia are on the threshold of full democracy and see removal of Soviet forces as a symbolic affirmation of independence. Gen. Anton Slimak, Czechoslovak chief of staff, said Thursday the Soviet withdrawal would begin next week in Bruntal, 160 miles east of Prague, the official news agency CTK reported. Later, however, CTK said Soviet and Czechoslovak delegations meeting in Prague agreed the withdrawal would begin Feb. 26, the day President Vaclav Havel starts his first visit to Moscow. Czechoslovakia had sought withdrawal of all 73,500 Red Army troops by the end of this year, but Slimak said that would not happen. Moscow wants to have until the end of 1991, and sources in Prague said earlier this week that June 1991 was a likely compromise. No final date was agreed at Thursday's talks in Prague, but talks will continue to nail that down, CTK said. In Budapest, a senior Hungarian official was quoted Thursday as predicting agreement within a month on ending decades of Soviet military presence. Magyar Nemzet, a Hungarian daily, quoted Foreign Ministry official Ferenc Somogyi as saying Hungary could ``count on working out the agreement within a month.'' Czechoslovakia has insisted the Soviets withdraw, whatever the results of East-West talks in Vienna on reducing conventional forces in Europe, but Hungary has not. Officials on both sides appear confident of conventional forces agreement this year, now that the Soviets have accepted President Bush's proposal to reduce the number of U.S. and Soviet soldiers in Central Europe to 195,000 for each side. Hungary wants all 50,000 Soviet soldiers off its territory by early 1991, but Somogyi said compromise was possible because of Kremlin concerns about transportation and providing facilities for the returning soldiers. ``We have to take into account our negotiating partner's position,'' he was quoted as saying. Slimak said withdrawal from Czechoslovakia could not be completed by the end of 1990 for technical and social reasons. A preliminary agreement indicates about 35 percent of the soldiers will be withdrawn by the end of May, along with 40 percent of the tanks, 30 percent of other combat vehicles and nearly one third of helicopters and artillery, Slimak said. Czechoslovakia has asked that a substantial part of the Soviet forces be out before elections scheduled for June.

DOC.HEAD: Government Lawyers Attack Keating Claims
DOC.TEXT: The top aide to Charles H. Keating Jr. says government regulators were responsible for Keating's Lincoln Savings and Loan Co. losing a $9 million profit from a stock deal. Government lawyers attacked the claims Thursday, saying Keating never meant for Lincoln to reap all the profits from the transaction, a centerpiece of the allegation that Keating illegally used the $5.5 billion thrift's federally insured deposits to make risky investments in junk bonds and finance his Arizona real estate empire. Regulators say taxpayers could have to pay up to $2 billion to cover Lincoln's losses, making it the costliest of more than 500 thrift failures the past two years. The transaction, which involved Memorex stock, came in the week after the Oct. 19, 1987, ``Black Monday'' stock market crash. In the 12th day of a hearing on Keating's lawsuit to undo the federal takeover of Lincoln in April, his top aide testified Lincoln could not have bought back 79,275 shares of Memorex it sold four months earlier without violating a promise to regulators to buy no more stock. Judith Wischer, president of Lincoln's holding company, American Continental Corp., said the pledge was made at an Oct. 21, 1987, meeting with regulators. Because of that, Wischer told U.S. District Court Judge Stanley Sporkin, she and other top executives of Lincoln and American Continental decided Oct. 23 to have the parent company buy the stock rather than have Lincoln repurchase it from Tucson stockbroker and developer Ernest C. Garcia. Regulators in the Treasury Department's Office of Thrift Supervision and former Federal Home Loan Bank Board have denied any such pledge was made at the Oct. 21 meeting. Government lawyers Thursday presented a deed of transfer of the Memorex stock from Garcia to American Continental signed by Lincoln's president, Bruce Dickson, and dated Oct. 21 _ two days before Mrs. Wischer said the decision was made. ``The date is not the correct date,'' Mrs. Wischer said. ``I don't know why the dates differ. The transaction was agreed to late Friday night or Monday morning (Oct. 23 or Oct. 26).'' Dickson, who also was a senior vice president of American Continental, has refused to testify on Keating's suit, claiming a Fifth Amendment constitutional protection against self-incrimination. A federal grand jury in Los Angeles is considering possible criminal charges against officials of Lincoln and American Continental. Government attorneys contend the Oct. 21 deed is evidence that Keating never intended for Lincoln to take all the profits from the Memorex stock and that the purchase through American Continental was an illegal ``usurpation of corporate opportunity.'' They also cited Lincoln's purchases of $19 million in stock in November and another $17 million in December as evidence that Lincoln was continuing to invest in equities despite claims by its officials they had promised regulators they would not. Lincoln acquired the Memorex stock for $1 a share in December 1986 as a ``sweetener'' to its purchase of $40 million in junk bonds yielding 14 percent interest that were financing British investor James Goldsmith's takeover move on the Dutch computer company. The bonds were sold the following April and May at a $1.5 million profit to Lincoln. The thrift then sought from regulators, but was effectively denied, permission to sell the stock for $2.8 million to American Continental. In June 1987, Lincoln sold the stock to Garcia for $1 million _ about $12.50 a share _ with an option to buy it back for $4.25 million, or about $53.50 per share.

DOC.HEAD: Record Played After 53 Years: `A Grand Time' in New York
LaserPhoto SE1
DOC.TEXT: Doris Hagberg's mother spoke to her this week, more than 20 years after her death. The voice came through scratchy but excited on a record made in 1937, atop the Empire State Building, that Mrs. Hagber set aside until she found a special wooden needle to play the souvenir. ``All these years I've been thinking about it,'' she said before she found a windup Victrola and wooden needle. Every now and then Mrs. Hagberg, who is 68, would look at the record and wonder what message her mother had recorded during that New York vacation. The hitch was the needle: an inch-long, clamp-in stylus. She searched record stores and antique shops around her home in Port Angeles, a city of 17,000 across from Victoria, Canada, on the Juan de Fuca Strait. She wrote letters to stores in Seattle and traveled across the Puget Sound to rummage through record collections and thrift shops in that city. She even asked relatives to search in Los Angeles. Nowhere could she find the right needle. She looked again at the envelope her mother used to mail the five-inch silver disc. ``It said `Empire State Observatory,' and that was the only place I could think of to try that I hadn't.'' She wrote a letter in January adressed to ``Whoever'' at the building, asking for help. Observatory director Laura Fries forwarded Mrs. Hagberg's letter to The New York Times, and it appeared in that paper's ``Metropolitan Diary'' column. Ms. Fries reported getting more than 50 calls offering needles or suggesting alternatives such as toothpicks, rose thorns and cactus spines. She sent a couple of needles by Federal Express, and Mrs. Hagberg arranged with the Clallam County Museum in Port Angeles to use their 1918-vintage Victrola to play the record. On Valentine's Day, the late Ella Goller spoke to her daughter once more. On hand were former museum director Virginia Fitzpatrick and Bob Blake, a recording studio technician who brought a portable four-track recorder to capture the record's sound in case it was damaged in the playing. Blake set his recording levels. Mrs. Fitzpatrick clamped the needle in place, cranked the metal arm at the side of the four-foot phonograph cabinet and set wood to groove. Mrs. Hagberg leaned close from her seat beside the cabinet and listened. Out came a scratchy, barely audible female voice. None of those present could make the message out. Mrs. Fitzpatrick tried another needle, and the voice came out again, not much louder but clear enough to make out this: ``Having a grand time...'' Mrs. Hagberg repeated the words. The record was played again, and the words ``There's so much to do'' could be heard. The voice on the record giggled, and Mrs. Hagberg's eyes brightened with a memory of the time her mother left for a monthlong New York trip in 1937, leaving her, then 16, with her father. ``I remember my dad making chow mein with venison, and burning it when she was gone. The night she went I was babysitting and I locked myself out of the house.'' She smiled. Not much else could be gathered from the record, but Blake's recorder cleared up some of the crackling. ``One could spend the entire day here, there's so much to see,'' Mrs. Goller said on Blake's enhanced recording. ``The buildings look just like towers down in the street.''

DOC.HEAD: Academic Milestone: Asian American to Lead UC-Berkeley
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: One of Chang-Lin Tien's earliest memories of America is a segregated drinking fountain he saw in Kentucky. That memory could be a portent of what awaits Tien as chancellor of the University of California-Berkeley, which has been wracked by controversies over minority admissions and faculty hiring. At a news conference Thursday to announce his selection as Berkeley chancellor by the UC Board of Regents, Tien indicated prejudice was still very much on his mind. ``You maintain and enhance academic leadership through excellence and primarily diversity, which means in all levels _ students, faculty, staff, campus life in general,'' said Tien, a 54-year-old Chinese immigrant. In his only reference to ongoing disputes between students and administration over issues affecting minorities, Tien said he believed the university had taken ``very positive steps and has good momentum'' toward resolving those problems. He would not otherwise comment. University officials believe Tien is the first person of Asian ancestry to head a major U.S. university. Rep. Norm Mineta, D-San Jose, a Japanese-American, praised Tien's selection. ``For Americans of Asian ancestry in particular, Dr. Tien's appointment represents a milestone not only because he is the first Asian American to head a UC campus, but also because of the campus he will lead.'' Berkeley's academic standards generally are considered the highest among the nine University of California campuses. Tien, chosen over 250 others, assumes the $165,000-per-year job on July 1. He will become Berkeley's seventh chancellor since the position was created in 1952. He came to the United States in 1955 after earning a bachelor's degree at National Taiwan University. He received his doctorate from Princeton University in 1959, the same year he joined the Berkeley faculty. Tien, an internationally recognized authority in heat transfer technology, stayed at Berkeley for 29 years before becoming executive vice chancellor at UC-Irvine 18 months ago. At Berkeley he served three years as vice chancellor of research and seven years as chairman of the mechanical engineering department. His list of high honors is long: a member of the National Academy of Engineers, his field's most prestigious professional association; a winner of the distinguished teaching award at Berkeley; and awards for his scholarship in West Germany, Japan and China. The new honor, the chancellor position, will be ``one of the greatest challenges in the world,'' said Ira Michael Heyman, who is retiring from the post June 30 after 10 years. ``Berkeley is a place where you always walk on eggs,'' Heyman said. ``I hope he will scope out some major things he wants to work on and not get mired down in administrative details, which is so difficult.'' At Irvine, Tien was widely liked because of his efforts to include faculty in greater administrative roles, a highly contentious issue at the Berkeley campus. The high-profile Berkeley campus, recognized not only for its academic performances but also its history of student political protest, has 32,000 students and 11,000 faculty and staff employees. It is considered the most ethnically diverse major university in the nation. The campus has been divided in recent years over charges of racism by both black and Asian students. In 1982, 63.2 percent of undergraduates were white; that dropped to this year's 45 percent of the 22,000 students. Asians are the largest minority group with 27 percent of the undergraduates, while Hispanics account for 13 percent and blacks 8 percent. After months of debate, the faculty adopted an ethnic studies requirement that reflects the racially diverse student body and promotes tolerance. The school also next year will begin using new admissions criteria that eliminate quotas. The change was supported by Asian groups, who considered the quotas biased against them. The school also has been accused of not being aggressive enough in recruiting minority faculty. Law students last year demanded an immediate freeze on the hiring of non-minority law professors.

DOC.HEAD: White Opposition Demands President de Klerk Resign
DOC.TEXT: The opposition Conservative Party charged today that President F.W. de Klerk was spreading fear among whites with his plans to share power with blacks and called for his immediate resignation. The right-wing party issued the call after thousands of its supporters marched through Pretoria Thursday night in a major show of strength to demand new elections. Police said today that up to 40,000 whites took part in the march. De Klerk's decision to free black leader Nelson Mandela and legalize the African National Congress had created fear and uncertainty among South African whites, the party said in a statement in its newspaper, Die Patriot. ``With one stroke great uncertainty about the future has been created. The voters have been lied to too often,'' the statement said. Marchers carried placards saying ``Hang F.W. de Klerk'' and ``Keep South Africa White'' as they marched to City Hall for a rally at which Conservative leader Andries Treurnicht warned the government faces a growing white backlash. Treurnicht told the cheering crowd that De Klerk had betrayed whites ``by granting people with revolutionary aims, and who want to enslave others by means of violence, freedom of movement and the right to organize.'' ``It's an injustice against the nation.'' The march and rally kicked off the party's campaign to try and force elections to oust de Klerk for freeing Mandela on Sunday and legalizing black opposition groups. De Klerk wants to end white-minority rule and negotiate on sharing power with blacks to bring peace to South Africa. The Conservatives have threatened to stage strikes if de Klerk ignores its demand to resign. Many signs at the rally called for creation of a separate white state excluding blacks. Hundreds of uniformed stormtroopers of the neo-Nazi Afrikaneer Resistance Party joined the march with swastika flags and signs saying, ``Hang Mandela.'' Some stormtroopers hanged a small black doll representing Mandela and others marched with a severed black dolls head mounted on a stake. But most of the participants were conservative middle-class and working- class whites. Hundreds of women and children took part in the march. ``We want to stay a nation of whites. We're going to fight to stay a nation on our own,'' said Ter Schumann, one of the marchers. ``We are going to stay a white nation.'' Local observers said the turnout was an impressive show of strength for the Conservative Party, which won 31 percent of the white vote in elections last September. Dozens of buses from surrounding towns brought people into Pretoria for the march. The Conservatives demands the creation of separate white and black states. It claims whites and blacks cannot live together because of their different cultural values. About 5 million whites live in South Africa, with 28 million blacks and 4 million people who are mixed-race or Indian. Mandela, 71, said Thursday that the ANC ``would like to move away from the situation of conflict and confrontation'' but the government must end its 3{-year-old state of emergency and free all political prisoners before direct talks with the government could begin. Mandela also said his movement considers government facilities legitimate targets and will continue attacking them until South Africa's white leaders negotiate an agreement on racial equality. He was arrested in 1962 and had been serving a life sentence for planning the start of the ANC's sabotage campaign against the government.

DOC.HEAD: 35 Million Americans Have Arthritis; 6 Million Won't See Doctor
DOC.TEXT: Federal health officials are at a loss to explain why about 6 million Americans who complain of arthritis will not see a doctor about it. The national Centers for Disease Control said Thursday in a new survey that 35 million Americans, or 14.6 percent of the population, reported having arthritis, but only about 29 million had consulted a doctor. ``These findings indicate the need ... to determine why these persons have not sought medical care, and to identify approaches for overcoming barriers to care,'' the CDC said in its weekly report. Dr. Arthur Grazel, senior vice president for medical affairs at the Arthritis Foundation, said the report ``confirms our suspicions that many people think they can treat arthritis themselves.'' Prolonged arthritis without medical care can lead to irreversible joint damage, Grazel said. Foundation spokesman Steve Erickson said there ``is a real big misconception'' that only over-the-counter pain medication is useful in treating the ailment. The warning signs of arthritis include joint swelling, early morning stiffness, recurring joint pain or inability to move a joint that lasts for more than two weeks, he said. The survey of 3,000 people taken in 1987 found higher rates of arthritis in women than men, with the rate of incidence increasing with age. For people over the age of 75, the rate was 53 percent. The report also said that overall, 3 percent reported arthritis was limiting their activities. Race had no statistical relevance as a factor in people reporting arthritis. The rates were 15 percent for whites and 14 percent for blacks.

DOC.HEAD: Thai Government Facing Internal Rifts, Scandals
An AP Extra
DOC.TEXT: The country's first popularly elected prime minister is battling political infighting, corruption and possibly meddling by the military that could bring down his government. In this land where military coups were once as dependable as the monsoon rains, Prime Minister Chatichai Choonhavan's chief rival is an officer who insists democracy is here to stay. ``One scandal after another has hit his coalition government. He has muddled through so far _ but he is no James Bond,'' a leading newspaper editor, Suthichai Yoon, wrote recently of Chatichai. While not quite in the league of the indestructible, fictional spy, Chatichai's image of a party-loving and energetic leader initially spurred his popularity. He also earned the nickname of ``Mr. No Problem'' for insisting that his immediate political problems and the deeper ones afflicting Thailand could easily be handled. But problems are now piling up for this longtime pro-Western country and for Chatichai's 18-month-old government. Last month, Bangkok's vital river port was closed down by a four-day strike amid allegations of military involvement. In addition, police allegations have linked a senator and former economic adviser to Chatichai, Kitti Damnernchanvanich, to large-scale illegal logging in Thailand's ravaged forests. These and other problems are being vigorously exploited _ if not partially orchestrated _ by political opponents. They have also created splits both within the six-party governing coalition and Chatichai's own Chart Thai Party. Local editors and other anlaysts have talked of a possible Cabinet change. Others have predicted dissolution of Parliament when it reconvenes in May, followed by elections that could oust 68-year-old Chatichai before his term expires in 1992. The army commander, Gen. Chavalit Yongchaiyudh, is widely seen as a rival or successor to Chatichai. The general has indicated he will retire from the military in April and enter civilian politics. Chavalit personally intervened to settle the port strike, leading to speculation the military had orchestrated the whole thing to enhance its image. This was a tactic frequently used in past decades, when coups by military strongmen determined who ruled Thailand. But Chavalit denied involvement in the strike and has frequently stated that the days of coup-making are over. Chavalit's accession to power _ through democratic means or otherwise _ would probably have little effect on Thailand's general course. In recent years, one ruling clique has replaced the next while the country itself has remained pro-Western, capitalist and respectful of the constitutional monarchy. Corruption has remained entrenched in the system. But some academics, political opposition figures and other critics claim the Chatichai government has sunk to a new low. ``Allegedly, cronyism has been a prominent feature of the present system. Indeed one is reminded of the Marcos regime,'' wrote political scientist Likhit Dhiravegin recently, referring to the toppled Philippine government of the late Ferdinand Marcos. ``It is estimated that 10 to 15 businesss groups rallying around the power center have hastily taken the opportunity to exploit the gold mine.''

DOC.HEAD: Haitians: Blood Donation Policy is Racist
DOC.TEXT: Haitian community leaders dismissed as racist a new federal policy prohibiting Haitians and sub-Saharan Africans from donating blood because of the high incidence of AIDS in their home countries. The policy announced this month by the Food and Drug Administration requires blood collection agencies regulated by the FDA to refuse blood from donors who were born in, or emigrated from those countries. The decision is based on the high incidence of Africans and Haitians infected with the AIDS virus through heterosexual contact, which ``seems to play a major role in transmitting the virus,'' according to the FDA. ``We still have the stigma then, that we are carriers of AIDS,'' said Chantal Thomas, executive director of the Haitian American Community Center in West Palm Beach. ``It is insulting, how dare they do something like that?'' FDA spokesman Brad Stone defended the rule. ``We can understand how individuals from Haiti would be upset by this policy. In many cases they probably won't have it, but right now this is the only fairly reliable method we have to protect the blood supply,'' Stone said. Most of the other groups in the United States considered to be high risk _ intravenous drug users, homosexuals and prostitutes _ are discouraged from donating blood. But ``it seems that in Haiti and other countries the roots of transmission may be different,'' Stone said. ``That makes it very hard, at this point, to set up criteria for self deferral... ``We are not happy with this, we understand the sensitivities, nor is the policy an indictment of the Haitian people or in any way a racial policy,'' Stone said. Joseph Fanfan, a Fort Lauderdale doctor with a family practice, blasted the decision. ``You can't just consider an ethnic group or nationality as being a risk group,'' said Fanfan, former chairman of the Haitian American Community Organization of Broward County Inc. ``Sexual promiscuity is being practiced by a lot of people and is not inherent in just one group of people.'' Acquired immune deficiency syndrome is a deadly disease caused by a virus carried in the blood. It is spread through the use of infected hypodermic needles and sex. For reasons that are not clear, AIDS was first diagnosed in the United States mainly in the gay community and among Haitian immigrants. A previous FDA policy permitted donations from Haitians and sub-Saharan Africans if they came to this country before 1977. But ``the more we looked into AIDS we found that 1977 is a fairly good year to pinpoint its start in the United States but it may not be a good year to pinpoint in other parts of the world.'' Stone said.

DOC.HEAD: Survey Finds Doubts About Social Security Benefits
DOC.TEXT: Nearly half of working American adults do not believe Social Security will be able to pay them benefits when they retire, a survey says. The December survey of 1,001 adults found that 49 percent of those who had not yet retired were confident Social Security would be able to pay them benefits, 47 percent did not expect to get benefits and 4 percent were unsure. The survey released Thursday by The Gallup Organization was commissioned by the Employee Benefit Research Institute, a non-profit, non-partisan research group. Dallas Salisbury, the institute's president, said the results indicate people are ``unrealistically pessimistic'' about the Social Security system and have not been well educated about how it works. Salisbury said confidence in Social Security could drop further as public debate continues on a proposal by Sen. Daniel Patrick Moynihan, D-N.Y., to cut Social Security taxes to keep the government from using Social Security revenue for general government operations. The debate ``is bringing into question the ability of the system to pay future benefits,'' Salisbury said. President Bush has criticized the Moynihan proposal and claims that it could jeopardize benefits for future retirees. The survey found that confidence in Social Security benefits was highest among those closest to retirement, with 76 percent of those aged 55 and older expecting to receive benefits compared with 46 percent of those aged 18-34.
DOC.HEAD: Car Wax Recalled Due to Defective Containers
DOC.TEXT: One of the nation's largest manufacturers of car cleaning products has recalled about 200,000 cans of a new car wax because the containers may rupture and cause injury. The Consumer Product Safety Commission said Thursday that Connecticut-based SIMONIZ recalled its ``Quick Gloss'' car wax after three incidents in which container corrosion caused a build-up of pressure that ruptured the cans. No injuries were reported. However, CPSC spokesman Dan Rumelt said various parts, including the metal dome, may separate from the container and cause injury. The agency said approximately 200,000 cans of ``Quick Gloss'' were sold nationwide since February 1989. Consumers should spray the wax into trash cans away from any open flame and immediately dispose of the metal containers, the CPSC said, warning consumers not to puncture, incinerate or use a trash compactor in disposing of the cans. Consumers should call 1-800-243-6400 for information on how to receive a refund.
DOC.HEAD: Study Says Most Targeted Companies Have Reduced Use of Animals in
DOC.TEXT: Testing

Most companies targeted by animal rights groups for their use of animal testing in consumer product research have significantly reduced their use of animals, according to a private study. However, a leading animal rights group said it wants corporations to release internal information to back up the findings. ``I would challenge the companies to substantiate the claims that the numbers are down,'' said Susan Rich, special projects director for People for the Ethical Treatment of Animals, the nation's largest animal rights group. ``By looking at the figures of animal use in their in-house laboratories does not give us the true picture,'' Rich said. The report released Thursday by the Investor Responsibility Research Center examines data submitted to the Agriculture Department by U.S. companies reporting animal use in fiscal years 1986, 1987 and 1988. It also offers in-depth profiles of animal testing from 1984-88 of nine companies that introduced shareholder resolutions on animal testing after being targeted by PETA. The study shows six of nine companies targeted by PETA cut animal testing by 42 percent from 1986-88. Two of the companies _ Avon and Greyhound _ say they no longer use animal testing for cosmetic and household product research, the report said. Other companies highlighted in the study were American Home Products, Bristol-Myers Products, Colgate-Palmolive, Gillette, Johnson & Johnson, Proctor & Gamble and Schering-Plough, which produces Maybelline cosmetics.
DOC.HEAD: Doxycycline Recalled
DOC.TEXT: Federal officials say more than 3,000 bottles of an antibiotic distributed by Goldline Laboratories, doxycycline hyclate, are being recalled because one bottle was found to contain a muscle relaxant. Doxycycline hyclate is used to treat a wide range of infections, including venereal diseases, acne and life-threatening pneumonia. The Food and Drug Administration said Thursday that the mislabeled muscle relaxant, carisoprodol, could harm patients because it would not treat their infections and could impair their mental and physical abilities, making it dangerous to drive a car or operate heavy machinery. The recalled bottles of Goldline doxycycline hyclate 100 milligrams are in six lots. The bottles carry lot numbers 824039, 844059, 863069, 882079, 883079 and 919099. The carisoprodol tablets are white and round with the Bolar Pharmaceutical Co., Inc., logo on one side _ a ``b'' over an inverted ``b'' _ and the number 0094 stamped on the other side. The FDA said patients who find that they have the mislabeled product should stop using it, contact their physicians and return the prescription to their pharmacy.

DOC.HEAD: 43-Year-Old Woman Having Baby to Save Dying Daughter
DOC.TEXT: A couple whose 17-year-old daughter is dying of leukemia is having a baby in hopes the infant will prove to be a compatible bone marrow donor who can save their daughter's life. Abe and Mary Ayala of suburban Walnut undertook the desperate gamble against the advice of their doctor, following a fruitless nationwide search for a suitable donor, the Los Angeles Times reported today. ``It made me uncomfortable,'' said Dr. Patricia Konrad, a pediatric oncologist at City of Hope Medical Center in Duarte. ``It didn't sit well, if that was the only reason, to have a child to help another child.'' The odds are about one in four that the baby _ a girl who will be born in April _ will provide a compatible match, doctors say. ``I never thought I'd be pregnant at my age, but when you're faced with the possibility that your child is going to die, you desperately seek, and whatever you need to do, you do it,'' said Mary Ayala, 43. Konrad, despite her misgivings, has agreed to perform the marrow transplant if the baby turns out to have compatible tissue. Abe Ayala had undergone a vasectomy after their daughter, Anissa, was born. Doctors offered little hope a reversal would succeed, but Mrs. Ayala became pregnant six months after her husband's operation. ``We're just waiting and hoping that our miracle baby will be the miracle baby that Anissa needs,'' Mrs. Ayala said. Anissa's condition has stabilized, and doctors have told the family that bone marrow can be obtained at little risk from an infant who is at least six months old. If the tissue matches, Anissa will undergo a long and painful process of preparing for transplant surgery. Her existing bone marrow, which is being ravaged by the malignancy, would be destroyed through bombardments of radiation and chemotherapy. Donor marrow is harvested by inserting a thick needle repeatedly into the donor's hipbones. A healthy donor can regenerate lost marrow within a week. Medical ethicists said it is extremely rare for a baby to be conceived specifically to serve as a bone marrow donor for an ailing family member. Medical procedures, such as donating marrow during transplant surgery, require a patient's informed consent. With children, such consent usually is given by the parents or legal guardian. The Ayala case, however, raises questions about the parents' objectivity in deciding what is in the newborn's best interest. ``How much potential pain and risk can one parent demand of one sibling for the benefit of another sibling?''asked Jake Priester, a research fellow at the Center for Biomedical Ethics at the University of Minnesota. The Ayalas voiced dismay that their motives might be questioned. ``If it's not a match, we will love our baby just the same,'' Mary Ayala said. The couple discussed the idea at length with Anissa and their 19-year-old son, Airon, and they sought guidance from God, Mrs. Ayala said. ``I had a dream and God told me everything was going to be OK,'' she said. ``He wants me to have this baby.''

DOC.HEAD: Third American Kidnapped During Protest Over Bush Visit
With PM-Drug Summit, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Kidnappers seized a priest from New York during a visit by President Bush, and a U.S. official said he was the third American captured in a leftist guerrilla campaign to protest the trip. The Roman Catholic priest was abducted as Bush met in the coastal city of Cartagena with the leaders of Colombia, Peru and Bolivia to coordinate their war on drugs. The Rev. Francisco Amico Ferrari, from Rochester, was on his way to celebrate Mass Thursday at a church near his parish in a poor neighborhood of Cali when he was intercepted by armed men, said the Rev. Robert Seguin, of Detroit. No one claimed responsibility, but a State Department official in Washington said the kidnappers had identified themselves as members of the pro-Cuba National Liberation Army. Amico, 40, who has lived in Colombia since he founded a Cali branch of the Toronto-based St. Basilian priests in 1987, was the third American reported kidnapped by the guerrilla group this week. The group claimed responsibility for the bombing of two Mormon temples earlier this week. The State Department official, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said witnesses overheard the kidnappers say the priest would be released. In a telephone interview, Seguin said he hoped Amico would be freed when Bush leaves Colombia. Bush returned to Washington later Thursday. On Tuesday, members of the guerrilla group kidnapped two Americans _ David Kent and James Donnelly _ to protest Bush's visit and said they would put their captives on trial, according to police. Kent, 40, is a teacher from Indianapolis, while Donnelly is a 65-year-old businessman from Detroit. On Wednesday, the White House denounced the kidnappings of Kent and Donnelly. It said Bush would cooperate with Colombian officials to help ``in any way deemed appropriate to help resolve this situation.'' Rebels sometimes provide military protection for cocaine traffickers, who pay handsomely for the service. The RCN broadcast network said Amico is one of four priests working in the neighborhood of Aguas Blancas, one of poorest in the southwestern city. It quoted an unidentified parish priest saying he was with nuns of Mother Teresa's order when he was abducted. The report said the priests are helped by four nuns from the Missionaries of Charity, founded in India by the Nobel laureate. Cali, a city of 1 million people 450 miles south of Cartagena, is home to the Cali cocaine cartel, a rival of the Medellin cartel. The two are believed to manufacture 80 percent of the cocaine imported to the United States. A longtime friend of Amico's in Rochester, the Rev. Ronald Schwenzer, today was quoted as saying Amico told him in a recent letter that he feared the violence in Cali would escalate. ``What he wrote about was the lack of respect for life. People are killed on the streets for drugs. Human life is not considered precious; it's kind of cheap,'' Schwenzer was quoted as saying in the Rochester Democrat and Chronicle. ``They are aware that since this war on drugs began in the fall _ that as Americans, there was a possibility that they could be kidnapped, or shot and killed, or whatever.''

DOC.HEAD: Pastor of Historic Church Charged with Bookmaking for Congregation
DOC.TEXT: A pastor, his assistant, the church secretary and four other people were charged with running an illegal lottery out of an historic city church. Police on Thursday raided the Ebenezer A.M.E. church and 13 homes allegedly used as substations for the bookmaking operation. The arrests were partly a result of wiretaps placed on the pastor's phone after police were tipped off by members of the congregation who were offended by what was going on, said Sgt. George Klein of the vice unit. ``We were pretty skeptical about it at first,'' said Klein. ``We thought no one in their right mind would run a lottery out of a church.'' The Rev. Wendall Christopher, 39, was charged with allowing the church to be used for an illegal lottery, police said. Assistant pastor Jerome Berry, 58, and his wife, Mary Berry, 49, were charged with operating the lottery. Investigators said they believed Christopher might not have directly participated in the operation, but allowed it to operate from his study in exchange for a portion of the proceeds. Also detained were church secretary Julie Hall, 36; Rebecca Griffin, 57; Phyllis Cooper, 28, and Larry Cooper, 42, police said. Ebenezer is believed to be the oldest continuously used black church in the city. The site of the church was purchased by freed slaves in 1839, and the present structure was built in the 1860s. Police were tipped off about the alleged lottery in May and in October obtained a court order to tap the pastor's telephone, they said. Three- and four-digit numbers were collected from players each day at the substations and phoned to the church, police said. The operation used the winning Maryland State Lottery numbers to determine its winners. Police said they would not have an idea of the amount of money involved in the operation until they look at seized lottery slips.

DOC.HEAD: Man Arrested Asleep in Home Found Guilty of Burglary
DOC.TEXT: A man nabbed napping on the couch in a house he had just burglarized was sentenced to 20 years in prison, authorities said. Keith Sinclair, 24, pleaded guilty Thursday to second-degree burglary after police said he broke into a house, reclined on a couch and took a snooze. Asked what Sinclair had stolen, prosecutor Howard Cole said, ``He never had a chance to. I guess he got tired and sat down, and just fell asleep.'' Sinclair broke the glass on the front window of Diane Royal's home around midnight on Dec. 16, according to testimony in the Guilford County court. Royal's daughter was startled on returning home that night to find Sinclair _ clutching a pistol _ on the couch. She called police, who woke the dozing Sinclair. Sinclair's attorney, John Bryson, said his client was intoxicated when he broke into the house. ``My client was so grossly impaired that he had no recall of the event,'' Bryson said.

DOC.HEAD: Vargas Llosa's Motorcade Attacked in Northern City
DOC.TEXT: A stone-throwing mob attacked the motorcade of leading presidential contender Mario Vargas Llosa during a campaign swing in a northern city. Police said the candidate was not injured. A foreign journalist accompanying the candidate was injured and had to be taken to a hospital, said a statement by the Democratic Front, Vargas Llosa's center-right coalition. The party blamed supporters of President Alan Garcia's Aprista Party for the attack Thursday in the northern city of Trujillo, an Aprista stronghold. It was the second attack on a presidential candidate in eight days.
