The statement said ``an Aprista mob'' attacked the motorcade with sticks and rocks, ``destroying all of them (the cars) except the one in which the Vargas Llosa was riding.'' Police Gen. Diomedes Diaz confirmed the afternoon attack but said only one car was hit and no one was injured. The Democratic Front communique said Kevin Rafferty, a reporter for International Media Partners group, was injured. It did not give his nationality or further details on his injury. Trujillo is 350 miles northwest of Lima on the Pacific coast. Vargas Llosa, an acclaimed novelist, was making a campaign swing through the area, and his motorcade was returning to Trujillo from the town of Cartavio, 18 miles to the north, Diaz said. He said a group of people gathered in Campo Grande, a slum on the northern edge of the city, threw rocks at the motorcade as it passed. He said a car carrying journalists was hit by a rock, breaking the rear window of the car. Diaz said it was not known if the group that attacked the motorcade was composed of Aprista members. On Feb. 7, Marxist presidential candidate Henry Pease was slightly wounded in the leg by birdshot fired by police who also used tear gas to break up a campaign march in downtown Lima near the presidential palace. Five others were injured. Interior Minister Agustin Mantilla offered his resignation following the incident, but the government refused to accept it. Vargas Llosa, a severe critic of Garcia's government, is favored to win the April 8 elections. Other candidates are Alfonso Barrantes of the Socialist Left coalition and Luis Alva Castro of the center-left Aprista. By law, Garcia cannot run for re-election.

DOC.HEAD: 5,000 Teachers Rally at Statehouse, Storm Legislature
DOC.TEXT: About 5,000 teachers skipped school to attend a Statehouse rally where many of them kicked and pounced on the doors of the House of Delegates chambers, chanting ``Let us in.'' State legislators were not amused by Thursday's demonstration. ``How could you teach a child discipline when you're doing something like this?'' asked Del. Phyllis Given, a Democrat whose complaints of intimidation by the teachers prompted state troopers to patrol the chamber. ``As a former teacher, I respect their democratic right to come and solicit support for salary increases, but I was appalled that during the session they pounded, kicked the doors and yelled and screamed,'' said Del. Marge Burke. The teachers, angered by Gov. Gaston Caperton's declaration there is no money for pay raises next year, also picketed the governor's mansion. West Virginia teachers earn an average of $21,904, ranking them 49th in the nation, according to the state teachers' assocation. They received a 5 percent pay raise last month.

DOC.HEAD: Australian Leader to Try for Record Fourth Term
DOC.TEXT: Prime Minister Bob Hawke today called a general election for March 24 in a bid to gain a record fourth consecutive term for his Labor government. Hawke said Australians ``faced clear and stark alternatives'' in a vote over his government's economic record. ``We can as a nation make the choice to continue on the path of steady growth, or under the Conservatives we can choose to forsake the future in a traumatic rerun of the late 70s and early 80s,'' he said, referring to years when the opposition was in power. ``The central question is whether we will continue forward toward a fair society, an increasingly efficient Australian economy,'' he said. Hawke spoke at a news conference after meeting with Governor-General Bill Hayden to get approval for the election date. The timing of the election comes amid widespread dissatisfaction with 17 percent interest rates, which have hurt home buyers and small businesses. But the opposition coalition also has suffered from internal squabbling and difficulty outlining alternative policies. Hawke, 60, said he expected to lead the Labor Party to an unprecedented fifth term before retiring. Andrew Peacock, the 51-year-old opposition coalition leader, also predicted victory. ``It is good news for all Australians,'' he said of the election date. ``This has been a government which has put average Australians last. It has been a government for the very few and privileged.'' The Labor Party under Hawke was first elected in March 1983 and won in early elections in 1984 and 1987. The deadline for calling the next elections was May 12 with a three-year term of government. Hawke is considered one of the most popular leaders ever in Australia, despite his tearful confessions about infidelity many years ago, his daughter's former heroin addiction and his acknowledgment that he once had a drinking problem. Recent opinion polls show support for the Labor Party at 45 percent, compared with 42 percent for the Conservative Liberal-National Party coalition. Labor has 85 seats in the 148-seat House of Representatives, which chooses the government. The Liberal Party has 45 seats, and its coalition partner National Party has 18 seats. Hawke is hoping voters will remember the government's record of creating jobs while lowering personal and corporate taxes. The Labor Party has also deregulated the financial system and allowed foreign banks to operate in Australia.

DOC.HEAD: Unions: Daily News Has Out-of-Town Operations, Reporters Ready for Strike
DOC.TEXT: The Daily News' unions claim the newspaper has set up an out-of-state electronic layout operation and recruited reporters from sister newspapers as part of a contingency plan to publish in the event of a strike next month. The News recruited reporters at two non-union Florida newspapers owned by the News' parent, the Tribune Co. in Chicago, to work in New York should there be a strike, said Barry Lipton, president of Local 3 of The Newspaper Guild. ``I think they are trying to make honorable members of the working press scabs. It's bad news,'' Lipton said Thursday. ``They're trying to provoke a confrontation, not just with the Guild, with all the unions.'' John T. Sloan, the News' vice president for human resources, said: ``We are not going to detail our contingency plans. These plans are in the best interests of our paper and our employees. We are obliged to continue publishing regardless.'' Sloan said, however, that management believes the disagreements with the union ``will be fully resolved during the negotiations.'' The contracts of the 10 unions expire March 30. The News says it has to tighten work rules and eliminate overstaffing in order to turn a profit after losses of $115 million from 1979 to 1989. The unions, under the umbrella of the Allied Printing Trades Council, say the Tribune Co. is trying to break them. They call the News' contract proposals insulting. The Guild on Thursday held its first round of talks with the newspaper, which Lipton described as simply introductory. Lipton also said the law firm negotiating for the News, Nashville, Tenn.-based King and Ballow, had told union negotiators their pay would be docked for time spent away from their newspaper jobs. That never happened before at the News, Lipton said. The News is setting up an electronic layout system in Newport News, Va., where the Tribune Co. owns the Daily Press and the Times-Herald, Lipton said. Several reporters and editors at two Florida-based Tribune Co. newspapers, the Fort Lauderdale News-Sun-Sentinel and The Orlando Sentinel, have been recruited to work at the Daily News should there be a strike, Lipton said. Sources told New York Newsday that the reporters have been promised their current salaries, a per diem payment, paid transportation, lodging at hotels and protection by security guards. The Daily News, in a story in Thursday's editions, quoted company sources who said that reporters and editors also had been recruited at the Virginia newspaper. Management at the Fort Lauderdale paper threatened to fire anyone who spoke publicly about the offer, the News quoted an unidentified reporter as saying. Officials at the newspapers referred all calls to Sloan, who declined to discuss the job offers.

DOC.HEAD: Editor of U.S. Military Paper Resigns
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. Air Force colonel in charge of the Pacific Stars and Stripes resigned today, saying the Pentagon ombudsman had criticized him for managing the news published in the paper serving U.S. troops overseas. ``I believe it was appropriate for the good of the organization to tender my resignation,'' Col. Edwin J. Montgomery said. He said ombudsman Philip Foisie, whom the Defense Department named last year, had said in a report that ``I inserted myself into the newspaper's editorial process unnecessarily,'' especially in the early part of his nearly four-year tenure. Montgomery declined to give more details on the ombudsman's judgment, but said he was pleased that Foisie had not accused him of censorship. ``I am disappointed that he saw my efforts to fulfill the charter as management of the news,'' the Air Force officer said in a telephone interview. ``The mission I had was to publish a newspaper that was unafraid of news critical to its readers and their profession, but accurate, in good taste, and which assured that both sides of contentious issues were aired. I've done my level best to accomplish that.'' Foisie's report was not made public, and when The Associated Press reached him at U.S. Army headquarters in Heidelberg, West Germany, he declined to comment on Montgomery's resignation. Foisie was visiting the European Stars and Stripes, the sister paper of the Tokyo-based publication read by some 135,000 U.S. troops in the Pacific region. Since his appointment, Foisie has visited both Stars and Stripes papers to interview their military and civilian staff members to assess the free flow of information to the papers' military readership. Foisie is a former foreign editor of the Washington Post and former executive editor of the Paris-based International Herald Tribune. Civilian journalists at the Pacific Stars and Stripes have complained of censorship by military editors, news management and harassment of journalists who raise objections. One senior civilian journalist in Tokyo, Dewey Brackett, has testified to Congress about his complaints, and believes he was removed from the post of Pacific editor as a result. Montgomery, who has denied censoring the paper, is retiring from the military later this year and his replacement has already been named, Marine Col. Walter S. de Forest. He, like Montgomery, is to hold the titles of commander and editor in chief of the paper, though the ombudsman has recommended that a civilian be the editor while the commanding military officer hold the title of publisher. Foisie said in an interim report that having a civilian be the top news executive would make the paper less vulnerable to charges that the military censors it. The Stars and Stripes papers are ``authorized but unofficial publications,'' the Pentagon says. Their charter says they are to provide ``a free flow of news and information ... without censorship or news management.''

DOC.HEAD: Bomb Kills Undercover Narcotics Officer
DOC.TEXT: An undercover detective who worked on high-level drug trafficking cases was killed by a bomb planted in his unmarked police car, authorities said. Dennis Wustenhoff, 41, died at Stony Brook University Medical Center on Thursday after his car blew up in front of his home in in this Long Island city, said hospital spokeswoman Maxine Simpson. ``This was probably an assassination and job-connected,'' said Suffolk County Police Commissioner Daniel Guido. ``But we don't know whether it was revenge or related to a current case Wustenhoff was working on.'' Wustenhoff, a 20-year veteran, was assigned to the narcotics squad in 1984. He was involved in major ``high-level narcotics-trafficking'' investigations, said Cecilia Clausing, a Suffolk County police spokeswoman. The bomb blew out the entire front part of the late-model white Cadillac, throwing debris up to 200 feet, Guido said. There were no other injuries. The device was placed either in the engine or under the driver's seat, Guido said. It was unclear if it exploded when the officer turned on the ignition switch or whether it was set off when he sat in the driver's seat. A neighbor who heard the explosion came running and helped pull him out of the car. According to Guido, the officer was conscious and ``made some comments to the rescuer'' when asked if he knew who might have done it. Guido would not reveal what the comments were, but he said the killing ``was not a street level operation, it was much higher than that.'' Wustenhoff was decorated 10 times by the department and had worked with federal Drug Enforcement Administration agents on a number of projects. The presiding officer of the Suffolk County Legislature, Donald Blydenburgh, announced that a $1,000 reward is being offered for information about the blast that leads to arrests. Wustenhoff leaves a wife and three children, a 14-year-old boy and two girls aged 12 and 10. His wife and children were not in the house at the time of the blast.

DOC.HEAD: Visiting Soviet Leaders Impressed With American Military Hardware
DOC.TEXT: A Soviet legislator visiting U.S. military bases with members of the Supreme Soviet said his country was not interested in keeping up with American military technology. Ten members of the Supreme Soviet's Defense and State Security Committee toured the carrier USS Theodore Roosevelt at Norfolk Naval Base on the invitation of their U.S. counterparts in the House Armed Services Committee. ``Your Navy ... has produced a deep impression on us,'' committee Chairman Vladimir Lapygin said Thursday, speaking through an interpreter. ``We do have a navy of our own, but we don't want our navy to catch up with your navy because it is not so economical and this is not our target,'' Lapygin said. The Soviets seemed impressed by the technology and manpower they saw Thursday, and less enthusiastic about answering security-related questions asked of them during a 15-minute news conference on the ship's hangar deck. Asked about mutual European troop cuts announced Tuesday, Lapygin said the delegation was in this country at the time and hadn't discussed it. ``Our opinion is we have a deep respect for one another. There is nothing to fear. We think you can keep as many troops as you want,'' he said. The weeklong tour of U.S. military installations and scientific facilities began Feb. 11 and was ending today. Rep. Les Aspin, D-Wis., who led an American delegation on a tour of Soviet military bases last August, was host to the Soviet delegation aboard the Roosevelt.

DOC.HEAD: Cheney Meets With American Troops in Seoul
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Updates with X grafs with Cheney visit to frontline, quotes; picks up 4th graf pvs, Journalists were
DOC.HEAD: Precede SEOUL
LaserPhoto Available
DOC.TEXT: U.S. Secretary of Defense Dick Cheney peered through binoculars into heavily fortified North Korea today and said the experience reminded him of America's ``determination to protect freedom and democracy'' around the world. ``At a time when we are welcoming changes in Eastern Europe and the erosion of the Soviet position in the Warsaw Pact, it's important to be reminded that the United States and the Republic of (South) Korea still face a very hostile and threatening power in the North,'' said Cheney. Cheney was driven up steep, muddy slopes by jeep to this mountaintop South Korean army observation post along the 2.5 miles-wide Demilitarized Zone which separates the communist North from capitalist South Korea. The border between the two Koreas is one of the most heavily armed in the world, with some 1.5 million troops behind barbed wire and bunkers on both sides. South Korean Lt. Col. Chang Gwang-il told Cheney in a strategic briefing that Gongjak overlooked the Chorwon Valley, one of the main invasion routes used by the communist North at the start of the 1950-53 Korean War. A peace treaty has never been signed and the two nations remain technically at war. Col. Chang told Cheney he was visiting the site on the birthday of North Korea's Kim Jong Il, the son and heir apparent of ruler Kim Il Sung, the world's longest ruling communist dictator. ``We never forget that we fought here side by side. ... We're ready to fight!'' said the young South Korean colonel. Cheney was flown to the border outpost by helicopter after lunching with troops of the U.S. 2nd Infantry Division, but had to cancel a scheduled visit to Panmunjom, the truce village on the border of the two Koreas, due to dense fog. During his visit to Camp Casey, headquarters of the U.S. 2nd Infantry Division located 35 miles northeast of Seoul, he passed dozens of tanks, bunkers and guard posts covered with camouflage, buildings painted in speckled olive and brown and soldiers in full-dress battle fatigues. Journalists were told Cheney asked to have an informal lunch with 12 noncommissioned officers ``with no generals present.'' The special fare for the day at Camp Casey's Warrior's Club, where Cheney ate, was a ``Secretary of Defense Turkey Club Sandwich.'' Cheney explained the background of cuts in troop strength and defense spending to senior enlisted men and asked for their comments, one witness said. There are 43,000 U.S. troops stationed in South Korea under a mutual defense pact. U.S. officials said Thursday about 5,000 are expected to be withdrawn in the next three years. The secretary told Seoul officials earlier that he wants to cut U.S. forces in Asia and the Pacific by 10 to 12 percent _ at least 12,000 troops _ over the next three years. He said about 5,000 of the troops would be pulled out of South Korea and another 7,000 to 9,400 would be withdrawn from the Philippines and Japan. There are 120,000 U.S. troops based in the three countries. Cheney, who also will travel to Manila and Tokyo, said the troop cuts in South Korea would not be pushed ``precipitously.'' ``Our commitment remains strong,'' Cheney told reporters Thursday. At a meeting with South Korean President Roh Tae-woo Thursday, Cheney reaffirmed Washington's firm security commitment to Seoul and warned the military threat from communist North Korea ``remains undiminished.'' The Koreas, divided since 1945, face each other with more than 1.5 million troops deployed on both sides. On Thursday, North Korea charged that Cheney was in the region to observe South Korean preparations for war against the North. In a radio broadcast monitored in Tokyo, North Korea also demanded a halt to U.S.-South Korea ``Team Spirit'' military exercises underway since last month, calling them ``nuclear war preparations'' against the North. At a news conference at the end of talks Thursday, South Korean Defense Minister Lee Sang-hoon said his government would give ``positive consideration'' to increasing its support for the U.S. troops. An American official, speaking on condition of anonymity, said Cheney wants Seoul to double its $300 million annual contribution to the support of American forces. The official said many of the details will not be worked out until the fall. South Korean estimates it provides nearly $2 billion annually to U.S. forces, such as the rent-free use of land that is not counted in the American calculation.

DOC.HEAD: Daley Plans for Southeast Side Airport Gets Mixed Reaction
DOC.TEXT: Mayor Richard M. Daley unveiled a $5 billion plan for a third Chicago air terminal that would lower traffic and delays at the world's busiest airport, O'Hare International. Daley announced Thursday that officials are planning a 9,400-acre airport, to be called Lake Calumet Airport, near Indiana Harbor on the city's southeast side. Daley said the airport would cost $4.9 billion and generate $13.7 billion annually for the impoverished industrial area, which he called an ``ideal place'' for the long-discussed airport. Others weren't so sure. ``The only bright spot in an otherwise dismal proposal is the recognition by the city of the need for a third major airport for the region,'' said Rep. Henry Hyde, whose district encompasses O'Hare. Federal transportation officials attribute national travel delays to O'Hare's overcrowind problems. O'Hare is located northwest of downtown Chicago, and Midway Airport is in the southwest. ``The location proposed by Mayor Daley seems woefully inadequate and the proposed completion date of 2010 means that Buck Rogers will make one of the first landings at the new facility,'' said Hyde, a Republican. He said building an airport there would displace 3,500 homes and suggested the mayor go ``back to the drawing board.'' U.S. Transportation Secretary Samuel K. Skinner welcomed Daley's announcement, and said the site he mentioned should be considered along with others that have been suggested to the south of the city and in northwest Indiana.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Manages Slight Gain, Stocks Down in Tokyo
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs 6th graf to CORRECT weekly closing figure.
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. dollar turned weak late in the afternoon session to close at the day's lowest level today, while the key index on the Tokyo Stock Exchange slipped slightly. The dollar closed at 144.80 yen, up 0.10 yen from Thursday's close of 144.45 yen. After opening at 144.80 yen, the currency traded in a narrow range between 144.55 yen and 144.95 yen. Currency dealers said the exchange rate remained narrow prior to the release of U.S. trade figures for December, due out in Washington later today. ``There was some dollar-selling for position adjustment toward the closing bell'' in anticipation of a holiday in the United States next Monday, said Yuichi Tsuchiko, a dealer with Fuji Bank. U.S. currency and other financial markets will be closed Monday for Presidents' Day. On the stock exchange, the Nikkei Stock Average of 225 selected issues lost 11.67 points, or 0.03 percent, closing the week at 37,460.32. The index gained 316.10 points Thursday. An estimated 500 million shares changed hands on the first section, the same volume traded Thursday. Yozo Asai, a stock analyst with Yamaichi Securities Co., said the Nikkei index gained 201 points at one point during the morning session, but fell back on profit-selling in the afternoon. Despite Japanese media predictions that the governing Liberal Democratic Party will maintain a majority in Sunday's lower house elections, ``everyone is becoming weak over concern about what the actual results from the elections will be,'' Asai said. He said investors also worried about speculation that the nation's central bank will raise its official discount rate, charged on its loans to commercial banks, soon after the election. The Bank of Japan raised its key lending rate three times last year. The rate is currently 4.25 percent. At stake in Sunday's elections are 512 seats for the powerful House of Representatives.

DOC.HEAD: Britain, Argentina Restore Ties Despite Falklands Dispute
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS graf after 5th pvs, `In Buenos...' to UPDATE with Menem naming ambassador; picks up 6th pvs, `Menem, however...'
DOC.TEXT: Britain and Argentina renewed diplomatic ties severed nearly eight years ago over the Falklands War, but Argentina said it would keep pressing its claim over the islands. Foreign Secretary Douglas Hurd of Britain praised the accord reached Thursday in Madrid, Spain after two days of talks. ``It underlines the fact that we have no quarrel with Argentina, and this has been achieved without any sacrifice of sovereignty,'' he said on Britain's private Sky Television. Foreign Minister Domingo Cavallo of Argentina said Thursday's accord ``means passing from a state of war to a state of peace.'' In Buenos Aires, President Carlos Menem said the accord opened up trade possibilities for Argentina, a major meat exporter. It followed the resumption last month of direct air service between the two nations, who traditionally were heavy trading partners. Menem also named Deputy Foreign Minister Mario Campora, nephew of former president Hector Campora, as the ambassador to Britain. Menem, however, repeated Argentina's claim to sovereignty of the South Atlantic islands 300 miles off his country's southeastern coast. He said its claim was not diminished by restoring diplomatic ties. The Falklands War broke out after Argentine forces invaded the British-ruled islands on April 2, 1982. Britain sent a military task force that recaptured them after a 74-day war. The fighting claimed the lives of 712 Argentines, 255 Britons and three islanders. Britain began ruling the islands as a colony in 1833 after Spain ceased to govern Argentina and abandoned the archipelago. Argentina claims it inherited the islands under the name Las Malvinas from Spain and says Britain stole them. British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher has refused to discuss Falklands sovereignty with Argentina. In turn, Argentina refused until Thursday to declare the war officially over. U.N. Secretary-General Javier Perez de Cuellar applauded the accord, saying it ``creates an atmosphere of confidence.'' Talks between British and Argentine officials on resuming normal relations began in August after Menem said Argentina would not use them to raise its claim over the Falklands. A key to the Madrid agreement was Britain's agreement to lift its 150-mile military protection zone around the islands. British submarines, ships and planes have patrolled the zone. The islands are guarded by about 2,000 British troops. The British Foreign office said the two nations had agreed to inform each other about movements of their warships and military aircraft in key areas of the South Atlantic and give notice of large military exercises. Under the arrangement, Argentine warships wishing to come within 50 miles of the islands and Argentine warplanes wishing to come within 70 miles must give 48 hours warning. The Foreign Office said ambassadors will be exchanged ``in due course.'' Hurd said: ``It is for the Falkland Islanders to decide on their own contacts with the mainland (Argentina).'' Most of the 1,900 islanders are fiercely pro-British. Their legislative council refused an invitation to join the Madrid talks. William Fullerton, governor of the islands, told British television's Channel 4 News from Stanley, the capital: ``They accept that there should be good relations between Britain and Argentina.'' He added, `The thing they would be worried about is the sovereignty issue, and all along that has been specifically excluded from the talks.''

DOC.HEAD: Blast Rips Through University Auditorium, Injures 20
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with 39 injured, third such university bombing in 15 months; no pickup.
DOC.TEXT: An explosion ripped through a university lecture hall today, injuring 39 students, officials said. It was the third explosion in 15 months at universities in Brussels. ``It is probably a bomb attack, although we are still waiting for final details,'' said a police official on condition of anonymity. The two earlier explosions were bomb blasts. The blast occurred in an auditorium of the Univeristy of Louvain's faculty of medicine as about 100 students attended a pharmacy class. It was followed by a fire and dense smoke spread through the hall almost immediately. Officials said 13 students were badly burned and 24 slightly injured. Firefighters rushed in with gas masks to rescue the students. The police official said there were parallels with a bombing Dec. 1 at Brussels University in which two students suffered burns. A small bomb had gone off at the same university a year earlier. No one has claimed responsibility for these attacks.

DOC.HEAD: Snow in Northwest, Great Lakes; Rain in East
DOC.TEXT: Snow fell today with some thunder and lightning on the coasts of Oregon and Washington and from North Dakota to northern Michigan, while rain drenched the East Coast from Portland, Maine, to Atlanta. Thunderstorms were forecast today from Illinois to western New York state, and in the mid-Atlantic and the Southeast, which got heavy rainfall Thursday. Flooding struck Meridian, Miss., and Alabaster, Ala. Three feet of water covered roads between Lebanon and and Morrow, Ohio. A tornado that wrecked three mobile homes in Louisiana injured five people, while another twister Thursday destroyed a home and damaged eight to 10 others in Mississippi but caused no injuries. The National Weather Service also reported tornado sightings in Alabama and Kansas and hail the size of baseballs in Jackson, Miss. Winds gusted to 62 mph Thursday at Blytheville, Ark., and to 75 mph at Natchez, Miss. In California's San Joaquin Valley, record low temperatures this week caused frost damage to the citrus fruit and almond crops. Winter storm warnings for today were called for Nevada, Oregon's higher altitudes, the northern Sierra Nevadas and Northern California's mountains. Advisories for winter weather today were posted over much of New England and central New York state. Near-blizzard conditions on Thursday closed the highway between Cheyenne and Laramie, Wyo. Watches for heavy snow snow were in effect through tonight for northwestern Wyoming. Rainfall during the 6 hours ending 7 p.m. EST Thursday included 5.32 inches at Meridian, Miss.; 2.88 inches at Centreville, Ala.; 2.45 inches at Tuscalloosa, Ala.; and 2.25 inches at Fort Knox, Ky. The coldest reading in the lower 48 states Thursday was minus 36 at West Yellowstone, Mont. High temperature records broken for Feb. 15 included 71 in Bluefield, W.Va.; 73 in Greenville-Spartansburg, S.C.; 76 in Pensacola, Fla.; 83 in Shreveport, La.; 85 in San Antonio; 87 in Del Rio, Texas; and 91 in Corpus Christi. Temperatures Thursday dropped to record lows in northern California: It was 23 degrees at Santa Maria; 24 at Fresno; 25 at Bakersfield, the city's coldest February reading on record; 29 in San Jose and at Sacramento's airport; 30 in downtown Sacramento; 32 in Moffett; and 36 in San Francisco. The previous record of 31 at downtown Sacramento had been on the books since 1883. Thursday's high temperature for the nation was 97 at McAllen, Texas. DOC.HEAD: Premier Gives Backing to VOA Station
DOC.TEXT: Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir gave his approval to building a Voice of America transmitting station in Israel's Negev Desert, despite protests from environmental advocates and air force officers. The dispute over the U.S government-funded station has caused strains between Israel and the Bush administration at a time of delicate contacts between the two countries over complex Middle East peace moves. The station expects to start broadcasting from Israel to Africa, India, Afghanistan, Soviet Asia, and Eastern Europe in 1993, its officials say. Environmental Affairs Minister Roni Milo of Shamir's right-wing Likud bloc has argued against the new transmitter, saying it seems unnecessary in light of recent changes in Eastern Europe. However, Malcolm Forbes Jr., chairman of the Board of International Broadcasting, said Thursday the new station was needed to further promote democracy. ``We agreed that in order to carry on the process of democracy, we must continue to have the exchange and free flow of information to all parts of the world,'' Forbes told reporters Thursday after a 20-minute meeting with Shamir. The board oversees the network. The planned station is seen in Washington as crucial to transmitting VOA programs among millions in Asia and Africa, where many governments have not undergone the recent liberalization in Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union. ``We are moving ahead as decided two years ago. Shamir was very supportive,'' Forbes added, referring to the agreement signed with Israel in June 1987. Shamir's spokesman, Avi Pazner, said the premier told Forbes that Israel would honor its agreement to allow the station. Israeli newspapers said the premier's consent follows a decision by the four senior leaders of the coalition Cabinet, made up of Likud and the center-left Labor Party. These top ministers stepped in after messages delivered through U.S. Ambassador William Brown were quoted by reports as urging ``quick completion of the planning stages.'' Work on the station has been delayed by lobbying from Israeli nature groups that claim the three-square-mile complex and 200-meter tall antennae would emit radiation and disrupt wildlife, including a bird migration route to Africa. Objections have also come from air force commander Maj. Gen. Avihu Ben-Nun, who fears an important bomber training field may have to be moved because the new station will interfere with its operation, Israeli media reported. Communications Minister Gad Yaacobi of Labor has backed the project, claiming it could bring up to $1 billion to Israel's debt-ridden economy over the next 25 years and provide hundreds of jobs.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Up, Gold Down
DOC.TEXT: The dollar rose against key currencies in European trading this morning. Gold was lower. In Tokyo, the dollar closed at 144.80 yen, up 0.10 yen from Thursday's close. Other dollar rates at midmorning compared with late Thursday: _1.6926 West German marks, up from 1.6805 _1.5045 Swiss francs, up from 1.4950 _5.7510 French francs, up from 5.7130 _1.9080 Dutch guilders, up from 1.8940 _1,256 Italian lire, up from 1,248 _1.2005 Canadian dollars, down from 1.2060 The British pound was quoted at $1.6855, compared with $1.6936 late Thursday. Bullion dealers in London fixed a recommended price of $414.90 per troy ounce at midmorning, from a $415.50 bid late Thursday. In Zurich, the bid price was $415, down from $415.75 late Thursday. Gold in Hong Kong dropped $2.64 dollars an ounce today to close at $412.69. Silver in London traded at a bid price of $5.34 a troy ounce, down from Thursday's $5.35.

DOC.HEAD: Students, Homeless Join In Sleep-out To Promote Affordable Housing
DOC.TEXT: Demonstrators left their homes to endure freezing rain, hail and snow during a five-night sleep-out with the homeless to promote affordable housing. ``The first night I slept out ... it was rather warm but last night it began to snow a little after midnight and it was very, very cold,'' Katie Wales, 22, a recent graduate of Brown University, said Thursday. ``It was a very frightening experience being that cold,'' Wales said. The camp-outs, which started Sunday and were set to end today, attracted about 80 people at locations in Providence, Cranston and Pawtucket _ nearly twice the original goal, organizer Jim Tull said. ``It was supposed to be only three at each spot, but people have just been coming down and adding to the numbers, including some homeless people,'' said Tull, 35, a co-director of Amos House, a shelter and soup kitchen. ``We've had families. We had a woman with three of her children last night and a gentleman with his daughter last night also.'' The effort is part of a nationwide campaign that started Dec. 25 and is scheduled to continue in 65 communities until April 15, Tull said. A similar vigil also was held in Washington, D.C., this week. Rhode Island's homeless population could be from 2,000 to 5,000, said Tull. Nationally, it is estimated there are between 3 million and 4 million homeless. The Rhode Island protesters faced sub-freezing temperatures earlier in the week; Thursday night it was warmer but raining. ``When that starts banging on the box it keeps you awake. The people who weren't in a box, they got soaking wet,'' said Ed, a 34-year-old homeless man, who said normally on a such a night he would have taken refuge under a downtown bridge. Ed, who asked that his last name not be used, said he is in line for a job and has been receiving counseling for his alcoholism. ``For me things are looking a lot better,'' he said. ``That's what I'm here for _ I'm trying to help other people, too.'' Participants said the public has been supportive, dropping off coffee, donuts and soup. Some brought blankets. ``One person reached out with a $50 bill to give to us to go get a hotel room,'' said Tull, who said the group declined. Ed, however, said it's not always like that. ``Some people put you down,'' he said. ``They tell you to go out and find a job.'' Tull said Rhode Island's congressmen, all of whom met with the group this week, were ``moved by the extent to which we had made our point.'' He said, however, that the night before the group met with Sen. John Chafee, a Republican, ``he crossed the street and walked around us,'' then crossed back over. Chafee was unavailable for comment but Mike Ryan, an aide, said Thursday, ``It certainly wouldn't have been intentional.'' Dan Newman, 20, a Brown student, planned to head to classes at the Ivy League university as usual today after his night on the street. ``I like to think of it as, I am a citizen like everyone else and because of the circumstance of how I was born I have an opportunity to help out and to raise awareness,'' Newman said.

DOC.HEAD: Soviet Property Bill Sent Back to Committee
DOC.TEXT: Lawmakers today demanded changes in a landmark bill legalizing private property after attacking the proposal as overly narrow, vague, and open to abuses. A group of 100 deputies fearing quick changes in the Soviet Union today announced formation of a parliamentary faction to ``resist the breakup of the U.S.S.R.'' Members of the new group vowed to fight separatism, nationalism and chauvinism. In the second day of its winter session, the Supreme Soviet parliament sent the bill to committee and said it would take up the issue next week. The property bill stems from the Communist Party's decision last week to diverge from orthodox Marxism and permit ``individual property,'' including ``means of production.'' But the 35-article bill never uses the words ``private property'' outright. Instead, it speaks of ``the property of citizens.'' Deputy Vladimir Tikhonov, an agricultural scientist, said he is concerned that it mentions the right to own property but does not require the often recalcitrant Soviet bureaucracy to sell it. Other lawmakers, speaking on the second day of debate over the proposal, argued the bill is not clear. ``Everything in the draft law has two meanings,'' said Anatoly Sobchak, a prominent reform-minded deputy from Leningrad. He said the law must specify that ``any form of property'' is legal. Mikhail S. Gorbachev's nearly five-year tenure as Soviet leader has led to many upheavals in politics and society, but few official proposals have the ideological sweep of the proposed Property Law. Citizens who were taught for generations that property is theft are now being asked to accept private ownership along with two other forms of property already in existence _ collective and state ownership. ``The words `private property' cause an allergy in us all,'' said one lawmaker who spoke in support of the bill. For decades, Soviet orthodoxy has forbidden the private ownership of farms, factories or equipment on a large scale, viewing it as the root of economic exploitation. But the proposed law has the blanket legalization of the ``means of production'' and says foreign firms, once scorned as agents of imperialism or neo-colonialism, can own factories and buildings. The law is designed to spur the stagnating economy through greater productivity and an inflow of Western capital. ``If we want to have a market economy and take part in the international marketplace, then we need such a law,'' Justice Minister Veniamin F. Yakovlev said in defense of the bill Thursday. The new parliamentary faction, ``Soyuz,'' Russian for union, appears to be opposing Baltic representatives who want to restore independence to their republics. It also seems to oppose the Interregional Group, an organization of progressive radicals demanding rapid, radical economic and political reform. The Interregional group includes leading reformer Boris N. Yeltsin. The official Tass news agency, which announced formation of the new faction, did not clarify if the faction was created by lawmakers in the Supreme Soviet or in the separate Congress of People's Deputies, a body created by Gorbachev. However, it called the new faction a ``parliamentary'' group, suggesting it is part of the congress.

DOC.HEAD: Party's Over For Homeless Who Feasted on Drexel's Lavish Leftovers
With PM-Drexel
DOC.TEXT: The party is over for the homeless who once feasted on Cajun-style blackened fish, gourmet soups and rich desserts _ all leftovers from Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc.'s Beverly Hills office. For two years, the homeless who gathered nightly at a nearby park often dined at picnic tables piled with tenderloin beef, chicken breasts, gourmet breads and New York-style cheesecakes left from the company's lavish lunches. But the bulk of Drexel's Beverly Hills staff faced layoffs today and the office was expected to close. ``This will hurt because they were our major source of food and we have no one to replace them,'' said Ted Landreth, a spokesman for the Greater West Hollywood Food Coalition, which distributes food to about 250 people in Plummer Park. ``The food from Drexel has been phenomenal, better than at most deluxe restaurants _ expensive meats, thick soups of all different varieties, lovely salads,'' Landreth said. In the company's heyday, the coalition sent a car every day to pick up an estimated $500 worth of food, or about 40 percent of its daily distribution, that had been passed over by busy financial traders at the 400-employee office. Drexel had offered the food free to employees on the advice of the company's junk-bond chief, Michael Milken, who since has been fired and faces federal securities-fraud charges. ``It was Michael Milken's concept that everyone should be fed well. Everyone from the traders to the maintenance people ate well,'' said Neilson Cook, Drexel's food services director. ``He figured that if they were eating at their desks, they would be less likely to eat out and give away company secrets, and he also wanted to keep the amount of time spent away from work at a minimum.'' The investment bank's parent company, Drexel Burnham Lambert Group Inc., filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection Tuesday and immediately began liquidating billions of dollars in assets.

DOC.HEAD: Cuomo Son to Marry Kennedy Daughter
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 3 grafs to recast and add details. Picks up 4th graf, ``Kerry is....'
DOC.TEXT: The eldest son of Gov. Mario Cuomo plans to marry a daughter of the late Sen. Robert F. Kennedy, linking two of the country's most influential liberal families. Ethel Kennedy on Thursday announced the engagement of her daughter, Kerry, to Andrew Cuomo, and Gov. Cuomo said the whole family was ``very, very pleased'' about the union. The two said they would marry sometime this spring or early summer at Ethel Kennedy's home in McLean, Va. ``Kerry is a wonderful, wonderful young lady. We know her. We love her and we couldn't be happier,'' the governor said. Noting Andrew's age, he said: ``For those of us who went into marriage from puberty, 32 is kind of delaying it for quite some time.'' Andrew Cuomo, a lawyer, proposed to Ms. Kennedy on Valentine's Day and presented her an emerald-cut diamond ring. They dated for 18 months. Both have followed in their fathers' footsteps of public service. Cuomo ran his father's two successful gubernatorial campaigns. He also works full-time at the non-profit organization he founded that provides temporary housing for homeless women and children. Ms. Kennedy, 30, directs the Robert F. Kennedy Center for Human Rights in Boston, which supports political activists around the world. Ms. Kennedy, the seventh of 11 children, was 8 years old when her father was assassinated in 1968. She is a graduate of Brown University and Boston College Law School.

DOC.HEAD: Second Release of Poison Gas Affects 15,000
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 1 graf after 3rd graf, ```I'm certainly ...', with order lifted; pick up 4th graf, `In the ...'
DOC.TEXT: The second toxic chemical leak in two weeks at a plant considered among the most modern in the nation forced authorities to order 15,000 residents to remain indoors. About 500 gallons of muriatic acid leaked from a transfer hose at Rhone-Poulenc's Institute plant Thursday. No injuries were rported, but fears that poisonous vapor released in the spill would spread over Institute and neighboring St. Albans led officials to order people inside. ``I'm certainly concerned,'' said plant manager Ron Bearer. ``This is a serious incident when we have to recommend to emergency services'' that people stay inside buildings. The vapor didn't leave the plant, and authorities lifted the order 30 minutes later. In the first leak, on Feb. 2, a small amount of methyl isocyanate, or MIC _ the same chemical that killed 3,500 people in 1984 at Bhopal, India _ escaped from a pipe and injured seven workers. The Occupational Safety and Health Administration sent inspectors to the plant after the small MIC leak. They were still at the plant Thursday, and two more inspectors were dispatched to look into the muriatic acid leak, said Jack Hord, a spokesman for the U.S. Labor Department. After the Bhopal leak and a series of leaks here in 1985, OSHA performed a wall-to-wall inspection of the plant, which then was wholly owned by Union Carbide. The company was cited with 221 violations. A $1.37 million fine assessed by OSHA was settled out of court for $408,500 on the condition Carbide didn't have to admit fault. The plant, which is about 10 miles west of Charleston and is now owned by both Union Carbide and Rhone-Poulenc, a French company, was considered by Carbide as the safest in the nation after the company spent millions improving safety systems after the 1985 leaks. Hord said the recent incidents don't mean ``this is an unsafe operation. It doesn't compare to what happened in 1985. The problems at Institute in 1985 were just multiplying. You just have two incidents here.'' After an August 1985 leak at Institute, 135 sought medical help at hospitals. The muriatic acid leaked as workers filled a tank at the plant's wastewater and sewage treatment plant, where the chemical is used as a neutralizing agent. A truck apparently ran over a hose, causing it to split open, Bearer said. Muriatic acid is a mixture of hydrochloric acid and water. A condensed solution of hydrochloric acid causes severe burns and permanent visual damage may occur, according to The Merck Index, an encyclopedia of chemicals. If inhaled, it can cause coughing, choking and inflammation and ulceration of the respiratory tract. The U.S. Coast Guard stopped traffic on the Kanawha River for 30 minutes for fear the vapor cloud would sweep toward the river. The cloud dissipated soon after it formed. After the Feb. 2 leak, the plant owners were criticized for waiting three days to notify county emergency officials. Bearer changed plant policy to require the reporting of all leaks. Community leaders praised the company for its fast reporting Thursday. Kanawha County Manager Ron Gregory said county emergency officials received word within 30 seconds of the leak's discovery. ``I believe the recent MIC incident may very well have had a beneficial effect,'' Gregory said. ``It identified the communications problem we had. That's now been corrected.''

DOC.HEAD: Christian Forces Batter Rivals After Major Offensive
DOC.TEXT: Gen. Michel Aoun's gunners today battered a rival Christian militia with unrelenting artillery fire today after mounting a tank-backed offensive the day before that left 20 people dead and 54 wounded. The militiamen answered with a barrage of rockets in the latest clash in the 17-day duel for control of Lebanon's Christian enclave. Police said Thursday's casualties were the result of a 16-hour offensive by 36 tanks and about 900 soldiers of Christian Gen. Michel Aoun. They seized a chain of buildings around the district of Ein Rummaneh, a stronghold of Samir Geagea's Lebanese Forces militia. The power struggle has killed 554 people and wounded 1,829, including the latest casualties, since it began 17 days ago, according to police. Geagea's command said Aoun's gunners today were ``pouring their criminal howitzer shelling'' on Ein Rummaneh and the militia's two other East Beirut strongholds of Ashrafiyeh and Nabaa. The communique said Aoun's gunners were using U.S.-made 155mm howitzers, firing ``incendiary shells that started several fires on civilian property.'' Aoun's command said Geagea's gunners were hammering Aoun-controlled districts in east Beirut with multi-barreled rocket launchers. Police said Aoun's gunners and Geagea's forces also were exchanging intermittent shellfire in Kesrouan province, the Lebanese Forces' main power base north of the capital. Geagea told the Christian Voice of Lebanon radio that the fighting will ``last for as long as the general lives.'' Aoun's command, in its communique, said Ein Rummaneh has ``militarily fallen, adding ``our forces will be able to overrun it in a matter of hours.'' A mediation committee of independent Christian figures pleaded with the combatants to stop shelling hospitals. It said the French-administered Hotel Dieu, an important hospital, suffered ``severe damage.'' The committee's statement said the hospital administration was ``seriously considering the possibility of evacuating it ... if it was targeted by shelling again.'' The Syrian-allied government of President Elias Hrawi, based in Moslem west Beirut, called upon the estimated 1 million Christians living in the enclave to denounce both sides. Hrawi was quoted by the An-Nahar newspaper as telling a government meeting Thursday that ``intensified efforts are under way to put an end to the clashes.'' It gave no further details. Hrawi, a Maronite Catholic like Aoun and Geagea, was elected Nov. 24 under a peace plan brokered by the Arab League. The plan was designed to end the country's nearly 15-year-old civil war and provide more power to the nation's Moslems. Aoun has rejected the peace pact and the government of Hrawi, who has fired him as army commander. Aoun has criticized the plan for not laying out a timetable for a complete withdrawal of Syrian forces. About 40,000 of them control most of Lebanon. They came under a 1976 Arab League peacekeeping mandate, but Aoun says they have been backing the Moslems in the war. Geagea has recognized Hrawi, but he has been vague on the peace agreement.

DOC.HEAD: First Settlement Reached in Texas School Bus Accident
DOC.TEXT: The first settlement between a soft drink company and a family that lost a child in a school bus accident will bring the parents at least $2.7 million over 35 years, and possibly more, a lawyer said. Raul and Margarita Ortega reached the out-of-court settlement Monday with Valley Coca-Cola Bottling Co. Inc., the Ortegas' attorney, Kenneth W. Sparks of Houston, said Thursday. The Ortegas' son, Jose Luis, died on Sept. 21 when a Valley Coca-Cola truck collided with a school bus near the Mexican border, killing 21 students and injuring 60 others. Sparks also is seeking damages for two other family members injured in the accident: Jose Luis' brother, Raul E. Ortega Jr., 17; and a cousin, Marisela Ortega, 15. In the settlement, the company agreed to pay $1.5 million to the Ortegas. But an interest-earning annuity in the agreement will give the family more than $2.7 million over 35 years, and more if the parents live longer. The Ortegas were paid an undisclosed sum on Monday and will receive lifelong monthly payments that begin at $4,000, and increase to $7,000, Sparks said. His law firm received about one-third of the settlement total. If the parents die within less than 35 years, the monthly payments go to their heirs, he said. Sparks said the Ortegas did not want to comment on the settlement, but said, ``My clients have assured me that they would gladly refund all money in this settlement to obtain their son back.'' Valley Coca-Cola, based in the border town of McAllen, is a defendant in lawsuits filed by nearly 50 other familes in connection with the incident. Valley Coca-Cola wants the bus manufacturer, Blue Bird Body Co. of Fort Valley, Ga., to share the liability in any lawsuit verdicts. Valley Coca-Cola filed a lawsuit last month against Blue Bird, alleging the bus was unsafe. The truck driver, Ruben Perez, 25, faces trial on 21 felony counts of involuntary manslaughter.

DOC.HEAD: Airline Chairman Resigns; Accepts `Moral Responsibility' For Crash
DOC.TEXT: The chairman of Indian Airlines resigned today, saying he accepted ``moral responsibility'' for a plane crash in southern India that killed 91 people. Prime Minister V.P. Singh accepted the resignation of R.K. Prasad and asked the joint secretary of the Civil Aviation Ministry, P.C. Sen, to become managing director of the government-owned domestic carrier. Prasad joined Indian Airlines in 1956 and took over as chairman and managing director in April. The airline has been dogged for years by complaints of frequent schedule delays and allegations of mismanagement, poor staff morale, inadequate supervision and training of pilots, and poor maintenance of planes. The government declined to release details of Prasad's resignation, except to say he had accepted ``moral responsiblity'' for the crash. A 3-month-old Indian Airlines Airbus 320 crashed Wednesday about 50 yards short of a runway in Bangalore. The airline said 146 people were on the hourlong flight from Bombay and that 55 survived. At least 36 foreigners were on the flight, including American, Japanese, West German, British, Sudanese, Somalian and French nationals, officials said. A U.S. Embassy official in New Delhi said one American died, one was missing and five had survived. The official, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said today that their identities would not be released. The government has ordered an investigation into the cause of the crash. The weather was clear, and there were no signs of an emergency, officials said. Aviation Minister Arif Mohammed Khan said the plane's ``black box,'' the digital flight data recorder that logs all changes in altitude, speed and direction, would be sent abroad for analysis. He refused to say where it would be sent. The twin-engine plane is manufactured by Airbus Industrie, a European consortium based in France. Airbus sent a team of experts to Bangalore to help in the investigation. Wednesday's crash is the second accident involving an Airbus 320 and the first of an Airbus 320 in commercial service.

DOC.HEAD: East German Prime Minister Hears Polish Concerns About Border
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 12 grafs to UPDATE with Mazowiecki talks. Pickup 6th pvs, `West Germany...'
DOC.TEXT: Prime Minister Tadeusz Mazowiecki told the East German leader today that Poland must have at least a limited role in talks to reunify the Germanys, the Polish news agency said. Mazowiecki, meeting with East German Prime Minister Hans Modrow, reiterated Polish concerns that a united Germany may seek to reclaim land ceded to Poland after World War II. Modrow was welcomed today at Warsaw's Okecie Airport by Mazowiecki, with whom he had two meetings scheduled on political and economic issues. East and West Germany and the four World War II allies that divided them _ the United States, Soviet Union, Britain and France _ plan a series of talks on eventual reunification. Mazowiecki described his first session with Modrow as ``fruitful,'' the official PAP news agency reported. ``Both speakers in an open way expressed their views on the subject of the process which in the last few months has been developing and is leading to the reunification of Germany,'' Mazowiecki told PAP. This process has to take into consideration the ``full security of the rights of German neighbors,'' Mazowiecki said. ``Poland doesn't have to take part in everything, but it has to take part in everything that concerns Poland, it has to be present,'' he added, according to the PAP report. Sessions were also planned with President Wojciech Jaruzelski, and Modrow was to address the foreign affairs committees of the two houses of parliament. ``Hans Modrow will have a chance to join our postulate and voices of those states which think that Poland must be included in the unification talks,'' the government daily Rzeczpospolita wrote today. Modrow has said he accepts Poland's western border as permanent. East German government spokesman Wolfgang Meyer has attacked West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl for failing to assure Poland there would be no effort by a united Germany to reclaim former German territory forfeited after World War II. However, Modrow is likely not to be much of a factor in the talks. His Communist-led government, which took over when the former Stalinist dictatorship was overthrown last year, is expected to be ousted when East Germans hold their first free elections on March 18. West Germany has also said it has no territorial claims on Poland, but Kohl has said he cannot speak on the subject for a reunified Germany. West Germany foreign minister, Hans Dietrich-Genscher, on Thursday rejected Polish participation in the talks, saying no Polish territories would be included in the reunited Germany. But with no unequivocal statement renouncing future claims, such reassurances are unconvincing to Poles, subject to past German aggression and wary of German conservatives who contend Germany still in theory exists within its 1937 borders. The Polish border along the Oder and Neisse rivers incorporates 40,000 square miles of territory ceded by Germany following World War II, to compensate for an even larger territory taken from Poland in the east by the Soviet Union. Jaruzelski on Thursday called the border issue ``a question of life or death for Poland.'' More than 46 percent of the 1,803 Poles surveyed Thursday in 50 towns nationwide by the Gazeta Wyborcza newspaper said they felt ``fear'' at the potential reunification of Germany. Only 7 percent said they greeted the prospect with ``joy,'' and 22.6 percent said they had mixed feelings, according to the poll published today. The rest said they were indifferent, held another opinion or no opinion.

DOC.HEAD: Mrs. Marcos Denied Access to Classified Government Documents
DOC.TEXT: Imelda Marcos cannot view classified government documents to prepare for her federal racketeering trial next month, a judge has ruled. U.S. District Judge John Keenan, in a written decision Thursday, said lawyers for the widow of deposed Philippine leader Ferdinand Marcos had not proven that the U.S. government had assembled an interagency task force to investigate her and her husband. ``To say that `it is clear' there was, is advocacy run amuck,'' Keenan said in denying her request for classified documents from more than a dozen government agencies. These included the departments of Justice, Defense and Treasury; the offices of the president and vice president; the CIA, FBI, National Security Agency, the Navy and the U.S. Embassy in Manila. The judge also scoffed at claims by her lawyers that Mrs. Marcos and her husband were kidnapped from the Philippines by American military forces after Marcos' ouster in February 1986. Keenan cited a June 1988 letter from Marcos to President Reagan in which he thanked Reagan for his hospitality of two years ago and wrote how he came to the United States ``at your invitation.'' ``This is hardly the language of a kidnap victim,'' Keenan said. The judge has yet to rule on a separate motion by Mrs. Marcos that claims the U.S. government has no jurisdiction to prosecute her because she was brought to this country against her will. Mrs. Marcos, who lives in Hawaii, is scheduled to go to trial March 13 on charges that she and her husband embezzled more than $100 million from the Philippine treasury to buy art and Manhattan real estate. They also were charged with defrauding banks of $165 million in loans. Marcos died in exile in Hawaii on Sept. 28 at age 72. Prosecutors opposed the request for the classified documents, calling it a fishing expedition. Keenan noted that the prosecution had already turned over to Mrs. Marcos' lawyers about 350,000 documents, videotapes and other items seized in its investigation.

DOC.HEAD: Shoplifter Says TV Judge's Comment Inspired Her Crime
DOC.TEXT: A 68-year-old woman who shoplifted four packs of cigarettes said a comment by Judge Wapner led her to commit the crime. The woman admitted she stole the cigarettes and said she got the idea from an interview that late-night talk show host Pat Sajak had with Joseph Wapner, said Larry Ankrum, police spokesman at Mountlake Terrace, a suburb north of Seattle. Wapner, a retired judge, presides over the syndicated television show ``The People's Court.'' Ankrum said the woman quoted Wapner as having said in the interview that ``everybody steals, at least once in their life.'' The woman told police she pondered Wapner's comment for a while and then decided to steal the cigarettes from a store Tuesday ``for the thrill of it,'' Ankrum said. The woman was cited for shoplifting and ordered not to return to the store, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Controls Eased on Transfer of High Technology to Eastern Europe
DOC.TEXT: An international group screening the sale of sensitive technology has granted preferential treatment to Eastern Europe, recognizing it no longer presents a serious strategic threat, a U.S. official said today. However, the United States blocked moves by the majority of the group to grant the same preferred status to the Soviet Union. ``The strategic threat is changing, and COCOM must adapt,'' said a U.S. delegate to the special two-day executive meeting of the Coordination Committee for Multilateral Export Control. The Paris session ended late Thursday. But another official close to the talks, also speaking on condition of anonymity, said: ``I don't think the Americans conceded anything. Their position is thoroughly old fashioned, based on the Cold War perception of the Soviet Union as a country with missiles aimed at America's heartland. There is no recognition of the changes, no sympathy for the problems there.'' Decisions are reached by consensus among COCOM members, which include Japan, Australia and all 16 NATO countries except Iceland. The group, formed about 40 years ago, screens technology exports to prevent sensitive items from being diverted to military uses by Communist governments. But their work has become far more complex with the rapid moves toward democracy by the Soviet Union and countries such as Czechoslovakia, Hungary and Poland, the three nations which stand to benefit immediately by the new preferred status, which means their applications will be more favorably viewed. COCOM said an intensified review would begin immediately aimed at loosening the list of controlled high-tech goods in the areas of telecommunications, machine tools and computers, ``the areas most meaningful to the development of the East,'' the U.S. official said. For a country on the prohibited list to buy certain sensitive items, it must be granted an exception by COCOM. The three areas to be liberalized represent more than half of all the exceptions granted, the official said. The official said COCOM had received ``overtures'' from Czechoslovakia, Hungary and Poland, who promised to protect Western technology if allowed to purchase the sensitive items. Even with the change of status, however, Eastern Europe will not have the status enjoyed by China. ``There's still the question of diversion to Soviet military use. That's not a problem with China,'' the U.S. official said.

DOC.HEAD: Industrial Production Slipped 1.2 Percent in January
DOC.TEXT: Industrial production slipped 1.2 percent in January, the government said today, as abnormally warm weather reduced utility use and automakers temporarily laid off workers to reduce bloated inventories. The Federal Reserve said January's decline followed a revised 0.2 percent gain in output a month earlier as a major strike ended at the Boeing Co. and utilities fired up their operations to meet the demand prompted by the fourth coldest December on record. December's increase originally was reported to be 0.4 percent. It was the first dip in production since a 0.3 drop last October. ``In January, the output of motor vehicles was curtailed drastically and the extremely warm weather caused a sharp drop in utilities output,'' the department said. Output at utilities fell 10.7 percent last month, the warmest January in 96 years of government weather record-keeping, reversing a huge 6.3 percent advance in December. And the layoffs at auto factories drove overall manufacturing production down 0.9 percent. Manufacturing output represents 84 percent of the index. ``Automobile assemblies plunged to a 4.1 million unit annual rate from a 6.2 million unit rate in December,'' the department said. The interest-sensitive manufacturing sector has been among the hardest hit by Federal Reserve efforts to restrain inflation by keeping a tight grip on credit. Production of durable goods _ big-ticket items expected to last more than three years _ fell 1.7 percent after rising 0.3 percent in December and 0.4 percent in November. Non-durable goods production increased 0.2 percent, reversing a 0.2 percent decline in December. It rose 0.2 percent a month earlier. Output at mines, aided by the warmer weather, rose 2.1 percent after a 2.0 percent decline in December and a 0.2 percent gain in November. The changes meant the industrial production index in January stood at 140.9 percent of its 1977 base, down from 142.5 percent a month earlier. In another report, the Fed said the operating rate of the nation's factories, mines and utilities dipped 1.2 percentage point to 81.9 percent in January. Factory use had remained steady at a revised 83.1 percent in December, largely because of the weather-related 5 percentage point hike to 86.4 percent in the utility rate. It was the sharpest utility-rate increase in the 23-year history of the government's capacity utilization reports. The factory-use rate was 83.1 percent in both October and November. But reflecting the warmer weather in January, the utility rate plummeted to 77.1 percent. The department attributed the fall in large part to a 10 percentage oint drop in power plant utilization. The operating rate measures not only output but also changes in productivity levels. While it reflected sluggish output, the report could be interpreted as good news for consumers. The closer U.S. industry gets to full operating capacity, the greater difficulty it has producing enough to meet demand, leading to shortages and subsequent price increases. Analysts generally consider an operating rate of 85 percent or above as an indication of inflationary pressures. The manufacturing-plant operating rate in January slipped to 81.9 percent from 82.9 percent in December. The rate had peaked at 84.7 percent in January 1989. The rate at factories producing durable goods fell from 80.9 percent to 79.4 percent. ``Operating rates for auto and truck assembly facilities dropped to levels near their 1982 recession lows,'' the department said. The rate at factories producing non-durable goods fell 0.1 percentage point to 85.6 percent. The operating rate at mines was down 0.8 percentage point to 884.7 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Four Dead, 90 Injured in Chlorine Gas Leak
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Adds 1 graf at end with background on Bhopal disaster. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Chlorine gas seeped from a small paint factory early today, killing four people, and injuring about 90 others living in a nearby shantytown, police said. The dead included a 3-year-old girl, her 8-year-old brother and their 35-year-old father, and a worker at the factory, located in one of the city's most densely populated and poorest neighborhoods, police said. At least 20 of the injured were hospitalized, many in serious condition, said police officials, speaking on condition of anonymity. According to police, the gas leaked from a cylinder that was later plugged and removed from the factory. An arrest warrant was issued for the factory owner, they said. Prasanta Sur, the health minister of West Bengal state, ordered an investigation into the accident. About 3,600 people were killed and 20,000 injured when poisonous methyl isocynate gas leaked on Dec. 3, 1984 from a pesticide plant in the central Indian town of Bhopal. The factory was run by the Indian subsidiary of the U.S.-based Union Carbide Corp.

DOC.HEAD: Radar Planes Deployed for Anti-Drug Duty
DOC.TEXT: The Air Force has sent sophisticated AWACS radar planes to Puerto Rico to help detect aircraft and ships used for smuggling drugs into the United States. Pentagon spokesman Bob Hall said Thursday that the AWACS were dispatched this week from Tinker Air Force Base in Oklahoma to Roosevelt Roads in Puerto Rico for an indefinite period. ``The Department of Defense has been charged with responsibility for detection and monitoring of aerial and maritime smuggling into the United States,'' Hall said. ``In that regard we've been using AWACS to cover the Caribbean in support of Customs and Coast Guard operations ... they do the interdiction,'' he said. The AWACS _ short for Airborne Warning and Control System _ are designed to give broader detection ``for less air time,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: UMW Wins on Health, Pension Benefits in Proposed Contract
DOC.TEXT: United Mine Workers strikers won concessions on health care and pension benefits and Pittston Coal Group got the ability to run its mines almost nonstop in a proposed settlement distributed to miners today. If approved by the UMW's rank-and-file in Virginia, West Virginia and Kentucky, the settlement could resolve the union's bitter and sporadically violent 10{-month strike against the nation's largest coal exporter by next week. The Associated Press obtained a copy of the proposed contract from a source who insisted on anonymity. Since Pittston and the union negotiators reached agreement on New Year's Eve, they have kept contract details secret while both sides moved to dismiss lawsuits and fines stemming from the strike. UMW President Richard Trumka announced Thursday that union members would vote on the pact Monday, despite $64 million in fines pending in a Virginia state court for illegal strike activity. More than 2,000 union members packed into a building at the Russell County Fairgrounds this morning to receive copies of the 49-page contract, listen to pep talks by the union's top officers and receive a briefing on the terms. Trumka choked back tears as he congratulated the miners on what he said was a successful strike. ``I'm proud. I'm proud you did this,'' Trumka said as he raised the contract in the air to a round of applause. Some miners grumbled about terms in the contract but most gave it a favorable review. ``There's some good, some bad,'' said Jack Hale, a 48-year-old laid-off miner. ``We'll just have to weigh the good against the bad.'' The proposal in many respects mirrors health and pension benefits contained in the 1988 Bituminous Coal Operators Association contract, the industry's national labor contract. But it differs in two significant respects: Pittston won the ability to hire contract truck drivers and maintenance workers, as long as union miners are not laid off in the process. And the company would be able to run its mines around-the-clock and seven-days-a-week, except for Christmas and the Sunday day shift. Wages were not a major issue in the strike. But miners would receive a cumulative $1.20-an-hour raise at the end of three years. Top-scale hourly pay in selected positions would be $17.52. Pittston dropped out of the health-care plan negotiated between the union and the BCOA and spurred the strike by proposing payment of 80 percent of the covered medical expenses rather than 100 percent. The UMW won its demand to maintain 100 percent medical coverage for employees, pensioners and their families. The contract has a new health-cost containment provision in which Pittston issues $500 twice-a-year to each miner and pensioner under the age of 65 to cover their deductibles. After it dropped out of the BCOA, Pittston stopped contributing to the multi-employer retirement fund and promised to take care of its own retirees. It now has agreed to go back to the union pension fund. ``Pension benefits in the new contract are identical to those contained in the 1988 national agreement,'' according to a contract summary. The company wanted to be able to contract out work in five job categories but won the limited right in two areas: transportation of coal and repair and maintenance work. The company wanted to eliminate a provision that union contracts are not broken when a union mine changes hands or is conveyed from one subsidiary to another. But the settlement retains the successorship provision in the 1984 agreement and contains ``strengthened protection for UMWA members against internal company reorganization and shifting of coal lands,'' the contract said. Pittston's significant victory was its request to establish round-the-clock operations. During negotiations, the company dropped its original demand for a Sunday day shift, with four 10-hour shifts a week instead of five eight-hour shifts and the ability to call in workers for ``reasonable overtime'' with 12 hours notice, on a mandatory basis. The UMW wanted to stick with its traditional fixed five-day work week. The contract contains two ``flextime'' work schedules in addition to the regular work week. The flextime allows the company to work continuously. Pittston did not want to reinstate miners convicted of strike-related felonies. The UMW wanted all miners reinstated. A mention of the issue could not be found in the labor agreement.

DOC.HEAD: Body of Kenya's Missing Foreign Minister Found
DOC.TEXT: The partially burned body of Foreign Minister Robert Ouko was found today near his western Kenya home, three days after his mysterious disappearance. The government indicated he had been murdered. The discovery of Ouko's body was announced by President Daniel arap Moi, who said it was found ``in circumstances which at the moment suggest foul play.'' The body of the 58-year-old minister was found in a sugar cane field about four miles from his family farm in Koru, not far from Lake Victoria. The president's statement said the body was partly burned and pledged ``that anyone who may be associated with this horrible event will most certainly be apprehended.'' Ouko, considered one of the most skilled members of Moi's Cabinet, dropped from sight Tuesday. His disappearance went unreported until Thursday evening, when the offical Kenya News Agency broadcast an appeal from family members urging him to contact them or government officials. Moi said Ouko's death was a loss for ``the whole nation,'' calling him ``a brilliant leader, an articulate and courageous spokesman of this country and a loyal servant of the people.'' The minister appeared largely above the fray of Kenyan politics, his name rarely appearing in almost daily press accounts of rivalries within the country's single ruling party. Ouko was last seen publicly on Saturday, when he addressed a service club in Kisumu, 220 miles northwest of Nairobi and not far from his Koru home. State-run radio and television stations quoted unidentified family members Thursday night as saying no one had seen him leave his farm after he went to bed Monday night. The Kenya Times, a Nairobi daily newspaper, reported today that a white car arrived at Ouko's home at about 3 a.m. Tuesday and left with the minister. The paper attributed its report to two unidentified household employees. Before the discovery of Ouko's body, a senior government official, speaking on condition of anonymity, said: ``People are wondering how a full minister can disappear.'' He referred to the fact that the homes of Cabinet ministers are always guarded by armed policemen. They also use bodyguards when they travel. Ouko first served as permanent secretary in the Ministry of Foreign Affairs in 1963-64. He then held a number of other high-ranking government jobs before being tapped by Moi to head the Foreign Ministry in 1979.

DOC.HEAD: Kathleen Sullivan Bids Farewell To `CBS This Morning'
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New throughout to UPDATE with quotes from show, confirmation that Zahn will succeed Sullivan.
DOC.TEXT: Upbeat but appearing near tears, Kathleen Sullivan said farewell today as co-anchor of ``CBS This Morning,'' telling viewers that she's proud of the show and jokingly asking them not to forget her. Sullivan, who has been on the show with Harry Smith since it began in November 1987, also confirmed in her farewell what CBS spokesmen thus far have refused to comment on _ that ABC's Paula Zahn will succeed her. ``Paula Zahn has been the stepmother to two of my other children at ABC, and now I'm sure she'll take great care of my third, `CBS This Morning,''' Sullivan said in her final day on the show, which originated today from Disney World in Orlando, Fla. Before joining CBS, Sullivan co-anchored ABC's ``World News This Morning'' and the news segments of ``Good Morning America.'' She was succeeded on those programs by Zahn, who bid viewers of those shows goodbye on Thursday. Their back-to-back farewell addresses came about after CBS News executives decided to replace Sullivan, whose contract expires in November. According to her agent, Ron Konecky, they gave no reason. He said he is discussing other possibilities for her at the network. Zahn's agent has confirmed that his client is joining CBS News. According to a source close to her contract talks, ABC officials liked her work but decided against battling CBS' offer of a $1.1 million-a-year, four-year contract. Zahn, who had been earning $275,000 a year at ABC, could start co-anchoring CBS' show as early as Feb. 26, according to another source knowledgeable about negotiations for her switch to CBS. CBS has said that Faith Daniels, who co-anchors the ``CBS Morning News'' that precedes ``CBS This Morning,'' will be the latter program's temporary co-anchor next week. Sullivan, whom Smith today thanked ``for being such a great friend and such a great teacher'' during her stay on the show, told viewers that ``I'm very proud of what we've accomplished here in the last 2{ years. ``We've restored the credibility that said we meant business in the morning here at CBS.'' That was an indirect reference her program's predecessor, ``The Morning Show,'' a frothy, short-lived entertainment show that CBS tried after years of generally failing to make a dent in the ratings with a morning news program. Although there were cheers at CBS News when the division got the morning time period back and put in ``CBS This Morning,'' the program still is a distant third in ratings to the top-rated ``Good Morning America'' and NBC's ``Today.'' Sullivan, noting that eight of her 10 years on national television have been spent on morning shows, told viewers that she plans to take a break and that ``I'm hoping to do some really wild and wonderful things.'' She didn't elaborate, but added: ``So, if I show up on your doorstep because I ran out of gas or my horse broke down, please don't forget me.'' Sullivan began her television career as an intern in 1977 at Los Angeles station KNXT-TV, which is owned by CBS and now has the call letters of KCBS-TV. Alluding to the Olympics telecasts she co-anchored while at ABC, she wryly concluded her farewell by saying, ``Yeah, I'm the one who wore the sweaters in the Olympics... I'm a bit older, but I'm also a bit wiser.''

DOC.HEAD: Chinese Uprising Photo Wins World Press Photo Award
DOC.TEXT: The picture of a lone Chinese demonstrator defiantly blocking a column of tanks during the June crackdown of the popular uprising in Beijing won the 1990 World Press Photo award today.
