The photo honored was made by Charlie Cole, a Newsweek magazine staff photographer. The scene also was captured by other photographers. ``The picture symbolizes the events of 1989 ... it's the individual standing up to a repressive regime, to a military juggernaut,'' said Michael Rand, art director of London's Sunday Times Magazine and chairman of the nine-person World Press Photo jury. Established in 1955, the World Press Photo award is one of the most prestigious prizes in photo journalism. This year, 11,047 pictures were submitted by 1,280 photographers from 64 countries, Rand said. In the spot news category, the second place was for a picture by Agence France Press staffer Ron Haviv showing political opponents of Panama's Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega being beaten by Noriega henchmen. Eric Bouvet of the French agency Gamma won first prize in the news features category. His entry shows hysterical Iranians mourning the death of Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini in June. Pictures of West Berliners tearing down the wall dividing their city, taken by Anthony Suau of the American agency Black Star, won first prize in the spot news series category. Norbert Rosing of West Germany's Silvestris Fotoservice won first place in the humor category with his ``Seagull Attacks.'' Associated Press photographer Jim Mone won second prize with a picture of former President Reagan exposing his partly shaved head one week after he underwent skull surgery last year.

DOC.HEAD: Lockheed to Pay $1 Million Smog-Related Fine
DOC.TEXT: Air quality officials say they hope other companies will heed an agreement by Lockheed Aeronautical Systems Co. to pay a $1 million fine for inadequate smog control record keeping. ``We hope this settlement sends a message to the regulated community that the AQMD is determined to crack down on so-called technical violations such as record keeping, because these violations have a serious effect on our air pollution problem,'' said Diana Love, chief prosecutor for the South Coast Air Quality Management District. The agency described the civil penalty announced Thursday as a landmark air pollution settlement under which Lockheed promised to use more sophisticated painting equipment to cut down on pollution. Most violations involved errors in records related to the use of coatings and solvents, the Burbank-based aerospace manufacturer said. Some of the coatings and solvents the company uses emit volatile organic compounds that are key ingredients of smog. Lockheed is allowed to use those materials under a plan in which the company also uses coatings and solvents with lower-than-required emission levels. ``Lockheed has assured the district that it wants to protect the environment and is committed to complying with district rules,'' said Dale Daniels, Lockheed executive vice president. Lockheed said it will have a central dispensing station for its coatings and solvents, to better monitor their use. The company also agreed to outfit all its plants with the latest pollution reducing equipment.

DOC.HEAD: Reporter Allegedly Beaten by Army Major
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Contents may offend some readers.
DOC.TEXT: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti (AP) _ Radio Metropole said one of its reporters was beaten by a high-ranking army officer and forced to sit in human excrement after a quarrel with a drunken policeman. The privately owned station said Ertho Zamor was arrested by a drunken traffic police sergeant Wednesday night during a wake for a member of Zamor's family near Bon Repos, 10 miles north of Port-au-Prince. Radio Metropole said the unidentified sergeant brought Zamor to a Bon Repos army post, where Maj. Isidore Pongnon arrived shortly afterward. The station said the two then slapped and beat Zamor with rifle butts, forcing him to sit in human excrement. The report could not be independently confirmed. In an interview with Radio Metropole, Pongnon acknowledged he was present during the incident but denied he beat Zamor, saying Zamor attacked the sergeant at the army outpost. He said Zamor had been arrested because he was pretending to be an army officer. Zamor, who said he was not charged, was released early Thursday morning and was being treated in the capital for head injuries, the station said. Pongnon is assistant director of the Port-au-Prince Prefecture. He formerly commanded Fort Dimanche, a dreaded military outpost where thousands of political dissidents disappeared during the 29-year Duvalier family rule. It was closed last year. Opposition and human rights groups had demanded its closure since dictator Jean-Claude Duvalier fled to exile France in 1986 after a popular uprising.

DOC.HEAD: Tadzhik Communists Reject Embattled Leaders' Offers to Resign
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 14 grafs to UPDATE with Central Committee rejecting resignation offers. Pickup 16th graf, ``We think ...'
DOC.TEXT: Tadzhik Communist Party officials today rejected offers by the republic's leaders to resign, and the legislature formed a committee to investigate more than a dozen deaths in ethnic rioting. Thousands of protesters Thursday defied a ban on demonstrations to demand the resignations of leaders in their Soviet Asian republic. On Wednesday, the party chief, premier and president offered to resign, but said they could not quit until the party and local parliament released them. The Tadzhik party Central Committee declined to accept the offers and decided to keep the current leadership, said Anatoly Larenok, a correspondent for the national newspaper Vozdushny Transport, Russian for air transport. He had no details of today's action. Residents interviewed by telephone said the streets were quiet today in Dushanbe, the capital of Tadzhikistan. Western reporters have been barred from traveling to the region. The republic's Interior Ministry raised the death toll from 18 to 20 in the violence that began Saturday, Larenok said. An Interior Ministry spokesman said 568 people were injured, of whom 178 are hospitalized. Forty-two were arrested. The Presidium of the Tadzhikistan Supreme Soviet formed a special deputies commission to investigate the deaths, said Boris K. Pugo, a non-voting member of the ruling Politburo visiting Dushanbe. ``The situations during the aggravation of events were complex. For example, there were many bullet wounds. But so far it's not known who was shooting and from where,'' Pugo told the army newspaper Red Star. Tadzhikistan, which borders China and Afghanistan about 1,600 miles southeast of Moscow, is the latest in a string of republics torn by ethnic strife since Mikhail S. Gorbachev came to power five years ago and relaxed some controls. He has repeatedly warned that the turmoil threatens his reform program, and has had to resort to force to put down uprisings in several republics that killed hundreds of people. The violence in Tadzhikistan began Saturday night after rumors spread that ethnic Armenians fleeing persecution in Azerbaijan were being moved into the Tadzhik republic, where housing is scarce. Officials said only a few dozen refugees had arrived. On Monday, authorities declared a state of emergency, which bans demonstrations and sets an overnight curfew. The official Tass news agency reported 5,000 troops and policemen were enforcing the state of emergency. It also said more troops poured into the city, including Red Army soldiers assigned to protect government buildings and factories. On Thursday, about 8,000 protesters defied a ban on demonstrations and gathered near Communist Party headquarters to demand further resignations by the republic's leaders, Soviet media reported. They also demanded better housing, more jobs and a ban on selling pork, a forbidden food for the majority Moslem population, Tass said. In addition, they want the withdrawal of troops and an end to the curfew. ``We think that the current Tadzhik leadership is incapable of resolving socio-economic problems,'' said Tadzhik government planning chief Buri Karimov, chosen by the demonstrators to lead a Provisional People's Committee uniting the leaders of unofficial organizations and intellectuals. ``People must wait years for good housing, and unemployment, especially among young people, is on the rise,'' Karimov said. Tass said as many as 200,000 people in the area are jobless.

DOC.HEAD: Wiesel to Gorbachev: Voice Concern over Anti-Semitism
DOC.TEXT: Nobel Peace Prize winner Elie Wiesel is calling for Mikhail Gorbachev to personally condemn a growing number of anti-Semitic incidents in the Soviet Union. Wiesel said at a news conference Thursday that during a visit to Moscow last month all the Jews with whom he spoke ``agreed the situation is becoming increasingly dangerous.'' In six visits to the Soviet Union, he said, he had never seen Jews there ``living and dwelling in such fear.'' He said he was told of many cases in which Jews were publicly beaten or insulted as police or soldiers looked on impassively. ``The time has come for (Gorbachev) personally to address the issue,'' Wiesel said. ``It must come from him _ directly, clearly.'' He said he supported the Soviet president's reforms and was confident of his intentions. ``I'm convinced Gorbachev is not pleased with anti-Semitism in the Soviet Union,'' he said. ``I'm convinced he would like it to disappear.'' Soviet officials have warned that fanning racial hatred is a crime punishable by imprisonment. But some Soviet Jews have complained that not enough is being done to protect them from attacks by right-wing groups that have flourished in the Soviet Union as central authority has waned.

DOC.HEAD: First Lady Has Operation for `a Small Cancer'
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Top 5 grafs with first lady ``great'' today; picks up at pvs 3rd graf, The outpatient
DOC.TEXT: Barbara Bush, taking care not to smile too broadly, said today she feels great following outpatient surgery to remove a small cancer on her lip. The first lady was chipper and upbeat at a downtown hotel today as she toured an interior decorating exhibit that benefits one of her favorite charities, the Washington Home, which operates health-care and hospice programs. Asked how she felt, Mrs. Bush emphatically told reporters, ``Great.'' Her lip was almost imperceptably swollen, with a row of subtle stitches in place after removal of what she calls ``a small cancer that you get because you were stupid and sat in the sun all your life.'' ``I've had a little operation ... So don't do anything funny, no matter what. No laughing _ don't even look funny,'' she jokingly told a group of pre-schoolers she visited at a New York day-care center on Thursday. ``Don't make me laugh.'' The outpatient operation to remove the small basal cell cancer was performed Wednesday at the National Naval Medical Center in suburban Bethesda, Md., and the first lady had local anesthesia. Announcing the procedure on Thursday, her office called it ``a routine outpatient medical procedure'' and said no side effects were expected. The first lady visited All Children's House in Manhattan on Thursday and returned to Washington before accompanying President Bush today for a holiday weekend at their vacation home in Kennebunkport, Maine. ``I feel wonderful,'' Mrs. Bush told reporters in New York. ``I'm great _ from here down and here up,'' she said, pointing below and above the stitches above her lip. She said she would not require further treatment. ``It was a small cancer that you get because you were stupid and sat in the sun all your life. It is totally gone. And the doctor tells me that it's ... the least serious of all.'' The stitches run from the bottom of her right nostril down over her lip, said her press secretary Anna Perez, adding the first lady suffered barely noticeable swelling. ``It only hurts when she laughs,'' the spokeswoman said. Mrs. Bush, 64, has suffered for a year from Graves disease, an immune system disorder that affected her thyroid and irritated her eyes. The thyroid problem, causing overproduction of hormones, was cured by a dose of radioactive liquid. However, her eye problems have persisted. She underwent a series of 10 radiation treatments, ending a month ago, designed to reduce the swelling behind her eyes that causes double vision, especially in the mornings, and bulging and irritated eyes. Basal cell carcinomas are common skin cancers that occur most often on the face or on other skin areas that have been exposed to the sun. Light-skinned people are most susceptible.

DOC.HEAD: Trump Lawyers Deny $100 Million Deal Report
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 9th graf, ``The usually...'' with 2 grafs to UPDATE with comment from Trump.
DOC.TEXT: Donald Trump's lawyers deny that the billionaire has agreed to give his estranged wife, Ivana, $100 million in exchange for quickly settling their much-publicized divorce. ``There are no offers and there will be none,'' Trump lawyers Jay Goldberg and Stanford Lotwin said in a statement. They said the Trump prenuptial and postnuptial agreements were ``ironclad.'' The last written agreement calls for Ivana to receive $25 million, custody of the couple's three children and the couple's mansion in Connecticut. But she wants more. And according to reports in New York's tabloid newspapers, which have avidly covered the Trump divorce, she'll probably get it. Liz Smith, gossip columnist for the Daily News, reported in today's editions that Trump is negotiating to offer Ivana ``more money than even the aforesaid $100 million.'' New York Newsday had quoted Trump associates as saying Trump planned to up the ante to $100 million. Mrs. Trump, who runs the Plaza Hotel and Trump Castle in Atlantic City, N.J., has said she wants ``a fair and equitable share'' of Trump's estimated $1.7 billion fortune. Trump, who has been unusually quiet lately, broke his silence in an interview with New York Newsday, saying a divorce settlement worth more than the $25 million in the written agreement was a longshot. ``I don't rule anything out, but it's highly unlikely,'' said Trump, who called his pre-nuptial agreement ``100 percent'' solid. Beefy security men hustled him in and out of the Plaza Hotel Thursday for a news conference about the championship boxing match between Thomas Hearns and Michael Olajide. Asked by a reporter if he planned to give Ivana more money, Trump smiled politely and said: ``Have a good time.'' Hearns' manager, Emanuel Steward couldn't resist a gentle jab at Trump. ``I want to thank The Donald for getting the crowd out for us today,'' he said. ``The Donald'' is Ivana's pet name for her husband. Hearns, asked to predict the winner in the Trump vs. Trump fight, made a sure bet: ``A Trump is gonna win somewhere.'' Trump, 43, walked out on his wife Sunday after nearly 13 years of marriage amid reports he was involved with 26-year-old actress-model Marla Maples, whom a source said he met at the church where the Trumps were wed. Ms. Maples has not commented on the Trump split, but her agent, Chuck Jones, denies she's involved. Try telling that to the New York Post, which today ran this headline across its front page: ``Marla boasts to her pals about Donald: `Best sex I've ever had.''' The Post said Maples once told an unidentified actress who studied with her from 1987 to last spring at the Actors in Advertising school in Manhattan that Trump was a ``wonderful, wonderful lover.'' The Post also said that Trump told Maples' parents he would ``take care'' of their daughter. Meanwhile, the News set up a Trump Phone Poll so readers could register their support for either Trump. Results were to appear Sunday.

DOC.HEAD: Suspected Informer Axed to Death In Front Of 250 Villagers
DOC.TEXT: Six Palestinians dragged an alleged Arab informer into the square of a West Bank village and axed him to death in front of about 250 spectators, Arab reporters said today. Villagers chanted ``Kill him! Kill him!'' after the man confessed through mosque loudspeakers that he had informed on fellow Palestinians since 1968 and once led three PLO men into an army ambush, the reporters said. The body of Mohammed Khatatbeh, 52, was found today in the village square in Beit Furik near the West Bank city of Nablus, Arab reporters said, speaking on condition of anonymity. The incident began Tuesday when six gunmen in camouflage uniforms kidnapped Khatatbeh from his Beit Furik home. A day later, they took him to the village mosque where he confessed to being an informer, the report said. Late Thursday, Khatatbeh's captors hacked him with axes and knives in the Beit Furik square as villagers looked on. The army confirmed that a body was found and said police were investigating the case. The public slaying of Khatatbeh was rare since alleged collaborators usually are slain without witnesses, with their bodies later left in public places to warn would-be collaborators. Khatatbeh's death brought to 185 the number of Palestinians slain by fellow Arabs during the 26-month-old uprising against Israeli rule in the West Bank and Gaza Strip. Some 656 Palestinians have been killed by Israeli soldiers and civilians, and 43 Israelis also have died in the violence. Also today, the army defended itself against Palestinian accusations that soldiers seeking a suspected activist fired wildly into his home, killing a teen-age girl, and that border police beat more than 40 high school students who were in custody. An army official said preliminary findings showed that in the first case a soldier shot the girl to death on Dec. 22 after she stabbed his hand as he broke a window and tried to enter her house. The official was unable to say if other relatives were wounded. In the other case, the army said it stood by its report that the 40 students in Bethlehem were all hurt falling from a wall as they fled paramilitary border police after a stone-throwing attack. The army response came after the Jerusalem Post quoted school officials as saying the students were being held in a schoolyard and Palestinian doctors as saying the students' injuries appeared to be from beatings, not from falls. One doctor told the newspaper that not one student suffered a sprained ankle, the most common injury in falls.

DOC.HEAD: Slain Judge Heard Appeal from Man Investigated in Bombings
DOC.TEXT: A man targeted in the probe of a series of mail bombs across the Southeast twice appealed a case to the court on which a slain judge sat, a court official said today. Judge Robert S. Vance of the 11th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals was one of two victims of the bombs sent to targets in Georgia, Alabama and Florida. Walter LeRoy Moody of Rex, one of three men investigated by the FBI in connection with the mail bombs, was charged in 1983 with attempted murder in Florida. Court documents show that Moody, using the name Roy Moody, appealed in December 1988 the dismissal of a lawsuit alleging malicious prosecution and false arrest in that case. A panel of the 11th Circuit, including Vance, dismissed Moody's appeal. A court official, who asked that his name not be used, said the panel did not hold a hearing before dismissing the appeal and Moody never appeared before the court. Moody again appealed the dismissal in August 1989. Court documents show that Vance and two other circuit judges heard oral arguments in Miami on Aug. 29, but the case is still pending. The court keeps no transcripts of oral arguments and has no way of knowing whether Moody was present at the hearing, the court official said. Moody's attorney, Grafton Carlson of Fort Lauderdale, argued the case. Moody, 55, appealed over allegations made during the 1983 case in which he was charged with abandoning in the Gulf of Mexico three Georgia divers he had hired to photograph an underwater propulsion device he planned to market. Jurors were deadlocked, and the judge declared a mistrial. The state decided against retrying Moody. Vance was killed by a bomb sent to his Mountain Brook, Ala., home Dec. 16. Two days later, Savannah, Ga., lawyer Robert Robinson died after he opened a mail bomb sent to his office. Two other bombs were sent to targets in Atlanta and Jacksonville, Fla., but were intercepted by authorities. Investigators have searched the homes and businesses of three men, including Moody, in Alabama and Georgia. No arrests have been made in the case. Meanwhile, Moody's attorneys sought a gag order Thursday, which would restrict information about the case. The attorneys asked U.S. District Judge Richard C. Freeman to issue the gag order, to seal all documents in the case and to order the return of materials seized by agents who searched Moody's Clayton County home last week. The request met opposition from lawyers for several news organizations. Freeman said he needed more time to study documents filed in the case. He scheduled another hearing for Wednesday, and said that a portion of the hearing may be closed. Moody's lawyers, including the local president of the American Civil Liberties Union, argued that the intense publicity over the bombs case has hurt their client's reputation.

DOC.HEAD: Critics Criticize New Plan For China Takeover of Hong Kong
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New thruout to UPDATE with vote on plan, reaction. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Representatives of China and Hong Kong voted today to allow the British colony slightly more democracy after it returns to Chinese rule in 1997. The changes were announced Thursday by negotiators drafting a constitution for Chinese rule. The full committee of 51 representatives adopted the meaasures today in Beijing. The measure is to go to the National People's Congress, China's legislature, for approval at the end of next month. But the plan has been widely criticized as too conservative, and about 1,500 students chanting pro-democracy slogans and waving placards marched today to the Chinese diplomatic mission to protest. The agreements announced would increase the number of seats directly elected to the 1995-1999 legislatures from 18 to 20. There are 60 seats in legislature, which is chosen by the government and special interest groups. Since China's crackdown on last year's pro-democracy movement, Hong Kong and Britain have been pushing for faster and greater democratization than provided in the first draft of the constitution, known as the Basic Law. In London, Foreign Secretary Douglas Hurd said today that the agreement produced ``a substantially greater first step toward democracy in HK than was planned two years ago.'' ``We shall continue to press the case for a faster pace of democratization. There will be further evolution between now and 1997,'' Hurd told the House of Commons. ``He has caved in completely to China,'' responded Gerald Kaufman, the opposition Labor Party's spokesman on foreign affairs. ``Although he told the people of Hong Kong last month that Britain alone was responsible for governing Hong Kong until July 1997, his surrender to China on elections to the legislative council has in fact given China a decisive voice in what happens in Hong Kong not in 1997, but now.'' One Hong Kong representative, Dr. Raymond Wu, told reporters that the decisions represented only ``a little bit of improvement _ bits and pieces.'' China has pledged to allow the thriving British territory to retain its capitalist economy and lifestyle for 50 years. Britain agreed in 1984 to hand over its territory to China when its lease runs out in 1997.

DOC.HEAD: Officials of Western Nations Meet on Aid for Eastern Europe
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Inserts 7 grafs after 12th, `Officials said...' to UPDATE with aid requests. Pickup 14th pvs, `Their requests...'
DOC.TEXT: Officials from 24 Western nations gathered today to consider of litany of requests for financial help from five Eastern European countries trying to convert to free-market economies. The officials streamed into a building near the headquarters of the 12-nation European Community to consider the requests of Romania, Bulgaria, Czechoslovakia, East Germany and Yugoslavia. The new governments in those once solidly Communist countries want to be included in a program originally set up last summer to promote economic and political change in Poland and Hungary. Foreign ministers of the 24 Western nations taking part in the program have agreed in principle to offer assistance to the other countries to encourage their drives toward democracy and free-market economies. But it was unclear whether the lower-ranking officials meeting today would give the go-ahead to put together packages of aid for the others. Some had indicated before the meeting a final decision was unlikely and would probably be deferred to their foreign ministers, expected to meet later in the year, possibly in June. But others today appeared ready to act more quickly. ``You've got to maintain the momentum,'' said another official as he entered the conference. He demanded anonymity. The plan is one of several Western mechanisms aimed at restoring economic health to Eastern European economies languishing after decades of central planning under hard-line Communist rule. The aid programs are expected to amount to the largest campaign of regional assistance since the Marshall Plan rebuilt Western Europe after World War II. In July, President Bush and other key leaders of industrial nations put the European Community, a group of Western European nations, in charge of fashioning an economic aid package for Poland and Hungary. Since then, other emerging democracies in Eastern Europe have appealed for help. Officials said Bulgaria, Romania, East Germany, Czechoslovakia and Yugoslavia have submitted papers giving details of their reform efforts and outlining their economic needs. The appeals varied widely. Romania said the new government has been left with an economy in ``deep crisis.'' Czechoslovakia said, ``There is no unemployment in Czechoslovakia _ however, a considerable part of the labor force is tied up in inefficient operations.'' Yugoslavia said it would need $2 billion to rebuild its banking system and convert to a free-market economy. Several expressed concern about the effect of wrenching economic changes on their people. Bulgaria said an economic program ``has to be supplemented by a feasible and economically sustainable social program.'' East Germany said, however, it can fall back on its well-trained labor force, agricultural sector and technical base. ``Relying on its own performance and making use of the economic support being offered to it, (East Germany) has an opportunity to achieve economic reform without going through periods of acute social tension,'' it said. The nations are all trying to move their economies to the free-market models of the West. But some, such as Poland, are strapped with hefty foreign debts. Polish Prime Minister Tadeusz Mazowiecki has already asked the creditor nations would accept a moratorium of payments on their share of Poland's $39 billion foreign debt while he implements a radical economic plan to transform Poland's economy. Their requests are expected to be discussed at the meeting of the Group of 24, the name given to the Western nations participating in the program. But officials said they doubted whether any final decisions would be made on extending the aid program. Foreign ministers of the participating nations are likely to meet later in the year to settle the question. Under the program, about $6 billion has been granted or promised to Poland and Hungary in the coming years, according to officials. The aid ranges from emergency food shipments for Poland to export and investment credits for both countries. The Soviet Union has not been invited to submit a request for help. Nations attending the meeting include the European Community members: Britain, Ireland, Norway, Denmark, Belgium, the Netherlands, Luxembourg, Germany, France, Spain, Italy and Portugal. Also attending were Austria, Australia, Canada, Finland, Iceland, Japan, New Zealand, Norway, Sweden, Switzerland, Turkey and the United States.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Yanks Northrop TV Ads During Fraud Trial
DOC.TEXT: Television commercials featuring Chuck Yeager promoting Northrop Corp. as a conscientious defense contractor were ordered off the air by a federal judge presiding over the aviation company's fraud trial. Judge Pamela Ann Rymer said Thursday the commercials could bias potential jurors. The advertisements featuring the legendary test pilot have been running for several weeks. Jury selection begins Tuesday. ``In my judgment, the running of these ads at this time is a serious threat to the impartiality of the trial on which we are about to embark,'' the judge said. Northrop and two employees are charged with fraud in the AV-8B Harrier jet program. Northrop is accused of failing to test key parts the company built for the military jet. The judge's order bars the showing of the commercials in the Los Angeles media market until the end of the trial in her court and another in which Northrop is accused of fraud in the cruise missile program. The ruling applies only to the ``Hard Work'' series of ads in which Yeager vouches for Northrop and employees describe the firm as a hard-working, scrupulous and professional contractor dedicated to quality. Northrop attorney Brad Brian argued that the company had a ``very substantial First Amendment interest'' in using the commercials to battle bad publicity from the trials. Rymer recently was appointed to the U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals, but is hearing the case as a federal district judge.

DOC.HEAD: Former Presidents Give Views on Panama Invasion
DOC.TEXT: Former President Nixon says he understands why President Bush ordered the invasion of Panama, but believes that generally the United States should not act directly to depose foreign leaders of whom it disapproves. Nixon and former Presidents Reagan, Carter and Ford were asked by the Sunday newspaper supplement, USA Weekend, for their views on the invasion of Panama. ``I support the Bush administration,'' said Reagan, a Republican as is Bush. The desposed Panamanian leader, Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega, now facing drug charges in the United States, ``is where he belongs and the people of Panama are beginning to put the pieces back together,'' he said. Ford, another Republican, said, ``I applaud the president's strong action.'' Carter, a Democrat, said, ``I deplore the invasion and feel a great responsibility now for our nation to help repair the damage caused by U.S. economic embargo and our military action.'' However, he added, ``Perhaps the invasion can bring about real freedom, democracy and economic prosperity for Panama.'' Republican Nixon said, ``I understand why President Bush acted as he did.'' On the other hand, he said, ``When the United States decides by itself who is going to run a country, it runs the risk of ending up running the country itself.'' Nixon, Carter and Reagan replied in writing to questions submitted by the publication. Ford was interviewed by telephone. All four indicated they had no interest in returning to the presidency, and all said they believed there should not be a formal role in government for former presidents, such as a seat as senator-at-large as has been suggested occasionally. ``Our Constitution is clear on who is and who is not an official part of the government,'' said Reagan. Carter agreed that former presidents should have no formal role, but said they ``should be willing to serve in special cases when requested by the incumbent president.'' Similarly, Ford said, ``My experience has been that a sitting president does call upon a former president informally. And I have worked with President Carter, President Reagan and now President Bush when I've been asked to.'' Said Nixon: ``There is a great deal former presidents can contribute to thier country, but another bureaucracy should not be one of them.''

DOC.HEAD: Pulitzer Prize Winner Keyes Beech Dead at 76
DOC.TEXT: Keyes Beech, who won a Pulitzer Prize for his reporting on the Korean war, is dead of emphysema at 76. Beech, who died Thursday at Sibley Memorial Hospital in Washington, was a longtime international correspondent. He won the Pulitzer for his coverage of the Korean war in 1951 while serving as Far East correspondent for the old Chicago Daily News. Beech also was the first correspondent to climb to the top of Mount Suribachi on Iwo Jima during World War II. He was among the first group of correspondents to enter mainland China under Communist rule in 1957. Beech, who began as a copy boy in St. Petersburg, Fla., had a career that spanned five decades, including positions as a feature writer with the Akron Beacon Journal and Washington correspondent for The Honolulu Star-Bulletin. He also wrote several books including, ``The U.S. Marines on Iwo Jima,'' ``Uncommon Valor'' and ``Tokyo and Points East.'' Beech, a native of Pulaski, Tenn., retired as the Los Angeles Times' correspondent in Bangkok in 1983. He is survived by his wife, Yuko, of suburban Bethesda, Md.; a daughter and two sons.

DOC.HEAD: EPA Suggests $4.4 Billion in Modifications To Cut Grand Canyon Haze
DOC.TEXT: A federal agency has proposed that $4.4 billion worth of pollution-control equipment be installed at a northern Arizona power plant to cut emissions blamed for wintertime haze at the Grand Canyon. The Environmental Protection Agency's proposal has yet to be approved by the White House and its Office of Management and Budget and should not be considered definite, officials cautioned this week. ``It's just a proposal at this point. Proposals have been changed before,'' said Christine Shaver, an attorney with the National Park Service in Denver. David Stonefield, head of the EPA's Office of Air Quality Research in Research Triangle Park, N.C., said the EPA was proposing a 90 percent reduction in sulfur-dioxide emissions _ from 300 tons a day to 30 tons _ from the Navajo Generating Station's three 770-foot stacks. The EPA estimates that emissions from the coal-fired plant near Page fouls as many as 15 percent of the days at the canyon from November through March. It also says it is possible that the plant's emissions may cause haze during other seasons. The utilities that own the plant, led by the Salt River Project based in Phoenix, dispute the EPA's contention that the plant is responsible for haze at the canyon. Salt River officials and consultants have cited automobile pollution from the Los Angeles area as a more likely cause. John McNamara, a Salt River Project associate general manager, said he was not surprised by the EPA's proposal, but he said his utility was pleased that the EPA had agreed to consider Salt River's own $10 million study into whether the plant is causing the canyon haze. Results of that study are expected before a decision is made on the EPA proposal, possibly in October. The EPA estimated the cost of pollution-control equipment at $4.4 million, while Salt River has said it would cost $1.6 billion. A lawyer in Boulder, Colo., for the Environmental Defense Fund called the EPA proposal a ``very positive sign.'' ``It's significant in that they ask for a 90 percent reduction, which is everything we've asked for,'' said Robert Yuhnke, whose group filed a 1982 lawsuit that forced the EPA to check into the canyon haze.

DOC.HEAD: Report: West Germans Approved Weapon Sales to Saudi Arabia
DOC.TEXT: The West German government has approved the sale of Gepard anti-aircraft weapons to Saudi Arabia and deliveries of two submarines to Israel, a newspaper reported today. The independent Sueddeutsche Zeitung said the Krauss-Maffei company in Munich had applied for permission to deliver about 100 Gepard systems to Saudi Arabia. The national security council approved the sale at a recent meeting, the Munich-based newspaper reported. The Gepard systems are outfitted with 35mm cannons designed to shoot down low-flying aircraft. The systems are mounted on bodies of Leopard tanks. The newspaper said the security council also approved a request by the Deutschen Werft AG shipbuilding company in Kiel to sell two ``strategic'' submarines to Israel. The report did not describe the submarines further. The sale of submarines was approved despite misgivings on the part of West German Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher, the newspaper said. West Germany's main opposition Social Democratic Party has criticized the sales and accused the government of violating laws that ban arms exports to areas of conflict, such as the Middle East, according to the report. The newspaper quoted the oppostion party's parliament deputy, Norbert Gansel, as saying that Chancellor Helmut Kohl's government delivers weapons to war zones to support ``neutrality.'' ``On all sides weapons are being sold,'' the newspaper quoted Gansel as saying. Gansel, in a statement provided to The Associated Press today, confirmed the accuracy of the newspaper report and added: ``The pretended restrictive arms export policy of the Kohl-Genscher government has been completed with a sad chapter. From now on, all dams for arms exports have been broken open.'' Asked about the reported arms sales to Saudi Arabia, West German government spokesman Dieter Vogel declined to comment because of national security concerns.

DOC.HEAD: Regents Vote To Have Students Taught More About Minorities
DOC.TEXT: New York state's education policy-setting board voted today to change the way history is taught to include more about contributions by non-whites. The Board of Regents voted unanimously to appoint a team of scholars who will try to wipe out examples of bias from history books and classroom curricula. ``We have to understand better than we now do the diversity of the country,'' said state Education Commissioner Thomas Sobol. The action came seven months after a task force, appointed by Sobol and dominated by non-whites, released a report that said much of what school children learn in New York is based on ``hidden assumptions of white supremacy.'' The report, titled ``A Curriculum of Inclusion,'' suggested that many courses minimize the contributions of minorities and largely ignore the wrongs committed by whites against non-whites. The team of scholars, to be picked by Sobol, will study state curricula to determine how they can be improved. The regents decided to establish a separate and permanent advisory council to make sure all ethnic groups receive ``appropriate and accurate attention'' in classes and books. Some regents suggested the changes would be more beneficial to whites than blacks and other minorities. ``Many of our children who have successfully come through our system do not know each other and do not have a legitimate basis for developing respect for each other,'' said Adelaide Sanford, a former high school principal from New York City. Regent Walter Cooper said it was important for schools to incorporate the information about minorities into traditional textbooks, and not as separate units on non-white cultures. One regent, Edward Meyer, suggested putting off action for a month so it could be studied more. But Sobol, noting the controversy the report has generated in educational circles, said any delay would send the wrong signal. Some members of the policy-setting board, testy about the controversy generated by the report in recent months, said the state has been moving to include more minority contributions for 15 years. ``I think the teachers of this state are doing what we've been talking about here,'' said regent Laura Chodos. ``We just don't know about it.''

DOC.HEAD: Wrongful Death Lawsuit Filed Against Winemaking Gallos
DOC.TEXT: The family of a woman killed in an automobile accident involving members of the winemaking Gallo family has filed a wrongful death suit. The lawsuit was filed in Santa Clara County Superior Court after a California Highway Patrol investigation failed to assign fault in the accident that killed Sharon Kauk, 27, of San Jose. Kauk was killed and her husband and infant son injured Jan. 2 when their car collided on Pacheco Pass with a car driven by Julio Gallo's wife, Aileen. Both Julio Gallo, 79, and Mrs. Gallo, 76, were hospitalized with injuries suffered in the crash. Witnesses gave conflicting reports of the accident. Some told the Highway Patrol the Gallos' car veered across a double yellow line and struck the Kauks' car. But witnesses who came forward about a week after the accident denied that version. The lawsuit filed on behalf of Kauk's husband, Timothy, and son, Matthew, does not specify damages, according to the Kauks' lawyer, Vincent Ruocco. He said the Gallos have not offered to pay any of their medical bills. Gallo and his brother, Ernest, run the Modesto-based Gallo Winery which controls 28 percent of the U.S. wine market and records more than $1 billion in annual sales.

DOC.HEAD: Bulgaria to End Restrictions on Private Farming
DOC.TEXT: The government has agreed to end restrictions on private farming by lifting curbs on how much land individuals can till, the state BTA news agency reported today. A government decree, slated for publication later in the day ``will encourage free enterprise in agriculture,'' BTA said, reporting on a Cabinet meeting Thursday. ``Restrictions on the size of land plots available for cultivation by private farmers will be lifted.'' Farmers had been allowed private ownership of only small strips of land, primarily meant to fulfill their own needs and that of their families. BTA did not indicate whether the farmers would now be free to buy as much land as they wanted or whether they would have to lease additional acreage for private use. The decision was among the efforts by the moderately reformist Communist government to defuse pressure from the opposition for the introduction of market mechanisms into the moribund economy. Complicating the generally stagnant economic picture in recent months has been an unprecedented wave of strikes _ generally for better wages _ that has resulted in the loss of hundreds of thousands of man-hours of production. Bulgaria also is wrestling with a gross foreign debt of more than $10 billion _ one of the highest per capita in the Soviet bloc. In an apparent bid to strengthen its credit-worthiness, the government also decided to apply for membership in the International Monetary Fund and the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development, BTA reported.

DOC.HEAD: Telltale Sex Tape Found Inside Purloined VCR, Burglar Victim Jailed
DOC.TEXT: A shocked buyer of a stolen VCR found it contained a homemade child sex tape, recognized the girl and gave the tape to her mother, leading to a neighbor being jailed on molestation charges. Ward Rafay, 28, was being held pending a March 1 hearing on nine counts of child molestation and one of possessing a kilogram of marijuana for sale. He had not made his $50,000 bail and remained in jail today, said Los Angeles County Sheriff's Deputy Bill Linnemeyer. Rafay allegedly owned the sex tape found in a stolen videocassette recorder, Deputy District Attorney Dean Shotwell said Thursday. Two weeks ago, Rafay reported a burglar stole a VCR from his Downey apartment about 10 miles southeast of downtown Los Angeles. The unidentified thief then sold the VCR and telltale tape, Shotwell said. Rafay was arrested last weekend after the mother contacted police. ``The mother of the victim notified us Saturday that she had a tape depicting immoral acts with her children,'' said Downey police detective Capt. Bob Williams, who divulged little else. ``We don't want to hamper the investigation. We have a possibility of possibly three other victims,'' Williams said. If convicted of all charges, Rafay faces up to 25 years in state prison, Shotwell said. The two-hour tape shows a man discussing sex with a child, winning her cooperation and engaging in sexual acts with her, according to police reports. The mother wasn't identified, but Shotwell confirmed she lives with her daughter in the same building as Rafay.

DOC.HEAD: American Experiment to Return From Soviet Space Station
DOC.TEXT: The first American experiment aboard the Soviet space station Mir will return to Earth on a Soviet Soyuz spacecraft Monday, the company that created the experiment said Friday. Payload Systems Inc. of Cambridge, Mass., said the protein crystal growth will have spent 61 days in orbit, the longest period in weightlessness for a such an experiment. The experiment was launched on a Soviet spacecraft Dec. 20 after Payload Systems became the first U.S. company authorized by the Department of Commerce to fly experiments aboard the Mir. The company has contracted with the Soviets to fly six more experiments over a four-year period. Protein crystal experiments have been flown a number of times on the U.S. space shuttle, but those flights have lasted only seven to 10 days. Extended exposure to weightlessness is believed to be important in the growth of protein crystals. Experts use protein crystals to understand the fundamental structure of biological proteins. Once the crystal pattern is analyzed, companies can make pharmaceuticals that will have specific effects. Such ``designer drugs'' are believed to be important in the future treatment of many diseases. The company said the experiment should arrive in the United States on Wednesday and the protein crystals will be removed Thursday at Brandeis University. The crystals will be analyzed at the Brookhaven National Laboratory next month.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
Precede WEST BERLIN
Military Defense Plan for United Germany Would Include NATO
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New throughout to UPDATE with West Germans proposing NATO military strategy for united Germany, state government system. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: West German officials today unveiled plans for a military defense strategy for a united Germany that would include NATO membership, a move opposed by the Soviet Union. The government also announced plans for a 16-state government that would encompass West and East Germany. West German Defense Minister Gerhard Stoltenberg met with reporters today to discuss a common security concept that he said was being drafted by his ministry. ``Defense obligations are indivisible and cannot be weakened for a whole Germany,'' Stoltenberg said, noting that military integration would be an important initial step in a single German state. He said that a cornerstone of the joint force would be its membership in the North Atlantic Treaty Organization. The Soviet Union has insisted a united Germany be neutral. Despite Stoltenberg's proposal, the military alignment of a united Germany is to be the subject of reunification talks this year among the German states, Soviets, the United States, Britain and France. Washington wants at least the West German portion to remain in NATO. East Germany is a key component of the Soviet-led Warsaw Pact. Whether Germany should be in NATO or neutral is likely to become an issue in the West German national elections in December. Stoltenberg said there likely would be a transition phase during which the East and West German armies would be merged. ``But we are not going to have two different armed forces in a united Germany for long,'' Stoltenberg said. There was no immediate comment from the Soviets or opposition leaders. The governors of West Germany's 11 states met today to discuss how a united Germany would be administered. In a rare show of unity among the state leaders split roughly equally between supporters of Chancellor Helmut Kohl and the opposition Social Democrats, the governors voted unanimously to pursue a 16-state federal structure once the Germanys are united. They proposed that the East German territory be divided into five states along the borders of the traditional regions, whose names in German are Brandenburg, Mecklenburg, Sachsen, Sachsen-Anhalt and Thueringen. Their promotion of a strong federal system where individual states enjoy broad autonomy and influence over the central government reflects the governors' interest in setting up a united Germany in the image of the West German and U.S. federal models. The conservative governor of Baden-Wuerttemberg state, Lothar Spaeth, appealed to East Germans to save years of legislative haggling by simply adopting West German laws and regulations. He said a wholesale borrowing of the legislation would speed monetary union and economic reform. Kohl's conservative Christian Democrats and the left-leaning Social Democrats have been wrapping themselves in the reunification issue in anticipation of the coming elections. During a raucous parliament session on Thursday, Kohl was accused of trying to take credit for the reunification developments, which have been proceeding at a break-neck pace. Some officials say one Germany could be formed this year. But the race to reunify has some European neighbors and victims of the Nazi regime worried about the rise of a powerful Germany that could again threaten peace and security. The reunification issue caught fire last year, after the revolts against hard-line Communist regimes swept into East Germany, toppling the government but creating a political and economic void.

DOC.HEAD: Woman Who Fought Amputation Dies Following Surgery.
DOC.TEXT: A woman who refused to have a gangrenous leg removed but changed her mind after a court battle died Friday of complications related to the operation. Doctors at Poriah Hospital in Tiberias said 84-year-old Ruth Trabelsi died of respiratory complications from the surgery, which was performed Feb. 9, Israel radio reported. A granddaughter, Sara Trabelsi, said the woman had been unconscious toward the end of the week and that some of her 258 children, grandchildren and great-grandchildren were at her bedside when she died. ``She so much wanted to die with her leg.... Maybe she lost her will to live without it,'' she told The Associated Press. Mrs. Trabelsi's leg became infected last month as a result of circulatory problems and blood-clotting, but she refused to consent to the amputation because she wanted ``to enter the Garden of Eden on both feet.'' The state took Mrs. Trabelsi to court when doctors said she would probably die without the surgery, but the case was dropped when a geriatric specialist testified that Mrs. Trabelsi understood the possible consequences of her decision. Mrs. Trabelsi finally consented to the operation at the urging of Mordechai Eliahu, one of Israel's leading rabbis. Her granddaughter said that Mrs. Trabelsi would be buried Friday with the amputated limb in accordance with Jewish tradition. ``Grandma Ruth will be buried with her amputated leg ... so that she can fulfill her wish to enter the Garden of Eden on both feet,'' she said. Israel radio Friday quoted hospital doctors as saying the delay in the operation caused by the court case had not helped Mrs. Trabelsi's condition and that she had been attached to a respirator since the surgery.

DOC.HEAD: Avalanche Threat Leads to Traffic Jams at Border
DOC.TEXT: Traffic was backed up for miles at the main border crossing between Italy and Austria on Friday after an avalanche threat led authorities to close other border points. Police said the traffic jam on the Italian side of the Brenner pass was six miles long. Other border points were closed Thursday after Italian authorities warned of possible avalanches because of heavy snow. About six feet of snow fell in the highest areas of the Dolomite mountains and in the Western Alpine regions this week. Because of rising temperatures, the ground now is not frozen hard enough to support the new snow, which ended a long dry spell. Helicopters took food and medicine to about 300 tourists blocked by snow and strong winds in Val Senales, northwest of Bolzano in the South Tyrol region. At least three people have died in neighboring France this week in avalanches.

DOC.HEAD: Alleged Informer Hacked to Death WHile Hundreds Watch
DOC.TEXT: Hundreds of people gathered at a village square in the West Bank to watch Palestinian militants hack to death an Arab man who admitted being an informer for Israel, Arab reporters said Friday. The body of the victim, Mohammed Khatatbeh, was left in the central square in the village of Beit Furik, and his family was not allowed to bury him in the town, the reporters said, speaking on condition of anonymity. At least 185 Palestinians have been killed by their brethren since the uprising against Israeli rule of the West Bank and Gaza Strip began in December 1987. Like Khatatbeh, most were accused of cooperating with Israeli authorities. According to the Arab reporters, Khatatbeh was kidnapped Tuesday from his Beit Furik home by six Palestinians armed with pistols and dressed in camouflage uniforms. The following day, they took him to the village mosque where he confessed over a loudspeaker that he had informed on fellow Palestinians since 1968 and once led three PLO men into an army ambush. Israeli officials say Palestinian activists often use torture and violent interrogations to force such confessions from suspected collaborators. The militants then asked what should be done with Khatatbeh, and hundreds of villagers poured into the streets and chanted ``Kill him! Kill him!'' Khatatbeh was hacked to death with axes and knives in the square late Thursday as about 250 villagers looked on, the reporters said. The army command confirmed that a body was found in Beit Furik and said the case was being investigated. In addition to the alleged collaborators, another 656 Palestinians have been killed by Israeli soldiers or civilians in the uprising, and 43 Israelis have died. Jerusalem Mayor Teddy Kollek said Friday that Israel should give up the occupied territories and concentrate on absorbing the hundreds of thousands of Soviet Jews expected to immigrate to Israel. Kollek, Jerusalem's mayor for the last 25 years, said Israel will need so many human and material resources to handle the immigration flow ``that I maintain it is impossible to continue at the same time to occupy the West Bank and Gaza.'' Kollek's remarks were in an essay distributed by his office in reply to Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir's comment Jan. 15 suggesting that Israel needed to keep the occupied lands to settle some 300,000 Soviet Jews expected to arrive in the next three years. Shamir's statement drew angry Arab responses as well as condemnations from the Soviet Union and United States, which consider settlement of the occupied lands an obstacle to peace. Shamir has since reiterated that there was no government policy of settling immigrants in the occupied lands. Also Friday, the Foreign Ministry said European sanctions against Israel for its handling of the Palestinian uprising were counterproductive and would discourage peace efforts. ``Israel flatly rejects the attempt by the Commission of the European Community and the European Parliament to suspend certain activities with Israel,'' the ministry said in a statement. ``These attempts discourage dialogue and work against peace.'' A week ago, the European Commission indefinitely postponed two scheduled European-Israeli seminars, one on economic cooperation and the other on science. Earlier, the 518-member European Parliament voted in mid-January to recommend freezing scientific cooperation with Israel. The parliament and the commission are policy-making bodies of the European Economic Community.

DOC.HEAD: Police Say 10 Killed in Bus and Train Collision
DOC.TEXT: Ten people died when an overcrowded bus collided with a train and then plowed into a sidewalk cafe, police said Friday. Police quoted by Radio Nigeria said the accident occurred Thursday during the morning rush hour in Lagos. Most of the 33 people injured in the accident were treated at hospitals and released. A few remained under treatment Friday at a general hospital and an orthopedic center, the radio reported.

DOC.HEAD: Too Many Pesticides Used in Tulip Growing
DOC.TEXT: Tulip growers are flooding local waterways in this flower-growing region with pesticides, including such banned substances as DDT, to protect their crops, water officials said Friday. ``All kinds of pesticides were found in surface waters in the bulb growing area, and their levels were far above the norms in most cases,'' said Hans van der Hoek, a spokesman for the local water management board. ``In samples, we've even found long-banned substances such as DDT, aldrin, and dieldrin,'' Van der Hoek told The Associated Press. All three are highly toxic substances, but Van der Hoek said it had not been determined if the pesticide levels in the water were a threat to public health. One-fifth of the Netherlands' 39,500-acre bulb-growing area lies just north of this western Dutch city. The remainder is spread over the northwestern and central Netherlands. Van der Hoek said that the water management board had launched a joint study with the bulb growers on how to tackle the problem. A spokesman for the Dutch Agriculture Ministry said that ``we're aware of the problem and working hard to get rid of it.''

DOC.HEAD: ANC to Send Delegation to Meet De Klerk
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 15 grafs to UPDATE with Sisulu to lead ANC delegation, Mandela to leave to Zambia, other details. Pickup 13th, `The ANC, which...'
DOC.TEXT: In a major breakthrough, the exiled leadership of the African National Congress said today it would send a delegation to South Africa for talks with President F.W. de Klerk. The meeting would be the first ever between the guerrilla movement's exiled leaders and a South African head of state. The talks would focus on removing obstacles to formal negotiations. Both sides say they want to work out a new constitution that would include the black majority. Alfred Nzo, secretary-general of the ANC, also said the guerrilla movement was prepared to negotiate ``a suspension of hostilities'' once de Klerk meets the group's remaining conditions for formal talks. The ANC has said the white-led government must release all political prisioners, lift the state of emergency and allow exiles to return before formal negotiations begin. De Klerk has said he plans to take these steps, but has not said when. There was no immediate comment on today's ANC statement from de Klerk's office in South Africa. ANC leader Nelson Mandela, released from prison Feb. 11 after 27 years in prison, is to visit the ANC's exile headquarters in Lusaka next week, probably on Tuesday. It was not clear whether the delegation of ANC exiles would go to South Africa before or after the Mandela visit. Nzo said that Walter Sisulu, released in October after more than 25 years in prison, would lead the effort to rebuild the ANC in South Africa. ``It is important immediately to begin the work of re-establishing the ANC within the country,'' Nzo said, adding that the organization's estimated 15,000 exiles would soon begin to return on a large scale. Nzo said the ANC ``resolved to meet Mr. de Klerk as soon as possible to discuss with him the need to address these issues so that a climate conducive to negotiations is created.'' The guerrilla movement said the delegation would include exiled members as well as leaders inside South Africa. That could include Mandela and Sisulu, although Nzo did not specify anyone by name. The ANC, the main black group fighting white rule in South Africa, has been waging a bombing and sabotage campaign since 1961. However, the armed struggle has been largely dormant in the past year and poses no serious threat to the white-led government. The announcement followed three days of meetings to evaluate recent reforms announced Feb. 2 by de Klerk, such as legalizing more than 60 opposition groups, including the ANC, the release of Mandela, the easing of press restrictions, and a moratorium on executions. Nzo said the ANC views these reforms ``in a positive light.'' The ANC, which was banned for 30 years, also said it would open offices in South Africa. De Klerk and his predecessor, P.W. Botha, met with Mandela while he was in prison. But no South African leader has met with any ANC leaders as free men. Mandela, in an interview today, said he would be willing to meet with de Klerk to discuss the prospect of negotiations. ``I have found him to be a man of integrity with whom I can do business,'' Mandela said. De Klerk wants to negotiate a new constitution that will include the 28 million black majority in the national government. But he opposes a one-man, one-vote system and outright black majority rule, the basic demand of all leading anti-apartheid groups, including the ANC. He envisions some mechanism that will give whites veto power on major policy decisions.

DOC.HEAD: First Lady Cheerful After Minor Surgery, But Smiling's a Pain
DOC.TEXT: Barbara Bush kept an active schedule Friday, saying she felt great following minor skin-cancer surgery that left her with a slightly swollen lip and a row of stitches below her nose. The first lady was cheerful and energetic as she toured an interior decorating exhibit benefitting the Washinton Home, a health care and hospice program with which she has long been associated. Smiling, but not broadly, she replied ``great'' when asked how she felt following the outpatient operation Wednesday to remove a small basal cell cancer on her upper lip. Her press secretary, Anna Perez, said Mrs. Bush still has some soreness when she smiles. On Thursday, she told children at a New York day-care center, ``Don't make me laugh.'' Accompanied by daughter-in-law Margaret Bush, Mrs. Bush met several individuals who had rooms of their homes duplicated in the exhibit, titled ``Entertaining Alfresco.'' Mrs. Bush's lip was almost imperceptibly swollen. The dozen stitches were not visible from a few feet away. The first lady attended a private luncheon for the exhibit before travelling to Kennebunkport, Maine, to spend a long weekend with President Bush at their seaside vacation home. On Thursday, Mrs. Bush said the operation had been performed to remove ``a small cancer that you get because you were stupid and sat in the sun all your life.'' Basal cell carcinomas are common skin cancers that occur most often on the face or areas of skin exposed to the sun.

DOC.HEAD: Architects Say Earthquake-Damaged Freeway Should Go
DOC.TEXT: An architects' organization has recommended tearing down the earthquake-damaged Embarcadero Freeway in downtown San Francisco and replacing it with a waterfront boulevard. ``We believe a surface roadway emerges as the better alternative,'' said Clark Manus, chairman of the urban design committee of San Francisco's chapter of the American Institute of Architects. The chapter released a report Thursday which concluded that tearing down the 1.5-mile elevated freeway would be safer, cheaper, faster and more compatible with other improvements in the area than rebuilding it. Alex Bonutti, president of the AIA San Francisco chapter, called demolition ``a practical solution which minimizes further disruption to the city.'' Before the Oct. 17 earthquake, the freeway carried 60,000 cars a day.

DOC.HEAD: Bomb in University Injures 40 Students
DOC.TEXT: A firebomb ripped through a crowded university lecture hall Friday and injured 40 students, including 13 who suffered severe burns, officials said. It was the third such bomb attack in just over a year at universities in Brussels. No one has claimed responsibility for any of the attacks. The bomb went off at 9 a.m. in a Louvain University auditorium packed with about 100 students attending a pharmacy class, said a police official who asked not to be named. The explosive device was hidden in a briefcase. It included fluid soap, which has an effect like napalm when it is part of a bomb, the official said. A similar bomb was used in a Dec 1, 1989 bomb attack at Brussels University across town. ``There was a sudden blast, a big fire and part of the roof came crashing down,'' said Paul Tulkens, who was in the class Friday. Some students ran out with hair and clothes on fire. Evidence of a firebomb was found in the hall, officials said. University spokesman Paul Macq said the university had not received any threats or warnings.

DOC.HEAD: Schlesinger Library Plans Oral History Project on NOW, Betty Friedan
DOC.TEXT: The National Organization for Women was born in a hotel room in 1965, its name scribbled on a napkin no one saved. Loss of any other details about the beginning of NOW would hinder future historians seeking to chart the start of the modern battle for women's equality. To preserve the stories of the women who spearheaded the modern women's movement, Patricia King is coordinating an oral history project of NOW and founder Betty Friedan. The $100,000 project at the Schlesinger Library of women's history at Radcliffe College is being underwritten largely by Mary Jean Tully, a former president of the NOW Legal Defense and Education Fund. ``We were creating a revolution, a revolution that's changed ... the way people think about women, the way they think about men and the way they think about each other. It also changed the way women think about themselves, their rights as human beings,'' Tully said from Juno, Fla., where she was vacationing. ``I want my granddaughter to be able to study these things. I want books to be written about it. It's affected everyone's life.'' There is little solid documentation of the early years of NOW. ``We were using corporate hotel rooms and Xeroxes, lots of Xeroxes, but there was very, very little written down. We thought we were changing the world, and nobody was taking notes,'' said Tully. ``The only way we can get any documentation is the memories of those of us who were there.'' Tully is 64. Friedan is 69. Some of NOW's earliest movers and shakers are now in their 70s. The youngest are reaching 50. The oral history project is expected to take three years and include interviews with about 40 people present at the early founding and establishment of NOW. It will also contain interviews with associates of Friedan before and after she wrote ``The Feminine Mystique,'' the 1963 analysis of women in American society. An oral history of NOW also will show the continuity of women's history and that the movement was much more than one woman, said Susan Ware, a historian of 20th-century U.S. and women's history at New York University. Ware said she hopes to find in the first-person accounts of NOW's story a way to ``trace the developing feminist agenda and the way in which issues like economics and the ERA, the whole controversy over abortion, how those kinds of issues began to develop, whether they were divisive, how they were mobilized.'' The voices of past efforts will have a message for the present and the future as well, said Ware. ``Anytime you study a feminist organization, it forces you to look again at all the problems women face in our society,'' Ware said. ``When you study it, you find out how much has changed and how much remains.'' Some say the women's movement grew out of the civil rights movement. Others insist it was really born in the last century with the effort that culminated in women's suffrage. King, director of the Schlesinger Library, points out that other women's groups preceded NOW. But it was NOW that galvanized feminists, moved into the grass roots, learned how to use the media and continues to thrive as a political voice for women.

DOC.HEAD: Floods Recede; Two More Bodies Found
DOC.TEXT: At least three people drowned in two days of flooding in southern West Germany, officials said Friday. The floods, which stopped barge and ship traffic on the Rhine and Neckar rivers in Baden-Wuerttemberg state, were brought on by heavy rains and snow in Switzerland, France and West Germany on Wednesday and Thursday. Water from melting snow and rain poured down from steep hills in the Black Forest region and flooded scores of basements, streets and homes in dozens of towns in a wide area around Stuttgart. Officials raised the known death toll from the flooding to three after finding a wrecked car Friday and two drowned passengers in the Gutach river near the town of Triberg. Police said witnesses spotted the car as it was swept downstream the day before. The other death also occurred Thursday when a 41-year-old woman in the town of Aalen fell into a flooded creek and drowned while trying to retrieve her umbrella blown away by a gust of wind. Police said waters had peaked and conditions stabilized in most of the hardest-hit areas of the Black Forest region by Friday afternoon.

DOC.HEAD: Shoe Sorter Finds $3,000 Cash Socked Away in Shoe
DOC.TEXT: A Goodwill Industries worker accustomed to finding change in donated shoes ran across one shoe with a bit more _ $3,000. ``I took one look at that and I said, `Oh, oh, oh,''' said Fred Kuhrt, who has worked in a Goodwill program for the disabled for 20 years. The $20 and $50 bills were in several bank envelopes marked with the name Mrs. Henry Konarske and an address. Henry Konarske, who is recuperating from a recent hernia operation, answered the telephone call from Goodwill employees. He said his wife, Martha, died recently, and he had donated some of her belongings. Then the Goodwill employees told the 90-year-old retired postal worker about the cash. ``I didn't know what to say,'' Konarske said. ``It was a surprise to me, I didn't know anything about it. Until she got sick about two years ago, she took care of all the bills.'' Konarske said he and his niece have found $7,000 in dressers and shoe boxes around the house since his wife's death. All of the money has been deposited in a bank.

DOC.HEAD: Weather Stays Wild in Much of U.S.
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 16 grafs to UPDATE with drowning, tornado confirmed in Ga., quotes on tornado and flooding, picking up 14th graf pvs, `Schools were....'
DOC.TEXT: Severe thunderstorms in the South spawned tornadoes and caused flooding that forced hundreds to evacuate today, while thousands still had no power in the Midwest and Northeast after snow and ice storms pulled down power lines. Flooding after as much as 9 inches of rain closed schools today in parts of Georgia, Alabama, Kentucky and North Carolina. One man apparently drowned in a high North Carolina river today. Traffic accidents on slippery roads have killed at least 11 people since Wednesday _ four each in Kansas and Minnesota, two in Michigan and one in Missouri. Ice also was blamed for a 20-car crash in Arizona; nobody was injured. A section of Interstate 87 was closed in both directions north of Albany, N.Y., today after four trucks collided. Snow and ice on runways and ice on wings closed airports in Illinois, Oklahoma, Connecticut, New York and Wisconsin. Snow and slippery roads closed schools Thursday in parts of 13 states from the Plains to the Northeast, and some remained closed today. More snow was expected to move through the Pacific Northwest and Great Lakes today, while snow changing to freezing rain threatened more power outages in northern New England. Accumulations Thursday reached 8 inches in parts of Wisconsin and Michigan and 7 inches in Vermont. Craig, Colo., got 24 inches. An apparent tornado struck rural central Alabama today, tearing apart a fire department building in Enterprise and destroying several mobile homes at Cooper, Chilton County sheriff's officers said. Frank and Judy Higginbotham were in their mobile home with their 9-year-old daughter when lights began flashing and everything started shaking about 7 a.m. ``All of a sudden the roof went one way and the floor went the other way. I cradled my daughter to my chest and we were blown through the wall into another room,'' Higginbotham said. Alabama's Shelby County received more than 9 inches in less than 24 hours and 30 people evacuated from two trailer parks that were under 6 to 8 feet of water had to be moved twice. ``We had them in an armory, but the water got so high there we moved to them to the Baptist and Methodist churches in Pelham,'' said Bill Klein of the Alabama Emergency Management Agency. It was the third straight week of treacherous weather for Alabama, and Gov. Guy Hunt on Thursday requested a federal disaster declaration to aid weather victims. In Georgia, a tornado destroyed 15 homes and injured 10 people in Carrollton today, the National Weather Service confirmed. And at least 300 people were evacuated today from Trion after as much as 9 inches of rain fell. Authorities could not determine if a dam on the Chattooga River at Trion had burst because ``it's 10 feet under water and the currents are so fast going across it that they can't see the dam,'' said Chattooga County sheriff's deputy Tammy Owings. Western North Carolina got up to 6 inches of rain today and the body of a trout farmer who apparently was swept away from his hatchery was found downstream on the French Broad River, police said. Residents of several low-lying areas were evacuated. Schools were closed in four Kentucky counties today because of high water on roads and 15 to 20 people were evacuated, authorities said. A tornado that wrecked three mobile homes in Louisiana injured five people, while another twister Thursday destroyed a home and damaged about 10 others in Copiah County, Miss., but caused no injuries. ``We tried to get out to a ditch near the house, but we couldn't because it was too bad. The trees across the road were splitting and blowing away. We just caught each other's hands and prayed. We just praise the Lord we weren't hurt,'' said witness Ruth Sojourner of Crystal Springs. Flash flooding along a creek in Mendenhall, Miss., forced 250 to 400 people to flee their homes. ``It rose about 2 feet in about seven minutes,'' said Brad McLendon, a Mendenhall police dispatcher. The National Weather Service also reported tornado sightings Thursday in Alabama and Kansas and hail the size of baseballs in Jackson, Miss. Schools were closed Thursday in parts of Washington state, Arizona, Wisconsin, Michigan, Indiana, Iowa, New York, Ohio, Pennsylvania, New Hampshire, Kansas, Missouri and Oregon. Ice and snow snarled traffic and knocked out electricity to more than 146,000 customers Thursday in northern Ohio, although most service was restored Thursday. At least 42,000 customers lost power in Illinois and 37,000 remained blacked out today. Outages also were reported in Indiana and Pennsylvania. Some 36,000 customers were without electricity today in Connecticut after snow and ice pulled down power lines, and Bradley International Airport outside Hartford was closed for seven hours during the night. In New York state, at least 32,000 customers had no power today in the Buffalo area, utility officials said. Mail delivery was canceled in Champaign, Ill. Gov. James R. Thompson declared Champaign County a state disaster area. Rain and freezing drizzle swept across much of northern and central Illinois today, hampering utility crews sent in from southern Illinois, Indianapolis and St. Louis to help restore power. An ice storm in Erie, Pa., pulled down power lines and tree limbs, causing fires and closing schools. All five TV stations in the city were knocked off the air and two of them were evacuated for fear their transmission towers would collapse under the weight of the ice.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Briefs Cabinet on Drug Summit
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Inserts 3 grafs on U.N. drug session after 9th graf, `I'll give'
DOC.TEXT: President Bush met with his Cabinet today to review the the ``ice-breaking'' drug summit in Colombia and to discuss the next steps in the international battle against narcotics. Bush waved off reporters' questions at the outset of the Cabinet meeting, saying, ``We've got a lot of business to do.'' The president laughed when asked if he was still upset with reporters over stories that suggested he has sometimes misled the media. He said Thursday that such reports might lead him to cut back on news conferences _ but then he held two of them. ``I'm going to get upset if you don't get the hell out of here,'' Bush said kiddingly as reporters were escorted from the Cabinet Room. Bush was flying to Kennebunkport, Maine, later today for a three-day holiday weekend at his oceanfront home. He returned to the White House late Thursday night from what he called the ``ice-breaking meeting'' in Cartagena that will lead to more ambitious international efforts to control drugs. ``We, in fact, created the first anti-drug cartel,'' Bush declared after he and the presidents of Colombia, Bolivia and Peru signed a communique vowing closer coordination in the war on drugs. And while the ``Document of Cartagena'' broke no major new ground in specifics, Bush hailed the session as ``having forged an unprecedented alliance against the drug trade.'' The president said he hopes to enlist U.S. allies in Europe and elsewhere in the drug fight, and that an international effort against drug trafficking will be high on the agenda at the July economic summit of major industrial democracies in Houston. ``I'll give a full report'' to U.S. allies ``on this ice-breaking meeting here,'' he said. The United Nations will hold a special session on narcotics controls next Tuesday through Friday. Secretary of State James A. Baker III will head the U.S. delegation and speak on Tuesday afternoon. ``The U.S. is hopeful that the special session will result in a stronger, more balanced multilateral role for the United Nations in drug control,'' Richard Boucher, a State Department spokesman, said today. Beyond that, Boucher said the United States hoped the United Nations will concentrate also in the future on ways to reduce demands for narcotics and supplies of illicit drugs, as well as suppression of drug traffic and improved treatment and rehabilitation. The communique, which aides said was written before Thursday's session, calls for a ``world conference against illicit drug trafficking'' in 1991 and a ``high level'' Latin American followup in six months. It also commits the Bush administration to provide economic aid to help the three Andean nations wage the drug battle and help persuade their farmers to switch to legal crops. It calls for tougher enforcement of drug laws, better exchanges of information and increased restrictions on the movement of firearms. And, it asserts that the drug problem is one equally troubling to drug-producing nations and drug-consuming ones. Bush's journey to Colombia came off without incident amid intensive precautions for his safety. Because of security concerns over the safety of the airport at Cartagena, Bush flew into and took off from the more secluded airport in Barranquilla, about 60 miles away. He flew back and forth between Barranquilla and Cartagena by helicopter. But Bush shrugged off any concern about his own safety. Asked in Barranquilla if he was surprised there was no violence to protest his visit, Bush said ``I am not surprised,'' and he complimented Colombian and U.S. Secret Service security details for doing a good job. Still, William Bennett, the U.S. drug control policy director, told reporters on the return flight aboard Air Force One, ``A lot of people told him not to go.'' ``It was risky, but itwasn't foolhardy _ and this is what leadership is about,'' Bennett added. The communique spelled out that military force could be used to bolster police activity against drug activity _ but only by each nation within its own territorial limits. That appeared to rule out any Andean role for the U.S. military, such as stationing warships off the coast of Colombia. Bush said he didn't raise the idea of using U.S. ships to establish a ``radar net'' task force to track cocaine-carrying aircraft. He said, however, that he reasserted ``my intention to interdict narcotics coming into this country,'' including action on the high seas.
