Colombian President Virgilio Barco told a Cartagena news conference after the drug summit that a U.S. naval presence close to the Colombian coast was ``not necessary. Colombian territorial waters are being controlled by us.'' Bush vowed to work to help open U.S. markets to more Andean nation products and to seek to ease current trade disputes between Colombia and the United States over coffee and cut flower pricing. A key consensus, Bush said, was agreement that growing coca ``for the international drug market is immoral and wrong,'' no matter how lucrative to Andean farmers. Bush has proposed a $2.2 billion, five-year plan for aiding Andean nations wage the drug battle. On the return flight to Washington, a parade of administration officials visited the press section of Air Force One to declare the session a success. ``This is a real sea-change in the international debate about drugs,'' said Assistant Secretary of State Bernard Aaronson. Bennett declared ``this day could be the day these things came to maturity'' in the drug battle. Secretary of State James A. Baker III also trumpeted the outcome of the conference. Earlier Thursday, Bush displayed some testiness in a conversation with reporters, complaining that some recent news stories had made him sound deceptive and secretive. He said he might hold fewer news conferences so he wouldn't ``be burned.'' He referred to stories noting that on Monday, he told a news conference he did not think it was time for a four-power conference on German reunification; on Tuesday, an agreement was announced calling for just such a conference. Bush said he didn't know about the deal at the time of his news conference.

DOC.HEAD: Red Cross Visits Noriega in Jail
DOC.TEXT: Red Cross officials today talked with Manuel Noriega in federal prison, a visit allowed by the United States under its agreement to treat the deposed Panamanian leader as a prisoner of war. All details of the visit are kept strictly confidential, said International Committee of the Red Cross spokeswoman Ann Stingle in Washington. Noriega is housed in a special cell at the federal Metropolitan Correctional Center south of Miami. A team consisting of a doctor and a Red Cross delegate visited the prison today to talk to Noriega and prison officials to ensure Geneva Convention regulations are observed. ``The United States government has granted the necessary facilities to carry out their work,'' said Jean-Marc Bornet, the chief delegate for Latin America from the International Committee, a Geneva-based organization concerned with prisoners' rights. After examining a prison, Red Cross officials generally conduct a private interview with the prisoner. They ask only about the conditions of detention, Bornet said, including subjects such as food, exercise, family contact and medical treatment. Charles Davis, spokesman for the federal prison, confirmed the Red Cross visit but said he could not release any information on the delegates' activities. After the visit, the team will make a report about Noriega's conditions at the prison, said Bornet, and that will be sent to the governments involved. Bornet said Noriega's attorneys have contacted the agency about the Geneva Convention, but that the visit was routine under an agreement the Red Cross reached with the U.S. government immediately after the Dec. 20 invasion of Panama. The Red Cross also is visiting several other Panamanian prisoners in the United States, including Noriega's co-defendant and jailmate, Luis del Cid, allegedly once a top aide to the deposed leader. Noriega's defense team had demanded he be treated as a POW, saying U.S. civilian courts had no jurisdiction over him. The government agreed to the POW treatment, but said he could still be prosecuted on a 1988 drug-trafficking indictment. U.S. District Judge William Hoeveler concurred last week, and ordered the legal proceedings to continue.

DOC.HEAD: Quake Shakes Iranian City
DOC.TEXT: A moderate earthquake shook the city of Shahrud about 200 miles east of Tehran on Friday, the Islamic Republic News Agency reported. It did not mention casualties or damage. The quake measured 5.2 on the Richter scale, said the report monitored in Cyprus. The Richter scale is a gauge of the energy released by an earthquake as measured by the ground motion recorded on a seismograph. A magnitude 5 quake can cause considerable damage in a populated area.

DOC.HEAD: Central California Site of 10th UC Campus
DOC.TEXT: The University of California regents' decision to expand into the state's farming heartland only eliminates some of the contenders in the political jockeying to land UC's 10th campus. The system's first new campus in a quarter century will bring jobs, development and a commercial boost to the area chosen. Alliances already have split the 16-county central region chosen Thursday. Tulare and Kings counties have joined forces in the south while Tuolumne and Stanislaus are fighting together in the north. Campaigns range from sweat shirts printed with imagined UC Merced logos to glitzy promotional videotapes to resolutions by local governments welcoming a new campus. William R. Frazer, UC's senior vice president for academic affairs, said the region was chosen over the northern and southern sections of the state because it has the greatest number of people living more than 50 miles from one of the existing campuses. Officials hope to have the campus open by 1998.

DOC.HEAD: Explosion Kills Woman, Injures 11
DOC.TEXT: An explosion in a bank on the island of Borneo on Friday killed a woman and injured 11 people, the national news agency Bernama said. Bernama said the blast was in the city of Miri, about 750 miles southeast of Kuala Lumpur. It quoted a Miri hospital official as saying three of the injured were in intensive care. The cause of the explosion was under investigation.

DOC.HEAD: Norwegians Fingers Do The Walking to Poetry Recitals
DOC.TEXT: Thousands of Norwegians are putting stress on hold for 30 seconds to call Dial-a-Poem, the lyrical version of Norway's popular Joke Line. A test of the poetry line drew up to 8,000 calls a month, so the state phone company made the service permanent, the national news agency NTB reported Friday. Poets from the Norwegian Authors' Center read a 20- to 30-second selection into a tape recorder. A message assures waiting callers, ``Soon you'll get a poem in your ear.'' Last year the phone company introduced the Joke Line for comic relief.

DOC.HEAD: Philadelphia Mayor Says He Plans to Write, Teach After Term Ends
DOC.TEXT: W. Wilson Goode, who has two years to go on his second term, says he wants to write and teach after leaving office. The city's charter prohibits a third consecutive term. ``I'm going to teach and I'm going to properly record my tenure in office,'' Goode said this week. Goode said he has started recording notes on tape for a first book. ``I'm going to write a book or two and will, I think, tell the story of my administration, my philosophy _ what I tried to do, what I did, why I think I missed the mark on some things, why I think people did not properly give me credit for other things,'' the mayor said. During his years in office, Philadelphia has seen a construction boom downtown, capped by One Liberty Place, the city's tallest building. Goode's worst day in office was the confrontation with MOVE radicals, when a bomb dropped on their house on May 13, 1985, started a fire that killed 11 people and destroyed a neighborhood. He was elected the city's first black mayor in 1983. Goode said he expects the book to help other officials avoid some of the problems he had. The mayor said he had started negotiating for a teaching position, too. ``I'm engaged in discussions with a number of universities at this time and will by the beginning of 1991 have something set and will announce it at that time,'' Goode said.

DOC.HEAD: Chain Saw-Wielding Woman Fails in Holdup Attempt
DOC.TEXT: A woman wielding a chain saw failed in her attempt to hold up a motel clerk when she was tackled by the clerk's brother, police said. Karen Lee Joachimi, 20, of Lake City was being held Friday in the Columbia County jail on $86,000 bond on charges of armed robbery, grand theft and two counts of aggravated battery. Ms. Joachimi was drunk when she entered the Howard Johnson Motel late Wednesday night, police Sgt. Billie Carter said Friday. She apparently picked up a chain saw that was sitting in one of the offices and allegedly demanded money from clerk Lucille Ferry. She did not start the saw. Ms. Joachimi allegedly struck the clerk in the head with the saw and ran toward the door with $300, Carter said. But Ms. Ferry's brother Walter Swearengin, who was visiting, jumped over a counter, tackled Ms. Joachimi and held her until police arrived. No one was injured, Carter said.

DOC.HEAD: People in the News
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Stepfanie is cq.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto NY44
DOC.TEXT: Stepfanie Kramer, who plays Sgt. Dee Dee McCall on NBC's ``Hunter,'' says it's time to turn in her badge. ``After six years on `Hunter,' I feel the time has come for me to expand creatively into other levels of expression,'' Miss Kramer said in a statement Thursday. ``This will include focusing on my music career and future acting projects.'' The show has yet to decide whether the actress' character will be killed in an upcoming episode _ or will just walk away at the end of the season. Because ``Hunter'' requires 12-16 hours a day on the set, Miss Kramer was unable to pursue other roles, her publicist, Susan Patricola, said. ``And it leaves no time for her social life,'' she said. ``Hunter'' stars former football player Fred Dryer as a Rick Hunter, a policeman who behaves much like Dirty Harry. In the Feb. 24 episode, it will be revealed that McCall and Hunter have slept together.

The lineup for this year's Spoleto Festival U.S.A. is in place with the addition of musicians Chet Atkins, Chick Corea and Stanley Jordan. The festival runs May 25 through June 10. ``This will be the finest festival we have ever had,'' General Manager Nigel Redden said Thursday. ``We wanted this festival to be an appropriate reaction to the difficulties Charleston has been through.'' Redden said ticket sales are running 10 percent ahead of last year despite a two-month marketing delay caused by Hurricane Hugo, which smashed into the city on Sept. 21. Corea, a pianist who has won numerous Grammy awards, will perform at the Gaillard Municipal Auditorium on May 28. Atkins and Jordan will perform together for the first time on June 3. Atkins is well-known for more than 100 recordings while Jordan's album ``Magic Touch'' recently spent a year on the charts. The details of the festival's opening concert featuring Leonard Bernstein also have been finalized with Bernstein scheduled to conduct Beethoven's Symphony No. 7. This season's visual arts program will feature black American artists and American landscape painters. Spoleto productions announced earlier include Richard Wagner's opera ``Parsifal'' directed by festival founder and artistic director Gian Carlo Menotti. Composer Phillip Glass, poet Allen Ginsberg and artist Jerome Sirlin will collaborate on a multimedia theater production ``The Hydrogen Jukebox.'' The Spoleto Festival U.S.A. was founded in Charleston in 1977 _ two decades after Menotti founded the Festival of Two Worlds in Spoleto, Italy.

Tempestt Bledsoe, the 16-year-old actress who plays Vanessa Huxtable on ``The Cosby Show,'' has become a finalist for a National Merit Scholarship, her publicist said. The nationwide academic scholarship is awarded on the basis of students' academic record and scores on the PSAT, a scholastic aptitude examination, according to a statement issued Thursday by publicist David Brokaw. Miss Bledsoe has studied at the Professional Children's School in New York City. She is graduating from high school with straight A's, Brokaw said.

The city of Warsaw and Brazilian Indian activists were among the winners of the Onassis International Prizes, given to those whose work reflects ``human values as conceived in Greek philosophy and culture,'' it was announced. Other winners of the $100,000 prizes announced Thursday were United Nations Secretary-General Javier Perez de Cuellar and the Goulandris Museum of Natural History in Greece. Warsaw's residents were honored for restoring buildings destroyed during World War II, showing ``deep dedication to their cultural heritage.'' Ailton Krenak and the Union of Indian Nations, which he heads, were honored for their work in protecting native populations and rain forests. Perez de Cuellar was honored for ``reinvigorating the United Nations'' and the museum was cited for preserving Greece's natural environment. The prizes will be awarded April 5 in Athens. They were first given in 1980 by the Alexander S. Onassis Public Benefit Foundation, created under the terms of the will of Aristotle Onassis in memory of his son.

DOC.HEAD: Farm Living's the Life for Mrs. Michael J. Fox
DOC.TEXT: Tracy Pollan has a steady acting career; a famous husband, Michael J. Fox; a 9-month-old son, Sam; and homes on both coasts. But she's not quite living her fantasy life, she says in the March 5 issue of US magazine. ``Michael and I both have our fantasy of the way life will be,'' said Pollan, who appears next week in the ABC miniseries, ``The Fitzgeralds and the Kennedys.'' ``I'd love for Sam to go to school in Vermont and just be a kid on a farm and have a real normal childhood,'' she said. ``I don't want him growing up in L.A. We'd work a couple of times a year, and the rest of the time we'd ride horses, cook, take Sam to school.'' Pollan and Fox _ who is taking four months off to help raise Sam _ have a house in Los Angeles, but their recently refurbished farm in Vermont will be home, she said. ``And we bought an apartment in New York,'' she said. ``We'll probably be based there and live in Vermont as much as we can. It's all part of the never-ending effort to keep life simple.''

DOC.HEAD: Junk-Bond Firm's Workers Start Beating the Pavement
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 10 grafs to UPDATE with layoffs official, comment, details; picks up 10th graf pvs, `Meanwhile, most...' A version moved on the financial wire.
DOC.TEXT: Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. fired thousands of workers today as the former junk bond powerhouse continued dismantling as part of the largest bankruptcy filing in securities industry history. ``There are some tears today. We all regard it as a real shame and a tragedy,'' said John E. Oden, director of institutional placement in Drexel's real estate division in Beverly Hills, Calif. ``I feel like it could have been prevented.'' Drexel spokesman Steven Anreder said letters of termination were sent to the bulk of Drexel's 5,300 workers today. The remaining employees _ from investment bankers to secretaries _ will stay on temporarily to finish pending business. ``You've got assets here,'' Anreder said. ``We still (have to) negotiate, try to straighten things out, real estate to unload.'' The investment firm said it was completing severance packages for most of the fired workers, which included the 400-member Beverly Hills junk bond division. The operation long headed by Michael Milken was largely responsible for the firm's rise from the margins of Wall Street to billion-dollar profits and subsequent decline amid crushing scandals of the late 1980s. The high-yield bond division was devastated last year by the departure of Milken after his indictment on fraud and racketeering charges, and the subsequent collapse of the junk bond market. As few as 10 to 15 percent of Drexel's 5,300 workers _ the most talented _ could expect to land jobs, Perrin Long of Lipper Analytical Services estimated. The securities industry has lost 35,000 people since the October 1987 stock market crash. ``This isn't the best of times,'' Long said. Drexel employees have been looking for new work since the investment bank's parent, Drexel Burnham Lambert Group Inc., filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy court protection Tuesday. Many found banks unwilling to accept their last paychecks because of uncertainty about whether they would clear, The New York Times reported today. Meanwhile, most of Drexel's multibillion-dollar Treasury securities portfolio was liquidated by Thursday, aided by a rise in bond prices in the past week, Drexel executives said. The firm's junk-bond holdings, estimated to be worth about $1 billion, were being dumped below market value. ``There are parts of this business that are still good and represent value, and those will be disposed of in an orderly way,'' said Alan Miller, the bankruptcy lawyer handling the case. Across Wall Street, competing firms picked at Drexel's carcass to evaluate what holdings might be worth taking over. Soon to be ex-Drexel employees were said to be job-hunting alone and in groups of up to 50 people. ``Sure we're looking at their clients. They had lots of good people working there as well,'' said Joel Cohen, head of mergers and acquisitions at Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Securities Corp. Arthur Kirsch, chief of Drexel's worldwide equity business, told his 600-member division he still was trying to arrange for a mass movement to another firm. But employees and analysts were skeptical that would happen to Drexel divisions, which consist of people and contacts, not products. ``I think it's a great proposal but nobody will buy it,'' said Long of Lipper Analytical Services. ``Lincoln supposedly did away with slavery with the Emancipation Proclamation,'' he said. ``You can't sell people.''

DOC.HEAD: Barry Calls New Drug Charges a `Political Lynching'
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Inserts new 3rd graf, U.S. District, with assignment of judge and arraignment date
DOC.TEXT: Mayor Marion Barry vows ``I will be exonerated'' of new drug-related charges, but a city official is calling for his resignation and a top adviser wonders whether the mayor has any political future. Barry, 53, was indicted Thursday on five misdemeanor counts of cocaine possession and three felony counts of lying to a grand jury questioning him on drug use. U.S. District Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson, who was assigned the case today, tentatively scheduled Barry's arraignment for next Wednesday. Meanwhile, close advisers to Barry said Thursday that the mayor will leave a Florida drug treatment clinic by the end of the month to continue treatment elsewhere. Barry entered the Hanley-Hazelden Clinic in West Palm Beach four days after his Jan. 18 arrest on a cocaine possession charge in what authorities said was a videotaped hotel sting. The new clinic has not been chosen, but an adviser speaking on condition of anonymity said a top priority will be to ensure that Barry is isolated from the media. Barry, in a defiant statement issued through his office, said the indictment was ``a continuation of the political lynching and excesses of the Justice Department in this multi-year, multimillion-dollar effort to investigate me.'' ``Now that we will be moving into the courtroom _ which is where this case should be tried, not in the press _ I am relieved,'' Barry said. ``I know that when a trial is held, I will be exonerated.'' Barry has steadfastly denied ever using drugs, and his statement said he was undergoing treatment for ``the disease of alcoholism.'' The mayor said he is giving no thought to resigning. But one aide, who asked not to be identified, said the indictment dealt ``a crippling blow, an absolutely devastating assault'' to Barry's re-election chances if he seeks a fourth four-year term in November's election. Asked if Barry should resign, City Councilwoman Betty Ann Kane said, ``It might be in his best interests and the city's best interests. As a person who cares about the city, I would make that recommendation, now that it's gotten to this point.'' The Washington Post said in editorial today that Barry ``has lost any last claim to a position of leadership'' and should resign. ``For the sake of the city _ and of all the talent that stands ready to enlist public support for new leadership in city hall _ Mr. Barry should let go _ entirely,'' the newspaper said. Under city law, Barry would be forced to resign if convicted of a felony, and City Council Chairman David Clarke would become acting mayor. Each of the three perjury charges, stemming from Barry's association with convicted drug dealer Charles Lewis, carries a five-year maximum prison term and a maximum fine of $250,000. Each cocaine possession charge _ four stemming from Barry's visits to Lewis' hotel room in December 1988 and one from an FBI sting operation that resulted in his January arrest _ carries a maximum sentence of one year in a jail and a fine of $100,000. Only one of the possession charges stems from the videotaped hotel room encounter between Barry and Rasheeda Moore, a one-time Barry girlfriend who is cooperating with investigators. U.S. Attorney Jay B. Stephens said of the perjury charges, ``Mr. Barry falsely testified ... that he was unaware of any narcotics activity by Mr. Charles Lewis, when he stated that Mr. Lewis had never given him, Mr. Barry, any narcotics, and when he stated that he, Mr. Barry, had never given any narcotics to Mr. Lewis.'' Barry told aides privately on the weekend following his arrest that he would abandon plans for a fourth term, but he has not yet made any public statement to that effect. Stuart J. Long, Barry's financial co-chairman, said the mayor would face an uphill battle if he decided to run again. ``He's got the trial, probably a one-week thing, up or down,'' Long said. ``After that, well, who knows?'' Four candidates, including Clarke, already have announced their candidacies; Jesse L. Jackson has refused to rule out a campaign if Barry is not in the race. Meanwhile, law enforcement sources said two witnesses _ both social companions of the mayor _ were called to the federal courthouse under subpoena but left without testifying just before the indictments were issued. Sources said the witnesses _ Gaylord Tissueboo and former Birmingham, Ala., official Willie Davis, were expected to be asked whether they had ever seen Barry use drugs or if they had provided drugs to him. It was not clear whether they or other witnesses would later be called before the grand jury, which is empaneled until June, the sources said. The federal probe of Barry began in December 1988 after city police aborted an attempt to make an undercover drug buy from Lewis when they discovered that the mayor was in Lewis' hotel room. Lewis, who pleaded guilty to two cocaine conspiracy charges in November, testified in court that he had supplied Barry with cocaine. Lewis, who has cooperated with prosecutors investigating his relationship with the mayor, has been convicted of selling crack cocaine to undercover FBI agents in his native Virgin Islands.

DOC.HEAD: Janet Turns to History Book for Album Title
DOC.TEXT: It was no mystery when ``Janet Jackson's Rhythm Nation: 1814'' went platinum. But that number in the title is a mystery to many fans. It's true that `R' is the 18th letter in the alphabet and `N' is the 14th, but that's just coincidence, Jackson said in the March 5 issue of US magazine. ``What actually happened,'' Jackson said, ``was that while writing `Rhythm Nation' I was kidding around, saying, `God, you guys, I feel like this could be the national anthem for the '90s.' ``Just by a crazy chance we decided to look up when Francis Scott Key wrote the national anthem, and it was September 14, 1814.'' Jackson said that when she told A&M Records executives what it meant, ``They didn't want me to say. So I didn't. They still don't want me to say, but everyone keeps asking me.''

DOC.HEAD: Mandela Offers to Meet With De Klerk
With South Africa-ANC, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: African National Congress leader Nelson Mandela said Friday he is ready to meet President F.W. de Klerk to try to launch talks on resolving South Africa's racial conflict. Mandela made the comment as the African National Congress announced in Lusaka, Zambia that it would send a delegation to meet de Klerk to prepare for negotiations on ending white-minority rule and sharing power with blacks. Mandela said he was ready to play a role in talks on a new political structure, including meeting with de Klerk. He said he did not know when such talks might take place and he would have to consult with the ANC leadership. ``They (the ANC) might want me to meet Mr. de Klerk and convey certain messages. This will be decided by them,'' he said. Mandela, who was released from jail Feb. 11 after 27 years in jail, plans to visit Lusaka, probably next week, for talks with the ANC's exiled leaders. Mandela's role in the ANC is yet to be determined, but he is regarded as the most popular and important black leader in South Africa. He said the ANC still wants de Klerk to meet its conditions for talks, including releasing all political prisoners and ending a state of emergency. De Klerk, who legalized the ANC and other opposition groups Feb. 2, has said only political prisoners not guilty of violent crimes would be released. Mandela said he believed the ANC and the government could make rapid progress. ``We have made it easy for him (de Klerk) that an agreement should be reached as soon possible. As far as we are concerned we are fully prepared to cooperate in easing problems with him.'' Mandela met earlier Friday with diplomatic representatives of about 20 nations, including the United States. He outlined his hopes for South Africa during the closed-door meeting and urged other nations to help end apartheid. Talking to reporters at his home, Mandela was questioned about the many invitations he has received from world leaders to visit their countries. President Bush has invited Mandela to Washington. The chance to meet Bush was ``an honor'' and an opportunity which would be ``very important to any people who are struggling for change in their own country,'' he said. But a decision whether to accept such an invitation would have to come from the national executive committee of the ANC, he said. Mandela said he was not worried about opposition from right-wing whites to attempts to end white-minority rule, although they might pose a threat to his personal safety. He dismissed the white opposition Conservative Party, saying it had ``no policy at all except to appeal to rabid racialism.'' Thousands of whites protesting de Klerk's overtures to the black majority marched through Pretoria Ton hursday night in a major show of strength to demand new elections. Police said today that up to 40,000 whites took part in the march. De Klerk's decision to free Mandela and legalize the ANC had created fear and uncertainty among South African whites, the party said in a statement in its newspaper, Die Patriot. ``With one stroke great uncertainty about the future has been created. The voters have been lied to too often,'' the statement said.

DOC.HEAD: African National Congress Agrees to Meet de Klerk
LaserPhoto LUS1
DOC.TEXT: The African National Congress said Friday it is now willing to meet with South African President F.W. de Klerk to discuss opening talks on ending the group's three-decade guerrilla war against apartheid. Such a meeting would be the first between the guerrilla movement's exiled leaders and a South African head of state. It could represent a major step toward finding a solution to South Africa's black-white divisions. The group also said thousands of black guerrillas exiled decades ago would be returning to their homeland as the once-outlawed group moves back to South Africa. The ANC's national executive committee said delegates would visit South Africa to try to clear the way for negotiations on ending white-minority rule and sharing power with blacks for the first time. The ANC gave no date for the visit. The offer follows the government's historic release on Sunday of Nelson Mandela, the most famous symbol of anti-apartheid resistance. Mandela was freed to a tumultuous welcome after 27 years in prison. Alfred Nzo, secretary-general of the ANC, also said the guerrilla movement was prepared to negotiate ``a suspension of hostilities'' once de Klerk meets the group's remaining conditions for formal talks. ``To achieve this objective, in the shortest possible time, the National Executive Committee resolved to meet Mr. de Klerk as soon as possible,'' the anti-apartheid group said. The group's conditions for formal talks are a lifting of the state of emergency and the release of all political prisoners. A South African government spokesman said his administration was waiting to see the ANC statement and would have no immediate response. But it was unlikely that de Klerk would refuse such a meeting. The ANC, the main black group fighting white rule in South Africa, has been waging a bombing and sabotage campaign since 1961. However, the armed struggle has been largely dormant in the past year and poses no serious threat to the white-led government. Mandela said Friday he was ready to meet with de Klerk to further negotiations and end apartheid. Mandela, released Sunday after 27 years in jail, is expected to visit Lusaka next week to consult with the exiled leadership. ``I have found him (de Klerk) to be a man of integrity with whom I can do business,'' Mandela said at his home in Soweto, outside Johannesburg. The ANC said de Klerk still had not met all conditions to clear the way for talks on creating a new political structure for South Africa and cited the 3{-year-old state of emergency. The statement also called for an end to all political trials and army troops be removed from black townships. Nzo said the ANC ``resolved to meet Mr. de Klerk as soon as possible to discuss with him the need to address these issues so that a climate conducive to negotiations is created.'' ``The meeting agreed that the Pretoria regime had not yet created a climate conducive for negotiations,'' Nzo said. Nzo said that Walter Sisulu, released in October after more than 25 years in prison, would lead the effort to rebuild the ANC in South Africa. ``It is important immediately to begin the work of re-establishing the ANC within the country,'' Nzo said. He said the organization's estimated 15,000 exiles would soon begin to return on a large scale. The guerrilla movement said the delegation would include exiled members as well as leaders inside South Africa. That could include Mandela and Sisulu, although Nzo did not specify anyone by name. The ANC's statement followed three days of meetings to evaluate recent reforms announced Feb. 2 by de Klerk, such as legalizing more than 60 opposition groups, including the ANC, the release of Mandela, the easing of press restrictions, and a moratorium on executions. Nzo said the ANC views these reforms ``in a positive light.'' The ANC, which was banned for 30 years, also said it would open offices in South Africa. De Klerk and his predecessor, P.W. Botha, met with Mandela while he was in prison. However, no South African leader has met with any ANC leaders as free men. De Klerk wants to negotiate a new constitution that will include the 28 million black majority in the national government. But he opposes a one-man, one-vote system and outright black majority rule, the basic demand of all leading anti-apartheid groups, including the ANC. He envisions some mechanism that will give whites veto power on major policy decisions.

DOC.HEAD: Tape Renews Controversy over Skipper's Maneuvers After Grounding
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 7 grafs to UPDATE with today's testimony; picking up 3rd graf pvs. SUBS 11th graf pvs, `Hazelwood's chief...' to delete now redundant first reference to Kunkel.
DOC.TEXT: The chief mate of the Exxon Valdez said today that in the first minutes after the tanker went aground, he thought the skipper was trying to move the ship off a reef but later decided to keep it stable. James Kunkel, concluding his testimony in Joseph Hazelwood's criminal trial, said the captain of the tanker never told him whether or not he was trying to slide the ship off the jagged reef _ a move prosecutors say could have caused it to capsize and sink. Jurors already had heard a tape recording of conversations between Hazelwood and the Coast Guard on March 24 after the nation's worst oil spill indicating Hazelwood tried to move the grounded ship. Kunkel testified that his first report to the skipper, upon checking computer readings after the disaster, was that the ship was stable. ``On the basis of the instructions and commands the captain was giving you, did you believe the captain was trying to keep the vessel on the reef?'' asked Hazelwood lawyer Michael Chalos. ``At that time, no, I did not,'' Kunkel said. ``I felt that perhaps we were trying to get off the reef at the beginning.'' Minutes later, he said Hazelwood told him to ``ballast the ship down'' and it was clear he was trying to stay on the rocks. ``We are working our way off the reef,'' Hazelwood was heard saying in a radio message minutes after the tanker was gashed open and began spilling oil into Prince William Sound. The port commander warned Hazelwood against doing ``anything drastic'' and suggested, ``I wouldn't do much wiggling.'' The prosecution hopes to establish that Hazelwood's effort to extricate the ship demonstrates his recklessness, which must be proved for a conviction on the felony charge and one of three misdemeanor counts that Hazelwood faces. Defense attorneys say Hazelwood's orders were aimed at stabilizing the tanker on the reef. The Coast Guard tape, played in a hushed courtroom, began with routine inquiries from Hazelwood about ice conditions and his report that he planned to divert around shipping lanes to avoid ice. Shortly after midnight, Hazelwood called the vessel traffic center again. His voice was gravelly and he sighed as he said, ``It's Valdez back. We should be on your radar. We've fetched up hard aground.... Evidently we're leaking some oil and we're going to be here for awhile.'' Within minutes, the captain of the port, Coast Guard Cmdr. Steven McCall, called Hazelwood asking for more information. ``A little problem here with the third mate but we are working our way off the reef,'' Hazelwood said. ``The vessel's been holed ... right now we're trying just to get her off the reef and we'll get back to you as soon as we can.'' The third mate, Gregory Cousins, was in control when the ship grounded. He has blamed the accident on the helmsman's inability to take steering orders. Kunkel testified Thursday the skipper had a calming influence on the crew in the wake of the accident. ``What was the captain's demeanor?'' asked Hazelwood lawyer Michael Chalos. ``Very sullen, but all business,'' said Kunkel. ``Cool, calm, in charge.'' Hazelwood, 43, of Huntington, N.Y., is charged with second-degree criminal mischief and misdemeanor charges of reckless endangerment, negligent discharge of oil and operating a vessel while intoxicated. If convicted, he could draw up to 7\ years in prison and $61,000 in fines. Kunkel, in charge of loading the ship's cargo of oil, said he rushed to the cargo room after the grounding and saw the oil gauges dropping. He said he programmed the ship's computer with facts about the grounding and it told him ``the ship could not go out onto a seaway.'' He said he relayed this to Hazelwood. Kunkel said he had warned Hazelwood earlier that the helmsman, Robert Kagan ``needed practice in steering'' and required ``special supervision'' in even the simplest tasks. Kunkel said he sailed with Kagan four years earlier and wrote an evaluation saying the seaman ``tended to drift off'' while steering. He said he once assigned Kagan a simple task painting a bulkhead but found he had to watch him to ensure he used the right paint and brush. But Kunkel said he had ``no doubt'' that Kagan was capable of executing a 10 degree right rudder turn _ which Cousins has said Kagan failed to achieve at the crucial moment. The Exxon Valdez spilled 260,000 barrels _ or 10.92 million gallons, Kunkel said. After the grounding, Kunkel said he and Hazelwood discussed abandoning ship, but the skipper feared there would be panic among the crew. Lifeboats were lowered as a precaution, he said. The prosecution contends Hazelwood risked the lives of crew members by letting them sleep through the disaster, but Kunkel said he thinks abandoning ship would have been riskier. ``It was the middle of the night,'' the chief mate said. ``... In Prince William Sound it's always pretty dangerous to put people in the water.''

DOC.HEAD: Namibia Elects Sam Nujoma as First President
DOC.TEXT: Sam Nujoma, a former guerrilla leader who spent 30 years in exile, was elected Namibia's first president Friday and will take office when the territory wins independence from South Africa on March 21. Nujoma helped found the South-West Africa People's Organization in 1960 and led it through a 23-year bush war against South African rule of Namibia, Africa's last colony. ``On behalf of the Namibian people and myself I want to express my sincere appreciation for the trust and honor you have bestowed upon me,'' he told the 72-member Constituent Assembly after its unanimous vote. ``I call on all Namibians to remain united behind our government and work together for peace and stability,'' he said. U.N. Secretary-General Javier Perez de Cuellar will swear Nujoma into office on Namibia's independence day. Namibia's South African administrator, Louis Pienaar, will remain in charge of the territory until then. More than 20 heads of state are expected to attend the independence ceremonies. SWAPO leaders say they will invite both South African President F.W. de Klerk and recently released African National Congress leader Nelson Mandela. Nujoma will serve five years, then will be eligible for a second term. However, the constitution limits a president to two five-year terms, a rarity on a continent where most leaders serve for life. South Africa, which has ruled Namibia since 1915, agreed to grant the territory independence under a regional peace accord signed in 1988 with Angola and Cuba. More than 6,000 U.N. military and civilian personnel have been monitoring the transition to independence, which began in April. The Rev. Jesse Jackson attended the assembly session Friday and was allowed to speak to its members. ``I'm impressed by people civilized enough to agree and disagree,'' Jackson told the assembly. ``This is an example of how a democratic society can work when people move from polarization to coalition.'' Jackson, a former U.S. presidential candidate, completed an eight-day visit to South Africa on Thursday and said Namibia could become a ``shining example'' of democracy for South Africa. Jackson, who has known Nujoma for many years, told the Namibian leader that ``God has rewarded you for all your suffering.'' Jackson said he would urge the U.S. government to increase aid to Namibia and other black-ruled countries in the region. Leftist SWAPO won 41 of the assembly seats in elections last November; six other parties captured the remaining 31 spots. Despite a hard-fought election and sharp ideological differences, the parties quickly worked out a democratic, Western-style constitution that was unamimously approved earlier this month. Also, Nujoma has named whites, businessmen and opposition party members to his Cabinet in a bid to heal the deep divisions caused by a war that lasted from 1966 until April 1989. Nujoma, 60, has little formal education, but is considered a shrewd, instinctive politician who has maintained leadership of his organization despite several challenges over the years. He helped found the Ovamboland People's Organization, the forerunner to SWAPO, in the late 1950s. He went into exile in 1959 and was named president of newly formed SWAPO in 1960. Under his leadership, the movement was recognized by the United Nations as the ``sole and authentic representative of the Namibian people'' although the territory had dozens of political parties. Nujoma helped launch SWAPO's guerrilla war in 1966 and traveled widely during his years in exile, particularly to communist and Third World countries. In exile, he generally was portrayed as a Marxist, but has sounded much more moderate since returning to Namibia in September. Even his political opponents have praised his efforts at reconciliation, and the transition to independence has gone much more smoothly than most observers expected.

DOC.HEAD: Soviet Spokesman Says Troop Ceilings Will Soon Be Irrelvant
DOC.TEXT: The Soviet Union agreed to letting the United States have more troops in Europe because it expects events to make irrelevant within ``a year or two'' the newly agreed-upon ceilings, Soviet spokesman Gennady Gerasimov said Friday. ``We want to lower the level of military confrontation in Europe,'' said Gerasimov, a spokesman of the Soviet Foreign Ministry, in a telephone interview on National Public Radio's Morning Edition. ``We want it to be zero confrontation, and we want foreign troops to be removed from foreign soil everywhere,'' he said. Gerasimov said the Soviets didn't accept the U.S. argument that the United States needs to have 30,000 more troops in Europe than the Soviets because of the difficulty in moving forces across the Atlantic in the event of a conflict. But the Soviets decided to accept President Bush's proposal for 195,000 troops for each superpower in Central Europe with an additional 30,000 Americans allowed elsewhere in Europe to clear the way for a Europe-wide treaty on cutting conventional forces, Gerasimov said. ``The political situation in Europe is changing at such a pace that a year or two from now these figures of 195,000 and 30 additional thousand will become irrelevant,'' he said. ``This is my hope. ``So not to stop this process with small obstacles we decided to make this concession to common sense,'' Gerasimov said. ``... If you want to keep additional troops, it's your taxpayers' money.'' He said he had been reading remarks by French President Francois Mitterrand that alliances can exist only if they have enemies, suggesting that the Warsaw Pact and the North Atlantic Treaty Organization ``may fade away.'' ``Today nobody in his right mind can argue that the Soviets want to attack Western Europe,'' said Gerasimov. ``And I hope that nobody in Western Europe or in your country thinks in terms of attacking Eastern Europe or the Soviet Union.'' Military capability must be cut to be in line with the good intentions of both sides because intentions ``may be changed tomorrow,'' he said. The Soviet Union continues to oppose U.S. demands that a reunified Germany remain a member of NATO, but the diminished importance of the alliances could make the issue irrelevant, Gerasimov said.

DOC.HEAD: Tunnnel Firm Ordered to Pay Contractors
DOC.TEXT: A court on Friday ordered Eurotunnel to pay contractors $114 million for their work on a rail tunnel under the English Channel. The Commercial Tribunal of Nanterre in suburban Paris made the ruling on behalf of Transmanche Link (TML), the consortium of contractors working on the project. The decision follows a series of conflicts between the parent company and the Anglo-French consortium. A Eurotunnel spokeswoman said the company will appeal. The dispute stems from TML's refusal to sign a financing agreement with Eurotunnel and creditors allowing Eurotunnel to draw $701 million from the $8.7 billion in new loans granted to the venture. The Eurotunnel spokeswoman said the company lacks the funds to pay TML because the consortium refuses to sign the agreement and free up new loans. Disagreements between TML and Eurotunnel have centered on the appointment of Alistair Morton, former British president of the parent company, as the new chief executive. Eurotunnel stock fell 60 cents per share to $9.39 on Friday with 1.9 million shares changing hands. The tunnel, being built from both sides, is due to be opened in mid-1993 to rail traffic. About a third of the 34-mile project is complete.

DOC.HEAD: Bonner: Gorbachev Gets Too Much Credit for Soviet Changes
DOC.TEXT: Soviet human rights activist Yelena Bonner said today that President Mikhail S. Gorbachev deserves praise for his foreign policy but gets too much credit for changes taking place in the Soviet Union. ``We do not know what it is he wants,'' Bonner said at the opening of a forum on human rights. ``Is he only interested in personal power? Or he is interested in the rights of the people?'' Bonner appeared at the Peace Prize Forum at Augsburg College in place of her husband, Nobel Peace Prize winner Andrei Sakharov, who had been scheduled to address the forum before his death in December. She said Gorbachev's actions in allowing changes in the Soviet bloc are widely misinterpreted by Western countries. She said revolts have been brewing for a long time and Gorbachev deserves credit only for not stamping them out. Bonner said the Soviet Communist Party's platform issued three days ago has only slight changes from party platforms of past decades. She also said Gorbachev's initiatives in making elections more democratic came too late because the changes were made after the deadline for filing for office had closed. The elections, scheduled in March in the Soviet Union, are extremely important, she said. ``If he would have done this six months ago, it would have been a courageous act,'' Bonner said. ``But now, so what?'' She also said people in the Soviet Union are afraid Gorbachev is claiming too many powers. ``Gorbachev has shown himself as a very strong leader in the struggle for his own power and his own survival,'' she said. Bonner also criticized Gorbachev for using military force to handle demonstrations and other disruptions. ``The analysis of the Western media stops at, `Poor Gorbachev, how difficult it must be for him to govern in such circumstances,''' she said. Bonner opened the forum with a news conference also attended by former Vice President Walter Mondale. Her remarks in Russian were interpreted in English by her son. The theme of the Peace Prize Forum is ``Human Rights in the Global Village.'' It is sponsored by five colleges of the Evangelical Lutheran Church in America, including Augsburg, and is being held in conjunction with the Oslo-based Norwegian Nobel Institute, which awards the Nobel Peace Prize. Sakharov won the Nobel Peace Prize in 1975 for leading the human rights movement in the Soviet Union for decades.

DOC.HEAD: Molasses Coats Streets in `Sweetheart City'
DOC.TEXT: A mass of molasses oozed through two blocks of Colorado's ``Sweetheart City'' on Friday after a storage tank ruptured, forcing a kindergarten to close and blocking several businesses. No one was injured, but before the syrupy mess was identified, authorities took precautions against what they thought was a potentially dangerous chemical spill. Word of the spill reached authorities early Friday after a car spun out of control on a slippery substance and ran into a ditch. City Manager Mike Rock said two young males were in the vehicle and ``one of them told me it was like hitting glare ice. His windshield was so splattered with the stuff he couldn't see.'' The molasses was steaming when it escaped but it thickened in the 5 degrees below zero temperature. It flowed down a busy street, into an industrial park and on into an irrigation ditch where it ran for another half-mile, said police Cpl. Al Sharon. ``It gives a whole new meaning to the term Sweetheart City,'' Sharon said. Sharon estimated the ruptured tank was three stories high and 30 to 50 feet in diameter. Jack Fulton, director of government relations for Western Sugar Co., owner of the molasses, said 3,400 tons or about 618,000 gallons were in the tank leased from Great Western Salvage Co. ``We have engineers on the scene trying to determine the best way to clean up the spill,'' Fulton said. The molasses is used as an animal-feed supplement, often added to barley or other grains. Traffic was directed away from Madison Avenue, which was covered with 1 to 7 inches of sticky, brownish-black goo. Rock said of the cleanup effort, ``maybe we need to bring in a big bunch of pancakes.'' This city of approximately 30,000 people, 53 miles north of Denver, postmarks special Valentine's greetings on thousands of envelopes each year at this time. The kindergarten and businesses in the industrial park were closed because their entrances were blocked by the running mass.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Commission Says European Airport Security Has Improved
DOC.TEXT: A U.S. commission on aviation security and terrorism appointed after the Flight 103 disaster said Friday that airport security has improved in Europe but Africa is a ``basket case.'' ``If there is an Achilles' heel in aviation security, it is Africa, which is literally a basket case,'' said U.S. Rep. James L. Oberstar, chairman of the House Public Works and Transportation Subcommittee on Aviation. Oberstar said cited poor training for security personnel, high staff turnover, insufficient detection equipment, and economic pressures on African governments. Oberstar, a Minnesota Democrat, was speaking at a news conference given by the commission near the end of a week of consultations with airline, government and security officials in West Germany, France and Britain. The commission is to report in May to President Bush on American policy toward the terrorist threat to civil aircraft and to make safety recommendations. Bush appointed the seven-member commission after Pan AM Flight 103 from Frankfurt to New York via London was blown up by a terrorist bomb over the Scottish town of Lockerbie on Dec. 21, 1988. All 259 people aboard the Boeing 747 and 11 people on the ground were killed. Oberstar said the attitude of France toward the terrorist threat to aircraft had changed markedly since Sept. 19, when a DC-10 of the French airline UTA crashed in Niger, West Africa, killing all 171 passengers and crew. UTA said the apparent cause was a bomb. ``The attitude in France a year ago was this is an American problem,'' said Oberstar. ``After UTA the (French) attitude is it is a worldwide problem.'' The French government has given more than $5 million to African countries to train airport security personnel since the UTA disaster, the commissioners said. They added that the attitude toward air security generally was tougher in Europe than a year ago. West Germany, for example, markedly improved its system of checking baggage and passengers. ``The fact is right now, I think we are improving,'' said commission leader Ann McLaughlin, a former U.S. labor secretary. Commissioner member Sen. Alfonse M. D'Amato, R-New York, said no one still knew for sure where the radio-cassette bomb was put aboard Flight 103. British officials maintain it was in Frankfurt. West German police seized similar bombs in October 1988 and arrested 16 Palestinians, but soon released all but two of them. including a Jordanian suspected by some of assembling the bomb in Frankfurt that blew up the Pan Am flight. The commission members will spend the day in Lockerbie on Sunday before going home.

DOC.HEAD: Trade Deficit Improves But Still Tops $100 Billion
DOC.TEXT: A surprisingly large 30 percent trade-balance improvement in December allowed the nation to close out 1989 with a $108.6 billion deficit, the smallest in five years, the government said Friday. While conceding that most of the December improvement was dependent on special factors, the Bush administration hailed the 8.4 percent narrowing in the deficit for the year as evidence that the administration's effort to open foreign markets was succeeding. However, private economists were not as enthusiastic, pointing out that while U.S. exports hit an all-time high last year, so did imports, driven upward by America's growing dependence on foreign oil. Some economists forecast that the deficit this year will resume worsening as consumers continue their love affair with imported products and the foreign oil bill rises. But other economists were not as pessimistic, believing that 1990 would show another slight improvement in the deficit, although probably not enough to dampen protectionist cries in Congress. ``The trade deficit is coming out of a six-month period of deterioration but what happened in December overstates whatever improvement is occurring,'' said Allen Sinai, chief economist of the Boston Co. In other economic news, the government said that industrial production fell 1.2 percent in January, pushing the operating rate at the country's factories, mines and utilities down to 81.9 percent, almost 2.5 percentage points below where it was a year ago. While much of the January drop was a factor of unseasonably warm weather reducing the need for utility production, analysts said much of American industry, particularly automaking, remains in a slump. The 1989 trade deficit followed a $118.5 billion deficit in 1988 and was the smallest since a $106.7 billion deficit in 1984. However, it still represented the sixth consecutive year that the difference between imports and exports remained above $100 billion. Many econmists believe the huge trade deficits are symbolic of America's inability to compete internationally. But the Bush administration maintains that after hitting a record high of $152.1 billion in 1987, the past two years of trade improvements showed that the country was regaining many of its lost overseas markets. Commerce Undersecretary Michael Darby noted that U.S. exports climbed by 13 percent last year to an all-time high of $364.3 billion, while imports were up 7.3 percent to $472.9 billion, also a record high. ``Growth in exports was strong across most categories of goods, including a wide variety of manufactured goods, especially machinery and telecommunications equipment,'' Darby said. However, the export increase was just half the 26 percent rise enjoyed during 1988, a year when American manufacturers benefited from a falling dollar that made their goods more competitive on overseas markets. While economists at DRI-McGraw Hill forecast that the trade deficit will climb to $123 billion this year, other analysts forecast it would dip to just under $100 billion, reflecting their belief that strong growth overseas would provide markets for American products, helping to offset the negative impact of higher oil imports. In 1989, oil imports surged by 27.2 percent to $48.94 billion, $10.5 billion more than in 1988. It was the highest yearly total since a $52.4 billion foreign oil bill in 1984. The American Petroleum Institute said Thursday that imports hit a record 54 percent of total U.S. demand during January while domestic production was falling to its lowest level in a quarter-century. ``Petroleum must become the principal issue in the trade debate. We are becoming very dependent again on imported petroleum,'' said Barry Rogstad, president of the American Business Conference, a coalition of fast-growing, medium-sized companies. As usual, the country's largest imbalance in 1989 was with Japan, a $49 billion deficit that accounted for 45 percent of the total. This was down only slightly from a $51.8 billion deficit in 1988 with Japan, but some economists noted as encouraging the fact that U.S. export sales to Japan were up by 18.2 percent, helping to offset a 4.5 percent rise in Japanese imports. The United States enjoyed a rare surplus of $1.5 billion with the 12-nation European Community, a sharp turnaround from a $9.2 billion deficit in 1988. After Japan, the largest deficits occurred with Taiwan, $13 billion; Canada, $9.62 billion; South Korea, $6.26 billion, and China, $6.18 billion. One of the biggest surpluses was with the Soviet Union, with U.S. exports exceeding Soviet imports by $3.57 billion. The December deficit of $7.17 billion was the lowest monthly imbalance since a $6.79 billion deficit in December 1984. The 30 percent improvement from November's $10.29 billion deficit occurred because exports rose 2.4 percent to $31.11 billion, the second-highest level on record, while imports fell 5.9 percent to $38.28 billion. Exports were up in December in large part because of a big jump in sales of aircraft and parts, reflecting the end of the Boeing strike. There were smaller increases in office equipment, artwork and antiques and industrial machinery.

DOC.HEAD: Property Bill Sent Back to Committee
DOC.TEXT: Soviet legislators said a bill legalizing private property was too vague and sent it back to committee Friday, then took up legislation that would let invididuals own land. Legalizing two fundamentals of capitalism banned for generations in this Communist state is intended help revive the moribund economy by spurring individual initiative and attracting foreign investment. Alexander Nikonov, president of the All-Union Agricultural Academy, told the Supreme Soviet legislature the proposed Law on Land gives farmers a voice in choosing the appropriate form of ownership and how to use profits from their harvests. Agricultural land now is distributed among state and collective farms. The constitution, which must be changed if the bills become law, says ``the land, its minerals, waters and forests are the exclusive property of the state.'' Debate on the land bill is to continue next week. The deputies decided to consider the separate private property bill again in a week, after the committee work, and vote separately on each of its 35 provisions. That law would legalize ownership of ``means of production,'' but it does not define the term, and says even foreign companies, once scorned as agents of imperialism, may own factories and buildings. Legislator Vladimir Tikhonov, an agricultural scientist, complained that, while the draft Property Law mentioned the right to own property, nothing in it required the often recalcitrant Soviet bureaucracy to sell property. Other deputies, in the second day of debate on the property bill, said it was not clear. ``Everything in the draft law has two meanings,'' said Anatoly Sobchak, a prominent reformist from Leningrad. He said the law must say private ownership of ``any form of property'' is legal. In an appeal Thursday for approval of the property bill, Justice Minister Veniamin F. Takovlev said: ``If we want to have a market economy and take part in the international marketplace, then we need such a law.'' President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's five years as Soviet leader have brought many upheavals in politics and society, but few official proposals have the breadth of those on property and land. Citizens who were taught for generations that ``property is theft'' now are being asked to accept private ownership along with ownership by collectives and the state. In other action, 100 deputies said they had formed a parliamentary faction called Soyuz, Russian for union, to ``resist the breakup of the U.S.S.R.'' They appear to be opposing Baltic representatives, who seek independence for their republics, and the Interregional Group, an alliance of Boris N. Yeltsin and others who demand radical economic and political reform.

DOC.HEAD: Most States Allowing Food Stamp Recipients to Work on Census
DOC.TEXT: Most states are going along with an experiment to waive family income rules so people receiving food stamps can work on the 1990 census without losing their monthly benefits, the Agriculture Department said Friday. Assistant Secretary Catherine Bertini, who oversees USDA food and consumer services, said the program will enable participating families some extra income and provide the Census Bureau with much-needed temporary assistance. The bureau expects to hire about 300,000 temporary workers to help with the count, which is conducted every 10 years. Pay will range from $4.50 to $9 per hour, depending on the region and type of work. Normally, additional income would lead to a reduction in food stamp benefits, which are based on household size, income, assets and other factors. ``So far, all but seven states _ Alabama, Connecticut, Florida, Georgia, Idaho, Kansas and New Hampshire _ have indicated they would participate,'' Bertini said. The Family Support Administration of the Department of Health and Human Services will conduct a similar demonstration project using waivers for recipients of aid to families with dependent children (AFDC), the announcement said.

DOC.HEAD: FEC Won't Appeal Ruling; GOP Senate Panel Could Face Hefty Fine
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 1 graf after 4th graf pvs `The commission's ...' to UPDATE with reaction from Common Cause. Picks up 5th graf pvs `Common Cause ...'
DOC.TEXT: The Federal Election Commission said Friday it won't appeal a judge's ruling that it improperly dismissed a complaint alleging a Republican Party fund-raising group illegally funneled more than $2 million to 1986 Senate candidates. That means the FEC accepts the judge's order to reconsider the complaint, an action that could result in a hefty fine against the National Republican Senatorial Committee. U.S. District Judge Gerhard A. Gesell, ruling Jan. 24 on a lawsuit filed by Common Cause, said the FEC's initial refusal to act on the complaint ``cannot be upheld, because it ignored the plain language of the applicable regulation and was not rationally explained.'' The commission's only alternative to reconsidering was to appeal, which FEC spokeswoman Sharon Snyder said the commissioners decided not to do. ``This action involved very serious violations of the law and now the commission has to go back and determine what the proper penalties are,'' said Common Cause President Fred Wertheimer. Common Cause alleged that the NRSC violated contribution limits by illegally funnelling proceeds of a fund-raising campaign to 12 Republican Senate candidates. The NRSC, through letters signed by then-Vice President Bush, raised about $2.8 million and gave it to the candidates, all of whom ultimatelty lost as the Democrats regained control of the Senate. No candidates were identified in the various versions of the letters. By the time of the fund-raising campaign, the Republican Party already had made the maximum contribution it was allowed to make to each Senate candidate. Common Cause complained to the FEC, saying the NRSC had pushed the party over the limits by giving the proceeds of the letter-writing campaign to the candidates. The NRSC contended the donations could be treated as individual donations to the candidates, but Common Cause noted the checks were made out to the NRSC and its affiliates. The FEC's general counsel agreed with Common Cause and estimated the excess contributions totaled $3.2 million. But on a 3-3 vote, with the three Republican FEC appointees siding with the NRSC, the commission blocked action on a key portion of the complaint, reducing the amount of excess contributions to $534,249. The NRSC paid $20,000 to settle that portion of the case. Common Cause challenged the refusal of the FEC to act on the major portion, arguing the donations were clear violations of the party spending caps, and Gesell agreed. ``The decision of the FEC not to enforce in the circumstances presented by the record was contrary to the intent of Congress to limit the participating of national parties in campaign fund-raising,'' Gesell wrote.

DOC.HEAD: 19-year-old Pleads Innocent in 911 Computer Hacking Case
DOC.TEXT: A 19-year-old Missouri man has pleaded innocent to federal charges he broke into the 911 emergency telephone network for nine states, then published information on its access to other computer buffs. Craig Neidorf, a student at the University of Missouri, was indicted earlier this month along with Robert Riggs, 20, of Decatur, Ga. Prosecutors said the two used computers to enter the 911 system of Atlanta-based Bell South, then copied the program that controls and maintains the system. The stolen material was then published in a computer bulletin board in Lockport, a Chicago suburb, prosecutors said. The 911 system operated by Bell South controls emergency calls to police, fire, ambulance and emergency services in cities in Alabama, Mississippi, Georgia, Tennessee, Kentucky, Louisiana, North Carolina, South Carolina and Florida. On Thursday, Neidorf pleaded innocent to charges of violating the wire fraud act and the Computer Fraud and Abuse Act of 1986, and to charges of interstate transportation of stolen goods. If convicted on all counts, he faces a maximum of 31 years in prison and a fine of $122,000, said assistant U.S. Attorney Dan Gillogly. At Thursday's hearing, assistant U.S. Attorney William Cook was granted a motion to prevent the 911 program from becoming part of the public record during the trial, being heard by U.S. District Judge Nicholas Bua. Riggs is to be arraigned Thursday, Cook said. In addition to charges he violated the wire fraud act and the Computer Fraud and Abuse Act of 1986, Riggs faces charges of transportation of stolen property, Cook said. At the time of their indictment, acting U.S. Attorney Ira H. Raphaelson declined to say whether the accused had disrupted any emergency calls or caused other damage. Bua set a trial for April 16.

DOC.HEAD: American Accused of Meteorite Theft Leaves Argentina
DOC.TEXT: An Arizona businessman charged with trying to steal a 37-ton meteorite from a small Argentine town left for home Friday after a judge ordered a 90-day postponement of his trial. ``I've got my passport, and I'm out of here,'' Robert Haag, 33, of Tucson, said in a telephone interview a few hours before departure. ``I'm supposed to come back in 90 days,'' said Haag, also known as the Meteorite Man. ``I'd like to come back and clear myself, but I just don't know. Right now all I want to do is get back to my business'' of selling meteorites. Haag, Tucson photographer Jeffrey Smith, 31, and Miguel Fernandez, an Argentine, were arrested Jan. 21 when they were stopped by police near the small town of Gancedo, in Chaco Province, 620 miles northwest of Buenos Aires. The three defendants were charged in the neighboring town of Charata with the theft of the meteorite, roughly the size of a small automobile, that police said they found in the back of a tractor-trailer the men were driving. The meteorite, found in the 1960s, reputedly is one of the world's four largest. Charges against Smith were dropped and he returned to Tucson. The area is rich in meteorites, and several years ago provincial lawmakers made all meteorites provincial property and forbade their unauthorized sale. Haag was released on $20,000 bond but was forbidden to leave Argentina. Fernandez, unable to post $8,600 bond, remains in custody in Charata. Haag claimed he planned to purchase the meteorite in a deal arranged by Fernandez with the owner of the land on which the object had been found. But he expressed no regrets Friday over the outcome of the expedition. ``This has been a super adventure,'' he said. ``I met a lot of people in the Chaco, and at the end all kinds of them were trying to sell me meteorites.'' Haag's case was being heard in Charata by Judge Juan Carlos Clauter. The judge postponed the trial and returned Haag's passport on Wednesday after Haag said he needed to return home to take care of business. ``I'm losing at least $2,000 a day by being here,'' said Haag, who claims to do ``half a million dollars of business a year'' selling meteorites to private collectors, schools and museums. Haag, known to mineral enthusiasts back home as the Meteorite Man, said he planned to sell the meteorite he is accused of trying to steal. ``I could have gotten a million dollars for it,'' he said. If convicted, Haag could be sentenced to from 30 days to two years in jail. If he fails to return when his trial resumes May 13, he would forfeit his bail. Meteorites are common in the Chaco, Haag said, ``because a long time ago a giant asteroid broke into millions of pieces, showering the area with fragments, some the size of marbles and basketballs, others weighing a ton or more.'' The value of meteorites ``depends on the kind of material they contain,'' he said. ``Some are fragments of the moon, others are the heads of comets.'' ``But I'm through dealing with meteorites in Argentina,'' Haag added. ``The last thing I want to do is to try to get anything out of here.''

DOC.HEAD: Groundbreaking Ceremony For New Center Next Week
DOC.TEXT: A groundbreaking ceremony will be held next week for a religious center to replace a controversial convent on the grounds of the Nazi death camp at Auschwitz, the World Jewish Congress said Friday. The official announcement of Monday's dedication ceremony will be made following a meeting that day between Poland's Prime Minister Tadeusz Mazowiescki and WJC President Edgar Bronfman. The center will be located several hundred yards from the death camp site, which has been enshrined as a memorial to the hundreds of thousands of Jews and other victims exterminated by the Nazis. French Bishop Gaston Poulain announced Friday a drive to raise funds among French Catholics for the interfaith center, the WJC said. Other European churches will also take part in raising money. Jews viewed the convent, which houses 14 Carmelite nuns in a warehouse used by the Nazis to store gas cylinders for the Auschwitz crematoria, as a sacrilege to the memory of their brethren. In 1987, Catholic leaders reached agreement with the WJC to move the nuns to a new site near Auschwitz by February 1989. But no action was taken until the Vatican intervened last year after an outcry by the world Jewish community. The new, non-Communist government of Poland also intervened and the decision was made to honor the 1987 agreement. Jewish leaders have given the new government high marks for its commitment to fight anti-Semitism in Poland, where only a few thousand Jews remain from a pre-war community of about 3.5 million.

DOC.HEAD: Number of Cattle Due for Slaughter on the Upswing
DOC.TEXT: Cattle being fed for the slaughter market as of Feb. 1 in the seven major beef states totaled 8.53 million head, up 7 percent from a year ago and 4 percent more than two years ago, the Agriculture Department said Friday. Marketings of ``fed'' cattle in January totaled 1.63 million head, down 3 percent from a year ago and 7 percent below two years ago. The placement of new cattle and calves in fattening pens last month was reported at 1.9 million head, up 11 percent from a year ago and 14 percent more than two years ago. This was the second-largest January placement total on record, the report said. State feedlot cattle inventories are listed here for the seven states, which account for about three-fourths of the nation's beef. The first number is the number of cattle, in thousands, as of Feb. 1, and the second number is the percentage of a year earlier.
Arizona 246 95 California 465 109 Colorado 880 107 Iowa 1,030 109 Kansas 1,615 105 Nebraska 2,120 110 Texas 2,170 105

DOC.HEAD: Five East Europe Nations Ask For Aid
With AM-Germany, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Western officials on Friday considered pleas for cash and credit from five East European countries that shed Communist rule and now want to embrace free-market economies. The representatives of 24 Western nations took no immediate action on the litany of requests, leaving it up to a meeting in early June of foreign ministers. East Germany, Czechoslovakia, Bulgaria, Yugoslavia and Romania are seeking the same sort of Western assistance that was given to Poland and Hungary, two nations that led the remarkable string of anti-Communist revolts last year. Though taking no concrete action, the Western officials said they ``confirmed their readiness to coordinate assistance'' to the five nations. ``They expressed their encouragement and their support for the measures already taken or envisaged by each of these countries,'' a statement said. It said the European Community, which is coordinating Western assistance, would send fact-finding teams to the countries to get a first-hand look at their needs. Under the aid program, Poland and Hungary have accumulated commitments to more than $12 billion in loans and guarantees, as well as emergency food shipments to Poland. In their appeals, the other countries emphasized the ills plaguing their economies, including high inflation and heavy foreign debts. Some worried that quick economic changes would hurt living standards and create social tensions. They all promised to move toward open political systems and change their economies from centrally planned systems to the free-market models practiced in the West. Romania, which overthrew dictator Nicolae Ceaucescu, complained its economy was in ``deep crisis'' and suffered the effects of ``economic megalomania,'' poor investments, a sharp reduction in agricultural production and an ``inhuman policy toward the people.'' Bulgaria complained it was burdened by a budget deficit, weighty foreign debt and an economic structure that favors production of heavy goods over consumer products. Efforts to change the economy, it said, will expose ``individuals to a high economic risk which they might not be able to bear.'' Czechoslovakia said, ``There is no unemployment in Czechoslovakia _ however, a considerable part of the labor force is tied up in inefficient operations.'' East Germany, which has seen thousands of its citizens flow into wealthy West Germany in recent months, said it needed quick reforms to ``gain our people's confidence in the improvement of their economic and living conditions and attract (foreign investment.)'' The countries sent numerous pages of projects they have in mind for Western assistance, ranging from cleaning up the environment to upgrading their telecommunications technology. Yugoslavia said it would need $2 billion to rebuild its banking system and revamp its economy. The aid effort began when Western leaders in July put the European Community in charge of fashioning aid packages for Poland and Hungary. The Soviet Union has not been invited to take part in the program. Its economic woes greatly overshadow those of its neighbors. Nations attending the meeting included the Common Market countries of Britain, Ireland, Norway, Denmark, Belgium, the Netherlands, Luxembourg, Germany, France, Spain, Italy and Portugal. Also attending were the United States, Canada, Australia, Turkey, New Zealand, Japan, Sweden, Switzerland, Finland, Austria, Norway and Iceland.

DOC.HEAD: Eagleburger Says U.S. Aid To Eastern Europe Conditional
DOC.TEXT: Except for emergency food and medicine, U.S. aid to countries in Eastern and Central Europe will be conditioned on their adopting Western-style political and economic systems, a senior Bush administration official said Friday. Specifically, Deputy Secretary of State Lawrence Eagleburger told an American Chamber of Commerce forum, the countries should set up rival political parties and market economies with large private sectors. Rejecting the idea of a Marshall Plan for Eastern Europe, he defended the measured approach of the Bush administration and urged business executives in the audience not to try to ``make a quick buck'' in the region but to help build a long-range capitalistic structure. ``First we want progress toward political pluralism, based on free and fair elections, and an end to the monopoly of the Communist Party,'' Eagleburger said. ``Second, we want progress toward economic reform, based on the emergence of a market-oriented economy with a substantial private sector.'' Eagleburger will get a chance next week to push the U.S. policy directly with East Europeans. The State Department announced he would lead a U.S. delegation to Poland, Hungary, Austria and Yugoslavia Feb. 20-27 to gauge political and economic reform. Poland and Hungary are the most advanced of the Warsaw Pact allies in moving away from Soviet-style political and economic systems. U.S. aid over three years to Poland is $846.5 million, and to Hungary, $91.5 million. Austria is a neutral country with a Western orientation. State Department spokesman Richard Boucher said Eagleburger will meet there with government leaders to get their appraisal of developments in the region. Yugoslavia, which is not part of the Warsaw Pact, has a moderate Communist government trying to hold the country together amid tensions between diverse nationalities. Eagleburger said Eastern Europe is emerging from a 40-year time capsule. But, he said, ``we must not transfer substantial sums, as Western banks did in the 1970s, before implementation of truly fundamental market-oriented reforms.'' Still, Eagleburger added: ``Not all of our assistance will be conditional. Some of it will be available to countries as they need it and are able to use it. In this category, I would place emergency and humanitarian aid, designed to relieve deprivation and give a new government some breathing room.''

DOC.HEAD: Kathleen Sullivan Bids Farewell To `CBS This Morning' Viewers ^LaserPhoto NY48
DOC.TEXT: In the third farewell to viewers by a network news anchorwoman since October, Kathleen Sullivan of ``CBS This Morning'' said goodbye Friday and obliquely confirmed that Paula Zahn will succeed her. However, CBS News spokesman Tom Goodman said the network had no announcement to make on Sullivan's successor. A CBS source said the announcement of the hiring of Zahn, who has left ABC, is expected Tuesday. In her goodbye to viewers, Sullivan, who had co-anchored the show with Harry Smith since its premiere in November 1987, appeared upbeat but near tears. ``Paula Zahn has been the stepmother to two of my other children at ABC, and now I'm sure she'll take great care of my third, `CBS This Morning,''' she said. Before joining CBS, Sullivan co-anchored ABC's ``World News This Morning'' and the news segments of ``Good Morning America.'' She was succeeded on those programs by Zahn, who said her farewells on the latter show Thursday. NBC's Jane Pauley, replaced by Deborah Norville in January as co-host of the ``Today'' show, confirmed that controversial move on the air Oct. 29, and made her farewell on the show Dec. 29. She remains at NBC News. Zahn's agent, Richard Leibner, has said his client is going to CBS but said Friday that a few details still must ironed out. According to a source close to her contract talks, ABC officials liked her work but decided not to make a counter-offer to CBS' offer of a $1.1 million-a-year, four-year contract. CBS has said ``CBS Morning News'' co-anchor Faith Daniels will be next week's temporary co-anchor of ``CBS This Morning.'' On Friday, Sullivan did not say why she was leaving. Her agent, Ron Konecky, has said CBS executives gave no reason for their decision to replace her, and that he is discussing other possibilities for her at CBS. Her contract expires in November. Sullivan told viewers that she's proud of what her show accomplished: ``We've restored the credibility that said we meant business in the morning here at CBS.'' Her program's predecessor, ``The Morning Show,'' was a frothy, short-lived entertainment show that CBS tried after years of generally failing to make a dent in morning ratings with a news program. There were cheers at CBS News when it got the morning time period back and put in ``CBS This Morning.'' The program, while getting a larger audience than its predecessor, still is a distant third in ratings to ``Good Morning America'' and NBC's ``Today.'' Noting that eight of her 10 years on national television have been on morning shows, Sullivan said she plans to take a break. ``I'm hoping to do some really wild and wonderful things,'' she said, but didn't elaborate. ``So, if I show up on your doorstep because I ran out of gas or my horse broke down, please don't forget me.''
