Alluding to the 1984 Olympics telecasts she co-anchored while at ABC, she concluded her farewell by saying, ``Yeah, I'm the one who wore the sweaters in the Olympics. ... I'm a bit older, but I'm also a bit wiser.''

DOC.HEAD: More Money for Fighting Fruit Flies in California
DOC.TEXT: Agriculture Secretary Clayton Yeutter said Friday he has made an additional $15 million available to help fight an outbreak of Mediterranean and Oriental fruit flies in California. The funds were made available under emergency procedures put into effect on Thursday, the announcement said.

DOC.HEAD: US Advises Tourists to Take Care
DOC.TEXT: The State Department said Friday that most Philippine cities and tourist destinations are safe for travelers but urged Americans to avoid certain areas of ``ongoing communist insurgency and criminal activity'' and to take care at night in city entertainment districts. ``Since at any given time there may be unsettled conditions in any area of the Philippines, special care should be exercised when travelling via public conveyances as well as private vehicles,'' the department said. ``Except for major urban areas, road travel at night should be avoided and only national highways and paved roads should be used ...'' it said. ``While traffic to and from U.S. government installations flows normally, people should be aware that (insurgent) threat exists against U.S. official personnel and facilities,'' the department said. It listed as areas to avoid: Samar Island, Lanao Del Sur (Marawi City), Sulu Province, Basilan Island, the Province of Kalinga Apayao and the Cagayan Valley located in Cagayan and Isabela Provinces. Cebu City's entertainment district was named in a December advisory as a dangerous city area at night. The latest advisory extended the warning to other cities, asserting that ``due to criminal activities, travellers should exercise caution in major cities' entertainment districts at night and should avoid travel to Cebu Island's remote mountainous areas.'' ``Special care should be exercised when travelling to various areas of Luzon, principally Abra, Ifugao, and mountain provinces including Banaue and Sagada, Quezon Province, Aurora Province, southern Laguna Province, and all of Luzon south of Lucena City except for Lagaspi and Naga Cities,'' the department said. ``Due to continued crime and insurgency, travel on the island of Mindanao should be limited to Bukidnon Province and the cities of Butuan, Cagayan de Oro, Cotabato, Dipolog, Iligan, General Santos, Pagadian, Dapitan, Gingoog, Surigao City, and the downtown centers of Davao and Zamboanga Cities. ... Travel to Antique should be limited to the road between Iloilo and San Jose,'' it added. The department said that in the Negros islands, ``Americans are urged to confine travel to the urban areas of cities served by regular air service.''

DOC.HEAD: 2 Americans, 3 Others Charged with Producing, Distributing Drugs
DOC.TEXT: Two Americans and three employees of a West German chemical plant were charged with making and selling illegal drugs for distribution in Europe and the United States, officials said Friday. The West Germans work for Imhausen Chemie, the West German company that was accused in a separate case of helping manufacture a Libyan plant allegedly intended to produce poisonous gas. The five were charged with smuggling and selling millions of tablets of amphetamines, such as a synthetic drug known as ``Ecstasy,'' said a statement issued by the Offenburg prosecutor's office. All five were in investigative custody. The statement did not identify the suspects and there was no reply at the prosecutor's office on Friday. The two Americans are a 46-year-old lawyer and a 50-year-old chemist, the statement said. One of the three Imhausen employees is a French citizen and two are West Germans. West Germany is seeking the extradition of one of the accused Americans who is in custody in the United States; the other four are being held in West Germany, the statement said. Prosecutors accused Imhausen Chemie of delivering about 1 million tons of chemicals needed to produce amphetamines to illegal labs in Central America between 1986 and 1988. The two Americans were charged with smuggling the drugs to the United States. At the end of 1987, the Americans allegedly decided to move drug production to Europe and contacted the three Imhausen employees, the statement said. Until the group's arrest in early 1989, Imhausen Chemie allegedly supplied 1.3 million amphetamine tablets to the two Americans. About 400,000 tablets reached the European drug market, the statement said. Imhausen Chemie stood at the center of the scandal involving the Libyan plant, which shook the Bonn government last year and strained U.S.-West German relations for several months. The United States alleged the plant in Rabta, Libya, was built to produce chemical weapons. Libya denied the allegations and said it was a pharmaceutical manufacturing plant. Bonn first denied that West German companies were involved in the project but later acknowledged that West German companies played a major role in providing the technology for the plant to Libya. Juergen Hippenstiel-Imhausen, the former head of Imhausen Chemie, was arrested in May and remains in custody in connection with the case. West German officials said last week the Libyan factory has begun producing limited amounts of poison gas.

DOC.HEAD: Yelena Bonner Opens Peace Conference With Criticism Of Gorbachev
DOC.TEXT: Soviet leader Mikhail S. Gorbachev is a power-hungry politician who has an overblown reputation as a reformer, Soviet dissident Yelena Bonner said Friday at a peace forum. ``Gorbachev has shown himself as a very strong leader in the struggle for his own power and his own survival,'' the widow of dissident leader Andrei Sakharov said. ``Is he only interested in personal power? Or is he interested in the rights of the people?'' Bonner's remarks opened the Peace Prize Forum at Augsburg College, a two-day event held in cooperation with the Norwegian Nobel Institute. Sakharov, recipient of the 1975 Nobel Peace Prize, had been scheduled to attend the forum but died Dec. 14 of a heart attack. Bonner said Gorbachev's actions have been widely misinterpreted by the West. She said revolts for democratic change in the Soviet bloc have been brewing for a long time and Gorbachev deserves credit only for not stamping them out. ``He behaves that way not because he wants them to proclaim their independence from the Communist Party, but because he could not stop it,'' Bonner said. ``He had no way of influencing events in eastern Europe.'' Despite five years of perestroika _ the political and economic restructuring sought by Gorbachev _ the Soviet Union is still wracked by economic woes that have kept 43 million people in poverty, Bonner said. Ethnic battles and civil unrest have been worsened by military intervention directed by Gorbachev, she said. ``The analysis of the Western media stops at, `Poor Gorbachev, how difficult it must be for him to govern in such circumstances,''' she said. While Gorbachev deserves credit for a progressive foreign policy, he has not offered solutions to domestic problems, Bonner said. His five-year economic plan is ``not at all different'' from a long litany of previous five-year plans. The most recent Soviet Party platform, printed in Pravda earlier this week, also is unchanged, she said. ``Although it does include some new slogans, in its substance it is not very different from previous communist party platforms,'' Bonner said. ``These thoughts have lost their meaning to the Soviet people.'' Bonner, who volunteered for the Soviet army in World War II and suffered eye damage during battle, began voicing dissent in the late 1960s when the Red Army invaded Czechoslovakia. After marrying Sakharov in 1971, she was watched by the KGB and harassed for her ties to dissident publishers. In the mid-1970s, Sakharov was arrested and sent to internal exile in the city of Gorky after criticizing Soviet military intervention in Afghanistan. In 1986, Gorbachev personally informed Sakarov and Bonner that they were free to live and work in Moscow. Bonner, 67, opened the forum with a news conference also attended by former Vice President Walter Mondale. Her remarks were interpreted by her son, Alexey. Bonner and former President Carter were to address the forum Saturday.

DOC.HEAD: Farmers Develop Conservation Plans for Eroded Croplands
DOC.TEXT: Farmers have developed conservation plans for about 134.7 million acres of highly erodible cropland, the Agriculture Department said Friday. That represents more than 96 percent of the approximately 140 million acres of highly erodible cropland targeted for plans, according to the department's Soil Conservation Service. Under 1985 farm law, farmers were to have plans drawn up and actively applying conservation practices to the land by the end of last year. The plans must be fully implemented by Dec. 31, 1994, if they want to remain eligible to USDA farm program benefits. Wilson Scaling, chief of the SCS, said conservation plans have been fully implemented on 27 percent of the eligible cropland. Of the highly erodible cropland without plans, about five million acres were temporarily exempted until soil surveys are completed, he said. Also, there is some land that is no longer being used for crops or where the person has decided not to develop a plan at this time.

DOC.HEAD: In This Corner, Wearing the Pinstriped Suit, The Donald ...
DOC.TEXT: Day six of ``Trump: The Divorce'' arrived Friday with the billionaire developer saying he had no plans to pay estranged wife Ivana $100 million in a settlement to end their marriage. ``I don't rule anything out, but it's highly unlikely'' there will a settlement negotiated beyond an existing prenuptial agreement, Trump told New York Newsday. The paper had reported a day earlier that Trump told associates he expected to pay $100 million to end the case quickly. ``It's a very simple case. It's an open and shut case,'' Trump told the newspaper. ``I'll do whatever I have to do, but I don't see a settlement of this case.'' Trump's fortune, which includes the Trump Tower, the Trump Plaza Hotel and Casino, and the Trump Shuttle, is estimated at $1.7 billion. The couple has a divorce agreement which was updated four times during their nearly 13-year marriage. It reportedly would give Ivana $25 million, a Connecticut estate and custody of their three children. While Trump was focusing on the divorce itself, media coverage was touching on everything but the couple's marriage, including more reports on purported Trump girlfriend Marla Maples. Among the more interesting items Friday were: _ Advice on divorce from Roxanne Pulitzer. ``You can fight over money and everything ese, but I hope the children are kept from all this,'' she trumpeted in USA Today. _ Word from skater Peggy Fleming, a rumored Trump flame, that she and Donald are not buddy-buddy. ``I wouldn't even call him a close friend,'' said the former Olympian. _ Columnist Liz Smith's tidbit in the New York Daily News that Trump's father, Fred, told his son, ``If you don't stop what you're doing, it's going to give me a stroke!'' _ A front-page headline in the New York Post proclaiming, ``Marla boasts to her pals about Donald: `Best sex I've ever had.''' A picture of a smug-looking Trump ran alongside the headline, with a caption reading, ``We always knew Donald Trump was a tiger in the corporate board room, but now we know he's a wildcat in the bedroom, too.'' This last item produced an angry denial from Miss Maples' agent, Chuck Jones. ``It is an absolute, vicious lie _ L-I-E,'' said Jones. ``She would never make such a statement to an absolute stranger ... It's not logical. It's stupidity.'' Miss Maples turned down the chance to pose for a ``People'' magazine cover because the story was going to focus on the Trump marriage, Jones said. He also said she turned down a $250,000 offer to tell her story to the National Enquirer. The agent also raised the possibility of legal action stemming from the stories about his client. Jones has repeatedly denied that Miss Maples, who has yet to comment publicly on the divorce, is involved romantically with Trump.

DOC.HEAD: Government Claims 175 Rebels Slain, Angola and Cuba Meet Monday
DOC.TEXT: Angolan government forces said they killed 175 U.S.-backed rebels last week, and Angolan and Cuban officials prepared to discuss troop withdrawals, Angola's state news agency ANGOP reported Friday. The rebels, belonging to Jonas Savimbi's National Union for the Total Independence of Angola, or UNITA, died in fighting in northern Uige province, central Benguela, Cuanza South, Huambo, Bie and Moxico, and Cuando Cubango in the southeast between Feb. 7 and 13, ANGOP said. Government troops captured five rebels and military hardware, and liberated 44 civilian prisoners, said the ANGOP report, which was monitored in Lisbon. The agency quoted an army statement as saying 13 UNITA members surrendered. There was no independent confirmation of the report and no government casualties were given. In a separate report, the agency said Cuban and Angolan officials would meet Monday to discuss plans for repatriating Cuban troops under regional peace accords signed by the two countries and South Africa in December 1988. Some 32,500 Cuban soldiers have left Angola under the agreements, but Havana suspended troop withdrawal last month after four Cuban soldiers died in a UNITA raid. All 50,000 Cubans are scheduled to leave by mid-1991. UNITA, backed by a reported $50 million in annual U.S. aid, has been fighting the Marxist Luanda government since Angola gained independence from Portugal in 1975. Government forces, backed by Soviet arms, launched a major offensive in southeastern Angola in late December and have been battling the rebels for control of the strategic Mavinga airstrip.

DOC.HEAD: Bright & Brief
DOC.TEXT: It's not often that depositors rush to help bail out a bank, but local supporters remember the good times with Connecticut Bank and Trust Co. ``Wait a minute,'' said Bill Faude, director of the non-profit Old State House group. ``This is good old CBT that has always been there for every civic group, shelter, soup kitchen or fund-raising drive in this town. They're the ones who drop the first shoe. They've had a member on every board. They need to know they've got some friends.'' Faude walked into the bank on Tuesday with $50,000 of Old State House funds to put in a certificate of deposit. He also drafted a letter to the hundreds of other non-profit groups in the area urging them to show their support. Faude came up with the idea last week after hearing of the financial woes affecting CBT's parent. Last month the Boston-based Bank of New England announced an anticipated 1989 loss of $1.05 billion due to the slumping real estate market. The Boston bank said it was selling $6 billion in assets as part of its recovery plan. But some municipalities withdrew funds, prompting the Boston bank to borrow money from the Federal Reserve to tide it over. CBT lost $355 million last year and lost 16 percent of its deposits during the first five weeks of this year, according to state banking reports. Faude's idea picked up momentum, with checks or promises flowing in from such groups as the Connecticut Opera, River front Recapture, the Urban League and the Connecticut Historical Society. The groups said they'd either deposit new funds or add to current CBT accounts. Sandy Bender, a bank official, said more than 80 percent of the bank's officers serve in at least one community volunteer position. The bank provided more than 300 volunteers for the Special Olympics last year, and collected more than four tons of food for a food drive. She said withdrawals from the bank have stopped, but she was impressed by the groups' outpouring of support. ``It's an extremely gracious and supportive gesture,'' Bender said.

DOC.HEAD: Illinois Farmer to Head Packers and Stockyards Administration
DOC.TEXT: Agriculture Secretary Clayton Yeutter said Friday he has named Virgil M. Rosendale, a farmer and livestock industry leader from Augusta, Ill., as head of the Packers and Stockyards Administration. The Agriculture Department agency handles fair-trade regulatory programs designed to protect consumers and members of the livestock and poultry industries from unfair, deceptive or monopolistic business practices. Rosendale has managed a 2,000-acre grain and livestock farm. He is past president of the National Pork Producers Council, former chairman of the National Livestock Meat Board, and was the first president of the National Pork Board in 1986-89. Yeutter said Rosendale, whose salary will be $81,400 a year, ``brings to the job 30 years experience running a successful livestock operation, and a wealth of leadership experience within the livestock industry.''

DOC.HEAD: Barry's Attorney Says Perjury Charges Not `Hardest' to Defend
DOC.TEXT: Reminders of past trial success by Marion Barry's attorney _ he won the last major perjury case in the nation's capital _ and Barry's own talk of federal persecution could signal defense strategy as the Washington mayor fights drug and perjury charges. ``I've tried three perjury cases before and I don't think perjury charges are the hardest to defend against,'' lawyer R. Kenneth Mundy told reporters Thursday after Barry was indicted on three felony perjury counts and five misdemeanor charges of cocaine possession. Mundy reminded reporters that two years ago he persuaded jurors to acquit the former president of the city's public university of five perjury charges as well as mail fraud and theft. The two cases have parallels that may foreshadow the type of defense Mundy will offer for the mayor. Both Barry and Robert L. Green, the former president of the University of the District of Columbia, are veterans of the 1960s civil rights movement in the South. As in the Green case, Mundy appears ready to portray Barry as a scapegoat for white federal prosecutors intent on getting a conviction at all costs. In a statement after the indictment, the mayor himself evoked the specter of persecution. Barry, undergoing treatment at a drug and alcoholism clinic in West Palm Beach, Fla., called the indictment ``a continuation of the political lynching and excesses of the Justice Department.'' In the Green case, Coretta Scott King, the widow of slain civil rights leaders Martin Luther King Jr., appeared as a character witness, as did Atlanta Mayor Andrew Young, another veteran of the Southern Christian Leadership Conference. In his summation, Mundy recalled Green's career as a civil rights worker in Alabama and Mississippi, urging jurors to ``search your hearts'' before judging him guilty or innocent. Earlier in the trial, Mundy had challenged the credibility of Green's chief accuser, who ironically is a top aide to Barry. The Barry case would seem to call for similar tactics, especially since a key witness will be a convicted drug dealer, Charles Lewis. Lewis says he used cocaine with the mayor on several occasions at a downtown hotel in late 1988. Barry is charged with lying to a grand jury when he said he nothing to do with Lewis in relation to cocaine. Four of the possession charges also stem from Barry's visits to Lewis' hotel room. In perjury cases, said Washington criminal lawyer E. Lawrence Barcella, a former federal prosecutor, ``first of all you have to establish the fact, then you have to establish the fact that someone lied about that fact. Here they are going to have a lot of difficulty establishing the fact.'' Mundy said that on these Lewis-related charges prosecutors appear to be relying on testimony rather than physical evidence of drug possession. But Barcella said ``dopeless drug cases'' are not unusual. ``There have been a lot of cases where there has been no white powder on the table,'' he said in an interview. Mundy also is laying the groundwork for a possible entrapment defense to the fifth cocaine possession charge, which stems from Barry's Jan. 18 arrest at a downtown hotel. Barry came to the hotel to see former girlfriend Rasheeda Moore, who was cooperating with the FBI. While Mundy admitted in a television interview that the FBI caught the mayor ``red-handed'' using crack cocaine, he also said that FBI videotapes of the episode show that Ms. Moore, not Barry, first mentioned the subject of cocaine. He also suggested, contrary to an FBI affidavit, that Ms. Moore lit the pipe from which the mayor smoked the drug. The Barry case was assigned Friday to U.S. District Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson, who presided at the 1987 perjury trial of former White House aide Michael K. Deaver. Jackson, who tentatively scheduled a Feb. 21 arraignment for Barry, fined Deaver $100,000 and ordered him to perform community service for lying under oath about his lobbying business. Also Friday, Walter Fauntroy, the District of Columbia's non-voting delegate to Congress, said he was ``agonizing'' over whether to run for mayor. Barry, who was first elected mayor in 1978, has given no public indication that he will not seek office again, though former supporters have been slipping away _ some urging Jesse Jackson to make the race. Calls for Barry's resignation also have been increasing _ The Washington Post said in an editorial Friday that Barry ``has lost any last claim to a position of leadership'' and should quit _ but the mayor has said he will not.

DOC.HEAD: Parliament Defies Excommunication Threat, Approves Civil Marriage
DOC.TEXT: Parliament approved civil marriage among members of the predominant Greek Orthodox Church on Friday, defying an excommunication threat by its Holy Synod. The decision is expected to lead to a break between the unicameral 50-member Greek Cypriot Parliament and the church. The pre-dawn vote after an overnight debate was 30 in favor, 12 against. The remaining members were absent. Deputies said the law was designed to bring Cyprus legislation in line with that of the European Economic Community and that a similar law in Greece has existed for years without any objection from the Greek Orthodox Church. Lawmakers accused the church of trying to retain the financial benefits _ the fees _ it gets from its monopoly on performing marriages and in divorces. The Synod issued a statement earlier calling the deputies' intention to allow civil marriage a sacrilege. The statement said, ``The Holy Synod considers it its duty to make it clear that the Church will not succumb to the arrogance of any worldly authority and will not abandon the sane sheep of the Christian flock at the mercy of wolves.'' It added that it would fight such a development ``not with weapons of the flesh, but those of the spirit, sufficiently powerful to result in excommunication.'' The Synod also warned that members of the church marrying under civil law, or attending as best man or bridesmaid at such ceremonies, would be automatically excommunicated. Glafcos Clerides, leader of the largest party, the conservative Democratic Rally, accused the synod of ``unacceptable interference in the legislative work of the House and contempt for the democratically elected representatives of the people.'' The parliamentary spokesmen of the three other parties, centrist, Socialist and Communist, branded the Synod statement variously as anachronistic, undemocratic, arrogant, insulting and completely unacceptable.

DOC.HEAD: Interview On Mardi Gras Safety Interrupted by Brick-Injured Victim
DOC.TEXT: The city's new public safety director was briefing reporters, saying it was safe to walk anywhere in the city, when he was interrupted by a man whose girlfriend had just been smashed in the face with a brick. ``Help me! Help me! She's been hurt!'' James Meleski screamed as he jumped out of his pickup while his bloodied girlfriend held her baby inside. ``Five or six guys did it over by the railroad tracks.'' Meleski had driven to City Hall for help and stopped right in front of reporters who were interviewing Reuben Greenberg, the Charleston, S.C., police chief currently on a six-month contract to help Mobile lower its crime rate. Greenberg sent police on horseback to the crime scene. Police said the brick was thrown through the pickup window shortly after a downtown Mardi Gras parade Thursday night. Greenberg said four or five males, probably juveniles, were described as the assailants. City officials posted a $1,000 reward Friday. The injured woman, Jill Gruendle, 27, of Chickasaw, was listed in fair condition at the University of South Alabama Medical Center. ``I'd like to nail them,'' Greenberg said. ``She has some very, very serious cuts to the face and probably will have permanent scarring.'' ``I want you to see everything there,'' Greenberg told reporters. ``We're going to catch them ... because you're going to put it on TV and in the newspaper and people will be so outraged that they will turn these guys in. We're going to find out who did it.'' The six mounted police officers Greenberg sent to the crime scene are from Charleston and were in Mobile to ride in Mardi Gras parades.

DOC.HEAD: Partially Burned Body of Kenyan Missing Foreign Minister Found
DOC.TEXT: The partly burned body of Kenya's foreign minister was found Friday in a cane field near his home, three days after he disappeared. The government indicated Robert Ouko had been murdered. President Daniel arap Moi said the body of the 58-year-old minister was found ``in circumstances which at the moment suggest foul play,'' about four miles from his family farm in Koru, not far from Lake Victoria. The president's statement said the body was partially burned and pledged ``that anyone who may be associated with this horrible event will most certainly be apprehended.'' Ouko, considered one of the most skilled members of Moi's Cabinet, vanished Tuesday. His disappearance went unreported until Thursday evening, when the offical Kenya News Agency broadcast an appeal from family members urging him to contact them or government officials. Moi said Ouko's death was a loss for ``the whole nation,'' calling him ``a brilliant leader, an articulate and courageous spokesman of this country and a loyal servant of the people.'' The minister appeared largely above the fray of Kenyan politics, his name rarely appearing in almost daily press accounts of rivalries within the country's single ruling party. Ouko was last seen publicly on Saturday, when he addressed a service club in Kisumu, 220 miles northwest of Nairobi and not far from his Koru home. State-run radio and television stations quoted unidentified family members Thursday night as saying no one had seen him leave his farm after he went to bed Monday night. The Kenya Times, a Nairobi daily newspaper, reported Friday that a white car arrived at Ouko's home at about 3 a.m. Tuesday and left with the minister. The paper attributed its report to two unidentified household employees. Before the discovery of Ouko's body, a senior government official, speaking on condition of anonymity, said: ``People are wondering how a full minister can disappear.'' He referred to the fact that the homes of Cabinet ministers are always guarded by armed policemen. They also use bodyguards when they travel. Ouko first served as permanent secretary in the Ministry of Foreign Affairs in 1963-64. He then held a number of other high-ranking government jobs before being tapped by Moi to head the Foreign Ministry in 1979.

DOC.HEAD: Average Residential Phone Costs Off Nearly 5 Percent
DOC.TEXT: Average residential phone costs dropped nearly 5 percent nationwide in 1989 as declining long-distance prices continued to offset increases for local phone service, the Federal Communications Commission said Friday. The commission said that based on the Labor Department's Consumer Price Index, the cost of telephone service for an average residential subscriber fell 0.3 percent during 1989. The CPI showed that local service charges increased 0.6 percent, while toll charges for in-state calls dropped 2.8 percent and interstate long-distance charges fell 1.3 percent. The FCC noted that the overall inflation rate was 4.6 percent for 1989. ``Thus, in real terms, the cost of telephone service dropped about 5 percent during the year,'' the FCC said. The 0.6 percent increase in local phone service charges was a sharp change from 1988, when such costs rose an average of 4.5 percent. The FCC also released the results of a semi-annual, 95-city survey of phone costs that showed the average monthly charge for one-party residential local service with unlimited calling was $12.28 in October 1989, compared with $12.32 a year earlier. When taxes and federal and state subscriber line charges were added in, the total local service bill averaged $17.54 in October, compared with $16.57 in October 1988. The total does not include additional charges for touch-tone service. Total local charges for unlimited, private-line service ranged from $8.14 in Anchorage, Alaska, to $27.03 in Huntington, W.Va., the FCC said. The federal subscriber line charge, which helps defray the costs of connecting the local phone system with long-distance circuits, was $3.50 per month for most residential customers in October 1989. As the subscriber line charge goes up, long-distance rates tend to go down. That is because as long-distance companies pay less for the connection charge, the FCC requires them to pass the savings along to long-distance customers. The average household spent $499 on phone bills in 1987, the most recent year for which such statistics are available, the FCC said. That compared with an average $471 in 1986.

DOC.HEAD: Brothers Brawl in Courtroom During Murder Trial
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Contents may be offensive to some readers.
DOC.TEXT: The murder trial of a man accused of helping to kill and decapitate his brother's girlfriend was halted Friday when the brothers got into a fistfight in court. The scuffle erupted as Eustaquio Deases was called to testify in the trial of his brother Ruben, who according to witnesses described the killing in the style of a rap singer. As Eustaquio, 23, was led into the courtroom, he lunged across the defense table, swinging at Ruben and cursing him. Ruben struck back, and the men scuffled until they were separated by sheriff's deputies and defense lawyers. The jury was asked to leave, and District Judge M.D. Seiser called a recess. Ruben, who turned 18 Monday, is on trial in Story County District Court for first-degree murder in the May 28 death of Jennifer Ann Gardner, 20, who shared an apartment with Eustaquio. Another brother, Edward Deases, 21, awaits trial on the same charge. Eustaquio is in prison on a federal drug charge. Another brother, Johnny Deases, testified previously that Edward and Ruben planned to kill Ms. Gardner because they believed she stood in the way of Edward's advancement in a drug-dealing business allegedly run by Eustaquio. Earlier Friday, Jack Leinen, a former youth service worker at the Meyer Hall juvenile detention center in Des Moines, testified he'd heard Ruben describe the crime, using the style of a rap song. ``She thought she was cool, and I was a fool. And now she's dead, and I'm ahead,'' Leinen recalled the defendant saying. The victim's head was found in a roadside ditch south of Ames by a jogger May 29 and her torso was discovered in a lake north of the city June 1. Glenn Kirkpatrick, a youth services worker at the State Training School at Eldora, said he overheard Ruben Deases tell another inmate ``that he had helped kill this gal and helped behead her.'' Kirkpatrick said he took the statement to be a boast and conceded in cross examination that tough-guy bragging is common among youths detained at the school. Lynn Balbanz, also a youth service worker at Eldora, said he overheard Ruben Deases rap to other inmates that his brother had killed a girl. Monica Meister said she was supervising Ruben at a laundry at the institution when he rapped, ``I knew a girl named Jennifer Gardner, she was a dancer, she was going to narc my brother off, my brother did her in and now I'm doing time.'' ``Narc off'' is an apparent reference to turning in a drug dealer, lawyers said earlier. Johnny Deases, 16, previously testified Ruben choked Ms. Gardner unconscious with his arms and that Edward strangled her with a belt.

DOC.HEAD: Farmers, Officials See No Immediate Impact of Drug Summit
With AM-Drug Summit
DOC.TEXT: Farmers and government officials say the Cartagena drug summit will have no immediate impact on Bolivia's anti-drug campaign. However, the officials are pleased that the United States recognized a shared responsibility for cocaine trafficking and will provide more financial support for alternative crops to replace coca grown by Bolivian farmers. ``In the short-term, I don't think the Cartagena summit will have much impact on fighting cocaine trafficking,'' Information Minister Manfredo Kempff told The Associated Press. ``In a medium-term, though, we should be able to count on greater collaboration from the United States.'' President Jaime Paz Zamora attended Thursday's summit in Cartagena, Colombia, along with presidents Bush, Alan Garcia of Peru and Virgilio Barco of host Colombia. In their communique, the presidents noted that persuading Andean farmers to turn from coca production to legal crops such as coffee would have ``significant, immediate and long-term economic costs'' on Colombia, Peru and Bolivia. Bush said he would request an economic aid package from Congress for fiscal years 1991-94 to help offset some of these losses, the communique said. ``Some critics say we received no firm monetary commitments,'' Kempff said. ``We went to Cartagena for the United States to understand our position, to make a firm commitment to fight against cocaine trafficking and from there intensify the fight with greater foreign collaboration. Now the effective collaboration must come.'' Evo Morales, leader of the Chapare region's coca-leaf farmers union, said the Cartagena summit did not provide concrete programs to address the needs of farmers. ``In the summit declarations there is nothing clear and it does not assure us markets or prices for alternative crops. We do not trust the Bolivian or American governments,'' Morales said. Pastor Velazquez, leader of the country's farmers confederation, said ``only general positions were approved'' at the summit. He said without more funds invested in rural areas, eradicating coca will remain ``practically paralyzed.'' Velazquez added that coffee is often mentioned as a possible alternative crop, but noted even ``Colombia is worried because the price for that product is so low.'' Under-Secretary of Justice Roger Pando said the Cartagena declaration ``backs our position of alternative development and makes it possible for the United States and Europe to understand Bolivia's investment requirements to substitute coca leaves.'' Bolivian farmers destroyed a record 3,038 acres of coca plants in December and January, and tens of thousands of coca-leaf farmers left the Chapare, the country's principal coca-leaf producing region. This was in response to a sharp drop in coca-leaf prices from the Colombian drug crackdown and increased interdiction by Bolivian police and U.S. Drug Enforcement Administration agents. In Bolivia, about 93,600 acres are devoted to coca-leaf cultivation. In Peru, however, eradication programs were suspended one year ago and there is strong sentiment among coca growers, the government and the general public against forced eradication. The government of Alan Garcia has linked voluntary eradication to receiving hundreds of millions of dollars in economic development aid to provide alternative sources of income for coca-growing peasants. In Bolivia, farmers receive $2,000 U.S. dollars for every hectare (2.4 acres) of coca destroyed. The U.S. government is providing about $40 million for fiscal year 1990 for crop substitution programs. Fifteen million dollars are budgeted this year for cocaine interdiction program. Additional U.S. funds are only now beginning to reach Bolivia due to delays in Congress. Total U.S. aid to Bolivia is about $100 million. Cocaine provides the Bolivian economy, the poorest in South America, with at least $300 million a year. The country's total legal export earnings are about twice that amount. The government says at least $500 million are needed for alternative development programs to wean farmers from coca-leaf farming. At least 250,000 farmers live from coca-leaf cultivation in the Bolivian sub-tropical lowlands. ``We will maintain a steady rhythm of eradication that is acceptable and encourage consuming nations to fulfill their obligations to help develop alternative crops,'' Kempff said.

DOC.HEAD: Owner Sentenced To Prison For Mauling Death Of Toddler
DOC.TEXT: The owner of a pit bull dog who fatally mauled a toddler who wandered within reach of its chain was ordered Friday to spend three years and eight months in prison. Michael Patrick Berry, 39, was convicted in December of involuntary manslaughter in the death of 2-year-old James Soto and three lesser charges. A Santa Clara County Superior Court jury acquitted him of second-degree murder. Berry's pit bull, Willy, mauled the child after the child wandered into Berry's yard, where the dog was tethered to a stake. Berry claimed during his trial that the toddler's parents shared the blame for his death because they allowed him to wander near the dog. The victim's father, Arthur, said he and his wife had left the boy on their back patio while they went shopping at garage sales and found him being ``torn apart'' when they came home. Deputy District Attorney Dale Sanderson acknowledged there was no evidence of malice or intent to kill but that their case was based on the theory of implied malice, which allows a murder conviction for someone whose actions show wanton disregard for human life. Willy, since the attack, has been kept alive as evidence at the Santa Clara County Humane Society, but eventually will be killed. Berry was the first person in the United States to be charged with murder because of an animal's action, according to the prosecutor and the Humane Society of the United States.

DOC.HEAD: New System Designed to Speed Traffic into Canada
DOC.TEXT: A new automated system for calculating and collecting duties will be installed to speed up traffic at 22 U.S.-Canada border crossings, officials said Friday. The system will give Canadians a quick calculation of the duties and taxes they owe on goods purchased in the United States, including an allowance for the daily exchange rate, Otto Jelinek, minister of revenue, said. ``We expect to cut the transaction time in half for Canadians required to pay duty on goods purchased out of Canada,'' Jelinek said. A large number of Canadians, lured by lower prices on a variety of goods, have taken to shopping in border areas of the United States recently. The shopping traffic has been blamed for long delays at border crossings, particularly on weekends. The system will be installed at 22 major crossings, including the four in the Buffalo and Niagara Falls, N.Y., area, by the end of April, and will eventually be installed at all Canada Customs offices, Jelinek said.

DOC.HEAD: Creditors Reschedule One-Fourth of Polish Debt to Aid New Government
DOC.TEXT: Seventeen creditor nations agreed Friday to reschedule nearly one-fourth of Poland's $40 billion foreign debt and suspend payments on it until March 1991 as a way to help the hard-pressed new non-Communist government. The agreement is the most generous so far by the informal grouping of creditor nations known as the Paris Club, said Jean-Claude Trichet, club chairman. Trichet said the arrangement, negotiated over two days, reflects Western support for the government and its radical plans for adopting a market economy. Friday's agreement allows Poland to reschedule $9.4 billion of its $27 billion debt to Paris Club nations, including $3.4 billion of arrears. The covered debt, which was due March 1, 1991, is to be spread over 14 years with an eight-year grace period on principal. Prime Minister Tadeusz Mazowiecki of Poland sent messages to creditor governments Feb. 9 asking them to suspend principal and interest payments for 1989 and 1990 on the entire $40 billion Poland owes and to consider freezing the debt, or even reducing it. Mazowiecki said the debt was the greatest threat to Poland's dramatic attempt to switch from a centrally controlled economy to a free-market system. After March 1991, Poland will pay only interest on the $9.4 billion for seven years, after which the principal is to be paid over six years. Henryk Wozniakowski deputy government spokesman, said in Warsaw the agreement will reduce payments to the West by about one-fourth. Poland had been paying about $1.5 billion a year on annual interest of $3.7 billion. Trichet described the accord as ``exceptional.'' Janusz Sawicki, head of the Polish delegation, said it was the best Poland could obtain and should be viewed as a response to the Mazowiecki's appeal, the Polish news agency PAP reported. The Paris Club agreed with Mazowiecki's suggestion that consultatons be held on the possibility of reducing the debt in cooperation with the International Monetary Fund, PAP reported. Two weeks ago, the IMF approved Poland's economic restructuring plan, which involves eliminating a huge budget deficit by cutting subsidies to unprofitable state-run industries and attracting foreign investment by establishing a convertible currency. Elimination of price controls and subsidies created 78 percent inflation for January alone. The World Bank estimates ending industrial subsidies will cost 1.7 million jobs in 1990. Poland's foreign debt is the largest in Eastern Europe. The partial payments it was making consumed nearly all its hard currency earnings, leaving little to rebuild its obsolete industry. Most of the debt was accumulated during the 1970s when Edward Gierek was Communist Party chief. He spent borrowed Western money on ill-conceived projects, and on consumer goods in an effort to win public support.

DOC.HEAD: Tornadoes, Floods In Southeast, Blizzard In West
DOC.TEXT: Thunderstorms produced tornadoes and flooding Friday in the Southeast, while a new Pacific storm rolled into the West and dumped as much as 3 feet of snow in northern California's Sierra Nevada. Tornadoes touched down at Carrollton, Ga., injuring 11 people, and at Irmo, S.C., where no injuries were reported. In Chilton County, Ala., a tornado smashed several mobile homes in the Cooper community near Clanton, and smashed the building of the volunteer fire department in the Enterprise community, police said. Flooding forced hundreds to evacuate in parts of Georgia, Tennessee, North Carolina, and Alabama. Wind gusted to 63 mph during a thunderstorm at Robins Air Force Base, Ga. A blizzard warning was posted for California's Sierra Nevada north of Yosemite National Park, and winter storm warnings were posted across western Nevada, the mountains of northern California above 1,000 feet and the Sierra Nevada south of Yosemite. Snow fell at higher elevations of the northern Sacramento Valley during the morning. At Incline Village, Nev., on Lake Tahoe, Diamond Peak spokeswoman Lee Weber said the resort had received 3 feet of new snow by midmorning and had blizzard conditions. Snow also fell on Oregon, with up to 2 feet in the mountains. In Nevada's Reno-Carson City area, the storm closed schools, snarled traffic and all but closed state and local governments. Police urged businesses to close early. Rain fell at lower elevations of northern California. Elsewhere, snow fell across northern Maine, northern Lower Michigan, Upper Michigan, northern Wisconsin, eastern Minnesota, northeastern Iowa, western Montana, Idaho, northeastern Washington, and western wyoming. Freezing rain extended over east-central New England. Showers and thunderstorms extended from southern Mississippi across southeastern Alabama, the Florida Panhandle, northwestern Georgia, western South Carolina, western North Carolina, Virginia, West Virginia, Delaware, Maryland, and northwestern Pennsylvania. Heavier rainfall during the 6 hours up to noon included 2.13 inches at Atlanta; 1.93 inches at Montgomery, Al a.; 1.29 inches at Anniston, Ala.; and 1.21 inches at Marietta, Ga., the National Weather Service said. Temperatures hit record lows in the Southwest and West, including 16 at Alamagordo, N.M.; 28 at Bakersfield, Calif.; 3 below zero at Raton, N.M.; and 30 in downtown Sacramento, Calif. But in the East, temperatures hit record highs, with 74 at Cape Hatteras, N.C.; 58 at Mansfield, Ohio, and 77 at Norfolk, Va. Temperatures around the nation at 3 p.m. EST ranged from 10 below zero at Cut Bank, Mont., to 85 at Lakeland and Melbourne, Fla. Friday's low for the Lower 48 states was 19 below zero at Gunnison, Colo.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Says China Bid To Join GATT on Hold
DOC.TEXT: Progress on a Chinese application to join an international group aimed at expanding world trade has been slowed because of questions about China's commitment to economic reforms, the State Department said Friday. It said that a number of members of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (GATT), including the United States, have expressed concern about measures China has taken ``which restrict market access and are incompatible with GATT principles.'' ``We believe these questions need to be adequately addressed before further action is possible on China's application,'' the department said in a written response to press questions. At the same time, the department said it was looking forward to the eventual inclusion of Taiwan in GATT's membership because of the island's importance in the global trading system. It added that the United States has maintained a consistent policy on GATT membership for both China and Taiwan over the years. ``We have told both parties that we want eventual access for both on meaningful terms agreed upon by GATT members,'' it said.

DOC.HEAD: Jewish Groups to Pay for Resettling Soviet Refugees
DOC.TEXT: Jewish groups concluded an agreement Friday with the U.S. government to pay for the resettling of up to 8,000 Soviet refugees _ mostly Jews _ in the United States. The Council of Jewish Federations and the Hebrew Immigrant Aid Society will cover the costs of processing and transporting the refugees and pay for their medical examinations, placement and initial resettlement for two years after they enter the country. The estimated cost is about $30 million. Besides Jews, the refugees include Armenians, Evangelical Christians, Ukrainian Catholics and Ukrainian Orthodox. The 8,000 refugees are among the 10,000 that President Bush last October decided to admit in the current fiscal year if private funding was obtained. Another 40,000 Jewish refugees from the Soviet Union are emigrating with U.S. funds. Other U.S. programs, including one known as parole, could bring in up to 30,000 more. In the first four months of this fiscal year, which began Oct. 1, 21,000 Soviet Jewish refugees have entered the United States. Some 20,000 are waiting in Rome and Vienna. They should be admitted by next summer, and the way-stations will be closed down. Processing of refugees is being switched to U.S. offices in the Soviet Union. The Jewish exodus is spurred by a more lenient Soviet emigration policy and a resurgence of overt anti-Semitism. It far exceeds the quota and thousands of Jews who might normally come here are going to Israel instead.

DOC.HEAD: Hostage Sister Arrives in Tunis for Talks With PLO
DOC.TEXT: Peggy Say, sister of the longest-held hostage in Lebanon, arrived in this North African capital Friday hoping to meet with PLO Chairman Yasser Arafat. Ms. Say said she was on a ``humanitarian pilgrimage'' seeking to ask Arafat if he ``would use his influence to get us out of this terrible impasse.'' Arafat spokesman Torgeman Bassel said he hoped the Palestine Liberation Organization leader would return to Tunis from Baghdad in time to meet Ms. Say and her group. Arafat was due to return late Friday or Saturday, Bassel said. Ms. Say is the sister of Terry Anderson, chief Middle East correspondent of The Associated Press, who was abducted by gunmen from a Beirut street on March 16, 1985. Her group arrived from Strasbourg, France, where Ms. Say appealed to the European Parliament for help in freeing the hostages. She has also met with U.N. Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar in New York and Pope John Paul II in Rome. The delegation later plans to meet UNESCO Director General Federico Mayor in Paris, Syrian Foreign Minister Farouk Al-Sharaa in Damascus and Anglican Archbishop Robert Runcie in Canterbury, England. Repeated requests to go to Iran have gone unanswered by authorities. Radical Shiite Moslem groups claiming to hold some of the hostages are believed to have ties to Tehran. Asked whether she planned to travel to Lebanon, Ms. Say said, ''My family has been through enough without my going through any foolish risks.'' In an interview with The Associated Press two years ago, Arafat adviser Bassam Abu Sharif said the best way to win Anderson's freedom would be to make an official request asking the PLO to intervene through its contacts in the Middle East. A group describing itself as Islamic Jihad, or Islamic Holy War, claims to hold Anderson and Terry Waite, Runcie's special envoy in the Middle East, who disappeared while trying to negotiate the release of the hostages Jan. 20, 1987. Eight Americans, four Britons, two West Germans, two Swiss, an Italian and an Irishman are being held in Lebanon. In Strasbourg, Ms. Say urged the European Parliament to ``hear their cries for freedom'' and seek the captives' release. ``I am their voice because they cannot speak for themselves,'' she told Enrique Baron Crespo, the Parliament's president, and Ken Coates, chairman of its human rights subcommittee. Baron said the Parliament will debate the hostage issue next month and issue a resolution to governments in the Middle East. Some Middle Eastern nations hope for improved relations with the 12-nation European Community, Baron told Ms. Say, saying such help would come only if they help in efforts to free the captives. Ms. Say is accompanied on her tour by Don Mell, an AP photographer who was with Anderson when he was abducted, and Larry Heinzerling, a deputy director of The AP, which is financiall and logistically supporting Ms. Say's efforts in pressing its own efforts to win Anderson's release.

DOC.HEAD: More Unrest in Volatile Kosovo Province
DOC.TEXT: Several thousand ethnic Albanians demonstrated in Kosovo and thousands of pupils stayed out of school to protest the virtual state of emergency in the violence-ridden southern province. About 1,000 children marched peacefully through Titova Mitrovica, 30 miles north of Pristina, the provincial capital, with their hands raised in V signs, local journalists said. School attendance in the province was low because most ethnic Albanian students stayed away in ``a massive boycott of classes,'' the official Yugoslav news agency Tanjug reported. Ninety percent of Kosovo's 1.9 million people are ethnic Albanians. Belgrade radio said 1,000 people protested in Podujevo, 20 miles north of Pristina, demanding an end to the year-old state of emergency. It said riot police were present, but did not interfere. Podujevo was a focus of protests and riots last month in which at least 26 ethnic Albanians were killed. Violence began last year after Serbia, the largest of Yugoslavia's six republics, made constitutional changes that gave it almost total control over the poor southern region adjacent to Albania. Before that, Kosovo was an autonomous province within Serbia. Recent unrest has been directed at the strict security measures imposed after the violence last year, and against alleged human rights abuses by authorities. ``Forces in Serbia that are interested in perpetuating tension in Kosovo have succeeded in blocking every attempt to solve existing problems,'' the Democratic Alliance of Kosovo, a new independent group, said in a statement Friday. Serbian authorities claim the predominantly Moslem ethnic Albanians harass the Slavic minority in Kosovo, which was the heart of medieval, Christian Serbia. The alliance, which claims more than 200,000 members, is not officially recognized and authorities have called it a front for ethnic Albanian ``separatists and terrorists,'' terms often used to describe the autonomy movement. Five people were sentenced Friday to 40 days in jail for organizing a strike by ethnic Albanians last month in Urosevac, 30 miles south of Pristina, Tanjug reported. A province-wide general strike was in progress at the time to protest the deaths in January. A prosecution witness in the trial of 15 ethnic Albanians accused of inciting a 10-day strike at the Trepca lead and zinc mine in Kosovo last year, described them as ``no more to blame than anyone else,'' Tanjug reported. It quoted Ferid Fejka, a mine worker, as telling the court: ``Their demands were the demands of all the strikers.'' Among the defendants is Azen Vllasi, the popular former Communist Party chief of Kosovo. They are charged with ``counterrevolutionary activities,'' for which the maximum penalty is death.

DOC.HEAD: Bushes Head to Maine for Long Weekend
Precede WASHINGTON
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Top three grafs new with arrival, one graf edited for transition; picks up 3rd graf WASHINGTON: ``The president;'' INSERTS 4th graf: ``National security,'' with Scowcroft remark; ADDS two grafs on house and activities; adds byline
DOC.TEXT: President Bush and his wife, Barbara, flew to their oceanfront home Friday for the three-day Presidents' Day weekend. The president landed at Pease Air Force Base across the state line in New Hampshire in fog as darkness was falling. The weather forced Bush to drive to Kennebunkport, a 40-minute trip, instead of making a far quicker helicopter trip. The area was covered with snow and the temperature was 27 degrees compared with an unseasonable warm 64 degrees in Washington when the president left. Before his departure, Bush held a Cabinet meeting, had lunch with Vice President Dan Quayle and conferred with Secretary of State James A. Baker III. The president, who returned late Thursday from the drug summit in Cartagena, Colombia, laughed at the outset of the Cabinet meeting when reporters asked if he would talk to them. National security adviser Brent Scowcroft told reporters flying with the president that Bush told Cabinet members, ``We want this thing to work,'' in reporting on the Cartagena meeting. Bush told reporters Thursday he planned to cut back on news conferences because of reports accusing him of giving misleading answers. He had two news conferences in Colombia after saying that. ``This is a photo opportunity and we've got a lot of business to do,'' Bush said at the outset of the Cabinet meeting. When a reporter asked if he was still upset with the media, Bush said kiddingly, ``I'm going to get upset if you don't get the hell out of here.'' The Bushes planned to see how remodeling work is progressing on the family home overlooking the Atlantic at Walker's Point in Kennebunkport. The Bushes decided to remodel some rooms as a gift to each other on their 45th wedding anniversary last month. Only two rooms now can be heated in the winter, a bedroom and a kitchen. Spokesman Steve Hart said the Bushes planned to spend the weeekend ``privately relaxing,'' with no planned activities and no guests, before returning to Washington on Monday.

DOC.HEAD: Couple Conceives Baby in Effort To Save Older Daughter From Cancer
LaserPhoto LA8
DOC.TEXT: A couple conceived a child in hopes the baby's bone marrow cells could save the life of a teen-age daughter who is dying of cancer, but ethics experts said Friday the decision is outrageous and troubling. Such criticism means little to Abe Ayala and his wife, Mary. They found out this week that despite one-in-four odds, their unborn baby girl will be a compatible bone marrow ``stem cell'' donor for their 17-year-old daughter, Anissa, who was diagnosed with leukemia two years ago. ``We've been searching for a donor for almost two years and we haven't been able to find anybody, so this is the only other alternative,'' Ayala said in a telephone interview Friday. ``We can't just stand idly by and do nothing about it and wait for Anissa to die.'' The Ayalas live in the Los Angeles suburb of Walnut with Anissa and a 19-year-old son, Airon. They were told that Anissa has a 70 percent to 80 percent chance of surviving if she receives a transplant of stem cells _ bone marrow cells that help produce various blood cells _ but no chance if she doesn't, her father said. None of the Alayas have compatible marrow. So against the advice of Anissa's doctor and after years of resisting his wife's wish to have another child, the 45-year-old Ayala had his vasectomy reversed last year. Mrs. Alaya, 43, is due to deliver a baby girl in April. If not for Anissa's leukemia, ``it's true we would have never had another baby this late,'' Ayala said. ``It is troublesome to say the least,'' medical ethics expert Philip Boyle said from The Hastings Center think tank in Briarcliff Manor, N.Y. ``It's outrageous that people would go to this length.'' ``The ideal reason for having a child is associated with that child's own welfare _ to bring a child into being and to nurture it,'' said Alexander Morgan Capron, a professor of law and medicine at the University of Southern California. ``One of the fundamental precepts of ethics ... is that each person is an end in himself or herself, and is never to be used solely as a means to another person's ends without the agreement of the person being used,'' he said. The baby can't consent to the transplant, and the parents face a conflict of interest in making the decision, the experts said. The Ayalas' baby ``is not seen as an end in itself, but as a means to another end. The fact that the other end is laudable doesn't change that,'' Capron said. Anissa said Friday she is ``sort of upset'' by such criticism of her parents, but ``we're going to love our baby.'' Mrs. Ayala added, ``Our baby is going to have more love than she probably can put up with.'' Leukemia is a cancer of white blood cells. Doctors use high-dose radiation and chemotherapy to kill diseased bone marrow and blood cells. Then marrow from a matching donor, usually a sibling, is injected into the leukemia patient's bones so healthy stem cells from the marrow can produce healthy blood cells. Ayala said his daughter's leukemia is now stable, and doctors expect she will be alive even if they have to wait until her baby sister is 6 months old, the youngest age at which marrow can be transplanted. However, Anissa's doctors at City of Hope National Medical Center in suburban Duarte hope to make the marrow transplant unnecessary by obtaining stem cells from the baby's umbilical cord blood at the time of birth, a painless procedure, hospital spokesman Charles Mathews said. The doctors have said the baby faces little risk even if she is needed to donate marrow. The procedure requires the infant to be put under general anesthesia to block pain while needles are used to remove the marrow. ``The problem remains: a child will have been created for the purpose of being a donor,'' Capron said. The Ayalas' decision means ``we're willing to treat people like objects, and I don't think we ought to do that,'' Boyle said. He said similar reasoning might be used to justify ``fetus farming'' so live infants could be used as organ donors, or to rationalize conceiving fetuses so they can be aborted and their tissues used for life-saving purposes such as treating Parkinson's disease patients. Mrs. Ayala said she and her husband ``prayed hard'' before making their decision, and ethics experts should be worrying about the grave need for more organ and marrow donors rather than questioning their decision. ``There are thousands of people out there who are dying and need bone marrow transplants,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: Israeli Aircraft Attack Amal Base in Southern Lebanon
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout with Amal source reporting attack, no injuries, Israeli warning against Amal, background
DOC.TEXT: Israeli aircraft staged a surprise attack on a southern Lebanese base of the Shiite Moslem group Amal on Friday, the military command said. An Amal source said two Israeli helicopter gunships dropped four rockets into an empty Amal position but that no casualties were reported to Amal headquarters in Beirut. The Israeli army said the attack was in Al-Hajjah, a village six miles south of the Lebanese port of Sidon, and a staging point for joint attacks by Amal and the Palestinian groups. The Amal source said the position was near the Shiite town of Zifta, about 2{ miles southeast of Al-Hajjah. The army did not say what type of aircraft took part in the attack but that all returned safely. It was Israel's fourth air raid into Lebanon this year, and army sources said it came two days after a Palestinian attack in Israel's self-proclaimed security zone in southern Lebanon. The last Israeli attack was Jan. 25 against a Palestinian guerrilla base of the Abu Nidal faction east of Sidon. ``Israel has no absolutely no interest in a confrontation with the Amal movement but if this process continues Israel would not be able to sit idly and will have to respond,'' an Israeli army official said. The attack on Amal was highly unusual since that movement has been widely described by Israeli military observers as being at odds with Israel's fiercest enemies in south Lebanon _ Palestinian guerrillas and the radical Shiite Hezbollah, or Party of God group. However, Israeli army sources said Palestinian groups ``were assisted by senior Amal commanders'' at least three times in sending squads to carry out attacks in Israel's ``security zone'' in south Lebanon. One was a Jan. 26 incident in which an Israeli army officer was injured in a mine explosion in south Lebanon and soldiers also came under light arms fire in a separate attack, said the sources, speaking on condition of anonymity. The Democratic Front for the Liberation of Palestine, a Syrian-based Palestine Liberation Organization faction led by Nayef Hawatmeh, claimed responsibility for the shooting. The sources cited a Feb. 3 clash in which two guerrillas of the Palestine Liberation Front, led by terrorist mastermind Abul Abbas or Mohammed Abbas, were killed in a firefight with Israeli troops in the security zone. There were no Israeli casualties. In addition, Amal assisted in the Democratic Front's infiltration of the zone Wednesday, the sources said. One guerrilla was shot and killed by Israeli troops, and Israeli-backed South Lebanon Army militiamen captured three others. The mostly Christian, 2,500-member militia helps Israeli troops in patrolling the security zone, a 2{-to-12-mile-deep strip, designed as a buffer against border attacks by Palestinian and Shiite Moslem guerrillas. Israel carved out the zone in June 1985 as it withdrew the bulk of its troops from Lebanon following a three-year campaign.

DOC.HEAD: Former Soul Singer Sentenced to Four Years in Prison
DOC.TEXT: Veteran soul singer Ike Turner was sentenced Friday to four years in prison on cocaine charges, and a prosecutor said he hopes jail will help the 58-year-old one-time music star. ``Our hope is that when he gets out he'll do something along the lines of rehabilitation,'' said Deputy District Attorney Ralph Mayer. ``He's not the type of criminal that's in any way violent or selling the drugs. He's just a 20-year abuser of the drugs who should have been caught a long time ago.'' Turner admitted in 1986 that he had been addicted to cocaine for 15 years. Following sentencing by Superior Court Judge Robert Altman, Turner was handed over to a Los Angeles County sheriff's deputy for delivery to a state prison. Mayer said he didn't know which prison. ``It's the first time he's been to state prison,'' said Mayer. ``Four years for a man in his late 50s, he'll be over 60 when he gets out. I think that's appropriate.'' Last month, a Superior Court jury convicted the ex-husband of Grammy winner Tina Turner of two drug misdemeanors, driving under the influence of cocaine and being under the influence of cocaine. The panel deadlocked on two felony charges, transportation of cocaine and possession of cocaine for sale, forcing a mistrial. Turner then pleaded guilty, avoiding another trial, Mayer said. Mayer also consolidated a Los Angeles possession of cocaine case pending against Turner. A two-year sentence on that charge will run concurrently. The charges stem from an Aug. 19, 1987, arrest by sheriff's deputies who stopped Turner after the car he was in was seen traveling erratically in West Hollywood. Deputies found crystallized cocaine in a dental floss container and in a packet of foil. A Clarksdale, Miss., native, Turner was a backup rhythm and blues musician in the early 1950s. He went on to lead his own group, the Ikettes, before forming the Ike and Tina Turner Review with his former wife. The latter group, known for all-out, high-energy performances, had a string of hit records, including ``Proud Mary'' and ``River Deep, Mountain High.'' In 1976, after nearly 16 years of marriage, the two divorced.

DOC.HEAD: Rebels Claim Capture of Three More Sudanese Garrisons
DOC.TEXT: Rebels said Friday they had overrun three more government garrisons in southern Sudan and beaten back a military convoy trying to stage a rescue mission. In a clandestine radio broadcast, the Sudan People's Liberation Army said it captured Kologi in southern Kordofan province on Wednesday ``after seven days of heavy fighting preceded by a one-month siege.'' The broadcast said rebel forces also ambushed a 33-vehicle convoy, including four tanks, that was trying to reach Kologi and ``forced it to retreat with heavy losses.'' The rebels also claimed the capture of two smaller garrison towns, Bazia on Jan. 24 and Amati on Wednesday. The report could not be independently confirmed, but if true would bring to more than 15 the number of garrisons captured by the rebels the past three months.

DOC.HEAD: Soviets Say They Were Satisfied with Access to Bases
DOC.TEXT: The head of a delegation of Soviet lawmakers said Friday that his group was satisfied with its access to U.S. military bases and that the Soviet Union would be more forthcoming when Americans return the visit. Vladimir L. Lapygin, a member of the Supreme Soviet Presidium, spoke at a news conference after a meeting with the House Armed Services Committee to discuss ways to assure a smooth transition to a more peaceful co-existence. ``Let's decide about some specific issue to get from words to deeds,'' Lapygin told committee Chairman Les Aspin, D-Wis. The 10-member group, on a 12-day tour, has visited military bases, Los Alamos National Laboratories, NORAD, a Minuteman II missile site and the Strategic Air Command in Nebraska. On Saturday, the group was to visit the Tactical Air Command at Langley Air Force Base in Virginia and an Army chemical weapon facility at Fort McClellan, Ala. On Sunday, they planned to vist the Kennedy Space Center and Walt Disney World in Florida. Lapygin said some troop levels must be maintained despite mutual concerns about how to ease the return of soldiers to civilian life and convert war industries to peacetime use. ``We have to secure peace,'' Lapygin said, speaking through an interpreter. Aspin mentioned some areas of possible cooperation, including the conversion of industries and precautions against the accidental launch of missiles. ``I think that's a big area, the accidental launch,'' Aspin said. ``If you have a brand new relationship between the two countries there's a lot you can do in those areas.'' Aspin said his committee, which sponsored the trip, struggled with the Pentagon to give the Soviets as much access as possible. When gifts were exchanged, Aspin and other Americans were given fragments of an SS-20 missile that was destroyed in the presence of Aspin's delegation during a visit a year ago. The Soviets received paperweights with an etching of the Capitol. In a jovial exchange, Lapygin volunteered his telephone number at the Supreme Soviet, saying, ``Call us on the red phone and I'll find who you need.''

DOC.HEAD: Aoun's Gunners Hit Hospital, Orphanage
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 14 grafs to UPDATE casualties, include Eim Rummaneh falling, air force defection, details. Picks up 10th, `Police said' and DELETES last 2 grafs, which superseded
DOC.TEXT: Gen. Michel Aoun's gunners directed withering fire at rival militia strongholds Friday in the battle for Christian supremacy, but some of the shells landed on a hospital and an orphanage. Administrators of the Hotel Dieu hospital, which took 20 direct hits, and the Notre Dame orphanage said they would have to close if the shelling continued. A tank assault routed Samir Geagea's Lebanese Forces militia from the Ein Rummaneh district, its main stronghold in east Beirut, and imperiled Karantina and Ashrafiyeh, the militia's remaining strongpoints in the city. Survivors from the militia garrison in Ein Rummaneh withdrew to Ashrafiyeh at sundown ``after burning 23 bodies of slain comrades,'' a police spokesman reported. Lebanese Forces headquarters accused Aoun of using incendiary shells in the ``criminal'' bombardment of Ein Rummaneh and Ashrafiyeh. The militia has about 6,000 regulars and several thousand reservists. After Ein Rummaneh fell, Geagea said on Christian radio stations: ``I call the whole world and all Lebanese officials, especially the legitimate authority, to shoulder their full responsibilities ... to save Lebanon from this destructive catastrophe.'' That may have been an appeal to President Elias Hrawi and Syria to invervene. Syria has 40,000 soldiers in Lebanon under an Arab League peacekeeping mandate issued in 1976, and Aoun fought a six-month artillery war with them last year. Hrawi was elected by Parliament in November, with Syrian support, to implement a peace plan negotiated last fall. He dismissed Aoun as military commander, but the general has refused to step aside and commands about 19,000 men. Lebanon's air force, consisting of four Hawker Hunter fighter-bombers from World War II, declared allegiance to Hrawi on Friday. Police said the planes were flown from Halat airbase in Christian territory to the Kleiaat base in a part of north Lebanon under Syrian control. The police spokesman, whose name cannot be used under standing rules, said the planes might used against Aoun if Hrawi decided to intervene with troops from Lebanese army units or military help from the Syrians. A 16-hour Aoun offensive Thursday, using 36 tanks and about 900 soldiers, captured a ring of buildings around Ein Rummaneh. Police said 20 people were killed and 54 wounded in the attack. A total of 98 combatants have been reported killed since the battle began Jan. 30. As is usual in major battles of Lebanon's 15-year-old civil war, most of the casualties have been civilians. By police count, 583 people have been killed and 1,829 wounded in the struggle for control of the 310-square-mile enclave north and east of Beirut where 1 million Christians live. It is the worst intra-Christian fighting of the civil war. Police said the main Lebanese Forces clinic was captured Thursday and the militia arranged with the Shiite Moslem militia Amal to move wounded from Ein Rummaneh to the Moslem district of Shiyah, across Beirut's sectarian dividing line, Witnesses reported seeing at least two wounded militiamen carried on stretchers to Shiyah and taken in Amal ambulances to American University Hospital in Moslem west Beirut, which is patrolled by Syrian soldiers. The hospital is said to be treating 17 wounded members of the Lebanese Forces, which is the largest Christian militia and has fought Lebanese Moslems, Syrians and Palestinians throughout the civil war. Hospital spokesman Radwan Mawlawi would not confirm or deny the presence of Christian militiamen, but staff members confirmed said some were admitted late Thursday. One staffer said at least four were in critical condition and operated on. Observers said Amal was ``returning a favor'' to the Lebanese Forces, which helped evacuate and hospitalize trapped Amal fighters from Shiyah during a battle with Palestinian guerrillas in 1982. Alain Tessier, the French director of the Hotel Dieu hospital, said in a statement that ``every vital facility in the hospital has been hit. We cannot continue offering serious service.'' Police said the three-story hospital on the edge of Ashrafiyeh, which is supported by the French government, took at least 20 direct direct hits from Aoun's 155mm howitzers. Gunners shooting at another militia stronghold hit the mountaintop Notre Dame orphanage in Harissa, north of Beirut. Notre Dame asked that the orphans be evacuated ``as soon as possible, because we cannot continue providing them with our services.''

DOC.HEAD: Prince Returns to Florida for Polo, Charity
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 8 grafs to CORRECT Charles' age to 40 sted 41, team name to Ponte Vedra sted Ponte Verde; UPDATE with match played. Pick up 6th graf pvs, `The teams...
DOC.TEXT: Britain's Prince Charles took to the polo field Friday before a crowd swelled by royalty watchers, and his team won the first of two matches he was scheduled to play for charity. Nearly 2,000 people had tickets for the sold-out event. The tournament, played under extremely tight security, was the first scheduled public appearance in the Prince of Wales' week-long visit to the United States. The 40-year-old heir to the British throne arrived in Vero Beach on Friday afternoon, guarded by British and U.S. security officers. Wearing a cream-colored uniform with red letters, the prince joined the local Windsor Park team for a match with Canada's Maple Leaf team at the Windsor Park Polo Club, about 10 miles north of Vero Beach in the community of Orchid. Charles didn't score in his team's 11-7 victory. At one point, he broke the top off his mallet. Justin Fletcher, 18, of Vero Beach, working at the match, got to keep the mallet when Charles had it replaced. ``I think I'll frame it,'' Fletcher said. In Friday's first match, White Birch _ featuring Gonzalo Piernes, rated by many as the world's top polo player _ defeated Ponte Vedra 12-10 to advance. The prince's team will face White Birch on Sunday. The teams are competing for the Prince of Wales Cup, which the prince's team won 10-7 last year over Greenwich at the Windsor Club. Before Sunday's match, the prince is to appear at a $250-a-plate lunch at the club and watch a display of wild and endangered animals, including a baby cheetah and an aardvark. Charles will address the 550 expected luncheon guests on wildlife conservation. The prince has no public appearances planned Saturday and is expected to remain at the mansion of friends Geoffrey and Jorie Kent. Forty workers reportedly spent months renovating a wing of the mansion for the prince, who is traveling without his wife, Diana, or their children. Balconies were added to the prince's room and on the third-story observation tower with a vista of the Atlantic Ocean and Indian River. Security surrounding Charles includes dozens of bodyguards, State Department officials and police officers assigned round-the-clock. Sheriff's Lt. Paul Lekanides said he was assigning 12 to 15 off-duty deputies for round-the-clock security at the polo ground alone. During the polo matches, a special ambulance will be ready exclusively for the prince, said Indian River County chief paramedic Jim Judge. Sections of the coastal Route A1A will be closed to traffic and pedestrians, said security coordinator Jerry Burr. The prince is to visit the Kennedy Space Center on Monday before flying to Charleston, S.C., for an international business conference. His plans call for him to go to Washington where he will meet with President Bush and discuss environmental issues with the British ambassador.

DOC.HEAD: Defense Minister Resigns After Protest by Officers
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 9th graf `In Militaru's...' with 4 grafs to UPDATE with demonstrations reported in two other cities; government TV acknowledging officers' complaints. Pickup 10th `Soldiers battled...'
DOC.TEXT: Defense Minister Nicolae Militaru either quit or was fired Friday after a five-day protest by officers who demanded he be dismissed for serving the dictatorship of Nicolae Ceausescu. A brief announcement on state television indicated Militaru, who is 74 and came out of retirement to head the ministry after Ceausescu's downfall, did not go voluntarily. Ceausescu was overthrown Dec. 22 and executed Dec. 25. ``The president of the provisional Council of National Unity, Ion Iliescu, has accepted the request to remove Army Gen. Nicolae Militaru from the office of minister of national defense,'' the television reported. Who requested the removal was not clear. It said Lt. Gen. Victor Anastase Stancalescu, economy minister and first deputy defense minister, was appointed to replace him. The demand for Militaru's resignation was the first army challenge to the government it helped create. Hundreds of officers had remained outside government headquarters since Monday, demanding Militaru and Interior Minister Mihai Chitac be dismissed for links to Ceausescu and alleged action against demonstrators in Timisoara, the western city where the December revolution began. Most of them left Victory Square early Friday, after the government promised to investigate their complaints. The announcement of Militaru's removal indicated they may have been told of it in advance. Other demonstrations took place in Timisoara and the Black Sea port of Constanta, the officers said. In Militaru's defense, the television said he played a special part in defeating the ``terrorist forces that supported Ceausescu's dictatorial regime in Romania.'' But the statement read on TV also cited the officers' complaint that Militaru stirred discontent in the army. ``Some of the measures and methods used by the leadership of the Ministry of National Defense caused dissatisfaction within the army, thus contributing to the emergence of a state of tension which could have been avoided,'' it said. Soldiers battled agents of the dreaded Securitate secret police for several days after the fall of the Communist dictator, who had been in power 24 years. Four Securitate officers went on trial Friday in Bucharest. They are charged with helping Ceausescu flee by obtaining a helicopter that took the dictator and his wife, Elena, who was tried and executed with him, from the capital to Snagov, 20 miles to the north. Late Thursday, the television showed edited film of Vice Premier Gelu Voican meeting with 58 officers, listening to their complaints and promising to investigate. ``Why allow the army to be destabilized for the sake of one man?'' a colonel asked. ``After years of living a life of leisure,'' he said, Militaru ``cannot know (what) reforms are so drastically needed.'' A Border Guards officer accused Chitac, the interior minister, of personal involvement in suppression of protesters in Timisoara. The army turned against Ceausescu on Dec. 22 and fought the Securitate. Other officers were shown saying many of their fellows who opposed the revolution still were in uniform.
