One spoke of ``majors who shot into the demonstrators about 7-10 minutes with an automatic rifle.'' Another said the army had been ``killing innocent people,'' and added: ``We were shooting each other.'' ``We didn't know for sure on which side each commander was,'' a captain said. ``What are these compromised people still doing here?'' None of the officers was identified by name. The broadcast seemed to reflect a pledge by the new broadcasting chief, Razvan Teodorescu, that state televison would give more time to independent views. Opposition parties have accused the National Salvation Front, which took power during the revolution, of using official media against them.

DOC.HEAD: Baker Says Soviet Leader Is In Control
DOC.TEXT: Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev unquestionably is in control of his country even though opposition is building, Secretary of State James A. Baker III said Friday. ``He handled it,'' Baker said on the MacNeil-Lehrer NewsHour about Gorbachev's command of last week's meeting of the Central Committee of the Communist Party. ``I don't think there is any question he is in control,'' Baker said, adding that Gorbachev strengthened his political hand at the meeting. However, referring to economic problems and strains between ethnic groups in the Soviet Union, Baker said ``there's no question but that he is confronted with very, very difficult problems.'' Baker met with Gorbachev for four hours Feb. 9, two days after the end of the meeting that voted to end the Communist Party's monopoly on political power.

DOC.HEAD: Former Tennis Star Bjorn Borg Loses Libel Lawsuit
DOC.TEXT: Bjorn Borg and his wife Loredana lost a $40,000 libel lawsuit Friday against a Swedish gossip weekly that published an uncomplementary article about Mrs. Berte-Borg. The national news agency TT said a civil court acquitted Hant i Veckan because it did not find the weekly's information legally ``offensive.'' The article, published shortly before the couple married in September, insinuated the Italian rock singer was being unfaithful. TT said Mrs. Berte-Borg cried during the testimony. The article ``is an insult to the love that unites Bjorn and me,'' she was quoted as telling the court. Borg, the former tennis star, is involved in five legal battles, including a $600,000 libel suit against another Swedish weekly that published allegations by his former girlfriend, Jannike Bjorling, that he used cocaine.

DOC.HEAD: Avianca Limits Expenses for Relatives of Crash Victims
DOC.TEXT: Colombia's Avianca Airlines is cutting off expense money to families of the victims of last month's Boeing 707 crash on Long Island, which killed 73 people. The airline paid hotel bills through Thursday for relatives of the victims, _ 85 of whom survived the Jan. 25 crash and many of whom are hospitalized on Long Island. After that, the airline will advance no more than $2,500 per passenger ``in order to alleviate any personal hardship sustained as a result of the hospitalization of the injured passenger,'' according to a Feb. 14 letter from Avianca to the victims' relatives. A copy of the letter was provided by a lawyer for some victims of Flight 52. ``It is the most callous, disgraceful thing I've ever heard of, especially in view of the fact that they owe them a minimum of $75,000 under the Warsaw Convention,'' said Kenneth P. Nolan, a Manhattan lawyer specializing in aviation accidents who represents 10 crash victims. The Warsaw Convention limits damages on international flights to $75,000 per person, unless victims can prove willful misconduct by the airline, in which case victims can sue for more than $75,000. Avianca is ``going to take that $2,500 out of the $75,000, so all they're doing is advancing them money that is owed to them,'' Nolan said. He said he thought Avianca should make the full $75,000 available to crash victims now. Seventy-three people died in the crash. Avianca also pledged in the letter to ``continue to pay the medical and hospital expenses of the surviving passengers ... as well as medically necessary outpatient care,'' and to provide return transportation to Colombia for immediate family once the patient is released from the hospital. Avianca referred calls for comment to its lawyer, Michael Holland of Condon & Forsyth in Manhattan. He is out of the country until Tuesday, and an associate, George Tompkins, did not immediately return a call for comment. Nolan said that among those who will be hurt by the $2,500 limit on expenses is a woman who traveled to Long Island from Colombia to be near her 20-year-old daughter, Astrid Ballesteros Lopez, while she recuperates at Glen Cove Community Hospital. The daughter ``has had surgery for a broken ankle, both her legs, she broke her arm, she fractured her skull, she has her jaw wired for a fractured jaw, she had some facial reconstruction and she may have potential brain damage,'' said Nolan, who represents the woman. ``She doesn't speak the language and her mother wants to visit her every day to help her physically and psychologically,'' he said. ``Her own doctor says she will be in the hospital for months.'' He said his other clients include people who live in the metropolitan area but whose families need money to live on while the breadwinner recovers from crash injuries.

DOC.HEAD: Opposition Will Accept Clean Victory by Sandinistas
LaserPhoto MGA2
DOC.TEXT: The main opposition coalition will recognize a victory by the ruling leftist Sandinista Party if next week's elections are fair, an opposition official said Friday. Also Friday, two people were killed 85 miles northeast of Managua but versions differed as to whether it was an attack by U.S.-backed Contras on Sandinista supporters or a holdup. Antonio Lacayo, campaign manager for the United National Opposition (UNO), predicted his coalition will win the Feb. 25 election by 15 percent over the Sandinistas. But Lacayo, son-in-law of the group's presidential candidate Violeta Barrios de Chamorro, said that in the ``remote chance of a Sandinista victory'' the coalition would be willing to accept it, provided international observers declared the elections free and fair. ``If the majority decides the next government should be one of the Sandinista Front, I believe that we at UNO will respect the results. Dona Violeta has said so very clearly; this is democracy,'' he told a news conference. Lacayo also dismissed an exchange of threats between the coalition's vice presidential candidate, Virgilio Godoy, and President Daniel Ortega, calling them simply ``campaign speeches.'' Ortega had demanded an explanation of statements Godoy made in speeches that the coalition was going to ``make the Sandinistas pay'' after the elections. In campaign speeches, Ortega _ who is seeking reelection for a six-year term _ returned the threat. He said that if his Sandinistas win, they will shut down Mrs. Chamorro's newspaper, La Prensa, and confiscate her house and that of Godoy's. ``UNO, in its government program ... emphasizes national reconciliation ... and is completely incompatible with making anybody pay,'' Lacayo said. Ortega said in the town of Boaco that Contra rebels attacked Sandinista supporters on their way a campaign rally there. ``But the people, without weapons ... jumped on them and stoned them,'' he said. Ortega's was the third version so far of the incident 3 miles outside Juigalpa at around 7:30 a.m. Friday. Carlos Jose Estrada, who said he witnessed the incident, said two Contras in camouflage uniform and carrying AK-47 rifles stopped two pickup trucks carrying Sandinistas to the rally. He said one passenger, identified as Armengor Espinoza, shot and killed one Contra; the other Contra returned fire and killed Espinoza and wounded another passenger. But the receptionist at the Camilo Ortega Hospital in Juigalpa, where all victims were taken, said the attackers were masked highway robbers, not Contras. Defense and Interior ministry spokesmen in Managua said they had no information on the attack other than what they heard on the radio, and repeated telephone calls to police in Juigalpa did not get through.

DOC.HEAD: ETA Releases Businessman After Holding Him Nearly Three Months
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout with details of his release. No pickup
DOC.TEXT: A businessman kidnapped nearly three months ago by the Basque separatist group ETA was released unharmed in the woods outside town Friday night, the Spanish national radio said. Adolfo Villoslada, owner of a construction company in Pamplona, capital of the Navarre area bordering the three-province northern Basque region, was left hooded and tied to a tree, the radio said. He managed to untie himself and hitchhiked home. ``They have treated me well,'' he said of his captors after the ordeal that left him tired and pale with a full beard. ETA, a Basque-language acronym for homeland and liberty, seeks independence from Spain for the Basque region. It claimed responsibility for his kidnapping Nov. 24. Witnesses had said Volloslada was abducted by at least two gunmen, who forced him to drive from his Pamplona apartment building garage in his own car. The car was later found abandoned in a nearby town. The radio report made no mention of a ransom paid for his release. A local newspaper, Diario de Navarra, said Wednesday that Villoslada's family had already paid ETA an undetermined ramson. In the past, ETA has extorted money it calls ``revolutionary taxes'' from Spanish businessmen to finance its violent campaign for independence. Since taking up arms in 1968, ETA has claimed responsibility for killing more than 600 people, mainly police, military and civil guard officers, and for numerous bombings and kidnappings.

DOC.HEAD: Paper Reports Plan to Reorganize Polish Radio, Television
DOC.TEXT: One-third of the managers and directors of state radio and television have been replaced and the pro-Solidarity broadcast chief plans a full reorganization this spring, a newspaper reported Friday. Most of the new management people are former television journalists and directors who had been out of the field since martial law was imposed in December 1981 to crack down on Solidarity, the newspaper Gazeta Wyborcza reported. After martial law was declared, journalists were required to ``verify'' their loyalty to the Communist government and many were forced out. Bitterness toward Communist manipulation of the media, particularly television, to fight the opposition and create antipathy toward the West fed the public's desire for changes when the non-Communist government gained power in August. After becoming the first non-Communist prime minister in Eastern Europe, journalist Taduesz Mazowiecki appointed Solidarity journalist Andrzej Drawicz to run the Radio and Television Committee. Drawicz said there would be no witch hunt but newscasters most closely associated with the martial law period would be removed. The evening television news acquired a new name and look, and more open and varied programming was added. About the public clamor for more changes, Drawics told the pro-Solidarity newspaper: ``I hope to end this discussion in late spring.'' Under a draft proposal, radio and television would be governed by a supervisory board of four members recommended by Parliament, four chosen by the prime minister and one from the broadcast employee council, Gazeta Wyborcza reported. There are proposals to make one of the two television channels commercial and sell some air time to private producers. According to the paper, 40 of 124 television managers and all chiefs of regional television centers have been replaced and Drawicz recalled all television correspondents posted to countries of the Soviet bloc. Stefan Truszczynski, new head of the Warsaw television center, worked for a foreign trade company until recently and directed broadcast activities for Solidarity during negotiations with the governent in spring 1989, it said. Other new managers made films for the Roman Catholic church or held unrelated jobs, and one spent a year in prison for underground film work, Gazeta Wyborcza said.

DOC.HEAD: Three Killed, 12 Injured in Swiss Train Crash
DOC.TEXT: Three people were killed and 12 injured early Friday when an overnight express train traveling from Milan to Paris smashed into the rear of a railway maintenance train, authorities said. Killed were the train engineers, both Swiss, and a 19-year-old Swiss passenger, son of the passenger train's conductor, Federal Railways chief Claude Roux told reporters. Roux said the ``Galilei'' express had a green light and was traveling at 75 mph when it hit the maintenance train from behind in this southwestern Swiss town. The express train, comprised of an engine and six sleeping cars, derailed. Most of the 420 passengers were asleep when the crash occurred at 1:45 a.m., Roux said. They were mostly French, Italian and British. Two 16-year-old Italian girls were seriously injured. Also reported injured were six other Italian passengers, three French and a Turkish railway worker. Roux said human error was suspected in the crash because the maintenance train was not moved off the main track in time. The engine and two cars were being used to service overhead electrical wires. It was the worst rail wreck in Switzerland since five people were killed in the head-on crash of a local train with an engine near Lausanne in 1985. Train traffic through lower Valais canton was expected to be interrupted until Saturday.

DOC.HEAD: Son Of North Korean Leader Hailed as Heir-Apparent on Birthday
DOC.TEXT: Official North Korean media on Friday hailed Kim Jong Il, the son and assumed successor to aging Communist President Kim Il Sung, as ``Great Leader,'' a title previously used only for his father. The junior Kim, honored for his 48th birthday Thursday, had previously been called ``Dear Leader.'' The official Korean Central News Agency, monitored in Tokyo, said Minju Chosun, organ of the Supreme People's Assembly and the Administration Council, called the younger Kim Great Leader in an article congratulating him on the occasion. It said Minju Chosun stressed in a political essay that, ``To hold Comrade Kim Jong Il in high esteem as the Great Leader is the highest honor and happiness not only for the Korean people but also for all the people in the 20th century.'' Radio Press, a private Japanese agency monitoring communist news broadcasts, said it was the first time Kim Jong Il was ever referred to as the Great Leader. Instead, it said, North Korean media used to call him the Dear Leader or the ``Party Center'' since he became a member of the Politburo and No. 2 in power in the early 1980s. North Korea has never publicly acknowledged Kim Jong Il would succeed his father. But the 77-year-old elder Kim has said ``the question of inheriting the revolutionary cause has been satisfactorily solved,'' supporting a widely held belief his son will take over in the Communist world's first hereditary transfer of power. The elder Kim has ruled the North since the Korean Peninsula was divided in 1945 at the end of World War II, building a personality cult and installing family members in positions of power.

DOC.HEAD: Court Documents: Moody Appealed Three Cases to 11th Circuit
DOC.TEXT: A man being investigated in a series of mail bombings that killed a judge and a lawyer had been involved in three cases before a federal appeals court that was a target of some of the bombings, records show. Judge Robert S. Vance, who sat on the 11th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals in Atlanta and who was killed by one of the mail bombs, presided over oral arguments in one of the appeals, a lawyer said Friday. Walter LeRoy Moody of the Atlanta suburb of Rex is one of three men known to have been investigated by the FBI in four mail bombings in the South last year. Moody, 55, has previously denied involvement in the mail bombings. His attorney, Michael Hauptman, declined comment Friday. According to court documents and lawyers interviewed Friday, Moody had dealings with the 11th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals in three cases: an appeal of his 1972 conviction for bomb possession, an appeal in a malicious prosecution lawsuit stemming from his 1983 arrest for attempted murder, and an appeal of the handling of his mother's will. Judge Vance was killed by a bomb sent to his Mountain Brook, Ala., home Dec. 16. Two days later, Savannah, Ga., attorney Robert Robinson, who handled some civil-rights cases, was killed by a bomb mailed to his office. Similar bombs were intercepted at the 11th Circuit in Atlanta and at the Jacksonville, Fla., office of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People. A letter sent to a Georgia television station _ which contained information suggesting its writer had inside knowledge of the bombings _ claimed responsibility for what appeared to be a previously unknown white racist group. Moody, a literary consultant, filed his first appeal to the 11th Circuit to contest his conviction in 1972 on a federal bomb-possession charge. The appeal was rejected by a panel that didn't include Vance, and Moody served two years in prison. Prosecutors contended he planned to use the bomb to extort $65,000 from an Atlanta auto dealer who had repossessed his car. The bomb exploded when Moody's wife at the time, Hazel, opened the package, injuring her. Court documents show Moody filed another appeal with the 11th Circuit in December 1988, contesting the dismissal of a malicious prosecution and false arrest lawsuit he filed in a 1983 case. In that case, Moody was charged in Florida with attempted murder for allegedly abandoning three divers in the Gulf of Mexico. He had hired the divers to take photographs of an underwater propulsion device he planned to market. A mistrial was declared when the jury failed to reach a verdict, and he wasn't retried. Moody's malicious prosecution suit was dismissed by a lower court and the dismissal was upheld by an 11th Circuit panel that included Vance. Moody again appealed the dismissal in August 1989. Vance presided over a three-judge panel that heard oral arguments in Miami on Aug. 29, and the case is pending. Julius Parker Jr., a Tallahassee, Fla., attorney who represented Monroe County sheriff's officials, said he didn't recall Moody being at the hearing. In the third case, Moody filed a notice of appeal with the 11th Circuit on Oct. 31 involving a dispute with his sister and brother over their mother's will. He is appealing a decision by a U.S. District Court in Florida. William Morrison, attorney for Delores Ann Cummings and Robert B. Moody, said the Florida court dismissed the case for lack of jurisdiction.

DOC.HEAD: Feds Approve Plan To Keep D&H Running
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Tops with five grafs to CORRECT that trustee plan is for railroad to run itself rather than be sold; picks up 5th graf pvs: ``He identified,''
DOC.TEXT: The Interstate Commerce Commission voted unanimously Friday to continue service on the ailing Delaware & Hudson Railway for another week while a bankruptcy trustee tries to organize a new plan for the nation's oldest railroad to run itself under various subsidies ``I think we're all of one mind that the service should be maintained,'' ICC Chairman Edward J. Philbin said at a hearing. The ICC voted 4-0, with one commissioner absent, to allow three railroads to continue to run on D&H tracks: the New York, Susquehanna & Western, which operates the D&H under earlier ICC orders; Lackawanna Valley Railroad Corp. and North Shore Railroad Co. In the meantime, the trustee is working out a plan under which the D&H would be subsidized by the states of New York and Pennsylvania; two shippers; two Canadian railroads and a third unidentified railroad, said Charles H. White Jr., counsel for the D&H trustee. ``The whole exercise is for the trustee to run the railroad himself,'' White said afterwards. ``In other words, for the D&H to run the D&H.'' He identified the shippers as General Electric Corp. and International Paper Co. The two Canadian railroads, Canadian National and Canadian Pacific, are interested in buying the D&H. White estimated the subsidies would amount to $500,000 or more a month, but when asked for a copy of the agreement, White said there wasn't one. ``It's up here,'' he said, pointing at his forehead. The D&H in June 1988 filed for court protection from its creditors under the federal bankruptcy laws. The line has debts of about $100 million. D&H, which began in 1824 as a canal company, runs 20 to 25 trains daily. An important connection with Canadian railroads, the D&H owns 569 miles of track, mostly in New York and Pennsylvania, has rights to run trains over another 1,012 miles of track of other railroads. A shutdown would put 672 employees out of work. Earlier this month, bankruptcy trustee Francis P. Dicello recommended that the D&H be sold to Canadian Pacific Ltd., parent company of the Canadian Pacific, which bid $35 million. But the sale fell through when Canadian Pacific was unable to secure from Conrail the rights to run on its tracks from Harrisburg, Pa., to Hagerstown, Md. A competing bid by the Canadian National Railways also fell apart after the railroad lost its financial backing. However, lawyers for both Canadian railroads said Friday their clients were still interested in buying the Delaware & Hudson. ``We very much would like to reach an arrangement with Conrail,'' said Canadian Pacific lawyer Terrence Hines.

DOC.HEAD: Spain, EC's Worst Polluter, Sets Up Environment Secretariat
DOC.TEXT: The European Community's worst offender of anti-pollution laws set up a secretariat for environmental affairs Friday in an attempt to placate criticism from ecologists to clean up its act. The decision to upgrade a lower-ranking Public Works Ministry directorate general for the environment was seen as an attempt to show Spain is moving to improve its poor record regarding its natural resources. On Feb. 8, European Community Environment Commissioner Carlo Ripa di Meana named Spain as the worst offender of environmental protection legislation within the 12-nation EC. Last year, the EC cited Spain for 57 infractions of European environmental legislation covering pollution of underground and drinking water, industrial and toxic waste and protection of flora and fauna. Despite the criticism, news reports indicate the Spanish capital is the front-runner to be home to the headquarters of the EC's new Environment Agency. Spanish ecologists were not placated by the decision of Prime Minister Felipe Gonzalez's Socialist government because they claim an entire ministry is necessary to deal with the country's environmental problems. The government named Domingo Ferreiro, 44, to head the new secretariat in the Public Works Ministry that will coordinate environmental protection responsibilties, which remain spread across six different ministries. Public Works Minister Javier Saenz de Cosculluela acts as the country's environment minister at EEC meetings and international conferences.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Calls For Lithuanian Independence
DOC.TEXT: President Bush signed a proclamation Friday honoring the Lithuanian independence movement and calling the turmoil in the Soviet Union's Baltic states a remnant of the Stalin era. The United States has never recognized Lithuanian's incorporation into the Soviet Union. ``Lithuania's struggle for liberty, and that of its neighbors in Estonia and Latvia, served as an inspiration to many who saw the collapse of old empires as a harbinger of peace and freedom for Europe,'' Bush said in a statement. The proclamation commemorates the Feb. 16, 1918, birth of Lituanian independence. ``The free Republic of Lithuania prospered until the tragic events of 1940 _ when Soviet troops invaded and occupied the country,'' Bush said. He proclaimed Friday a day for the United States to observe the 72nd anniversary of that date ``in reaffirmation of their devotion to the principles of democracy and freedom throughout the world.'' Bush said the Baltic unrest was ``an unresolved legacy of the Stalin era.''

DOC.HEAD: Police: VD Test Results on Day-Care Center Owner Are Negative
DOC.TEXT: Tests show that a day-care center owner accused of possessing child pornography does not have a sexually transmitted disease found in three children who attended his preschool, police said Friday. John W. Shaver, who faces felony charges of possessing child pornography and procuring the sexual performance of a child, is currently free on $75,000 bond. He was given a venereal test Wednesday as part of the conditions for his release from jail. ``We're trying to determine the source of that infection, and so far, we have not,'' said police spokesman Ott Cefkin. ``At the time that they took a sample from Mr. Shaver, that was a few days ago, it was negative (for the disease).'' Shaver, 56, was charged last month with possessing child pornography after authorities discovered 3,200 photos of nude and semi-nude children at his home. Twenty children from Shaver's preschool were identified in the photos, police said. On Tuesday, police added 24 counts of procuring the sexual performance of a child. The new charges involve allegedly pornographic photo montages found in Shaver's home that combine pictures of preschoolers with nude pictures from magazines. None of the charges against Shaver relate to any known physical contact with children, and police have found no evidence that children at the center were sexually abused, Cefkin said. The court-ordered test of Shaver was made after police discovered gonorrhea in throat cultures of three children who attended Shaver's Rainbow Learning Center. ``You have to look at everybody that had contact with these children,'' Cefkin added. ``As far as Mr. Shaver is converned, they attended his day-care center and this seems to be the only common link among the three.'' Shaver's attorney, J. David Bogenschutz, said the negative result from the Broward County Health Department would help to exonerate his client. ``It means that three children have been found, at least as far as we know from the testing, to be positive, and my client has been negative.'' The three children were treated for the disease. Gonorrhea can be cured with penicillin or other antibiotics. The county's Sexual Assault Treatment Center tested children who attended the Fort Lauderdale preschool after police said they found nude photographs of children at Shaver's home. Medical tests on all the children have not been completed, Cefkin said. Cefkin said he did not know of anyone else being tested for gonorrhea in connection with the police investigation into whether children at the center were sexually abused. About 200 children have attended Shaver's preschool since its opening in 1985. County officials closed it down this month as the police investigation widened. Shaver operated a day-care center in Hawaii before opening the Rainbow Learning Center. But Hawaiian officials stripped his state license amid allegations that he fondled children in his care. No criminal charges were filed in that case.

DOC.HEAD: Mexican Women's Group Says Drug Fighter Covered Up Police Rapes
DOC.TEXT: Feminist groups Friday called for a congressional investigation of Mexico's leading anti-narcotics enforcement officer, saying he protected police from charges that they committed a series of gang rapes. Norma Vasquez, a spokeswoman for the National Network Against Violence Toward Women, told a news conference that bodyguards of Assistant Attorney General Javier Coello Trejo had been identified as suspects since September but were not arrested until January. Coello had ``covered up for the criminals, letting them go free, and they continued to commit more rapes'' until they were arrested, Ms. Vasquez said. A spokesman for the federal Attorney General's office immediately denied Coello did anything wrong and said the suspects were arrested when they were identified. Coello is in charge of a highly publicized effort by the government of President Carlos Salinas de Gortari to fight drug trafficking and reduce Mexico's reputation for corruption in law enforcement. Four officers of the Federal Judicial Police, which is under Coello's command, were arrested last month and are awaiting trial on charges of gang rape, kidnapping, abuse of authority and robbery. The suspects, three of whom served as bodyguards for Coello, were arrested after 14 women filed complaints in a series of rapes in southern Mexico City last year. The case has embarrassed the attorney general's office and focused attention on the issue of rape, rarely discussed or prosecuted in Mexico. Juana Santos, a member of the women's group, said the case was a symbol of raised consciousness about rape. ``We are beginning to notice changes. This is an example of those changes,'' Ms. Santos said. Ms. Vasquez said the women's network, an umbrella organization of 10 feminist groups in the capital, was calling for a congressional hearing on Coello's actions. ``He must explain how this was allowed to go on,'' Vasquez said. She said the network is in constant contact with the rape victims and their families, who want to remain anonymous and will not speak to reporters. Arturo Antelmo, a spokesman for the attorney general's office, said no action was taken against the men until January because ``internally, we did not know who they were.'' But the weekly magazine Proceso quoted a special prosecutor as saying the Mexico City prosecutor's office received photographs of the three bodyguards from Coello's agency in September. Rene Gonzalez de la Vega, in charge of the case, was quoted as saying that in each of the 14 cases, the women were with male companions when they were kidnapped by men in a police car and gang-raped. All the cases took place within a half-mile radius in the southern part of the city. Last year 1,500 rapes were reported in Mexico City, but Ms. Vasquez said they make up only a small percentage of the total ``because it takes a lot of strength'' to go through the legal process and ``repeatedly re-live the rape experience.'' Seven of the women who originally filed complaints decided later not to press charges because of threats, she said.

DOC.HEAD: President Signs State Department Bill
DOC.TEXT: President Bush signed a $9.8 billion measure approving funds for the State Department on Friday, but told Congress he would ignore parts reinforcing sanctions on China and dictating the conduct of diplomacy. Bush in a statement said that the sanctions, as well as a requirement that sensitive diplomatic contacts, like national security adviser's mission to Beijing last June, be reported to Congress, were an infringement on his constitutional prerogatives as president. The legislation authorizes $4.8 billion for the State Department and related agencies for the current fiscal year and another $5 billion for the year beginning Oct. 1. This year's funds already have been appropriated. The bill repeals 1951 legislation permitting immigration authorities to bar visitors on the basis of their political beliefs. The provision has been used to bar a number of world notables over the years; in the 1980s it kept Canadian naturalist Farley Mowat out of the United States because of a satirical comment about shooting at B-52s. Bush had vetoed an earlier version of the legislation, primarily over an amendment by Sen. Daniel Patrick Moynihan, D-N.Y., that would have prohibited the administration from seeking third-country financing of insurgent groups, like the Contras in Nicaragua. Congress dropped that proposal from the current legislation, as U.S. support of the Contras dwindled under a 1988 bipartisan accord with Congress. Bush praised Congress for removing that provision, but said, ``I regret that the Congress has included several provisoins that raise constitutional difficulties.'' The bill sought to write into law a series of sanctions that Bush imposed on China in the wake of last May's bloody crackdown in Tiananmen Square. They included a ban on military sales to China and restrictions on exports and foreign aid. Bush declared that ``legislatively mandated sanctions represent an unwise constraint upon the president's ability to conduct foreign policy.'' Nonetheless, Bush said he could sign the bill because it gives him discretion to disregard the sanctions if he finds that doing so is in the national interest. Deputy press secretary Stephen Hart said that the sanctions imposed by Bush, and reinforced by the legislation, all remain in effect anyway. Bush also balked at another section that would require the State Department to report secret diplomatic contacts. The restriction was an outgrowth of the clandesdine trip to Beijing last June, shortly after the Tiananmen Square crackdown, by national security adviser Brent Scowcroft and Deputy Secretary of State Lawrence Eagleburger. Bush put Congress on notice that he would flatly ignore the requirement, saying it would ``compromise my constitutional authority over such negotiations.'' ``Such blanket reporting requirements could be read to comple the disclosure of sensitive ongoing negotiations,'' Bush said. Bush's statements were the latest chapter in a series of confrontations with Congress over China policy. Earlier this year, he won a veto battle with Congress on legislation that would have extended visas of Chinese students studying in the United States. The Senate sustained Bush's veto after he asserted that he was affording similar protection to the Chinese students by executive order. The measure he signed also wold provide $16 million in start-up funds for ``TV Marti,'' which will broadcast from the United States into Cuba and be a sister station to the ``Radio Marti'' that has operated for several years.

DOC.HEAD: Cheney Peers Into Communist North Korea
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 1 graf after 11th graf to UPDATE with Cheney departure for Hong Kong.
DOC.DATELINE: GONG JAK OBSERVATION POST, South Korea (AP)
DOC.TEXT: Defense Secretary Dick Cheney, staring across the Korean frontier at North Korean soldiers staring back, said Friday that communism remains a ``very hostile and threatening'' foe in Asia even as it seems to be dissolving in Europe. Cheney slogged through mud and fog to make his way to this mountain-high outpost along the frontier that bisects Communist North Korea and the capitalist South, which are technically still at war under the longest truce in modern military history. As the defense secretary used bright yellow binoculars to peer north across the scrub-covered hills and gullies, a feminine voice wafted across the chill air _ a North Korean propaganda broadcast demanding the pullout of U.S. troops. In the distance at a small, bunkered North Korean post, two soldiers could be seen staring back at the American visitors staring at them from the South Korean barbed-wire observation post. ``It's always useful to come back to the Demilitarized Zone,'' Cheney told reporters accompanying him. ``At a time when we are welcoming changes in Eastern Europe and the erosion of the Soviet position in the Warsaw Pact, it's important to be reminded that the United States and the Republic of Korea still face a very hostile and threatening power in the North. ``And it's just as important for us to maintain our determination to protect freedom and democracy here in Korea and elsewhere in the world,'' Cheney said. The defense secretary had been forced to scrub a scheduled morning visit to the Panmunjom truce village in the morning due to the thick fog, but he was able to visit this outpost in the strategic Chorwon Valley later in the day after the air cleared. Cheney was transported several dozen miles northward from Seoul to the DMZ by Blackhawk helicopter, arriving in the mountainous Chorwon region, which was one of the main routes taken by the communist forces during the 1950 invasion. In a briefing conducted in English by South Korean Lt. Col. Chang Gwang-il, Cheney was told that some of the scrub-covered hills he viewed saw some of the most brutal and lengthy battles of the 1950-53 Korean War _ Pork Chop Hill, T-Bone Hill, Old Baldy. In all, the United States lost 34,000 men in battle, another 20,000 from other causes. The South Koreans suffered more than 225,000 deaths, while the North Koreans are thought to have lost 300,000 lives and its Chinese ally another 200,000. ``We will never forget we fought here side-by-side,'' the young colonel told Cheney. ``We're ready to fight!'' Cheney was joined by several Korean generals in symbolically ringing a huge bell hung high in a red bell tower perched upon one of the hilltops. The bell was rung five times to honor the South Korean 5th Division that guards the region. Cheney left South Korea Saturday morning for Hong Kong. Earlier in the day, the defense secretary lunched with some of the 43,000 U.S. troops stationed here that are posted near the border, and attempted to answer their queries about the budget-driven cuts in the military, one observer said. Cheney asked that no generals be present during his session with the 12 sergeants major of the 2nd Division. Cheney travels Saturday to Hong Kong before traveling on to the Philippines and Japan as part of a two-week Asian tour of allied nations that host U.S. forces. During his talks with Korean officials on Thursday, Cheney informed them that the Pentagon wants to cut some 10 percent to 12 percent of its 120,000 troops from South Korean, Japan and the Philippines over the next three years. He also got a pledge from the Korean officials, whose economy enjoys a trade surplus with the United States, to hike their financial support for the troops stationed here. Since the U.S. government contends it spends $2.4 billion annually to support the military here, Cheney asked the South Koreans to at least double their $300 million in funding for the U.S. military.

DOC.HEAD: South Korea to Establish Diplomatic Relations With Bulgaria
DOC.TEXT: The government said Friday it will establish formal diplomatic relations with Bulgaria next month when Seoul's foreign minister visits Sofia. Officials of the two countries on Thursday initialed a protocol on diplomatic relations in Sofia, the Bulgarian capital, they said. South Korea initialed a similar protocol with Czechoslovakia last month. South Korean Foreign Minister Choi Ho-joong plans to visit Sofia and Prague in mid-March to sign formal agreements to open relations with the two reformist East European countries. Capitalist South Korea has recently opened formal diplomatic relations with Hungary, Poland and Yugoslavia _ governments that also have recently moved away from hard-line Communist policy.

DOC.HEAD: Egyptian Consul's Son Arrested in Drug Sting Operation
DOC.TEXT: The son of the Egyptian Consul was arrested along with seven others for allegedly trafficking the synthetic drug Ecstasy, authorities said Friday. Sherif Elgamrawy, 27, son of Consul Bedair Elgamrawy, was arrested late Thursday after undercover officer bought about 1,000 tablets of the drug, said Sgt. Bill Kesseler of the Harris County Organized Crime Narcotics Task Force. He was held without bond Friday at the Harris County Jail, said Kesseler. Elgamrawy was on bond on three other drug charges at the time of his arrest, authorities said. One of those arrested was a 16-year-old girl, who was released to her parents' custody, Kesseler said. The other seven, including Elgamrawy, were charged with delivery of a controlled substance. Kesseler said the arrests were part of an investigation of Ecstasy suppliers in the Houston area. The younger Elgamrawy was driving a car with diplomatic license plates Kesseler said, adding he didn't know whether the son would have diplomatic immunity. The elder Elgamrawy didn't immediately return phone calls seeking comment. Ecstasy, which is manufactured as tablets in clandestine labs, has become more prevalent in the past year as law enforcement officials have cracked down on cocaine, Kesseler said. ``It's really big in the clubs and it's really big with the teen-agers and lower 20s,'' Kesseler said. ``It's cheaper than cocaine and (the high) lasts longer.''

DOC.HEAD: Premier Urges Gorbachev to Let Poland Take Part in German Talks
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with six grafs to UPDATE with French remarks, Genscher comments. SUBS 16th pvs, `West German' to conform. Picks up 17th, `Mrs. Niezabitowska...'
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Germany, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Prime Minister Tadusez Mazowiecki spoke with Mikhail S. Gorbachev on Friday and urged the Soviet leader to demand that Poland take part in negotiations on the reunification of Germany. Mazowiecki, reiterating Polish fears that a united Germany would try to reclaim land ceded to Poland after World War II, also discussed the issue with East German Prime Minister Hans Modrow. Mazowiecki wants Poland to be a part of reunification negotiations already planned for the two Germanys and four World War II allies that divided them: the Soviet Union, United States, France and Britain. In Paris, an official source speaking off the record said France and Britain have discussed the Polish proposal and agreed it should at least be considered _ although they were unsure what role Poland should actually have in the negotiations. West German Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher, addressing an election rally late Friday in Halle, East Germany, said that immediately after the East German balloting March 18, East and West Germany must declare they have no territorial claims against their European neighbors after reunification. ``This applies especially to Poland,'' he said. But he apparently made no mention of Poland joining the German unification talks. Mazowiecki spoke for about 25 minutes to Gorbachev, officials said. Later in Moscow, Soviet Foreign Ministry spokesman Gennady Gerasimov said the six-country formula for the negotiations does not rule out participation by Poland, ``which suffered most as the result of German aggression,'' the official news agency PAP reported. Mazowiecki also got a sympathetic ear from Modrow, who agreed that Poland's borders should be left intact. However, Modrow leads the remnants of a Communist system that was overthrown last year and that likely will be voted out when East Germans hold their first free elections on March 18. The cause for concern among many Poles has been West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl, who has refused to promise Poland that a united Germany would not stake a claim to its pre-World War II borders. Modrow, making a one-day visit to Warsaw, gave ``full understanding'' of Poland's concerns and said his government is ready to back Poland's demand, government spokeswoman Malgorzata Niezabitowska said. Mazowiecki also summoned U.S. Ambassador John Davis and French Ambassador Claude Harel to present Poland's demand for ``direct participation'' in the talks, the state news agency PAP said. During a speech to the foreign committees of the two houses of parliament, Modrow reiterated his government's acceptance of of Poland's western border, which incorporates 40,000 square miles of formerly German lands. ``The German Democratic Republic understands the will of the Republic of Poland to uphold its interests whenever the borders and questions of political security are being discussed,'' he said. Mazowiecki, after meeting with Modrow, said the German unification process has to take into consideration the ``the rights of German neighbors.'' ``Poland doesn't have to take part in everything. But it has to take part in everything that concerns Poland. It has to be present,'' Mazowiecki said, according to PAP. Solidarity leader Lech Walesa pressed the need for Polish participation. ``One must not talk about Polish borders without Poles,'' he said in a telephone interview with The Associated Press. Genscher on Thursday had rejected Polish participation in the talks, saying no Polish territories would be included in the reunited Germany. The U.S. State Department has also said it sees no need to admit Poland to the talks. Mrs. Niezabitowska said Poland was hoping to win Soviet backing for its opinion and was launching diplomatic initiatives with the six countries involved in the reunification talks, announced Tuesday during a foreign ministers' conference in Ottawa. A government spokesman later said Mazowiecki also was drafting a letter on its demand to the four occupying powers. PAP provided no details of Mazowiecki's conversation with Gorbachev. But the agency reported from Moscow that Gerasimov said the Soviet government ``approaches with understanding'' Poland's concerns.

DOC.HEAD: New York Man Arrested For 1946 Murder of Miami Officer
DOC.TEXT: A 61-year-old man was arrested for the murder of a Miami police officer in 1946, thanks to an anonymous tip from a conscience-stricken witness eight months ago, authorities said Friday. Leroy Strachan, a freight elevator operator, admitted to Miami detectives in late January that he had shot the officer when he was 17, police said. The victim, Officer John Milledge, was one of Miami's first black police officers. Strachan was arrested Thursday on a first-degree murder warrant, said Miami Detective George Cadavid. ``He knew us,'' said Cadavid. ``He said, `Are you going to arrest me?' '' and asked to call his attorney in Miami. ``He has admitted shooting the policeman and there is other evidence,'' Cadavid said. Strachan refused to waive his right to fight extradition during a brief arraignment at Manhattan Criminal Court on Friday. Strachan's lawyer, Alan Mass, told Judge Bruce Allen the fact that Florida has capital punishment played a part in Strachan's decision. ``No way if it's within our power that Mr. Strachan is going back to Florida,'' Mass told reporters. The judge ordered Strachan held without bail pending a March 14 hearing. Strachan is married and has three grown children, one of them a state corrections officer. Milledge was fatally shot Nov. 1, 1946, while on patrol outside a football game in Miami's Overton section, after he had chased and beaten several teen-agers who tried to sneak into the game, Cadavid said. The case was reopened in July 1989, because of a tip from a woman who had seen a youth with a .22-caliber rifle running from the shooting scene. ``The reason she never came forward was because her husband was very good friends with the shooter,'' Cadavid said. The woman's husband died a few years ago ``and her conscience was bothering her,'' he said. Cadavid and his partner came to New York in January and interviewed Strachan, then returned to Miami to build a case, locating witnesses. Florida doesn't have a statute of limitations on murder.

DOC.HEAD: Huge Tire Fire Outside Hamilton Continues Unabated
DOC.TEXT: A fire at the Tyre King Recycling dump in Ontario continued burning for a fifth day, pouring black smoke into air and forcing the evacuation of about 600 nearby residents. Ontario taxpayers may end up paying an estimated $1 million to clean the damage caused by the fire in Hagersville, 21 miles southwest of Hamilton, Environment Minister Jim Bradley said Friday. Bradley said the government may take the owner of Tyre King Recycling to court to force him to pay for cleaning the site, which contains 12 million to 14 million discarded tires. But if the owner, Edward Straza, is unable to pay, taxpayers will have to foot the bill. ``That is a possibility,'' Bradley said. ``But certainly my view is the person should assume the entire cost, when it comes down to how much (money) that person has, that's another determinant.'' Some environmental experts say the fire could burn for months because millions of old tires are fueling the blaze. The hundreds who have been evacuated from around town, home to 2,500 residents, will be eligible for compensation from the province, but the details must still be worked out, Bradley said. Tyre King, Ontario's largest tire dump, was declared an illegal waste site by ministry officials in December 1985. Since then, Straza has not applied for a certificate of approval to operate the site, according to a news report. Straza could not be reached for comment. Environment Minister Lucien Bouchard, speaking from Ottawa, rejected an opposition demand that the federal government send emergency crews to help fight the fire. ``This kind of fire cannot be put out now,'' Bouchard said Friday outside the Commons. ``It's horrible to say, but we don't know of any existing means to stop the fire immediately.'' The stench was pervasive Friday as fog and freezing rain kept the smoke hovering low instead of dissipating in the air. Ontario officials said there is no health hazard outside the 2{-mile evacuation area surrounding the fire. About 40 firefighters are working each six-hour shift to combat the blaze, but two water-bomb planes at the site remained grounded.

DOC.HEAD: Four Injured in Blaze at Puerto Rico High-Rise Condominium
DOC.TEXT: A policeman and three others were injured Friday evening when a fire raged through a high-rise condominium in the Condado tourist section of San Juan, authorities said. The blaze, brought under control after 90 minutes, caused no fatalities in the 10-story structure. The New Year's Eve fire at the nearby Hotel Dupont Plaza on Dec. 31, 1986, left 97 people dead and 140 injured in San Juan's tourist center. Firefighters said the blaze was believed to have started on the eighth-floor apartment in the condominium, but further investigation was needed. The firefighters' chief, Jorge Collazo, said all the condominium residents were safely evacuated though he had no exact numbers. The policeman, Luis Rodriguez, suffered an injured shoulder when he fell on the third-floor stairwell while trying to help in the evacuation, Collazo said. Collazo also said an elderly woman suffered slight injuries from smoke inhalation and that two other people were taken to Presbyterian Hospital with undisclosed injuries.

DOC.HEAD: RETRANSMITTING a0747 to restore AP logo
Live-In Companion to Canadian Millionaire Loses Guardianship Case
DOC.TEXT: The longtime live-in companion of Harold Ballard, owner of the Toronto Maple Leafs, has lost her bid to take control of the guardianship of the ailing professional hockey magnate. A judge who had declared Ballard, 86, mentally incompetent this week ruled Friday that four guardians recommended by his daughter look after the personal and financial affairs of the multimillionaire. ``I am now certain with the orders made he will be able to live in dignity and peace for as long as he needs help,'' said his daughter, Mary Elizabeth Flynn. Yolanda Ballard, 57, who lived with Harold for most of the 1980s and took his last name although they never married, lost in the latest battle she waged in the courts with his children. District Court Judge Donna Haley appointed former Supreme Court of Canada Justice Willard Estey of Toronto to look after the personal affairs of the owner of the Maple Leafs and their home, Maple Leaf Gardens. Named to look after Ballard's business affairs were Gardens directors Steve Stavro and Donald Giffen, and Donald Crump, who recently resigned as Gardens secretary-treasurer to become commissioner of the Canadian Football League. ``It should have been quite clear to Yolanda Ballard that she couldn't be a committee (guardian) of the person _ that it had to be someone independent of Mr. Ballard's estate and his person,'' Haley said in announcing her ruling. ``There is also no evidence before me of her personal capabilities of managing an estate as complex as Mr. Ballard's.'' Haley acknowledged Yolanda's contribution to Ballard's health care but did not grant her free access to the octogenarian, who has been in a Miami hospital for more than a month with kidney and heart problems. ``Yolanda should be allowed to express her concerns and her opinions as to Mr. Ballard's personal needs and have all access to Mr. Ballard as the committees (guardians) see fit.'' Yolanda, who remained stoic as the judge read her decision following three days of hearings, refused to say whether she would appeal. She did, however, make derogatory remarks about the Ballard children, with whom she has openly feuded for years. She called Ballard's sons Bill Ballard ``Cyclops William'' and Flynn ``Medusa Mary.'' ``At the eleventh hour, everyone comes to jump on Harold's coffin when he's not even in it yet,'' she said angrily, referring to Ballard's children. Son Harold Jr. was also involved in the court action initiated by his sister. An emotional Flynn said in her statement following the proceedings she was confident Estey would make sure her father got the best care possible. Ballard checked into hospital while vacationing with Yolanda in the Cayman Islands last month and was later transferred to Miami Baptist Hospital suffering from kidney failure. He requires dialysis three times a week and was listed Friday in satisfactory condition. Yolanda's visits to the Miami hospital were restricted after she was discovered trying to force-feed him a banana and Jell-O. A Florida court had appointed a guardian to handle Ballard's affairs until he was well enough to return to Toronto. The four named Friday now take over that task. Haley also ruled Yolanda should receive $2,500 from Ballard to cover her court costs. Since Ballard's illness, Maple Leaf Gardens has been run by the board of directors.

DOC.HEAD: Finance Minister Resigns, Social Democrats Seek to Form New Gov't
DOC.TEXT: The nation's finance minister quit Friday after Parliament rejected his proposed inflation-fighting plan. The departure of Kjell-Olof Feldt from the day-old caretaker government appeared to be an attempt by Prime Minister Ingvar Carlsson's long-governing Social Democrats to regroup, regain public confidence and build political support to form a new governing coalition. Carlsson's government, which is to stay on until a new government can be formed, announced that Feldt's deputy, Odd Engstrom, will fill the post. The prime minister resigned Thursday, shortly after his government lost a vote 190-153 on its bill to freeze prices, wages, rents, local taxes and corporate dividends for two years. The package was aimed at bringing inflation under control and stifling a wave of labor unrest. Feldt told a news conference he did not have the political backing or the personal will to scrap his program and start over. ``With the plans I have had, I don't have the strength to begin afresh. To have a new policy, I have to hand over to younger and better forces,'' he said with Carlsson at his side. Asked if the Social Democrats had an effective alternative to the wage-price freeze, he said: ``No, not today.'' In a separate development, the bank employees' union and the bankers' association annnounced an end to a three-week labor dispute, which had helped prompt the government to draw up its politically fatal crisis program. The two sides accepted a mediation offer of 13{ percent wage increase, and the banks said they would reopen Monday. The speaker of Parliament, Thage G. Peterson, met Thursday night with opposition leaders on forming a government. But the center-right parties admitted they had no chance without new elections. Political analysts predicted the Social Democrats would be able to reconstitute their government without going into elections by gaining support from the small Communist Party. The Communists had objected to many of Feldt's policies. Feldt was the architect of Sweden's recovery in 1982 from a deep recession, and won international recognition for measures that sought to adapt Sweden's socialist ideology with the free market policies of the industrialized West. Feldt's moves toward deregulating Swedish banking and revamping its tax system won praise from the business community and non-socialist opposition parties. His ideas on privatizing some public services were too radical for traditional socialists and set him on a collision course with his own party. Feldt credited himself with starting a process of rethinking in his party, though he said ``not all of my ideas were politically mature.'' Except for six years from 1976, the Social Democrats have governed Sweden since 1932. Since returning to office it has ruled as a minority government. Opinion polls published before the political uproar began gave the Social Democrats their worst showing in more than 45 years, with a 34 percent approval rating. But the three centrist parties, which governed in coalition from 1976 to 1982, also would not gain a majority in a new election, the polls predicted.

DOC.HEAD: Exxon to Pay $660,000 for Environmental Study of Waterway
DOC.TEXT: Exxon Corp. will pay the estimated $660,000 cost of assessing environmental damage from last month's oil spill in a waterway next to the Atlantic, New Jersey and New York officials said Friday. Also Friday, Exxon workers held a rally in Cranford, N.J., to support their embattled employer. The company has been widely criticized both for the local spill and a nearly 11-million-gallon leak caused by the grounding of the tanker Exxon Valdez in Alaska last year. In a joint announcement, New Jersey Gov. Jim Florio and New York Gov. Mario Cuomo said state and federal agencies and Exxon had reached agreement on a preliminary study of damage from the 567,000-gallon East Coast spill Jan. 1 and 2. The oil spewed from a ruptured pipeline into the Arthur Kill, a narrow waterway between New Jersey and the New York City borough of Staten Island. ``Exxon must accept full responsibility for this threat to our waters, wetlands and coastline, and it is only fair that they provide immediate funding to fully determine the damage caused by the oil spill,'' Florio said. Officials have criticized Exxon for what they say was a slow response to spill warning signs, and accused the company of understating the size of the spill in reports to the Coast Guard. But at the employees' rally, about 100 current and former Exxon workers and their families met at a restaurant to hear speeches criticizing what they called ``Exxon bashing.'' ``We're here to stand up and be counted to stop this constant lashing of Exxon,'' said Connie Conselyea, a tank car coordinator who has worked for Exxon 17 years. ``Accidents do happen and we do our best to clean them up. I'm proud to say I'm an employee of Exxon.'' Exxon spokesman Doug Walt said the rally was organized by the employees. About two dozen members of the Concerned Citizens of Linden picketed outside the restaurant as the Exxon employees entered, criticizing the company's environmental record. ``It's such a long, bad environmental track record that the employees should ... be as indignant as we are,'' said Beatrice Bernzott, Concerned Citizens president. ``We feel sorry for them. We know they're concerned about their jobs. But their indignation should be directed at their CEOs and Exxon management.''

DOC.HEAD: Former President Grilled For Poindexter's Iran-Contra Trial
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 1 graf after 2nd to UPDATE with comment from Poindexter's attorney.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto LA6
DOC.TEXT: Former President Reagan, known as the great communicator, went before cameras in a new role Friday _ explaining during secret court testimony what he knew about the Iran-Contra affair. Reagan smiled and waved but didn't speak to reporters as he entered the federal courthouse Friday morning to give a videotaped deposition in the trial of his former national security adviser, John Poindexter. ``I think he was very fair in his testimony,'' Poindexter attorney Richard Beckler said of the president afterward. Poindexter goes on trial March 5 on charges of concealing from Congress Oliver North's assistance to the Nicaraguan Contra rebels and lying about a 1985 shipment of Hawk missiles to Iran. Poindexter entered the courtroom a few minutes before Reagan, flanked by a half-dozen lawyers and legal aides, who had in tow a red cart with boxes of documents. The two exited separately about 6{ hours later, again ignoring shouted questions from the crush of reporters waiting outside. U.S. District Judge Harold Greene told reporters Reagan would be questioned again Saturday. The former chief executive was to return to court at 9:45 a.m. on the beginning of the Presidents Day holiday weekend. ``It's hard to tell, but we'll be finished by lunch,'' Greene said when asked how many more questions Reagan had to answer. The public was barred from attending the session, during which Reagan was to answer 154 questions in addition to follow-ups that focus on his meetings with Poindexter. Then Reagan faced cross-examination by Iran-Contra prosecutors. Greene allowed Reagan to give videotaped testimony at the federal courthouse near his Bel-Air area home rather than require him to appear in person at the Poindexter trial in Washington. Three cameras were positioned to record the testimony _ one pointed at Reagan, one pointed at the judge and the other directed at lawyers questioning the former chief executive. On Thursday, Greene rejected a request by news organizations that they be allowed to attend the deposition. However, he said he would order the videotape released within a few days, after editing to remove material deemed to touch on classified national security matters. Three years ago, Reagan portrayed himself as a president who was kept in the dark by his aides. But Poindexter contends he kept his former boss fully informed about all aspects of the affair _ with the apparent exception of the diversion of Iran arms sale money to the Contras _ and that Reagan authorized his activities. Reagan said early in 1987 that he hadn't known about ``secret bank accounts and diverted funds,'' two products of the Iran-Contra affair that he said he found ``personally distasteful.'' He told the Tower Commission he didn't know the National Security Council staff was assisting the Contras after Congress ordered a halt. Poindexter subsequently told Congress he believed Reagan understood that ``Col. North was instrumental in keeping the Contras supported without maybe understanding the details of exactly what he was doing.'' Friday's questioning, according to court papers, was to concern: _The president's knowledge of North's relationship with various individuals in the Contra operation and the Iran initiative. _Whether Poindexter told Reagan of the status of Richard Secord, who North enlisted to move supplies to the Nicaraguan rebels and who operated the network of offshore accounts known as the Enterprise to move money in the Iran-Contra affair. _Reagan's discussions with Poindexter regarding a chronology on a November 1985 Hawk shipment that forms the basis of four of the five criminal charges against Poindexter. _Whether Reagan advised Poindexter to tell congressional committees they already had been given information about whether North was secretly assisting the Contras. The earlier responses were denials that North was raising money and providing military advice to the Contras. They led to former national security adviser Robert McFarlane's guilty plea to criminal charges of withholding information from Congress.

DOC.HEAD: Red Cross Visits Noriega in Jail
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 2 grafs after 8th graf pvs, `The Geneva...,' to UPDATE with source saying Noriega attorneys plan to fly to Geneva. Picks up 9th graf pvs, `The details...'
DOC.TEXT: Manuel Noriega on Friday received his first prison visit from the Red Cross since the U.S. government agreed to treat the deposed Panamanian leader as a prisoner of war. A doctor and a delegate from the International Committee of the Red Cross sought to ensure Noriega's treatment was in keeping with the Geneva Convention, said Jean-Marc Bornet, the organization's chief delegate for Latin America. Meanwhile, an attorney for Noreiga filed a motion in federal court asking for the results of wiretaps he claimed were made by U.S. invasion troops while Noriega was being held in the Vatican embassy in Panama. ``We have received information that while the general was in the Papal Nunciature, the U.S. Army tapped the telephone, and recorded all the conversations,'' said the attorney, Frank Rubino. The defense wants to determine if the tapes will help Noriega's case, possibly by showing he was falsely induced to surrender to U.S. authorities. Noriega was flown to the United States on Jan. 4 to face drug-trafficking charges. He was first housed at the federal courthouse, but was later moved to a special cell at the federal Metropolitan Correctional Center south of Miami. Noriega's defense team had demanded that he be treated as a POW, saying U.S. civilian courts had no jurisdiction over him. The government agreed to the POW treatment, but said he could still be prosecuted on the drug trafficking charges. U.S. District Judge William Hoeveler concurred last week, and ordered the legal proceedings to continue. The Geneva Conventions are a series of treaties establishing the treatment of combatants, civilians and prisoners of war. Late Friday, sources close to the case who spoke on condition of anonymity told The Associated Press that Rubino and fellow Noriega attorney Steven Kollin are scheduled to fly to Geneva Saturday night to discuss Noriega's status as a prisoner of war with high-ranking Red Cross officials. Kollin said he would ``neither affirm nor deny'' that the two lawyers are going to the Swiss capitol when asked by the AP about the trip and its purpose. The details of Friday's prison inspection are confidential, but generally the procedure follows a pattern, Bornet said. ``This first visit is a very traditional task,'' Bornet said. ``We first of all have a discussion with the manager of the camp or prison. Then we visit all places of detention, we see the facilities, the cells, the kitchen.'' After the tour and the talks with prison officials, the Red Cross meets with the prisoner, Bornet said. ``We have private talks, and it is very important that they be without witnesses,'' he said. ``We speak only about the conditions of detention. It may be about food, about being allowed to go out, or to have contact with families, or about medical treatment.'' There will be follow-up visits to Noriega, but there are no set intervals, and timing will depend on conditions at the prison, Bornet said. Making the inspection were Erwin Boehi, regional delegate for the Red Cross, and Dr. Jacques Stroun of the agency's medical division in Geneva, Switzerland. They refused to comment when they left the prison late Friday afternoon. They also were to visit three other Panamanian prisoners at the jail, including Noriega co-defendant Luis del Cid, allegedly once a top aide to the deposed leader. The Red Cross refused to identify the other two prisoners. After the inspection, the team reports to the Red Cross and to the U.S. government. That report is confidential, said American Red Cross spokeswoman Ann Stingle in Washington. If there is a dispute over prison conditions, Bornet said, the agency tries to work it out amicably with the host government. Charles Davis, spokesman for federal prison, confirmed the Red Cross visit but said he could not release any information on the delegates' activities. Bornet said Noriega's attorneys have contacted the agency about the Geneva Convention, but the visit was routine under an agreement the Red Cross reached with the U.S. government immediately after the Dec. 20 invasion of Panama.

DOC.HEAD: Guerrillas Demands Talks for Release of Two Americans
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 12 grafs to UPDATE with guerrillas demanding talks, communique claiming responsibility. Pickup 4th `Amico was...'; EDITS thereafter to trim and conform
DOC.TEXT: Guerrillas holding two U.S. citizens demanded the formation of a committee to negotiate terms for their release, a television news program reported Friday night. Police said they had no word on a third American, a priest who was also kidnapped by guerrillas protesting President Bush's Thursday visit to Colombia for a drug summit. Parishioners prayed for the return of the New York priest. The TV program 24 Hours said relatives of James Donnelly were contacted by the abductors, who demanded formation of a committee to negotiate the terms to release Donnelly and David Kent. The abductors did not provide details on the conditions they would put forward during such talks, the report said. It also was not clear who the abductors wanted on the committee. Donnelly, a 65-year-old mechanical engineer from Detroit, and Kent, a 40-year-old school teacher from Indianapolis, were separately kidnapped in the northwestern city of Medellin on Tuesday. The pro-Castro National Liberation Front made public Friday night a communique claiming responsibility for their abductions. Officials had already blamed the group for the kidnappings of Donnelly, Kent and the priest, Rev. Francisco Amico Ferrari, who was abducted early Thursday. The guerrillas said the summit Thursday in the Colombian resort city of Cartagena between President Bush and the presidents of Colombia, Peru and Bolivia, was part of a military design for ``the military control of our (Colombian) territory.'' The summit approved a joint fight by the four nations against drug trafficking. A police spokesman contacted in Medellin by telephone said the police knew nothing of the guerrillas' demands. In the southeastern city of Cali, a San Basilian priests' community said it has no news on Amico, and a police spokesman from Medellin said there were ``no leads at all.'' A ``praying day'' was held in the Our Lady of the Assumption parish in Cali for Amico, who has run the parish since coming to Colombia in 1987. Amico was abducted by armed men while heading to a nearby church to celebrate Mass. Witnesses said the group forced him into a jeep that sped away. Amico, from Rochester N.Y., is the founder of the Basilian Priests' branch in the San Andres zone, one of Cali's poorest neighborhoods. ``Nobody has contacted us. We only pray for our superior and Masses and processions are being held in the parish,'' said Rafael Lopera, a Colombian member of the Basilian community in Cali. He said similar prayer sessions were held in Toronto at the Basilians' headquarters. Roman Catholic Church bishops in Cali issued a statement calling for the abductors to release Amico. The bishops also condemned guerrilla bomb attacks Thursday at two Mormon temples run by American pastors. Damages were estimated at $12,000, but no injuries were reported. Medellin and Cali are homes to the murderous drug cartels named after them. Both cartels are blamed for over 80 percent of the cocaine entering the United States.

DOC.HEAD: Sheriff Seizes National Guard Armory to Ease Jail Overcrowding
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 11 grafs to UPDATE with National Guard threatening legal action if prisoners aren't removed, other details. Pick up 8th graf pvs, `State Sen. Brian ...
DOC.TEXT: Fed up with months of overcrowding in the county jail, a sheriff on Friday commandeered a National Guard armory as a temporary prison. Hampden County Sheriff Michael Ashe said he took the action ``to prevent the collapse of the criminal justice system in this county due to lack of correctional facilities.'' ``It appears ... there is an imminent danger of a breach of the peace due to insufficient prison space in this county, and that reasonable and prudent steps must be taken in order to preserve the peace and quell such danger,'' Ashe said in a directive to the brigadier commander of the Massachusetts Army National Guard Armory here. The dramatic announcement at 2 p.m. _ and the transfer of 15 prisoners to the armory _ caught state officials by surprise. State Secretary of Public Safety Charles V. Barry issued a statement saying that Ashe had been notified it was illegal to put prisoners in the armory. He was ordered to have them removed or face prosecution for criminal trespass. ``This is no way to do business,'' Barry's statement said. ``If you would come to us to discuss the problem, we would see what we could do to accommodate you.'' Barry didn't plan any immediate action, saying he would ``pursue necessary legal action Tuesday to terminate the unlawful occupation of the armory.'' The secretary noted that the armory isn't up to code for the purpose of housing prisoners and Ashe would be responsible for their safety. Ashe said in a statement that he believed he acted correctly. ``This action is within my inherent power to keep the peace. I take full responsibility for this action to protect my fellow citizens,'' he said. Seventeen minimum security prisoners were taken to the armory's drill hall, said sheriff's spokesman Richard McCarthy, describing the area as similar to a large gynmasium. Two of the prisoners were later returned, McCarthy said, adding that all 15 held at the armory were prison trustees with less than two months more to serve. State Sen. Brian Lees, who went to the armory after hearing the news, said he wasn't sure whether Ashe had the authority to take over the building. ``We're waiting to see if this is legal and whether it falls under the guidelines of the constitution,'' he said. Friday's action followed a week of turmoil at the jail. On Wednesday, Westfield District Judge Philip Contant detained two Hampden County deputies for most of the day when they refused to take a prisoner back to the jail, acting on Ashe's orders. Ashe had refused to return the prisoner because the jail, built to hold 279 prisoners, had exceeded by one a federal order to house no more than 500 inmates. The jail filled up this week and Ashe's spokesman, Richard McCarthy, said the other remedies of early release, late sentencing and housing prisoners elsewhere in western Massachusetts weren't providing enough spaces. Judge Contant said he admired the job Ashe has done under trying circumstances, but he would pursue contempt charges if prisoners were turned away from the jail, which takes prisoners whose sentences are less than 2{ years. A new jail has been approved in nearby Ludlow, but that is expected to take two to three years to build.

DOC.HEAD: 80-Year-old Killed in French Alps Avalanche
DOC.TEXT: An 80-year-man was killed Thursday, the third fatality from avalanches in the French Alps the past two days. Joseph Canovas was trying to clear floodwaters from a road near the village of Les Reyssen when the hillside, loosened by rain and melting snow from 35 inches of snow this week, swept over him, firefighters said. Two others were injured. The death came hours after an avalanche rumbled down a mountainside at the Val d'Isere ski resort, causing no injuries but prompting authorities to warn people to stay indoors and avoid the famed ski slopes. Earlier Thursday police identified two victims of an avalanche Wednesday as a British school administrator and a French woman. Terrance Murnaghan, 46, the director of a nursing school in London, was crushed in an avalanche at the Val d'Isere. Two French skiers were seriously injured, police said. Cecile Puyg, 17, was killed when an avalanche swept her car from the road leading to the ski resort of Les Arcs near this southeastern French city, police said. Three others were seriously injured when their vehicles were swept off the road.

DOC.HEAD: Five Accused of Trying to Spring Drug Prisoners
DOC.TEXT: Five men reputed to be members of a terrorist squad linked to Colombian drug lords were arrested Friday in what authorities say was a plot to free prisoners from a county jail. The five were apprehended along Interstate 95, heading south in vehicles containing an array of gear including paramilitary uniforms, a stun gun, knives, two-way radios and smoke grenades, authorities said. They were charged with interstate transportation in aid of racketeering and could face state charges as well, said U.S. Attorney Bart Daniel. Agent Fred Verinder of the FBI said law agencies around the nation have received threats that ``Colombian drug cartels would use Colombian terrorist squads known as `narco-terrorism' to free Colombians held in American jails.'' Juan Carlos Perez, a Cuban national, was in the Charleston County Jail on charges stemming from last year's seizure of 1,069 pounds of cocaine on Hilton Head Island. He goes on trial Monday. A defendant convicted earlier in that case, Jorge Samuel Cruz of Puerto Rico, was also in the jail awaiting sentencing. Testimony in the trial linked the drugs seized on the island to the Medellin drug cartel in Colombia. In addition, a Colombian national, Alphonso Parada, was in the jail awaiting trial on state drug charges, authorities said. Charleston County Sheriff Al Cannon said authorities received a tip last week concerning a possible escape attempt by a prisoner. The five men arrested were seen outside the jail early Friday morning in two vehicles with Florida license tags. Among other items seized, authorities who searched the cars found paramilitary uniforms, two-way radios, binoculars, stun guns, mace containers, black baseball caps and ski masks, flares, hunting knives, flashlights and about $10,000 in cash. The five were arrested without incident, officials said. Lydia Glover of the U.S. Marshals Service said the agency has increased security and notified jails where other federal prisoners are incarcerated. Verinder said the FBI has created a special unit to handle such cases ``because we're concerned about intelligence reports that this is going to happen more and more as the extradictables are returned to the United States.'' The five arrested were Fernando Botero, 32, of Miami; Jesus Walter Jaramillo, 45, of Homestead, Fla.; Pedro Aragon, 41, of New York; Roberto Rego, 47, of Miami; and another individual who authorities said refused to identify himself.

DOC.HEAD: Severe Flooding Hits South; Thousands Have No Power In North
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 5th graf pvs, `One man...in Missouri,' to UPDATE with death confirmed in Georgia; SUBS 23rd graf pvs, `The sky...,'' to UPDATE with governor's emergency declaration, most flood evacuees returning home; SUBS next-to-last graf pvs, `On the...,' to UPDATE with power out to 230,000 customers. Pick up final graf pvs, `Driving conditions...
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto GAD1, CG1,2, ASV1
DOC.TEXT: Flooding forced hundreds of Southerners to evacuate Friday after thunderstorms generated tornadoes and up to 10 inches of rain, and a strong Pacific storm swept inland after dumping up to 3 feet of snow in the Sierra Nevada. ``All of a sudden the roof went one way and the floor went the other way,'' Frank Higginbotham said of a tornado that struck his home Friday morning in Alabama. ``I cradled my daughter to my chest and we were blown through the wall into another room.'' He had a bump on his head; his daughter was unhurt. Thousands of customers still had no power in the Midwest and Northeast after snow and ice storms. ``Hot wires are falling all over the place,'' said police dispatcher Rosemarie Million in Erie, Pa. Even sled dog races scheduled this weekend in Truckee, Calif., were postponed because of the blinding snow. One man apparently drowned Friday in a raging North Carolina river, and the body of a man washed away by floodwaters was found in Trion, Ga. Traffic accidents on ice and snow killed at least 11 people since Wednesday _ four each in Kansas and Minnesota, two in Michigan and one in Missouri. In Georgia, a tornado destroyed 15 homes and injured 11 people in Carrollton, the National Weather Service confirmed. And authorities said as many as 1,000 people were evacuated Friday from Trion in northwestern Georgia after 10 inches of rain fell in 15 hours and the Chattooga River rushed out of its banks.
