Authorities could not determine if a dam on the Chattooga at Trion had burst because ``it's 10 feet under water and the currents are so fast going across it that they can't see the dam,'' said Chattooga County sheriff's deputy Tammy Owings. Schools were closed in Chattooga and other counties of northwestern Georgia. In McCaysville, in extreme northern Georgia near the Tennessee border, the Toccoa River washed over its banks and forced an estimated 500 people from their homes, authorities said. No injuries were reported. Just across the state line in Copperhill, Tenn., the Ocoee River ran out of its banks and flooded the business section of the old mining town of 400 people. ``The entire downtown area of Copperhill is flooded, up to the second-story windows of buildings,'' said Russell Newman, a Tennessee Emergency Management Agency official. ``It's the worst flooding I've seen in the last seven or eight years,'' said Police Chief Charles Bond in Eton, Ga. ``Water in low-lying areas is 6 feet deep. One guy said it was up to the top of his pickup truck.'' Roads were flooded, bridges were out and mudslides and rockslides were reported in several mountainous areas. In nearby western North Carolina, up to 6 inches of rain fell and the body of a man who apparently was swept away from his trout hatchery was found downstream on the French Broad River, police said. A tornado touched down Friday afternoon in Robeson County near Maxton, said Robert Ivy, a communications officer with the county sheriff's department. Three trailers were damaged and one overturned, causing up to $15,000 in damage, Ivy said. There were no injuries. Officials in Harnett County reported an unconfirmed tornado. Some schools were closed because of slippery, muddy roads. But students in parts of Transylvania County were held in school because driving conditions were too treacherous for buses. An apparent tornado struck rural central Alabama early Friday, tearing apart a fire department building in Enterprise and destroying several mobile homes at Cooper, Chilton County sheriff's officers said. Flooding forced hundreds of Alabama residents to evacuate. Water was over the gas pumps of a service station near Baptist Medical Center-DeKalb at Fort Payne, where hospital workers used a motorboat and rowboat because a small bridge leading to the medical center was flooded. Alabama's Shelby County received more than 9 inches in less than 24 hours and 30 people evacuated from two trailer parks that were under 6 to 8 feet of water had to be moved twice. ``We had them in an armory, but the water got so high there we moved to them to the Baptist and Methodist churches in Pelham,'' said Bill Klein of the Alabama Emergency Management Agency. Mississippi Gov. Ray Mabus issued an emergency proclamation for all the state's 82 counties because of the wind and flood damage, the first step toward seeking federal disaster aid. In east-central Mississippi, in the town of Chunky, ``at the shelter that was opened at Hickory school, where about 100 people spent the night Thursday, water is coming up in the front yard,'' said Dusty Perkins of state emergency services. In the West, the snowstorm closed more than 70 miles of Interstate 80 _ the main east-west route across California's Sierra Nevada _ in both directions from Auburn, the California Highway Patrol reported. At Incline Village, Nev., on Lake Tahoe, Diamond Peak spokeswoman Lee Weber said the resort had received 3 feet of new snow by midmorning and had blizzard conditions. ``The storm's sure to hurt the holiday traffic in, but some people can't leave either,'' said Susan Hill of the Reno News Bureau. Wind clocked at 45 mph and low visibility at San Francisco International Airport closed two of four runways, causing delays of at least 20 minutes for arriving and departing aircraft, reported spokesman Ron Wilson. On the eastern slope of the Sierra in Nevada, the storm swept into the Reno-Carson City area, temporarily cutting off power to 230,000 customers snarling traffic, closing schools and shutting down the Reno airport. Driving conditions were poor across parts of Oregon and schools were closed over a wide area of western Oregon. Traffic was delayed as long as five hours on Interstate 5 over the Siskiyou Summit, where chains were required to navigate a foot of new snow.

DOC.HEAD: Life in Prison for Conspiracy to Distribute Heroin
DOC.TEXT: A man accused of running an eight-country heroin ring was sentenced Thursday to life in prison. U.S. District Judge Edwin Kosik passed sentence on Ralph Santana, 64, of Fort Lauderdale, Fla., who pleaded guilty last October to one count of conspiracy to distribute heroin. The former Pennsylvia man was arrested last June after a two-year investigation by state and federal authorities. At the time of his arrest, state and federal officials said Santana was involved in global heroin-cocaine trafficking involving co-conspirators in England, the Netherlands, France, Mexico, Colombia, Pakistan, Thailand and the United States. Drug enforcement agent Dennis Malloy said Santana conducted drug business from pay telephones in an attempt to avoid a tapped telephone line. A phone call for the drug ring could cost up to $150 in quarters, Malloy said. The case involved the U.S. Justice Department's first approval of a roving wiretap. ``This was a very sophisticated network of traffickers,'' said state Attorney General Ernie Preate Jr. ``They took every step along the way to defeat law enforcement officers.''

DOC.HEAD: Guard Charged with Bringing Hacksaw Blades for Breakout
DOC.TEXT: A guard at a maximum-security prison where six convicts escaped was arrested Thursday and charged with aiding the weekend breakout by bringing them hacksaw blades, authorities said. William S. Smith, a guard at the Joliet Correctional Center since 1977, was charged with conspiracy, official misconduct and aiding Sunday's escape, Will County State's Attorney Edward A. Burmila said. ``We have eyewitnesses who witnessed him, not only purchasing hacksaw blades, but having them inside the institution on two occasions,'' Burmila said, ``and we have evidence that these blades were the ones used for escape.'' A blade was found in the cell of one of the escapees, he said. Burmila said he did not plan to bring criminal charges against others. Smith, 46, of Joliet was arrested at the prison, and was being held in lieu of $500,000 bond, Burmila said. Smith was to be arraigned Friday. A state Department of Corrections investigation resulted in the suspension of Smith and another guard with pay and the reassignment of three others to less sensitive posts at the prison 40 miles southwest of Chicago, said department spokesman Nic Howell. One escapee was recaptured later Sunday and another was caught Wednesday, both in Chicago. The search continued Thursday for the remaining four escapees, three of whom are murderers. Prison officials described all four as extremely dangerous.

Hilari Yogi, known as a trick-shot artist as well as a golf instructor, died Thursday after a lengthy illness at age 85. He gave golf lessons to many celebrities, including entertainers Bob Hope and Mickey Rooney, and former President Dwight D. Eisenhower. Yogi was a golf hustler who would bet as much as $10,000 that he could break 70 both right and left-handed. In 1973, Yogi wrote the book ``Five Simple Steps to Perfect Golf,'' which is still in circulation.

Guy Schofield, former editor of London's Daily Mail and a founder of a group that investigates complaints against the press, died Wednesday at age 87. The cause of death was undisclosed. He began his career as a copy boy at the Leeds Mercury newspaper in Yorkshire in 1918, worked at London's Evening Standard and then was editor of the now-defunct Evening News from 1942 1950. He was editor of London's Daily Mail from 1950 to 1955. In 1947, he and an Evening News reporter refused to tell a House of Commons' committee the name of a Labor Party legislator who had leaked details about confidential party business. They were found in contempt and ordered to appear before the House of Commons. They were not ordered to reveal the name. In 1953, he was a founding member of the Press Council, which pursues readers' complaints. Schofield also served as publicity director for the Conservative Party and directed the United Newspapers group in the 1960s and 1970s. Twice widowed, he is survived by a daughter.

Jack C. Massey, who helped build Kentucky Fried Chicken Co. into an international success and co-founded Hospital Corp. of America, died Thursday of pneumonia at age 85. From a chain of six drugstores, the Nashville businessman founded Massey Surgical Supply Inc. in 1930. He sold that company for about $1 million in 1961. In 1964 Massey and businessman John Y. Brown, who later became governor of Kentucky, bought Kentucky Fried Chicken from its founder, Col. Harland Sanders. The two built the company into the world's largest commercial marketer of prepared food. They sold the business to the Heublein Corp. in 1969. Massey founded HCA with Dr. Thomas Frist, and his son, Dr. Thomas Jr., in 1968. Within 18 months the company had 11 hospitals, and within 10 years had reached $1 billion in sales and was country's largest owner and operator of hospitals. Massey retired from the company in 1978.

Arthur Henry Goldberg, a retired judge in New York City Criminal Court who decided several prominent cases, died Monday of respiratory failure at age 84. From 1937 to 1945, he was assistant corporation counsel under Mayor Fiorello H. La Guardia. He was a special counsel to parks planner Robert Moses. Goldberg, who retired in 1975 after eight years on the bench, was the judge who dismissed charges against hundreds of students who took part in demonstrations at Columbia University in 1968. He also was part of a three-judge panel that convicted the producer, playwright, and cast of the play ``Che!'' on obscenity charges.

Norman Parkinson, who specialized in photographing women and won fame for his pictures of British royalty, died Thursday in Singapore from a brain hemorrhage at age 76. Among his best known portraits are those of Princess Anne, daughter of Queen Elizabeth II, for Anne's 21st birthday in 1971, and the queen's mother, Elizabeth, on her 80th birthday in 1980. His ``snaps,'' as he called his photographs, were often exhibited at the state-financed National Portrait Gallery in London and featured in several best selling publications, including ``Sisters Under the Skin.'' His business interest in British pigs led him recently to start selling his own brand of pork sausages to top London stores such as Harrods.

Julius ``Slick'' Johnson, a stock car driver, died Wednesday from injuries sustained in a multi-car crash at Daytona International Speedway at age 41. The Florence, S.C., resident was declared brain dead at Halifax Medical Center. He had suffered a broken skull and chest injuries. The journeyman driver is the first stock-car driver to die of injuries sustained at Daytona International Speedway since Joe Young in 1987. The last previous fatality occurred in December, when driver Dale Robertson was killed in a go-kart race.

DOC.HEAD: Car Bomb Kills Undercover Narcotics Officer on Long Island
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 11th graf to CORRECT that car had been parked in front of home since 1 a.m. Tuesday, sted Wednesday.
DOC.TEXT: A bomb planted in an unmarked police car exploded Thursday, killing an undercover narcotics detective in front of his home, officials said. Dennis Wustenhoff, 41, died at Stony Brook University Medical Center nearly three hours after his car blew up just after noon in this Long Island city, said hospital spokeswoman Maxine Simpson. ``This was probably an assassination and job-connected,'' said Suffolk County Police Commissioner Daniel Guido. ``But we don't know whether it was revenge or related to a current case Wustenhoff was working on.'' The bomb blew out the entire front part of the late-model white Cadillac, throwing debris up to 200 feet, Guido said. A neighbor who heard the blast ran to the scene and helped pull Wustenhoff out of the car, the commissioner said. The officer was conscious and answered a question from the neighbor about who might have planted the bomb, Guido said, refusing to give specifics. Wustenhoff was airlifted to the medical center's burn unit, where he died. The bomb was placed either in the engine or under the driver's seat, Guido said. It was unclear whether the device exploded when Wustenhoff started the car or when he sat on the driver's seat. The car belonged to the police, and was being used in undercover work, said county District Attorney James Catterson. Guido said the slaying in this suburb on Long Island's south shore more than 70 miles east of New York City ``was not a street-level operation; it was much higher than that.'' The car had been parked in front of Wustenhoff's home since 1 a.m. Tuesday, Guido said. The detective had used the car between 5 p.m. and 1 a.m. while working that day. Wustenhoff had used the car Tuesday when he went to work at 5 p.m. He parked in front of his small, Cape Cod-style home after finishing his shift at 1 a.m. Wednesday. Federal agents examined the debris Thursday, and county police dogs sniffed through it for debris. Wustenhoff, a 20-year veteran of the police force, has been decorated 10 times by the department and had worked with federal Drug Enforcement Administration agents on a number of projects. He leaves a wife, a 14-year-old boy and two girls aged 12 and 10. The wife and children were not in the house at the time of the blast.

DOC.HEAD: Report: Slain Judge Had Case from Man Investigated in Bombings
DOC.TEXT: A man investigated by the FBI in a rash of mail bombings across the Southeast twice appeared before a federal appeals panel on which a slain federal judge served, a television station reported Thursday. WAGA-TV reported that Walter Leroy Moody Jr. of Rex went before the 11th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals in December 1988 to appeal the dismissal of a lawsuit alleging malicious prosecution and false arrest when he was charged in 1983 with attempted murder. A panel of the 11th Circuit dismissed Moody's appeal, saying it was premature. The television station said Judge Robert S. Vance served on that panel. Officials with the 11th Circuit confirmed that Moody had gone before the court. On a second appeal in August 1989, Moody went before the panel, which again included Vance. Oral arguments were heard, and the case is still pending, the station reported. Moody was appealing over allegations made during the 1983 case. In that case, he was charged with hiring three Georgia divers to photograph an underwater propulsion device he planned to market, then abandoning them in the Gulf of Mexico. Jurors were deadlocked, and the judge declared a mistrial. The state decided against retrying Moody. Vance was killed by a bomb sent to his Mountain Brook, Ala., home Dec. 16. Two days later, Savannah, Ga., attorney Robert Robinson was killed by a mail bomb. Two other bombs were sent to targets in Atlanta and Jacksonville, Fla., but intercepted by authorities. Investigators have extensively searched the homes and business of three men, including Moody, in Alabama and Georgia, though no one has been charged in the attacks. Moody, a literary consultant, was convicted in 1972 in U.S. District Court in Macon of illegal possession of a bomb. Detailed media coverage of the investigation spurred attorneys for Moody on Thursday to ask U.S. District Judge Richard C. Freeman to issue a gag order, to seal all documents in the case and to order the return of items confiscated by agents who searched Moody's home last week. Attorneys for several Atlanta news organizations are opposing the motions to restrict information about the case. Freeman, who said he needed more time to study documents filed in the case, declined to act on any of the motions. He scheduled another hearing for Wednesday when, the judge said, ``We'll let it all hang out.'' Moody's attorneys argued that the intense publicity over the bombs probe has hurt Moody's reputation. But Freeman said the media has a right to report whatever information it can get from authorities during an investigation.

Mayor Marion Barry vows ``I will be exonerated'' of new drug-related charges, but a city official is calling for his resignation and a top adviser wonders whether the mayor has any political future. Barry, 53, was indicted Thursday on five misdemeanor counts of cocaine possession and three felony counts of lying to a grand jury questioning him on drug use. Meanwhile, close advisers to Barry said Thursday that the mayor will leave a Florida drug treatment clinic by the end of the month to continue treatment elsewhere. Barry entered the Hanley-Hazelden Clinic in West Palm Beach four days after his Jan. 18 arrest on a cocaine possession charge in what authorities said was a videotaped hotel sting. The new clinic has not been chosen, but an adviser speaking on condition of anonymity said a top priority will be to ensure that Barry is isolated from the media.

One of Chang-Lin Tien's earliest memories of America is a segregated drinking fountain he saw in Kentucky. That memory could be a portent of what awaits Tien as chancellor of the University of California-Berkeley, which has been wracked by controversies over minority admissions and faculty hiring. University officials believe Tien, a 54-year-old Chinese immigrant who was appointed chancellor on Thursday, is the first person of Asian ancestry to head a major U.S. university. Tien, chosen over 250 others, assumes the $165,000-per-year job on July 1. He will become Berkeley's seventh chancellor since the position was created in 1952. Berkeley's academic standards generally are considered the highest among the nine University of California campuses.

Haitian community leaders dismissed as racist a new federal policy prohibiting Haitians and sub-Saharan Africans from donating blood because of the high incidence of AIDS in their home countries. The policy announced this month by the Food and Drug Administration requires blood collection agencies regulated by the FDA to refuse blood from donors who were born in, or emigrated from those countries. The decision is based on the high incidence of Africans and Haitians infected with the AIDS virus through heterosexual contact, which ``seems to play a major role in transmitting the virus,'' according to the FDA. ``We still have the stigma then, that we are carriers of AIDS,'' said Chantal Thomas, executive director of the Haitian American Community Center in West Palm Beach. ``It is insulting, how dare they do something like that?''

Two of the country's influential liberal families will be linked by marriage as the eldest son of Gov. Mario Cuomo takes the hand of a daughter of the late Sen. Robert F. Kennedy. Ethel Kennedy on Thursday announced the engagement of her daughter, Kerry, to Andrew Cuomo, and Gov. Cuomo said the whole family was ``very, very pleased'' about the union. No wedding date has been set. ``Kerry is a wonderful, wonderful young lady. We know her. We love her and we couldn't be happier,'' the governor said.

DOC.HEAD: Japanese Consumer Advocates Fight Lonely Battles
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: They are warriors in a country with more compliant consumers than consumer complaints. Fumio Matsuda, a former auto engineer, is a stinging critic of the Japanese auto industry's safety performance. Katsuko Nomura, a 79-year-old grandmother, singlehandedly introduced a U.S.-style consumer movement to Japan. They are anomalies here, where social harmony is revered and consumers' interests have been subordinated to the welfare of Japanese corporations. But both have made their mark. Mrs. Nomura lobbied for local freedom of information laws, now enacted in 32 of Japan's 47 prefectures (state) and about 130 cities and towns, and is working to get a national law on the books. She believes access to information about such things as chemicals in food will galvanize interest in consumers' rights. Matsuda operates a volunteer network of scientists and moles at Japan's largest auto companies. His 20-year-old Japan Automobile Consumers Union has uncovered defects in cars and shifted the spotlight of responsibility onto carmakers, contributing to a recent unprecedented number of recalls. Matsuda, 63, charges Japanese automakers have been feeding their export success by skimping on safety in domestic models while the government sets safety standards that are often too low and fails to enforce others. He claims several carmakers have substituted specially built cars in crash tests of new models for the U.S. and Japanese markets. But, he adds, the models later sold to consumers probably would have failed the tests. Matsuda uses the information he gets from scientists conducting chemical analyses of engine parts and employees at auto companies to help consumers claim damages from allegedly defective cars. Japan has no product liability laws, and the lack of legal precedent increases the burden on consumers to prove fault by automakers. ``I never get discouraged because I know we're right and that our information is correct,'' says Matsuda, a former engineer at the Nissan Motor Co. He keeps secret the identities of the 25 members of what he calls his ``brain'' to protect their jobs and his group's information-gathering ability. They never go to his office, and rarely call. Sometimes their wives meet to pass information. He bristles at the suggestion his network is spying. ``They are acting according to their consciences, and everybody is very proud of what we do.'' Spokesmen for Japan's major automakers deny Matsuda's charges and say they do not think their recall records are a problem. Bret Anderson, a Honda spokesman, says the company ``deals within the industry's regulations and standards, or tries to improve on them.'' A statement by Toyota Motor Corp. said, ``Mr. Matsuda, like any other so-called advocate, owes it to the consumers he supposedly represents to be responsible. Unfortunately, his track record to date doesn't say much for the sincerity of his implied intentions.'' That track record includes a conviction for blackmail stemming from charges brought by a group of Japan's largest automakers in 1971. They accused Matsuda of threatening to publicize information about defects in their cars unless they paid him. He was sentenced to four years of probation. Matsuda maintains he was negotiating for a group of car owners who suffered damages from defects and says he is appealing the conviction. Although some of Japan's major media regard Matsuda as an agitator, the national daily Asahi Shimbun has used his research as the basis for many newspaper stories, including an award-winning 1987 series on sudden acceleration in Audi imports. The Audis were recalled later in Japan and in the United States. Matsuda lives an austere life. On weeknights, he sleeps on a cot in his Tokyo office, bulging with files and littered with greasy auto parts. He sees his wife and two daughters at the family's seaside home south of Tokyo on weekends. He and Mrs. Nomura came from affluent families in which charity and compassion were taught at an early age. Mrs. Nomura recalled that when she was studying at Kyoto's prestigious Doshisha University in 1931, ``agricultural families were so poor they were selling their daughters while I was being taught how to say, `So nice to meet you,' in English class.'' Sensitive to the gap between the real world and the privileged one of her birth, she ignored English, read books on Marxism and social injustice, and married a like-minded classmate. Soon afterward she launched a 59-year career of consumer advocacy that has included organizing labor unions and bringing news of consumer movements to Japan. ``The Japanese people just don't get mad at manufacturers, they're not concerned with their rights,'' she said. ``So I get angry for them.''

DOC.HEAD: Brussels Says It's `Capital of Europe' and Rents Go Up
LaserPhoto Planned
DOC.TEXT: A city of low rents and few pretensions not long ago, Brussels now touts itself as the ``Capital of Europe'' but friction is building between rich and poor, Belgians and foreigners. Rents and real estate prices are soaring in anticipation of an influx of new ``Eurocrats'' in 1992 when the European Economic Community becomes a united, open trading bloc and much more attention will be focused on Brussels, the EEC headquarters. Construction crews are transforming old, modest neighborhoods into tonier places for new and wealthier inhabitants. ``Brussels, Europe's Crossroads of Poverty,'' said a sign recently in the Marolles, a working-class neighborhood where inhabitants are being forced out of their homes to make room for fancy apartments and shops on Sablon Square. ``Brussels Sparkles For Europe,'' counters a billboard on the square where fur-coated customers buy pastries at what has become the city's priciest bakery or frequent fancy expresso bars, restaurants and antique shops. Near the EEC headquarters, old homes have been bulldozed to make way for new offices and a $231 million convention center. All this, at a price. ``You cannot throw out residents like a pile of bricks,'' said the Rev. Jacques Van der Biest, a Roman Catholic priest and a leader of the Marolles' protests against sacrificing residents to urban renewal. But as 1992 fever grips Brussels, social considerations are overwhelmed by real estate speculation. Last fall, the Happy Babies nursery in central Brussels got a surprise eviction notice. The owner who had just bought the building wanted to sell it for a quick profit. Finding no other premises at $550 monthly rent it was paying, the nursery went into debt to buy the building. A Happy Babies official said the owner made a $35,000 profit in about a month. ``Now we have to spend double to pay off,'' she said. ``We don't stop talking about money now. The future looks very bleak.'' Pensioners have been forced out of their apartments to make way for middle-income families who can no longer afford rents in their old neighborhoods. The market is set to tighten even more, despite a decree limiting rent increases to inflation for the next year. ``We will have a battle between the haves and have-nots for the available homes,'' said Herve Cnudde, head of the urban conservation group ARAU. ``It is already the No. 1 issue in Brussels' social and political circles.'' Apartments that fetched $250-a-month in rent in 1987 now are double that in some neighborhoods. The blame is laid on the EEC, its 12,000 well-paid Eurocrats _ who get tax breaks locals do not get _ and its 1992 plan, which will lure even more Eurocrats and lobbyists to this city of just under a million people. In addition to the Eurocrats, Brussels already has 20,000 lobbyists and 800 international trade organizations in operation. ``Foreigners can spend a lot more on housing than locals,'' Cnudde said. When owners demand big rent increases, many locals opt to move _ some as far off as Antwerp or Charleroi, both 30 miles out. ``In the end there will be more foreigners than Bruxellois,'' said Jacqueline Godfroid, a director at the Office of Property Owners. Currently, some 25 percent of Brussels' population is foreign, including many low-income immigrants from North Africa. Foreign investors, however, find Brussels is still a bargain, despite the increased real estate values. ``Over the last two years a lot of people came in to buy: Scandinavians, Swiss, recently more Japanese and Americans because they realize the potential of the open market of 1992,'' said Godfroid. Increasingly, she added, they paid ``crazy prices'' for even dilapidated real estate. Van der Biest, the priest, said a house near his Marolles church that would have fetched less than $100,000 a few years ago was valued recently at almost a million dollars. Serious traffic congestion also has developed because of the construction of the new office complex and conference center in an already congested area of narrow, one-way streets. ``It is simply not made for such implantations,'' said Cnudde. ``They decided on the site before thinking about the consequences. It is the world turned around.''

DOC.HEAD: Books and Authors: A Student Survival Guide
DOC.TEXT: Author Bryna Fireside has three children. All were out of high school by age 16. Her daughter, Leela, started college at 15; Douglas graduated at 16 and got a job; Daniel also finished at 16 and went to California. So what happened to tradition? Why didn't they just graduate after 12th grade and go straight to college? First of all, they're three unusual kids, bright and non-conformist, who followed their parents' encouragement to live a little differently, take chances and break a few rules if necessary. Also, as Fireside points out in ``Choices: A Student Survival Guide for the 1990s'' ($10.95, Garrett Park Press), the rules have changed. Options for high school students are broader and more accessible than even she considered possible. ``If you don't have a good reason for being there, you shouldn't be in college,'' said Fireside, a free-lance writer and supervisor of student teachers at Cortland State College. ``It's an expensive proposition that can really be a marvelous experience if you know what it is you're after. ``There are so many things kids can do by spending a year away. By the time they get to college, they at least know what they don't want. They know it's hard to make friends in a work place at a low level job. For kids who travel and are willing to take that step in another part of the world, that can also be an eye-opener.'' Fireside had written magazine articles about high school students who ``stop out'' _ take time off before college _ and also researched internship programs and summer schools. The students impressed her and so did the parents. For adults, ``Choices,'' is a friendly arm around the shoulder from an experienced mother and writer. The message: Relax, trust your child. ``I was talking to someone in a large suburban area and I mentioned I had written about `stopping out' between high school and college. One parent said, `What if she never decides to go to college?' ``If parents value education, the kids will also value education. That's a very hard concept for parents to accept. A lot of parents think if they don't guide the kids all the way, if they let them step out of the mold, all will be lost. People mature at different rates. We ought to be able to recognize it in teens.'' ``Choices'' could be called ``The Conceptual Guide to Continuing Education.'' Structured like a school workbook, Fireside leaves plenty of room in the margins for notes and comments and includes dozens of organizations to contact. Call it Pop Education as well, important ideas available to all. ``There's a lot of information out there but it's not readily accessible to kids. A lot of guidance counselors don't have information either, or the kids don't feel comfortable with guidance counselors. ``The information doesn't seem to be in the bookstores. It's a nice, thin book (111 pages), and easy to read.'' Fireside includes chapters on internships, travel and jobs programs. She also discusses the military, a sensitive topic for a longtime activist who once organized the anti-nuclear ``Tasteful Ladies for Peace.'' But ``Choices'' means all choices, and for millions the military is a serious option. ``It is a very important part of American life. For those kids that feel there's something they can contribute to their country, this is a good way to do it and get a free education. But the object of the military is not to educate, but to teach how to kill.'' Education, Fireside noted, can be resumed at any time, and not only the young take chances. The most exciting time of her own life came in her 40s when she went back to school, creating a degree in children's literature at Cornell University. Fireside continues to be challenged by her own children, especially by Daniel, who at 19 is spending his junior year of college in Peru and hasn't hesitated to get involved in that country's turbulent politics. ``Even when I didn't agree with what my kid was doing, it was very exciting seeing my kid doing something he likes doing,'' she said. ``We all want our kids to be productive and think more about other things than just themselves. ``Many of the kids I talked to were not rebels, but pretty bright kids who just had something else they wanted to do. What I'm basically saying is that you don't have to plan out your whole life, you can just plan six months.''

DOC.HEAD: Man Gives Birth, Film at Nine
DOC.TEXT: It is not every night you see a man give birth. But it's happening tonight, by golly, on _ where else? _ ``Alien Nation.'' This shows how far TV has progressed since little Ricky's arrival on ``I Love Lucy'' in 1953. For starters, Lucy, who gave birth to Ricky, didn't have to chase bad guys and get punched in the beak to induce the blessed event. But she was neither a male plainclothes cop nor a Newcomer, as they call the aliens with the melon-shaped heads on this Fox network series. Detective George Francisco (Eric Pierpoint) is both. In last week's episode, his pregnant wife (Michele Scarabelli), transferred her tyke-in-progress to George's innards. You see, it is the Newcomer custom for men to endure the miserable last stages of pregnancy and to give birth. This may not strike Earthmen as a particularly good deal. Be that as it may, tonight's chapter also has police work facing George and his human partner, Matt (Gary Graham). They must track down a no-good who is selling a brace of bodybuilders a deadly, addictive, steroid-like drug made from essence of Newcomer (Newcomer men are far stronger than human males). But the main theme of the episode, ``Real Men,'' is what it means to be a man. And in its re-examination of conventional male and female roles, we get a fresh definition of what some call the New Man. (The old definition: A guy who isn't afraid to drink Perrier or let his date pick up the check). As do pregnant Earthlings, George suffers swollen ankles, an aching back and fears his mate has eyes for others. He also hears a succession of bad pregnancy jokes that brings him, understandably, to tears. But he doesn't quite catch on when Matt tries to enlighten him about the concept of macho, about how males are raised to be tough, to shun tears, and play football on knees so scarred they resemble beaver hors d'oeuvres. George tries, though. ``Ah,'' he says, ``like some Newcomer men. They don't feel truly masculine until they've given birth.'' He can't understand why Earthmen worry so much about impotency, though. Such talk fuddles Matt. And while he's extremely sympathetic about his friend's delicate condition, it's awkward for him that George, heavy with alien, insists on staying on the job until his time has come. It's equally awkward that a visiting playboy pal (Nick Shockley) puts the moves on Matt's lovely Newcomer neighbor, Cathy (Terri Treas). Even though it's only a subplot, Matt gets jealous. All this is told in a droll, if slightly leaden manner, with the finale offering a rousing late-night fight that pits the two constables against a drug-crazed weightlifter. The fight causes George to go into labor prematurely. Lying down on the floor, gasping for breath, he tells his frantic partner, ``Put your fists against my temples. It helps dilate the pouch.'' Will the babe be boy or girl? When it takes its first breath, will it emit a tiny cry of ``Na-no-na-no'' or demand to be interviewed by Geraldo Rivera? Find out for yourself. And remember, this is not the arrival of Little Ricky. But if you do get bored, put your fists against your temples. It helps dilate the mind.

Elsewhere in television... YOU CAN'T HEAR ``LOVE SHACK'' ON IT: NBC plans to create a new monthly newsmagazine, ``NBC News Pulse'' _ on audiocassette. The ears-only show will recap major news events, and offer reports on sports, music, film, business, medicine and science. You won't be able to buy it, though. A spokesman says NBC will offer its ``Pulse'' only to corporations and groups that want it as a marketing tool. The audiocassette, an NBC release explains, is ``intended for professional people on the go.''

DOC.HEAD: Winner of Nicaragua's Election Faces Mountain of Economic Woes
DOC.NOTE: Eds: The election is Feb. 25.
With LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: The winner of Sunday's presidential election not only has to bring peace but make life better for people like Liliana Perez, a teacher whose salary of a million cordobas a month is worth only $18. Or the housewife who has to pay 1,000 cordobas for a single tortilla and 15,000 for a pound of beans. Or the worker whose salary has steadily deteriorated the past 10 years as Ms. Perez's has. Pumping life back into one of the poorest economies in the Western Hemisphere most likely will be a crucial agenda item either for the incumbent Daniel Ortega and his Sandinistas or Violeta Barrios de Chamorros of the United National Opposition, the main challenger. ``Everything Will Be Better,'' the Sandinistas promised in their campaign slogan. ``UNO Can Change Things,'' said the opposition. Says Liliana Perez: ``We are not political, but we are convinced that this nonsense has got to change.'' She spoke after school as she helped her mother sell fruit drinks from a roadside stand to shore up the family budget. San Rafael del Sur, about 25 miles southwest of Managua, became a focus of discontent last year when teachers started a series of wildcat strikes to protest a standard of living that has plunged under 10 years of Sandinista rule. Ms. Perez, who is in her early 20s and said she will vote for UNO because of low wages, few jobs, high food prices and Sandinista-dominated labor unions, which she described as party cheerleaders instead of worker advocates. Real wages have retained only 10 percent of their value since the Sandinistas toppled dictator Anastasio Somoza in July 1979. The Sandinistas acknowledge they have made mistakes but blame most of Nicagua's problems on a U.S. commercial embargo, the civil war with the U.S.-backed Contra rebels and 1988 destruction by Hurricane Joan. Their critics say the Sandinistas imposed an inefficient centralized economy and disastrous fiscal policies, permitted bad administration and rampant corruption and showed little tolerance for opponents. The critics also maintain that Sandinista policies have been supported by charity from the Cuba and the old Soviet bloc _ charity they say will disappear now with the collapse of communism in Eastern Europe. Both sides in the races for the presidency, a new National Assembly and municipal offices seem in agreement that they must work together after the winners are declared. ``In the first place, it is necessary to start an economic reconstruction of the country,'' Vice President Sergio Ramirez said in a recently published interview. ``For that it is necessary to think first of a concordance of all the social forces after the elections.'' Apart from agreeing that cooperation is crucial, the Sandinistas have not come out with a clear program on how they will achieve the increased production needed to bankroll an array of social projects. Their opponents also know cooperation is vital to the country but keep pushing their demands for a ``tropical perestroika,'' as some of them put it, as a condition for that cooperation. ``There is no sense in us making a concordance or an economic pact'' under current conditions, said Gilberto Cuadra, president of the Council of Private Enterprise, Nicaragua's most influential consortium of private business. ``The system in itself doesn't make any sense anymore, either here, or in Cuba or in Eastern Europe.'' In January, the business council, which backs Mrs. Chamorro, made a series of proposals that strike at the heart of the Sandinista economic system. Among the most important points, the document calls for establishing trust between government and private enterprise and doing away with centralized state planning of the economy. But Alejandro Martinez, minister of planning and budget, said the banking system and foreign trade will continue as nationalized sectors of the economy, run by the central government, something that left businessmen shaking their heads in frustration. Relations between the leftist government and private enterprise have not visibly improved in the last year. In May, the government confiscated three large coffee farms when their owners criticized government policies. A few weeks ago, in a campaign speech, President Ortega threatened to confiscate a cooking oil processing factory. He had accused the factory's manager, a relative of Mrs. Chamorro, of causing a cooking oil scarcity to hurt the government. Shortly after Ortega's speech, the government announced it was importing several tons of soybeans to make cooking oil. ``Mr. Ortega couldn't hide his totalitarian instincts and he decided to make a show of who's boss,'' Cuadra remarked when asked about the incident.
