DOC.HEAD: SAN RAFAEL DEL SUR: the incident.
DOC.TEXT: A new Sandinista government would be operating under circumstances radically different from those of 10 years ago. Ortega returned from a 10-nation European trip last April with only $50 million in promises for aid, and that was before Communist governments began falling apart in the East. With Eastern Europe now ready to absorb the financial good will of Western Europe and a strapped Soviet Union reluctant to continue handouts, the Sandinistas will not be able to rely on foreign donations, estimated to have averaged $400 million a year. International lending organizations heavily influenced by the United States seem to be one of the few lifesavers left for the Sandinistas, but those loans will be forthcoming only if a Sandinista government seems serious about righting the economy and if it manages to persuade the United States the elections were fair, regardless of the outcome. At the beginning of 1989, Ortega announced a stringent economic austerity program that slashed the public budget by nearly half and called for the firing of at least 30,000 public employees. The aim was to rein in inflation that had shot up to a world record of 33,600 percent in 1988. According to government figures, inflation was down to a 1,700 percent annual rate by the end of 1989. However, the government has refused to say how many people were actually laid off and some economists say the inflation rate is higher than 1,700 percent because the cost of a basket of staples like beans and rice has risen 5,000 percent. The Sandinistas continued mass subsidies to a plethora of workers, and some public employees, notably those of the Interior Ministry, received hefty raises. UNO would seem to have an easier, though by no means easy, time in starting up the economy. For one thing, the United States most certainly would lift the commercial embargo it imposed on the Sandinista government in 1985. That would bring in U.S. aid and foreign loans to restart production and a large and profitable market for Nicaragua's traditional agricultural export crops. A U.S.-backed government, especially one that projects stability, also would have an easier time attracting foreign investment. But to achieve that stability, UNO would have to gain the cooperation of the Sandinistas in order to avert strikes by Sandinista-dominated labor unions that could thwart any economic effort. When the Sandinistas started their anti-inflation program last year, hundreds of teachers nationwide went on wildcat strikes for higher pay, following the lead of San Rafael de Sur teachers, in defiance of their pro-Sandinista labor union. That and strikes by cab drivers brought the Sandinistas face-to-face with their first serious labor unrest. Ortega gave pay raises to the teachers and subsidies to the cabbies, but those gains were soon eroded by inflation. ``What they have done to us is too much,'' said Ms. Perez. ``I can't forget that.'' Even those who say they will vote Sandinista are counting on brighter days ahead. ``If they're elected, the war will end. Then we'll have to demand that the economy gets better,'' said Ambrosio Sanchez, 26, who weaves hammocks with his wife, Josefa, in Masaya, near Managua. What if the economy doesn't improve? ``We'll have to see,'' he said, somberly looking at his wife and his 4-year-old son, bare-bottomed and barefoot playing in the dirt.
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Sunday, Feb. 25

DOC.TEXT: Profits plunged by 50 percent at General Motors Corp. and by 72.9 percent at Ford Motor Co. in the fourth quarter, as the nation's biggest automakers showed the impact of slow sales and costly buyer incentives. The quarterly results reported Thursday completed a sharp drop in annual earnings for the nation's Big Three automakers, which have been struggling with an industrywide slump that has prompted plant closings and thousands of layoffs. Autoworkers will get more bad news this spring: the decline in profits at GM, Ford and Chrysler Corp. will mean little or no annual profit-sharing payments this year.

Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. said it would lay off thousands of employees as it pushed to give away major business in a fire sale induced by the largest securities industry bankruptcy ever. The investment firm said Thursday it was completing severance packages for ``several thousand'' of its 5,300 workers who would be fired Friday. Drexel employees have been scrambling to find jobs since the firm's parent filed for bankruptcy court protection on Tuesday. They are looking for work during a recession on Wall Street.

The Bush administration got the go-ahead to finance its savings and loan bailout by borrowing through the Treasury, a method that could balloon the budget deficit this year by tens of billions of dollars and temporarily push up short-term interest rates. The Justice Department ruled Thursday that the Resolution Trust Corp., the agency created to dispose of failed thrifts, may legally borrow from the Federal Financing Bank. S&L bailout legislation enacted in August provided $50 billion through next year to cover the losses in failed thrift institutions. But the RTC needs to borrow as much as an additional $100 billion.

Housing starts jumped a record 29.6 percent last month as builders took advantage of the warmest January ever, the government reported, but analysts said the industry could not sustain the pace. ``Levels like the ones we're seeing here would indicate a housing boom and there is just simply no fundamental reason to believe that is going on,'' Thomas Holloway, senior economist for the Mortgage Bankers Association, said Thursday. Housing starts tumbled to 1.37 million last year, the lowest level since the 1982 recession, and many analysts do not expect much improvement in 1990 because of a weak economy and high interest rates.

Federated Department Stores Inc. and Allied Stores Corp. are making progress luring merchandise suppliers back during the chains' bankruptcy reorganizations, but sales have declined, their president said. ``We're going to have a very poor fourth quarter,'' James M. Zimmerman, president and chief operating officer of Federated and Allied, said Thursday, referring to the fiscal quarter that ended Feb. 3. The two retailers, both divisions of Toronto-based Campeau Corp., filed Jan. 15 for bankruptcy protection from creditors, listing $7.7 billion in debts.

IBM unveiled a line of computer workstations that the company says outperform and underprice the competition and should help it snare a major stake in a fast-growing market where it never had success. ``The opportunity is big _ it's growing at over 30 percent a year, and it's mostly a new opportunity for IBM,'' President Jack D. Kuehler said Thursday. The machines, called the RISC System-6000, also mark the first time that the world's largest computer maker has wholeheartedly embraced the Unix computer operating system that is fast becoming the industry standard.

Whittle Communications has signed up 2,510 schools and has sold $200 million in advertising for its commercially sponsored Channel One news program for the classroom, debuting March 5, the company said. Chairman Christopher Whittle said Thursday the schools have signed three-year contracts to show the daily 12-minute news program, which is tailored to teens and includes two minutes a day of commercials. He said the ad contracts also cover three years, including about $65 million in the first year.

Store owners in Israel, Australia and Switzerland pulled bottles of Perrier sparkling water from the shelves as a general worldwide recall got under way. But beverage industry analysts remained divided Thursday about whether the tony brand in the distinctive green bottle will ever recover its prestige. The recall affects 160 million bottles of the water in 120 countries and could cost the company as much as 200 million French francs, or $35 million, officials said.

The Agriculture Department said fertilizer prices are going up as spring planting approaches, but probably won't be as high as a year ago. According to a preliminary report released Thursday by the department's Economic Research Service, fertilizer prices may be up 4 percent from last fall. But despite the increase, spring prices may be down about 4 percent from year-earlier levels.

The stock market came out of the doldrums Thursday to close higher in brisk trading. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials rose 25.23 points to close at 2,649.55. The dollar advanced against all major currencies except the Canadian dollar. Gold prices were generally lower. News of a dramatic rebound in housing construction knocked bond prices lower. Gold and platinum futures prices weakened; copper futures rose; oil futures gained; coffee futures slumped; grains and soybeans were mixed; pork bellies surged and livestock futures were mixed.

DOC.HEAD: Prescient Book on the Hazards of Debt and Takeovers
First moved in advance.
DOC.NOTE: Eds: John Cunniff is on assignment.
DOC.TEXT: If Wall Street were a Western movie, people could call the sheriff to corral rustlers who ride off with corporate gold instead of putting it into research and updated plants needed to compete. That's basically what Michigan State University economics Professor Walter Adams urges in ``Dangerous Pursuits,'' a recently published book on the 1980s mania for mergers and takeovers that in light of recent events seems prophetic. ``Dodge City needs a sheriff to maintain law and order, to break up the brawls and to restore sanity to its inhabitants. So does Wall Street,'' he and co-author James W. Brock conclude in a chapter on ``Cowboy Capitalism.'' The kind of deals that characterized the 1980s kept entrepreneurs from creating new wealth, new jobs and increased competitiveness, they argue in the book. A rash of financial crises and bankruptcies at companies that expanded using high-risk ``junk bond'' debt is one of the consequences. ``These are jerry-built structures, basically,'' Adams said in an interview. ``They are a prime example of excessive speculation.'' The warnings in the book were underscored this past week, when the once-mighty Wall Street pioneer of the junk bond-financed takeover business sought bankruptcy protection itself. Few believe Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. will survive, and many say the era of unbridled junk financing is probably over. Mergers and acquisitions are the ``Dangerous Pursuits'' Adams and Brock, a Miami University of Ohio economics professor, describe in the book published by Pantheon Books in New York. The two previously wrote ``The Bigness Complex,'' on the influence of power groups in the U.S. economy. The book was named one of the top 10 business books of 1987 by Business Week magazine. Brainpower focused on wheeling and dealing for profit could be used better to improve U.S. companies' productivity or competitiveness, or to cut public and private debt that weighs down the economy, Adams said. Managers get into deep and unfamiliar waters when preoccupied by mergers, whether they're the hunter or the hunted, he said. The book quotes Esmark creator Donald P. Kelly as saying his company did everything from drilling for oil to selling meat and manufacturing bras, and, ``All it tells you is that you can be head of a holding company and not be very smart about anything.'' Adams said unfamiliarity was a reason Campeau Corp.'s 260-store retailing empire _ owner of Burdines, Lazarus, Jordan Marsh, Bloomingdale's and other well-known chains _ wound up in bankruptcy court seeking to reorganize and repay more than $7 billion in debts. Robert Campeau went far afield when he bought Allied for $3.6 billion in 1986 and Federated for $6.6 billion in 1988, Adams said. ``He's a real estate operator from Canada buying two major retail store chains in the United States.'' Campeau used junk financing that cost him more than 16 percent interest on much of the debt. ``He financed it with junk bonds, which you might call the fake wampum of the 1980s,'' Adams said. Among Adams' and Brock's suggestions to divert corporate brainpower and resources into constructive avenues: _End tax deductions for the interest on debt incurred simply to transfer corporate control. _Put a sliding tax on capital gains from sales of assets _ high if the assets are held a short time, low if they are held longer. _Enforce antitrust laws. The Clayton Act prohibits mergers or acquisitions that lessen competition or create a monopoly.

DOC.HEAD: Alan Hassenfeld Making His Mark As Hasbro CEO
LaserPhoto NY7
DOC.TEXT: There's something appropriate about Hasbro Inc.'s new line featuring New Kids on The Block. It's the first venture that smacks of Alan Hassenfeld since he became the new man in charge. Hassenfeld labored for years in the shadow of his older brother, Stephen. His brother's death of pneumonia last June at age 47, however, thrust Hassenfeld into the limelight as chairman and chief executive officer. Although the younger Hassenfeld had worked in the company in various capacities for two decades, including president since 1984, there were some who doubted his credentials. They wondered whether his experience as head of the international division had prepared him to run the nation's largest toy company. But as Hasbro touts its 1990 products at the annual Toy Fair in New York, the reports are that he is doing fine. In an interview during the toy trade show this week, Hassenfeld said several of Hasbro's toys making their debut demonstrate that the company can respond quickly to what consumers want. ``I think New Kids very definitely is a fascinating new introduction for us _ something that we had not been doing much of in the past,'' he said of the line of dolls and accessories based on the popular singing group. Berlin Wall commemorative puzzles from Hasbro's Milton Bradley division also illustrate the company's responsiveness, he said. ``I think it's very important that we be very topical. It just shows that we can move and move very quickly.'' Industry analysts and Hasbro insiders say that by going after a licensing pact with a hot group, such as the New Kids, Hasbro signaled a new approach to doing business. ``I think a few years ago Hasbro might not have picked up a license like New Kids on the Block. That's something Alan has accomplished to his tribute,'' said Al Verrecchia, one of Hasbro's chief operating officers. ``Alan is putting his mark on the company very quickly, signaling that he is going to very aggressively manage it for growth in the 1990s,'' said Paul Valentine, an analyst with Standard & Poor's Corp. ``The promotional side of the business had suffered in recent years,'' he said. ``The company, as was the case with other large toy companies, had become more bureaucratic and less innovative.'' Some critics had faulted Hasbro in the past for resting on its laurels and relying too heavily on classics like G.I. Joe, My Little Pony and The Game of Life. ``Alan is willing to try something that's unorthodox and innovative,'' Valentine said. Another thing Hassenfeld has been able to do is squelch the takeover rumors that surfaced after his brother's death. ``The odds of a takeover have sharply been reduced by the passage of time and the fact that Alan is very aggressively assuming control of the company,'' Valentine said. Hassenfeld said he has ``no intentions whatsoever about moving away from this business.'' A 41-year-old with a boyish sense of fun and a disarming smile, Hassenfeld expressed devotion to the company founded by his grandfather, Henry, as Hassenfeld Brothers in 1923. The founding Hassenfeld family owns 13.1 percent of Hasbro's stock and has effective voting control over another 13.6 percent. When Stephen Hassenfeld became chairman in 1980, the company, which also is parent of the Playskool division, had $102.3 million in revenue. Last year, revenue grew to $1.41 billion from $1.36 billion in 1988 and earnings were up 27 percent to $92 million from $72 million. Hassenfeld, who studied creative writing at the University of Pennsylvania, seems to genuinely like what he's doing. ``I've lived and died this business for over 21 years. It's in my blood and I love it,'' he said.``What other business could I be in that part of the day I can honestly be that seven-year-old?'' He added impishly: ``If you walked into my office and I was sitting on all fours playing ... I could legitimately get away with it and I could say I was product-testing or something.''

DOC.HEAD: East German Company Moves West, Acquires U.S. Company
DOC.TEXT: An East German company that has purchased a U.S. distributor of printing machines says it will out-hustle capitalist competitors to improve the company's sales. As Western businessmen stream to the East bloc looking for investments, the state-owned Polygraph Export-Import Co. has gone West, making East Germany's first U.S. acquisition. The West German bank that loaned Polygraph $25 million for the deal says Americans would be surprised by the entrepreneurial drive of citizens long ruled by hard-line Communists. ``If this deal is successful _ and I'm certain it will be _ it could be just the start of a series of such ventures here,'' said Arnold Schlappig, general manager of the New York branch of Bayerische Hypotheken und Weschsel-Bank, or Hypobank. ``The guys who did this deal (are) very open-minded, internationally oriented businessmen who understand capitalism,'' Schlappig said. ``Other East German companies just need an additional injection and they could export tomorrow.'' Polygraph, which exports machinery from five East German companies, said it bought Royal Zenith Inc., its U.S. distributor, to improve sales and technological ties with American businesses. The price was not disclosed. The company's name has since been changed to Planeta North America Inc. Frank an East German manager who is vice president of the new company, said the political changes in his country hastened the deal. The negotiations began while Communist hard-liner Erich Honecker was still in power in East Germany. But Seifert said there was less paperwork after Honecker was ousted Oct. 18 and democratic reformers took over, opened the Berlin Wall, brought non-Communists into the government and promised elections. ``We were hoping for a long time that this development would happen,'' said at company headquarters in a hillside industrial park just east of New York City. ``Let's say some of my dreams, politically and professionally, were realized by this.'' Seiffert, 49, a former salesman of computers and photocopiers, is one of two East Germans among 150 employees at the company, which expects sales of $50 million this year. Several members of the new U.S. management team are former executives of Royal Zenith who had left the company in recent years. Among them is the former company president, Allan Malachuk, who takes his old post. After rumors of a sale and low morale among workers for several years, ``there's an open-door policy here again,'' said operations manager Jeffrey Post, who has been with the company for 14 years. He said the German representatives are interested in making more contacts with U.S. graphics art companies to help improve designs of their printing machines _ and increase sales. In recent years, ``we had sort of an adversarial relationship with the (East German) factories. Their government was a problem back then, and it was difficult to exchange even things like blueprints and work documents.'' The company's main competitors are Japanese and West German manufacturers, which pay less than 4 percent in duties on imported machinery, compared to the 10 percent charged East Germany. ``Perhaps in America, you should have a certain perestroika,'' said Seiffert, using the Soviet term for economic restructuring to refer to U.S. tariff policy. The Bush administration has said it will make changes in trade policy after East German elections March 18. Seiffert said several investment and financing companies have asked him for ideas on East German acquisitions. He said he is not fearful that Western investors will dominate or exploit East Germany. Polygraph in 1988 accounted for $40 million of East Germany's $130 million in exports to the United States. Polygraph's associated printing companies have pioneered technological changes in the industry, said Bob McKinney, a former Royal Zenith executive who became vice president for marketing after the acquisition. Post said the sale might have aroused suspicion among Royal Zenith employees when East Germany was a strict Communist state, but not now. ``I think a big part of the resistance is gone. The Wall has come down,'' he said. ``Now that they're changing to the American system, there's no problem. It's just two guys doing business.''

DOC.HEAD: Scientist Who Found Tainted Perrier Sympathizes With French Bottler
DOC.TEXT: Tom Ward recalled reading the label on a Perrier bottle after he detected traces of the toxic chemical benzene in the bubbly water. ``The label said it had been bottled since 1863,'' said Ward, the environmental lab director for Mecklenburg County. ``I pondered over that for a few minutes. They are practically an institution, like Coke in this country. But never in my mind was there any thought of not telling someone. ``We checked (our results) very closely,'' he said. ``Once we made the call to the FDA we were 100 percent sure. There was no doubt whatsoever.'' Perrier isn't regarded lightly at the lab. Indeed, technicians there use the French sparkling water as a purity standard against which they test 25,000 water samples a year. So when benzene was found in six bottles with the same lot number last month, Ward notified federal officials and sent them two unopened bottles from the same batch. Sure enough, the Food and Drug Administration found traces of the cancer-causing chemical in both bottles. Ward's findings have turned out to be a multimillion-dollar headache for the French bottler, which has decided to dump 160 million bottles at an estimated cost of $35 million. ``We felt a lot of responsibilty ... a weight on our shoulders,'' said Ward, a 19-year county employee. Nevertheless, ``when we let it out, we knew it was the right decision.'' Earlier this week, about 72 million bottles of Perrier were withdrawn from the U.S. market based on the tests in Ward's lab. The recall since has spread to 120 countries around the world. Thad Wester, North Carolina's deputy health director, called the move ``primarily a business decision.'' ``To put it in perspective, the risks were not all inordinately great,'' he said of the chances of anyone getting cancer from drinking the water. ``What he did was what any responsible scientist would do. He recognized something was wrong and instead of just forgetting about it, he did something.'' Ward sympathized with the economic hardship the disclosure has caused for the French company, which is yanking shipments in 120 countries. ``I have concerns about that, but I'm also concerned about the benzene in the water,'' he said. ``Those concerns are greater to me than the financial problems it causes Perrier.'' In Paris, Perrier officials said some shipments of the bottled water were contaminated by a dirty filter at the company's underground spring in Vergeze, France. The filter is designed to remove naturally occurring benzene from the carbon dioxide gas that gives Perrier its distinctive bubble. ``It was complete negligence,'' said the company's managing director, Frederik Zimmer, who added that the workers involved had been disciplined. Importers have been advised to dump the bottles of the water on site and return the bottles to the company for cleaning and refilling. The decision is expected to disrupt distribution for about three months. Ward said the company was not overreacting. ``I don't think it poses an imminent health problem, but why take any additional risks?'' he said. ``I think they're acting in the right way.'' As for his staff's actions, Ward said they performed admirably. ``I think we did a good job,'' he said. ``We do this kind of testing on surface water every day. When we find contamination, we report it. But it usually doesn't cause such a stir.''

DOC.HEAD: Ford, GM Earnings Slide, Profit-Sharing Too
DOC.TEXT: Profit-sharing checks for more than a half-million General Motors Corp. and Ford Motor Co. employees will be significantly lower this spring because of a sagging U.S. auto market. No one at Chrysler Corp. will receive profit-sharing payments because the company didn't make enough money in the United States last year. Chrysler workers got an average of $720 each in 1988. The dramatic drop in profit-sharing is yet another piece of evidence that the U.S. auto industry is in recession. On Thursday, GM reported a 50 percent decline in fourth-quarter earnings, and Ford said its profits for the period plunged 72.9 percent. Earlier in the week, Chrysler said it lost $664 million in the final three months of 1989. The declines reflected stagnating sales and the high costs of incentives, including cash rebates and low-interest financing plans. Automakers said they were giving away up to $1,000 to sell each car at the end of last year. Profit-sharing figures are based, in part, on the profitability of the companies' U.S. automotive operations. For the past several years, GM and Ford have been relying on overseas earnings to help prop up the corporations profits. Chrysler has few overseas operations. Ford plans this afternoon to release the amount of its profit-sharing payments for about 150,000 hourly and salaried employees. On Thursday, Ford Treasurer David McCammon said it would be substantially less than last year's average payment of $2,800. Annual profits from Ford's U.S. automotive operations, which serve as a base for profit-sharing, declined 38 percent in 1989, McCammon said. GM officials said its 443,000 eligible hourly and salaried workers would get about $50 each in profit-sharing payments next month. Last year, GM employees got an average of $265 in profit-sharing. News of the sharply lower profit-sharing came seven months before the United Auto Workers contracts with the Big Three expire. It blackens the cloud over the talks already darkened by plant closings and temporary and indefinite layoffs, which are likely to make job security the top issue when negotiations open in July. ``The fact is that UAW workers have given the most effort and attention to rebuilding GM's strength where it counts the most, on the shop floor,'' said Stephen Yokich, head of the UAW's GM Department. ``They are not responsible for GM's costly blunders, including its repeated failures to understand and target a rapidly changing vehicle market.'' GM earned $700.2 million in the quarter ended Dec. 31, or $1.01 a share, compared with $1.4 billion, or $2.12 a share, in the same period of 1988. Ford posted profits of $314 million, or 68 cents a share, compared with $1.16 billion, or $2.42 a share, a year earlier. Ford's earnings declined largely because of a $424 million loss linked to the sale of its Rouge Steel Co. subsidiary. But even without that factor, earnings were down 36.3 percent. For the entire year, GM earned $4.22 billion, down 13.2 percent from 1988. Ford's earnings fell 27.6 percent to $3.84 billion last year. Together, Big Three profits in 1989 were $8.42 billion, 24.9 percent lower than the year before. Incentives took big bites from each of the company's earnings, especially in the fourth quarter. They could continue to take a big bite out of profits in the current quarter, especially for Chrysler. Incentives were on during all of January for the company's popular minivans, which boosted sales of light truck sales, but cost the company in the meantime. McCammon said Ford spent an average of $800 in incentives for every car and truck it sold in the fourth quarter, slightly more than double what Ford spent a year earlier. And by the end of the quarter, Ford was spending about $1,000 on incentives for each of its vehicles. ``They're as high as they ever have been,'' he said, but added that as production and inventory levels come back into line, the need for incentives will decline. GM declined to say what its incentive costs were in the fourth quarter, but officials said the company spent about $800 per vehicle during the entire year, up about $100 from 1988. It was likely that because of heavier use of incentives toward the end of the year, GM spent more than $800 a vehicle in the fourth quarter. Chrysler spokesman Tom Houston said the company does not disclose incentive costs, but it is likely that the costs weren't much different from GM's or Ford's.

DOC.HEAD: At Junk Bond Office, No More Milken, No More Jobs
With PM-Drexel, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Junk bond traders knew the end was near when the art came off the walls at Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc.'s famous Beverly Hills, Calif., office. The investment house made famous by Michael Milken began closing up shop in New York and Los Angeles on Thursday. Drexel said several thousand of the firm's 5,300 workers would get the ax today. In addition to taking down artwork, employees said Drexel changed the locks on some doors and stationed guards in lobbies to prevent workers from walking off with computers, sensitive documents and other materials. That material presumably could be sold as Wall Street's ex-powerhouse liquidates. Some employees were angry, others resigned, still others eager to move on after three years of turmoil at the firm credited with altering American finance with the junk bond _ a high-risk, high-yield piece of debt that let some small companies grow and others mount successful raids on corporate titans. Drexel's parent company filed for bankruptcy protection Tuesday in New York after defaulting on $100 million in short-term debt. Drexel blamed its demise on a capital shortage created in part by a decline in the junk bond market. An erosion of confidence in the firm didn't help either. ``The offers are pouring in,'' joked Joe Bencivenga, co-director of high-yield research in Beverly Hills, where Milken moved the junk bond division in 1978. Drexel said it was terminating the bulk of the division's 400 employees today. Bencivenga said professionals in the division _ located at the corner of Wilshire Boulevard and Rodeo Drive in a building owned by Milken and some partners _ were banding together in search of employment. ``There are a lot of individuals, a bunch of splinter groups. They form, they dissipate, they form. It's an active molecular structure,'' he said. ``People are cleaning out their stuff, typing their resumes and using the fax machine and phones extensively,'' he added. ``I don't think there's any offers yet. There's a lot of interest. It's only been one day.'' On Wall Street, firms were inundated with resumes and calls from soon-to-be ex-Drexel employees. Drexel was seeking to transfer whole departments to other firms for free as part of its unwinding. Bencivenga, who has been with Drexel since 1985 when the firm was at its heyday, was optimistic in the face of unemployment. ``I look at it as a major opportunity,'' he said. ``It's not very often in life you get to stop what you're doing'' and start anew. Some employees were angry about the frequent pleas by Drexel Chief Executive Frederick Joseph over the last three years to stand by the firm as it took a public flogging during the government's lengthy insider trading investigation. Joseph's pep talks were said to have boosted morale when Drexel hit its lowest ebb last year, pleading guilty to six felonies and agreeing to pay $650 million to settle civil and criminal fraud charges rather than face a racketeering indictment that could have crippled the firm instantly. ``There was a very high price to the loyalty we paid these guys,'' said a Drexel research analyst in New York who asked not to be named. ``We stayed and stayed and stayed. It seems at the end the reason the company went under is just a simple asset-liability problem. Who was running the show?'' Others were bitter that Drexel didn't warn its employees the end was near. The net worth of many Drexel workers, who own 54 percent of the stock in the privately held parent company, may have evaporated with the bankruptcy filing because stockholders typically stand at the end of the bankruptcy line. ``Those people aren't going to get paid anything now because the stock is worthless,'' said a longtime Drexel executive who left the firm recently. ``People could have been finding jobs out there in a normal period of time. It's just very poor management.'' The junk bond division was altered drastically by Milken's criminal problems. He quit the firm last June after his 98-count indictment, but had been working only part-time for close to a year. Under Milken's forceful and well-connected leadership, Drexel drummed up business seemingly at will and junk bonds generated large majority of the firm's profits. That changed after his departure, though Drexel still controlled 38.6 percent of junk-bond underwriting in 1989. Said Bencivenga: ``That was a whole different era, that was a whole different controversy.''

DOC.HEAD: Whittle Says 2,510 Schools Signed, $200 Million in Ads Sold for Channel One
DOC.TEXT: Whittle Communications has signed 2,510 schools to three-year contracts and has sold $200 million in advertising for its commercially sponsored Channel One news program for the classroom, debuting March 5. Christopher Whittle, chairman of Knoxville, Tenn.-based media company, said Thursday the schools have agreed to show the daily 12-minute news program, which is tailored to teens and includes two minutes a day of commercials. He said the ad contracts also cover three years, including about $65 million in the first year. That amounts to about two-thirds of the revenue that the company hopes to earn from Channel One ad sales. At a news conference, Whittle said the program will be seen in 400 schools with 300,000 students on the launch date and that 1,000 schools should be showing it by the end of March. Whittle said the number of participating schools will rise each week as the company installs television monitors and other equipment. He said was confident of reaching his goal of signing 7,000 to 8,000 schools with six million students by December. Those signed to date are in 34 states. Whittle declined to identify any of the schools or sponsors. The program has provoked critics who charge it is wrong for schools to hand over a captive audience to a commercial enterprise, selling access to makers of soap, candy or other products. The cable television industry has responded by developing commercial-free programs for use in the classroom. Turner Broadcasting Systems Inc.'s Cable News Network, for instance, has been running a daily 15-minute news program tailored to teens since August. Bert Carp, an executive at Turner, said more than 7,000 schools have enrolled to use the show called ``CNN Newsroom'' and said its surveys showed more than half of them are actively using the program. But Whittle contends that schools are ill-equipped to make use of those programs and that a survey conducted for his company indicated virtually none of 1,500 students contacted by telephone at home indicated they had seen a news program in school. Whittle blamed a lack of TV sets in classrooms. Schools that agree to show the Channel One program to their students get television monitors for every classroom, a satellite dish and two videocassette recorders. The school keeps the equipment only as long as it runs the show. In addition to the daily news show, schools are permitted to use the equipment for non-commercial programming, including specials that are being made available from public television for use in the schools. Whittle was accompanied at the news conference by former U.S. education secretary Terrell H. Bell, who heads a committee of educators advising Channel One, and others. The company also said it awarded a $900,000 grant to the University of Michigan's Institute for Social Research and the firm Interwest Applied Research to study Channel One's ``contribution to education over the next three years.'' State education officials in California and New York have banned Channel One from their public schools. Whittle said he expected to meet his goals without public schools from either state. Cynthia Kalish Samuels, a former planning producer for NBC's ``Today Show'' was named executive producer of the Channel One staff in October and has assembled a staff to produce stories for the program. She said one featured topic in the first week of programs will be the ramifications of the fall of the Berlin Wall, while subsequent weeks will have five daily segments on drugs, South Africa and the summer job outlook.

DOC.HEAD: Merchants Fret Over Spring Training Impasse
DOC.TEXT: It was a perfect day to begin spring training. A sea breeze was blowing toward right field. The sun cast crisp shadows. The air was sweet with citrus and freshly trimmed grass. But there was no crack of the bat; no ring of the cash register. ``It's kind of weird isn't it?'' Dodgertown ticket manager Olive Maiher said Thursday. ``Everything should be coming to life, and instead it's just nothing.'' Outside the empty ticket counter and souvenir stand, a man in sunglasses was taking a nap. Since 1949, Vero Beach has been decking itself in Dodger blue to welcome their major league heros from Los Angeles. This year, however, merchants and city officials are seeing red, worried about the possible loss of their share of the $300 million in revenue spring training brings to Florida each year. Only minor leaguers will be allowed to the spring training camps in Florida and Arizona under a lockout by owners, who are battling players over salaries and other revenue-related issues. Pitchers, catchers and injured players had been scheduled to report to the Dodgertown baseball compound Thursday. In Vero Beach, one of 18 spring training sites in Florida, the Dodgers pump $20 million to $25 million into the local economy each year, said J.B. Norton Jr., executive vice president of the Vero Beach-Indian River Chamber of Commerce. A lockout until the opening of the regular season would cost Vero Beach merchants up to $5 million, he said. The Dodgers' minor league teams and other activities will keep some of the revenue flowing. ``It's not going to kill us, but it's not going to feel good either,'' he said. A 1987 study by the Florida Commerce Department concluded fans spent more than $286 million at spring training and teams spent about $12 million. Among those with the most to lose by the lockout are restaurants and automobile rental agencies, said Norton. At Avis Rent A Car near the small Vero Beach airport, manager Joe Brennan has 30 cars that normally would be taken by Dodger players and personnel. He didn't even bother requesting the additional 40 cars he needed last year. ``It's really going to hurt us if the lockout goes on, but we'll survive,'' said Brennan. ``It trickles down through the whole community. If there are no games, everyone will suffer to some extent from the hot dog vendors to the gas stations. ``What's really a shame is the people who come down to see baseball and experience spring training. They are the real losers in all this.'' Both economically and emotionally, the Dodgers are held dear in Vero Beach, about 140 miles north of Miami. The town celebrated wildly following the Dodgers' 1988 World Series victory. Many residents boast the lavish Dodgertown complex far outshines the rival New York Mets' spring headquarters 20 miles south in Port St. Lucie. A Dodgers' cap is featured on the masthead of the local daily newspaper. ``This is a Dodger town and it will always be,'' said Alex Carson, a patron at Duke Snider's Restaurant and Bar, named for the Hall of Fame Brooklyn Dodger second baseman. ``If there's no spring training this year, you know the old saying, `We'll get 'em next year.''' Near Duke Snider Road in Dodgertown, Bill Richards and Elmer Otto sat on a railroad tie and took it easy Thursday. There were wearing their blue Dodger spring training T-Shirts and caps, but it didn't seem like a work day. Richards is assigned to the batting cage and Otto is a cashier at the stadium. Richards raised his hand in a mock toast. ``Well, here's to spring training,'' he said. ``Yup,'' said Otto. They got up and walked toward the dugouts.

DOC.HEAD: Futures Watchdog Declares Drexel's British Unit in Default
With PM-Drexel
DOC.TEXT: Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc.'s British unit has been declared in default, and regulatory groups have begun liquidating its contracts in cocoa, coffee, base metals and financial futures. The Association of Futures Brokers and Dealers,the International Commodities Clearing House and the London Metal Exchange took the action Thursday. Drexel refused to comment. The investment bank's parent, Drexel Burnham Lambert Group Inc., filed for U.S. Chapter 11 bankruptcy court protection Tuesday and began the biggest fire sale in the history of the securities industry, liquidating billions of dollars in assets. An statement by the British association of brokers and dealers said it took swift action Thursday after receiving information suggesting Drexel violated association ``rules relating to financial record keeping and financial resources.'' The Financial Times, Britain's leading business daily, quoted an unidentified London Metal Exchange representative as saying: ``The Drexel people can't even sign a check without the (association's) approval. But they are acting in a very gentlemanly manner, considering the circumstances.'' Earlier Thursday, the Bank of England outlined a special settlements procedure to ease payments on foreign exchange dealings involving Drexel's British unit. The British central bank said that Drexel's trading clients may make all payments due to Drexel to the Bank of England until Tuesday. The bank said it would hold the money until it was satisfied that Drexel had paid the clients the counter-value. This arrangement is stopgap measure to avoid liquidity problems stemming from market reaction to Drexel's bankruptcy filing in the United States.

DOC.HEAD: Federated-Allied Say Sales Down First Two Months
LaserPhoto CS1
DOC.TEXT: The Federated and Allied retailing companies will see lower sales for the first two months of this year but are committed to surviving their bankruptcy reorganizations intact, their managers say. ``We're going to have a very poor fourth quarter,'' James M. Zimmerman, president and chief operating officer of Federated Department Stores Inc. and Allied Stores Corp., said Thursday. Sales for the 260 stores that Federated and Allied operate in 28 states were up 3 percent in December from the previous year, but declined 9 percent in January and are down 4 percent this month, Zimmerman said. He declined to be more specific. January sales figures will be released March 5, while fourth-quarter and year-end results are to be released to creditors and the public May 3, company spokeswoman Carol Sanger said. The Federated-Allied fiscal year ended Feb. 3. Federated and Allied could emerge from their Chapter 11 reorganizations in as soon as eight months, said G. William Miller, the former U.S. Treasury secretary hired Jan. 16 as chairman and chief executive officer of Federated Stores Inc., the newly created parent of Federated and Allied. The two retailers, owned by Canada's Campeau Corp., filed Jan. 15 for protection from creditors, listing $7.7 billion in debts. Miller, addressing reporters with Zimmerman and new Federated-Allied chairman Allen I. Questrom, said his optimistic projection could occur if Federated and Allied develop reorganization plans within the 120 days they are allowed, and creditors and the U.S. Bankruptcy Court give quick approval. But Miller said, ``I don't promise you that that's possible or even feasible.'' Miller said he would like to keep Federated and Allied intact and not sell off divisions, because he thinks doing so would reduce their value for creditors. Zimmerman said management is reconsidering the previously proposed sale of Federated's New York-based Bloomingdale's store division, to evaluate whether Bloomingdale's would be more valuable to retain. Miller described Federated and Allied as viable and profitable, but said they must adjust the staggering debts amassed when the parent Campeau Corp. of Toronto acquired Allied in 1986 and Federated in 1988. ``The capital structure is what's broke, and is what brings us here today,'' Zimmerman said. The Chapter 11 filings have noticeably hurt confidence of customers and merchandise suppliers. Federated and Allied are now receiving about 85 percent of the merchandise ordered, compared with about 25 percent the week prior to the Jan. 15 filing, Zimmerman said. The bankruptcy court's approval Feb. 9 of $700 million in debtor-in-possession financing and $1.7 billion in credit facilities for receiving goods provided a critical boost for the two companies, Questrom said. Questrom, lured away from Neiman-Marcus Feb. 2 with a five-year contract that will pay him $1.2 million annually, said Federated and Allied face a challenge in trying to maintain market shares against financially healthy competitors. He said he will focus on drawing back more of Federated and Allied's vendors and in adjusting merchandise inventories to keep customers coming in. Zimmerman said he expects no across-the-board layoffs among the combined 100,000 Federated and Allied employees. The companies have suffered no major employee losses because of the Chapter 11 filings, but need to work on retaining employees, Questrom said.

DOC.HEAD: Kimberly-Clark Names Heir Apparent to Chairman
DOC.TEXT: Paper products manufacturer Kimberly-Clark Corp. has appointed a new head for the board of director's executive committee, putting him in line to take over the company when its chairman retires. Wayne R. Sanders, 42, also was named to the newly created position of president of world consumer, nonwoven and service and industrial operations. For now, Sanders also will continue as president of the personal care sector and have additional responsibility for certain corporate administrative functions, the company said Thursday. The company's current chairman, 63-year-old Darwin E. Smith, retires in two years. All but two of the operating divisions will report to Sanders, the Dallas-based company said. Sanders will remain based in Wisconsin, where much of the company's operations are located to help oversee a $2 billion capital expenditure program. Kimberly-Clark also announced two other executive changes it said were part of its ``continuing plan for management succession and development.'' James D. Bernd, 56, president of the household products sector, was named to the board and its executive committee. Claudio X. Gonzalez, 55, a board member and head of the company's Mexican affiliate, was named to the executive committee. Last year, Kimberly-Clark sold $5.7 billion worth of Kleenex, disposable diapers, paper towels, health care products, newsprint and other specialty paper items.

DOC.HEAD: Trade Creditors May Get Paid, Bond Holders Won't Get All They're Owed
Laserphoto CS1
DOC.TEXT: Executives of Federated Department Stores Inc. and Allied Stores Corp. say their goal is to repay the full amount owed to trade creditors. But bondholders who financed Campeau Corp.'s takeovers of the two retailing companies will have to forgive some of the $7.7 billion debt listed in the bankruptcy petition filed Jan. 15 by Federated and Allied, they said. ``It is clear that some of that (debt) will not be decapitalized,'' G. William Miller, chairman of parent company Federated Stores Inc., said Thursday. ``Some of it will have to disappear, permanently. ``For those who hold the debt, the market is no longer there ... We want them to get a reasonable recovery.'' Miller, Federated-Allied Chairman Allen Questrom, and President James Zimmerman read prepared statements Thursday to reporters and representatives of Federated-Allied's largest creditors. They built on the theme that Federated and Allied, which operate 260 stores in 28 states, are close to returning to business as usual and expect to be profitable. They also acknowledged that mistakes were made in financing the acquisition of Allied in 1986 and Federated in 1988 by Toronto-based Campeau, and in operating the stores the past two years. Zimmerman said that by September 1989, it was evident that Federated and Allied could not meet their debt payments and that major financial restructuring was necessary. But he said the decision to file for protection from creditors under Chapter 11 of the Bankruptcy Act wasn't made until January, and then primarily to prevent further erosion in the value of the businesses. ``There was no plot to deceive any creditors,'' Zimmerman said. ``There was no grand scheme in Toronto or elsewhere to trick anybody.'' ``These are quality companies ... companies of this caliber do not belong in Chapter 11,'' he said. ``We regret that any of our creditors were left holding the bag with checks that did not clear prior to our filing. Questrom was vice chairman of Federated Department Stores when it was acquired by Campeau. He said he left because of reservations _ ``as have been so tragically confirmed since'' _ about the parent company's ability to handle the debt it had assumed. He subsequently became president of Nieman-Marcus, but returned earlier this month _ for a guaranteed $10 million _ to find a company ``that deserved better than what it was getting, better than what had been inherited in the wake of two massive retail takeovers, inordinate organizational changes and months of debilitating uncertainty,'' he said. Miller, a former U.S. Secretary of the Treasury, said he assumed leadership last month of the parent company, Campeau (U.S.), on condition that it be renamed and assured autonomy, distancing itself from Robert Campeau, the Canadian real estate developer who engineered the junk bond-financed takeovers of Allied and Federated. Although creditors were invited to hear the presentations by the Federated-Allied officers, no questions were permitted by the U.S. Trustee who conducted the meeting. At a news conference following the meeting, officers refused to discuss specifics about reorganization. Zimmerman acknowledged that some stores will be closed, perhaps ``a handful of stores across the country,'' but said he expects no across-the-board layoffs. Miller said it was premature to sketch a reorganization plan publicly. ``I would prefer to bring out a comprehensive plan where I can make sure all the pieces fit and all the wheels mesh and that it turns smoothly rather than feed out ideas before they have been researched, before they have been discussed with the other side,'' Miller said. Miller said Federated-Allied still have three months to file their plan with the U.S. Bankruptcy Court. The Federated group includes Bloomingdale's (17 stores) and Abraham and Straus (15), both based in New York; Burdine's (30) of Miami; Lazarus (44) of Cincinnati; and Rich's (26) of Atlanta. The Allied group includes The Bon Marche (40 stores) of Seattle; Jordan Marsh (26) of Boston; Maas Brothers (38) of Tampa; and Stern's (24) of Paramus, N.J.

DOC.HEAD: Driver Training Took a Bite out of Domino's Pizza Profits
DOC.TEXT: Domino's Pizza Inc. tried to cut down on legal actions last year by giving its delivery people driving instruction, but the safety effort also helped steer profits down 16.4 percent. The Ann Arbor-based company also said launching a new product, pan pizza, led to a drop in 1989 profits to $5.1 million, compared with net income of $6.1 million in 1988. Domino's has been the defendant in a series of legal actions blaming traffic accidents on drivers rushing to meet the 30-minute pizza delivery deadline. The company said costs come out of store budgets and not drivers' pockets. A videotaped driver-training program was instituted in 1989. The privately held company's 5,200 stores, two-thirds of them owned by about 800 franchisees, sold an estimated 250 million pizzas in 1989, Domino's President Dave Black said. Systemwide sales rose 9.6 percent to $2.5 billion, compared with $2.3 billion in 1988, and Domino's corporate revenue rose 9 percent to $1.14 billion from $1.05 billion a year earlier, the company said.

DOC.HEAD: Castle Announces Dole Foods Spinoff, Fourth Quarter Earnings
DOC.TEXT: Castle & Cooke Inc. intends to separate its Dole Food Co. Inc. from its real estate operations, officials announced the day they released year-end earnings showing an 18 percent drop from 1988. Castle & Cooke noted that its earnings the prior year had included a $17.9 million pretax gain on the sale of Amfac Inc. common stock. The fully diluted year-end earnings showed a 6.2 percent loss, excluding the 1988 investment gain, according to information released Thursday. Castle's real estate development business reported higher earnings, while its Dole food business was hurt by imported fruit bans and strike-related costs. The conglomerate's 1989 fourth-quarter earnings were $23.8 million, or 40 cents a share, on revenue of $700 million. That compares with earnings of $19.3 million, or 33 cents a share including the investment gain, on revenue of $588.8 million during the same period in 1988. Under the proposed spinoff, stockholders would receive an additional share of Dole for each share of Castle held, the company said in a statement. Castle & Cooke would continue to be listed on the New York and Pacific stock exchanges, and an application is being made to list Dole on the same exchanges. The planned spinoff of Dole probably will occur in May or June, pending a favorable federal tax ruling and other governmental approvals, Castle said. Castle said it anticipates the tax ruling will enable the spinoff to be tax free to Castle and its shareholders. ``By separating into two companies, the management of each will be able to adopt strategies and pursue objectives appropriate to its specific business,'' said David H. Murdock, Castle's chairman and chief executive. Under the proposal, Murdock will be chairman and chief executive of both companies. Castle plans to retain all of its developed and undeveloped real estate holdings, including its approximately 98 percent ownership of the Hawaiian island of Lana'i, and all of its developments in California and Arizona. Its headquarters will be in Honolulu. Dole will be a food products company, incorporated in Hawaii, with headquarters in Los Angeles and Honolulu. Castle & Cooke reported 1989 earnings of $94.9 million, or $1.60 a share, on revenue of $2.7 billion. That compares to 1988 fully diluted earnings of $100.8 million, or $1.90 a share excluding the Amfac stock sale, on revenue of $2.4 billion. Including the investment gain, net income in 1988 was $112.3 million, or $2.05 per share. Dole's 1989 earnings were hurt by the temporary ban on the sale of Chilean fruit in early 1989, and by strike-related costs and reduced prices in Dole's fresh vegetables group. Dole also incurred start-up costs related to the introduction of new fruit juice products in the United States and Japan.

DOC.HEAD: British Stocks Higher
DOC.TEXT: Stock prices were higher on the London exchange Friday, as the market took hope from a steady demand for oil, water and banking stocks. At noon, the key Financial Times-Stock Exchange index, which measures the value of Britain's top 100 companies in terms of market capitalization, was up 14.1 points or 0.6 percent at 2327.9 points. The narrower Financial Times 30 share index was 8.7 points firmer, a gain of 0.47 percent, at 1838.2 points. Volume was a moderate 209.2 million shares.

DOC.HEAD: Nike Accuses L.A. Gear of Copying Design of Air Jordan Shoe
DOC.TEXT: Nike Inc. officials said they weren't flattered when they first saw L.A. Gear Inc.'s MVP-1 shoe, which they maintain is an imitation of their popular Air Jordan basketball shoe. Nike filed suit against L.A. Gear in U.S. District Court here on Thursday, maintaining that L.A. Gear copied the Air Jordan design. The suit alleging patent infringement and unfair competition also contends L.A. Gear copied the Nike-style sole for the MVP-1 and five other shoes. ``Imitation can be a form of flattery but this crosses the line,'' said Lindsay Stewart, an attorney for the Beaverton, Ore.-based Nike, the nation's top athletic shoemaker ahead of Reebok and No. 3 L.A. Gear. Gil N. Schwartzberg, chief administrative officer for L.A. Gear, denied the company copied Nike designs. He speculated Nike's lawsuit may be motivated by L.A. Gear's aggressive entry into the men's shoe market. ``When you're talking about basketball shoes they all look somewhat similar to one another,'' he said. ``There are a lot of shoes out there that look a lot more like the Air Jordan, but we're the one they sue.'' The Air Jordan is among Nike's top-selling shoes, generating $45 million in revenue for Nike since September 1988. It is named after Chicago Bulls superstar Michael Jordan. ``The Air Jordan is consistently the product we're concerned about,'' Stewart said. ``It is our bread and butter product. We really feel it is the backbone of our basketball shoe line and it is a big issue to us.'' Stewart said the Air Jordan has distinctive design features, including use of colors and materials. ``It's our contention that the MVP-1 incorporated most if not all of those distinctive features and they've done that to our disadvantage,'' Stewart said. He said Nike will seek substantial damages not yet undetermined.

DOC.HEAD: Olds Cuts Price on Two Ciera Models
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 1 graf after the 8th graf pvs, `I think ...' to include earlier announced VW and BMW price cuts; picks up 9th graf pvs, `As of ...'.
DOC.HEAD: With PM-Earns-Autos, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The Oldsmobile Division of General Motors Corp. said it was making rare price cuts of as much as $500 on the price of two of its models in an unusual attempt to spur sales in a sluggish auto market. While the nation's Big Three automakers all have incentives in effect to boost sales that have slumped since the model year began in October, Oldsmobile spokesman Gus Buenz said he didn't believe the others had cut base prices this year. ``As far as I know, this is the first time that I can recall that GM has, and certainly Oldsmobile, reduced prices in the model year,'' he said. ``Normally, when it occurs, it is at the introduction of a new model year.'' ``It's certainly not the trend. It is unusual,'' PaineWebber Inc. of New York analyst Ann Knight said. ``It's not unprecedented. It's done when the models are slow. The sales on those models have been weak.'' Increasingly in recent years, GM, Ford Motor Co. and Chrysler Corp. have offered cash rebates to buyers and other incentives to dealers to stimulate car sales. The increasing reliance on incentives has led some industry analysts lately to suggest that Detroit was simply pricing its cars too high. While the automakers might prefer price cuts to incentives, Knight said she was unsure if other companies would follow Oldsmobile's lead. ``I think companies would like to have price reductions instead of incentives. A price cut is more disciplined a relief. But incentives are so popular _ Americans love bargains,'' Knight said. ``It's the way Americans like to shop.'' As the 1990 model year began last fall, West German automakers Volkswagen AG and BMW cut prices on some of their cars, retreating from the rebate wars. As of Feb. 16, the price of Oldsmobile's Ciera S coupe drops $200 to $12,195, while the Ciera S sedan's price drops $500 to $12,495. ``If you take $200 off the base or offer a $200 rebate on the car, it's the same for the customer. But, the customer can start with a lower price when he's bargaining with the dealer,'' Buenz said. The price cuts have no effect on the current incentives on the models that factories are offering to car dealers. Buenz refused to disclose the amounts of the incentives. Cutlass Ciera S sales comprise 12 percent of total Oldsmobile sales, which totalled 163,208 between Oct. 1 and Feb. 10, the current model year. Earlier Thursday, GM said its earnings fell 50 percent in the fourth quarter of 1989 to $700.2 million from $1.4 billion in the last three months of 1988.
The NASDAQ Composite Index at 11am was 430.30 up 0.69 from the previous day's close.

DOC.HEAD: More Borrowing Amid Reports of Layoffs
DOC.TEXT: Financial troubles sent the Bank of New England Corp. to the Federal Reserve Bank to borrow money again amid reports the bank is ready to cut its workforce by some 5,500 employees. Bank spokesman Thomas Lavelle said the latest borrowing for the region's largest bank was ``on target with expectations.'' The Federal Reserve Bank of Boston Thursday reported loans totaling $931 million to member banks this week, compared with $723 million the week before. ``Certainly the finger does point at Bank of New England,'' said James Moynihan, senior vice president at Advest Inc. The Boston Globe today reported that bank sources confirmed the bank is expected to announce a massive reduction plan that would layoff some 2,500 employees and trim as many as 3,000 other employees through attrition and the sale of various subsidiaries. Bank officials did not immediately return calls this morning seeking confirmation of the move. The reductions, expected to be announced next week when the bank releases its 1989 financial statement, could have one-third of the bank's 17,500 employees off the payroll by the end of April, the newspaper said. A spokeswoman for the bank declined comment, the Globe said. Bank of New England, which had estimated losses exceeding $1 billion in 1989 because of bad real estate loans, has seen depositors withdraw millions of dollars. The bank has acknowledged that during the past few weeks it has sought help at the Federal Reserve Bank, considered to be the lender of last resort. The bank has been trying to raise cash by selling off $6 billion worth of assets. As of Thursday, the bank had sold or has agreements to sell $2.7 billion in assets, Lavelle said. The bank also announced Thursday it had reached an agreement to sell $1 billion of its loan portfolio to the Canadian Imperial Bank of Commerce. ``A lot of deals have not closed yet,'' Moynihan said, explaining the bank's persistent cash crunch. ``My guess was you might see them at this level.'' The bank might be feeling increased pressure from customers who held large certificates of deposit, exceeding the insured amount of $100,000, that have now reached their maturity dates, analysts said. Many of those certificates are bought on 90-day cycles, which means they were purchased prior to the recent gloomy disclosures about Bank of New England. These large depositors can be expected to transfer their money to other banks when the certificates reach maturity, Moynihan said. Bank of New England said it was selling assets from its Communications Lending Group, whose portfolio includes loans to companies in the U.S. communications and media industries. Canadian Imperial, one of the 10 largest banks in North America, will acquire the loans in stages, with payments planned to begin this month and to be completed by April 30. The loans acquired by Canadian Imperial are being sold at face value, meaning ``there's no gain on this,'' Lavelle said. But analysts say until Bank of New England's finances become more stable, the bank's priority is to raise cash. ``The sale of this portion of our loan portfolio is a major component of our asset sales plan,'' H. Ridgely Bullock, the bank's interim chairman, said in a statement. ``It will significantly bolster our liquidity and improve our capital ratios.''

The stock market staged a moderate advance today in response to better-than-expected news on international trade. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials climbed 7.43 to 2,656.98 by 11 a.m. on Wall Street. Gainers outnumbered losers by about 7 to 5 in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed issues, with 680 up, 467 down and 527 unchanged. Volume on the Big Board came to 52.72 million shares at midmorning. The Commerce Department reported that the nation's trade deficit shrank to $7.17 billion in December from $10.29 billion the month before. That came as a pleasant surprise to forecasters, who had generally been expecting the gap between imports and exports to be about $9 billion. But analysts said traders remained leery of chasing after the recent upswing in stock prices. Fears persist that a rise in worldwide interest rates so far in 1990 might have increased the chances of a recession and a continuing slump in corporate profits. Hewlett-Packard fell 2 to 45\. The company reported earnings for its fiscal quarter ended Jan. 31 of 72 cents a share, down from 83 cents in the comparable period a year earlier. Gainers among the blue chips included International Business Machines, up | at 104]; United Technologies, up ] at 51}; General Electric, up { at 63[, and Exxon, up ] at 48~. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks rose .33 to 185.03. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index was up .33 at 359.93.

DOC.HEAD: Crop Futures Open Lower; Profit-Taking Seen in Beans
DOC.TEXT: Grain and soybean futures prices were mostly lower in early trading today on the Chicago Board of Trade, with soybeans leading the way amid profit-taking. Soybeans for near-term delivery fell about 2 cents within minutes of the opening after climbing more than 4 cents Thursday in response to an active European market. Analysts said this morning's decline reflected both a weaker European soybean market and disappointment that soybean futures failed to follow through on Thursday's rally on a strictly technical basis when trading opened this morning. Some of this morning's overall weakness was seen as profit-taking and position-evening ahead of the three-day weekend. The markets will be closed Monday for Presidents' Day. In early trading, wheat futures prices were { cent to 1 cent lower with the contract for delivery in March at $3.85} a bushel; corn futures were } cent to 1 cent lower with March at $2.41} a bushel; oat futures were \ cent to } cent lower with March at $1.39} a bushel; soybeans were 2\ cents lower to 1 cent higher with March at $5.69 a bushel. Cattle futures were mostly higher while pork futures were mostly lower in early trading on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange. Live cattle were .10 cent lower to .25 cent higher with February at 79.67 cents a pound; feeder cattle were unchanged to .08 cent higher with March at 82.10 cents a pound; live hogs were .17 cent to .30 cent lower with February at 49.65 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were 1 cent lower to .03 cent higher with February at 50.25 cents a pound. Pork belly futures moved sharply higher Thursday amid reports the United States is considering subsidizing meat sales to the Soviet Union to boost exports. Hog futures fell Thursday while cattle futures advanced.

DOC.HEAD: Former Steel Exec Trying to Loosen Aluminum's Hold on Can Industry
Graphic
DOC.TEXT: Steel industry veteran Tim Moran believes he can loosen aluminum's grip on the beverage can industry with a less expensive steel container that has won enthusiastic approval from Pepsi and Coke. But if Moran and the steel industry are to penetrate aluminum's 96 percent share of the market, the key may not necessarily be in pricing their product but recycling it. ``If cost were the only factor, the potential switch from aluminum to steel would be greater,'' said Harold Sohn, an official at Ball Corp., a leading can producer based in Muncie, Ind. The aluminum can, he said, ``really is an environmentally sound package, and brewers and soft drink manufacturers want to be in that kind of package.'' The steel industry recognizes the need to recycle, and has formed the Steel Can Recycling Institute. Moran also recognizes that need, and created a recycling division within his 2-year-old company, Bev-Pak Inc. The 43-year-old Pittsburgh native left as general manager of the tin plate division of USX Corp. in 1987 to form Bev-Pak, which began production a year ago at Monticello in northwest Indiana, one of the world's largest steel-producing regions. Moran had seen the two-piece aluminum can slowly replace the three-piece steel product while the aluminum industry built a recycling infrastructure so efficient that today more than half its cans come back as scrap. Aluminum, which in 1964 accounted for only 2 percent of the beverage can market, had half of it by 1977 and reached 92 percent in 1983. In 1988, the last year for which the Can Manufacturers Institute has complete figures, aluminum accounted for 77.9 billion of the 81.2 billion beverage cans produced in this country. The price of aluminum cans has risen with its market share, and the cost advantage of steel had reached as much as $8 per 1,000 cans when Bev-Pak was starting out. Still, Moran sensed skepticism. ``Bev-Pak comes on the scene, builds a $100 million steel can plant, and the industry can't believe it,'' Moran said. His 200-employee plant can produce 1,600 cans per minute, or 2 billion cans per year. That represents half the total steel beverage can output in this country. Moran's customer base stretches around the key industrial cities of the Midwest. Soft-drink giants PepsiCo Inc. and Coca-Cola Co., leading users of cans, supported him from the start _ he considers them the ``core advocates that were the base of the business'' _ and beer brewers are starting to show interest. Bev-Pak recently added a line to produce cans for Miller Brewing Co. ``There is a place in the market for Bev-Pak. We've got major, billion-dollar companies watching us,'' Moran said. Moran estimates 20 percent of his cans are recycled, some collected through a Bev-Pak division called Recycle Indiana Resources. It draws upon a network of 400 recyclers in Indiana, Ohio and northern Illinois, operates 11 recycling trailers around Indianapolis and runs motor routes in other Indiana and Ohio cities. The two-piece steel can, with its aluminum top, is nearly identical to the all-aluminum can but slightly heavier. ``They're both so light today that it's almost impossible for the consumer to tell the difference,'' said Sal Porrazzo, director of environmental affairs for PepsiCo Inc. The competition between the two metals is fundamental to keeping prices down, Porrazzo said. Pepsi is using steel for 10 percent to 12 percent of its can packaging, he said. The steel can is produced at a lower cost because steel is cheaper than aluminum, but that factor becomes a negative in recycling. Where aluminum cans can fetch about 50 cents a pound, steel is closer to 10 cents or less. ``We certainly want to be in environmentally sound packaging,'' Porrazzo said. ``The issue that comes up is, are steel cans recyclable? ``When you get to consumer recycling aspects, there's a value difference that singles steel out as not being recyclable because it is not as valuable,'' Porazzo said. ``You shouldn't penalize a package just because its recycled value is not as high.'' Sohn, director of industrial affairs for Ball's Denver-based Package Products Groups, said aluminum's market domination was based on recyclability. Ball in 1973 opened a beverage can plant in Findlay, Ohio, with two steel lines, but converted one to aluminum by the mid-1980s. When it opened a new plant in Conroe, Texas, in 1987, it had one steel line and one aluminum. Its other five beverage can plants produce only aluminum cans, Sohn said. ``We make what the customer wants. We don't force something on them. Clearly, there's been a preference over the years for the aluminum, because of its recyclability and recycling weight,'' Sohn said. Customer interest in steel is growing, and the chances of steel regaining a greater share of the market are strong if aluminum prices remain high and steel gets its recycling program off the ground, Sohn said. The nation's top steel producers established the Steel Can Recycling Institute in 1988. Steel is the most recycled material in the world, and institute figures show twice as much steel was recycled in this country from 1979-88 than all other recycled materials combined. However, consumers weren't getting the message. ``It is fair to say the industry has not done a very good job of telling people they had a recycling infrastructure in place,'' said Elizabeth Olenbush, the institute's director of marketing.

DOC.HEAD: 1989 Trade Deficit Smallest in Five Years
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Inserts grafs 5-7, But the Bush, with comment. This also moved on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. trade deficit, aided by a dramatic 30 percent improvement in December, narrowed to $108.58 billion last year to post the smallest yearly imbalance since 1984, the government reported today. While economists were pleasantly surprised by the $7.17 billion December deficit, they were unimpressed by the modest decline for the year. The 8.4 percent decline in the annual deficit, down from $118.53 billion in 1988, represented a sharp slowing in the pace of improvement. The deficit had dropped 22.1 percent in 1988. Many economists are forecasting that the country's trade performance could actually worsen this year after two years of improvements as America's dependence on foreign oil grows to record highs and consumers' appetite for foreign goods shows little sign of slackening. But the Bush administration hailed the new trade figures as an indication that the improvement evident since 1988 was not in danger of stalling out. Commerce Undersecretary Michael Darby noted that U.S. exports were up 13 percent, outpacing a 7.3 percent rise in imports. ``Growth in exports was strong across most categories of goods, including ... a wide variety of manufactured goods, especially machinery and telecommunications equipment,'' he said. As usual, the country's largest imbalance in 1989 was with Japan, a $49 billion deficit that accounted for 45 percent of the total. Another big part of the deficit came from oil imports, which surged 27.2 percent in 1989 to $48.94 billion. It was the highest yearly total since a $52.4 billion foreign oil bill in 1984. One of the primary reasons analysts are looking for little or no improvement in the trade deficit this year is a belief that U.S. dependence on foreign oil will continue to grow. The American Petroleum Institute reported that imports reached an all-time record of 54 percent of total demand in January while domestic production fell to its lowest level in a quarter-century. The December deficit of $7.17 billion was the lowest monthly imbalance since a $6.79 billion deficit in December 1984. The 30 percent improvement from November's $10.29 billion deficit occurred because exports rose 2.4 percent to $31.11 billion, the second-highest level on record, while imports fell 5.9 percent to $38.28 billion. The trade deficit is the difference between imports and exports. For December, the $3.1 billion improvement represented a big jump in American exports of aircraft, reflecting the end of the Boeing strike, and smaller increases in office equipment, artwork and antiques and industrial machinery. The decline in imports in December represented in part a $300 million decline in oil shipments, which reflected a drop in volume that offset a rise in price. The Bush administration is counting on a continued improvement in the trade deficit this year to dampen protectionist sentiment in Congress and to spur overall economic growth. However, many private forecasters are predicting that the deficit will begin rising this year, reflecting slower growth in U.S. exports and the higher foreign oil bill. ``It is pretty fundamental that we are not competitive in world trade,'' said Allen Sinai, chief economist of the Boston Co. ``If Americans won't buy American goods, there is no reason to expect the rest of the world to do so.'' For 1989, exports climbed 13 percent to an all-time high of $364.35 billion. Imports also reached a record high of $472.93 billion, up 7.3 percent from 1988. The $49 billion deficit with Japan was down slightly from a $51.8 billion imbalance in 1988. Other large deficits occurred with Taiwan, $13 billion; Canada, $9.62 billion; and China, $6.18 billion. One of the biggest surpluses was with the Soviet Union, with U.S. exports exceeding Soviet imports by $3.57 billion.

DOC.HEAD: Vuitton Family to Purchase Lanvin Couture House
DOC.TEXT: An investment group led by the Vuitton family launched a buyout of the famed Lanvin couture house Friday, announcing it plans to buy 95 percent of the company's shares. The Orcofi investment group said it wants to buy the shares from the French subsidiary of the British bank Midland, with the goal of jointly controlling Lanvin with the L'Oreal SA cosmetics firm. L'Oreal is the world's largest cosmetics company. Leon Bressler, who joined Lanvin in September after working for Midland Bank SA, will be retained as Lanvin's chairman, Orcofi said in a press statement. Bressler said last year that a takeover was expected, allowing Midland to take a profit and invest in other areas. Lanvin posted losses of the equivalent of $17.5 million in 1988 but earned a $53 million profit under 1989 restructuring. The house, founded in 1890 by Jeanne Lavin, retained ready-to-wear designer Claude Montana last year to run its haute couture department but his first collection drew boos from fashion critics in January. Orcofi holds an 85.5 percent stake in Vuitton Investissement Gestion, the conduit for most of the Vuitton family's holding in the luxury conglomerate Louis Vuitton Moet Hennessey (LVMH). The purchase of the Lanvin stake follows investments by Orcofi in other luxury-goods companies, including the leather tannery Gordon-Choisy SA and Luxury Stores Investment, an international distribution concern. The Vuitton family has been at odds with Bernard Arnault, who shares control with Guinness PLC in Jacques Rober SA, a holding company with a 45 percent stake in LVMH shares. Arnault has said on several occastions that he would like to oust Henry Racamier, who represents the Vuitton family in LVMH, from Louis Vuitton SA, the baggage and leather goods maker. The dispute has repeatedly delayed the group's annual meeting and LVMH hasn't yet produced confirmed revenue figures for 1989.
