DOC.HEAD: Drexel Lived, Died in Free-Market Style
AP News Analysis
DOC.TEXT: Drexel Burnham Lambert, the pioneering Wall Street firm that abruptly collapsed last week, met disaster in the same go-it-alone style that once had brought so much success. During the glory years of the ``junk'' bond market it helped create, Drexel stamped itself as a maverick operation driven by aggressiveness and innovation. Then, after the firm's fortunes took a severe downward turn, few allies from either Wall Street or Washington stood ready to come to the rescue. So Drexel's transformation within a matter of months from the fifth largest firm in the securities business to Chapter 11 bankruptcy was widely described as a classic tale of ``live by the sword, die by the sword'' capitalism. ``It was a typical example of Wall Street excess,'' as one veteran analyst put it. ``You get something good and you push it until it blows up.'' Five years ago, Drexel seemed anything but a doomed business. Led by superstar financier Michael Milken, it dominated the market for high-yield, lower-quality bonds used to raise money for corporations of less than ``blue chip'' standing, and later to finance a boom in corporate takeovers and buyouts. By last week, though, all of Drexel's good fortune had run out. Milken was gone as part of a December 1988 agreement between the firm and the federal government to settle charges of fraud, and Drexel faced a host of other legal battles. Competitors had started gaining on it even as the junk-bond game was cooling. The woes of the ``junk'' market intensified late last summer when a deal in which Drexel played no part _ Campeau Corp.'s acquisition of Federated Department Stores and Allied Stores _ went sour. Finally, Drexel began to look in desperation for a merger partner or other source of outside capital, but found no takers. Regulators, after inspecting the firm on the brink of failure, declined to intervene. In no small measure, observers say, Drexel fell victim to its own success, the commotion it created, and maybe even the envy it aroused. As a prominent force behind the debt-financed buyout boom, Drexel had come to be seen as ``a source of aggravation and frustration'' to many government officials, said Lawrence Eckenfelder, an analyst who follows the securities industry for the rival house of Prudential-Bache Securities. Furthermore, he noted, because Drexel previously had disposed of the part of its brokerage business that dealt with the public, ``you didn't have a sense that the consumer had to be protected.'' The hunt for a merger partner, meanwhile, was severely hampered by the specter of Drexel's legal problems. ``That was probably the major thing that scared everybody away,'' Eckenfelder said. If Drexel once thrived as a seemingly indispensible part of the junk-bond business, it expired because it became ``irrelevant,'' in the view of Charles Vincent, a financial-services analyst at the Provident National Bank in Philadelphia. ``The junk-bond market no longer depended on Drexel, and they weren't doing anything outside of that that was unique on Wall Street,'' Vincent said. ``No one depended on them. Their failure represented no threat to financial stability.'' Such businesslike appraisals, of course, were cold comfort to the 5,000 Drexel employees left to cast about for other employment in an industry job market that has been tightening ever since the 1987 crash in stock prices. Drexel's other likely legacy, most observers agree, is a lasting role for junk bonds as a capital-raising tool in business _ though perhaps never again to the extent that they were used, or abused, over the last few years. ``I'm sure Drexel rubbed people the wrong way,'' said one analyst who declined to be identified. ``But I think it was more jealousy than anger. Any other firm on the Street, given half the chance, would have done the same thing.'' Said Eckenfelder: ``It was scary in a way to see how quickly they could fall.'' --- Editors note: Chet Currier has covered Wall Street for the AP since 1974.

DOC.HEAD: AT&T, Mitsubishi Announce Computer Chip Venture
DOC.TEXT: American Telephone & Telegraph Co. will produce computer memory chips for the international market under a joint venture with Mitsubishi Electric Corp. of Japan, the companies announced. The five-year agreement between Mitsubishi and AT&T Microelectronics, an AT&T division based in Berkeley Heights, N.J., involves technology sharing, worldwide marketing and manufacturing of SRAM microchips, company officials said Thursday. SRAM is an acronym for static random access memory, a type of computer memory chip that stores information as long as the power to the computer is maintained. SRAMs are used in computer workstations, advanced personal computers, super minicomputers and telecommunications equipment. Mitsubishi will provide design and engineering expertise for the chips, which will be made at AT&T's Orlando semiconductor plant. This is the first time AT&T has teamed up with a Japanese company in the semiconductor business, said company officials, who refused to disclose terms of the multimillion-dollar deal. AT&T hopes the venture will enhance the company's efforts to sell chips on the international market, officials said. ``Our goal is to rapidly increase sales worldwide to original-equipment manufacturers,'' William J. Warwick, president of AT&T Microelectronics, said in a statement. Preliminary work on the SRAM chip already has begun in Orlando, said Mary Lou Ambrus, a spokeswoman for AT&T Microelectronics Last month, International Business Machines Corp. and Siemens AG of West Germany announced a joint venture to develop advanced computer memory chips.

DOC.HEAD: Saratoga Mineral Water Hoping To Reap Benefits Of Perrier Recall
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Hellen in 12th graf is cq.
DOC.TEXT: Will Perrier's fizzle become Saratoga's bubbles? If experts' predictions hold out, the recall of Perrier's popular mineral water could be a boon to smaller competitors, such as the Saratoga Springs Mineral Water Co. It's too early to tell if Saratoga Mineral Water will capture some of the market dominated by the chic French brand. But initial signs are sparkling, say officials at Evian Waters of France Inc., the parent company of the Saratoga Springs firm. ``More distributors are calling and placing orders,'' said David Daniel, Evian's chief executive officer. ``It's busier than what you'd normally expect.'' Source Perrier SA recalled its water from worldwide distribution this week after small amounts of a naturally occurring toxic gas passed through a dirty filter and contaminated some bottles. Officials at Perrier's U.S. subsidiary have said they expect the green bottles to be kept out of the United States for several months. That will be a blow to Perrier, which built the U.S. sparkling mineral water market nearly from scratch in the 1970s. Its Perrier brand was the third biggest seller among all bottled water brands and the leading imported brand sold in the United States in 1988, accounting for 5.7 percent of the industry's $2.2 billion in sales, according to Beverage Marketing Corp. in New York. It could mean big bucks for competitors. ``If competitors move quickly they'll benefit,'' said Hellen Berry of Beverage Marketing. ``Perrier did a tremendous job getting into the market. But it's going to be gone,'' Berry said. ``Something will have to fill the void.'' That something could be Saratoga Mineral Water, which plans to launch a major new advertising campaign in the next few weeks. Daniel says the timing of the ad campaign and the Perrier recall is just coincidence. ``They were primed to go on no matter what happened,'' Berry said. Saratoga is no newcomer to the bottled water business. The waters of Saratoga Springs have drawn visitors to this quaint town for more than 200 years. According to folklore, George Washington drank from the springs here. By the 1830s, a thriving social scene had grown up around the springs. When Franklin Roosevelt was governor of New York, he pushed the development several mineral water bath houses. Roosevelt, a polio victim, was a regular user of the baths and consumed the waters. Saratoga Mineral Water was first bottled in 1872 when the then-Saratoga Vichy Co. developed a well near what is now the Saratoga State Spa Park. The water came bubbling up from the ground full of minerals and carbon dioxide percolated out of ancient volcanic faults in the Adirondack Mountain foothills. Salt, bicarbonate of soda and artificial carbonation were added to the spring water which was then bottled. It was a modest seller. The mineral water was eventually dropped in favor of a product that was more competitive with its European counterparts. Saratoga Mineral Water is now sold in stores, restaurants and bars in 23 states in the eastern half of the country. Daniel says the company is beginning to make a real push into supermarkets, where the bulk of mineral water is sold. Perrier's temporary absence may give Saratoga the edge it needs. ``Sales in bars and restaurants are good for your image. But volume tends to be relatively small in relation to the volume you can sell in major retail markets,'' Daniel said. Experts question whether the smaller bottled water companies are strong enough to fill the temporary void left by Perrier. There are about 450 water bottling plants in the United States, producing more than 600 different labels of drinking water, natural water and spring water, according to Bevmark Inc., a Los Angeles-based consulting firm. In addition, there are more than 50 brands of imported waters, Bevmark said. Berry said 1989 sales of Saratoga Mineral Water were greatly improved over previous years but were still small compared to Perrier's. She estimates last year's sales for Saratoga in the $10 million range. Perrier had sales in the United States of $150 million last year. Perrier officials say benzene, a chemical used in cleaning solvents, entered its water in traces when workers failed to change a pipe filter at the company's natural spring at Vergeze in southern France. Earlier, Perrier had said it believed an employee mistakenly used a product containing benzene to clean grease from one bottling line.

DOC.HEAD: Georgia Gulf Turns Down Simmons' Buyout Offer
DOC.TEXT: Chemical maker Georgia Gulf Corp. on Friday rejected a $1.1 billion buyout offer from Texas investor Harold C. Simmons, saying the $45-a-share bid was too low. In a letter to shareholders, Georgia Gulf's board of directors said they decided unanimously against the offer. The board called it ``inadequate, coercive and too conditional.'' The directors said shareholders would benefit more from the proposed recapitalization announced earlier by Georgia Gulf. Officials at NL Industries Inc., the Houston company controlled by Simmons that made the tender offer last month, could not be reached immediately for comment Friday. NL President J. Landis Martin did not return calls made to his office. ``In our view, NL's offer represents an attempt to take advantage of the current vulnerability of the company resulting from short-term economic and market conditions,'' said the Georgia Gulf letter released Friday. ``We believe that the $45-per-share price offered by NL does not reflect the kind of premium that ought to be received by the company's stockholders in a transaction ... in which control of the company would be sold,'' the letter said. Georgia Gulf's directors and officers own about 17 percent of the company, while Simmons has about a 9.9 percent stake. NL, in its tender offer, also proposed replacing the Georgia Gulf board. Georgia Gulf in January announced a proposed recapitalization of the company designed to discouraged Simmons from launching a takeover. The company valued the recapitalization, which has yet to go before shareholders, at $55 a share and it was widely believed the move would placate Simmons. The company did not say what the recapitalization would involve. NL, however, launched its tender offer two weeks later, saying the recapitalization probably would provide stockholders with less than $45 a share. Georgia Gulf said Friday it has received bank notification that no obstacles to financing the recapitalization have emerged so far. Under a recapitalization, a company usually borrows a large sum of money to fund a special dividend or an expansion.

DOC.HEAD: Italian Company Will Produce Mid-size Cars in Poland
DOC.TEXT: Fiat, Italy's auto giant, announced Friday that it has signed a preliminary accord to produce a mid-size car in Poland. Fiat won the agreement after nearly three years of talks and fierce competition with Japan's Daihatsu Motor Co. The dollar value of the deal was not disclosed. A spokesman for Fiat, Italy's largest private-sector industrial group, said production of cars, modeled after Fiat's popular Tipo model, is expected to start in the early 1990s. The spokesman did not disclose further details of the agreement, signed earlier this week at the Turin headquarters of Fiat with Fabryka Somochodow Osobowych, Poland's state-owned auto company. The agreement will further strengthen Fiat's presence in Poland. Fiat last year signed an agreement to produce 150,000 units a year of a small-size model called the Micro. Also last year, Fiat, which is owned by the Agnelli family, signed an agreement with the Soviet Union to produce in that country a car modeled after Fiat's Panda model. The contract calls for production of about 300,000 cars a year starting in 1993.

DOC.HEAD: Rates Drop
DOC.TEXT: Fixed-rate home mortgages are averaging 10.1 percent, down from 10.21 percent last week, according to a national survey released Friday by the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corp. On one-year adjustable rate mortgages, lenders were asking an average initial rate of 8.48 percent this week, up from 8.46 percent the week before.

DOC.HEAD: Investment Banks Swoop in on Drexel Deals
With AM-Drexel, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. is dying, not its deals. Like bargain hunters at a garage sale, Wall Street's big investment banks are sifting through the remnants of Drexel's businesses and scrambling to sign up its clients. Drexel fired most of its 5,300 employees on Friday, keeping only enough staff to wrap up pending deals or help transfer the business to other firms. ``Half of these things were in midstream,'' said Michael Madden, head of mergers and acquisitions at Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc., which picked up one large Drexel deal. ``Suddenly Drexel is without the ability to get it done. The client says, `Whoops! What do I do now?'' Deals stuck in limbo since the Chapter 11 bankruptcy court filing by Drexel's parent range from mergers to junk bond underwritings. The prospective fees total in the millions. Top investment banks such as Merrill Lynch & Co., Morgan Stanley Group Inc., Goldman, Sachs & Co. and First Boston Corp. are all angling for the business, industry executives said. With Wall Street in a prolonged slump, Drexel's passing has been an unexpected windfall for firms eager for some lucrative work. According to Securities Data Co., the dollar volume of mergers and acquisitions completed in the fourth quarter of 1989 declined 36.6 percent from the same 1988 period. ``Because of the slowdown, it makes the battle to get Drexel's primary clents all that more fearsome,'' said Perrin Long, who follows the securities industry for Lipper Analytical Services. Executives from Mesa Petroleum Co. jetted in from Texas this week and rode in limousines from investment bank to investment bank to complete the transfer of a planned $350 million to $400 million royalty trust offering that Drexel was supposed to manage. After losing to Drexel in the initial bidding to head the deal, Shearson beat out Merrill Lynch for the Mesa offering, which would create a royalty trust _ a legal vehicle to hold property _ on the company's Hugoton and Panoma natural gas fields in Oklahoma and Kansas. Mesa, which is headed by corporate raider T. Boone Pickens Jr., is offering a 32 percent stake in the fields to the public. The offer had been registered with the Securities and Exchange Commission for two weeks and was set to go ahead when Drexel fell. Drexel investment bankers have cooperated with the transition, which focuses on marketing the issue _ 16 million units to be priced between $22 and $25 each _ to institutional and retail investors. Marketing was supposed to start Friday but has been delayed. ``The Drexel guys were very cooperative,'' said Grant Porter, who heads Shearson's natural resources coporate finance group. ``They worked long and hard on this transaction and it's a great disappointment to them to have to step aside.'' But he added: ``People are ready, willing and able to step into the shoes of Drexel in these circumstances.'' Despite a drought in new issues of junk bonds to raise money, firms also are actively competing for about two dozen planned Drexel offerings worth in the billions for companies such as Foods 4 Less Supermarkets Inc. and General Host Corp. Firms won't necessarily try to sell the new bonds to investors immediately _there have been only two new junk-bond offerings so far this year, according to Secrutiies Data. But they do plan to get to know clients and strategy, analysts said. As in the Mesa offering, introducing corporate officials to a new team of investment bankers is causing delays. ``It's like moving into a new home,'' Long said. ``You get up in the middle of the night, you're bumping into things.''

DOC.HEAD: The AP
Drexel Considers Selling Units, Files British Bankruptcy Petitions
With AM-Drexel, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Drexel Burnham Lambert Group Inc.'s British units took steps Friday to wind down their operations following the U.S. parent company's bankruptcy petition Tuesday. Drexel officials were talking with various parties over the possibility of selling the British operations in pieces, a company official said. Meanwhile, KPMG Peat Marwick McLintock, the British arm of the international accounting firm, on Friday was appointed by Britain's High Court as administrator of Drexel Burnham Lambert Holding Ltd., a holding company for most of the London operations. It also was appointed administrator for two units, Drexel Burnham Lambert Ltd., its metals, soft commodities and oil futures trading arm, and Drexel Burnham Lambert Securities Ltd. These three companies filed petitions with the bankruptcy section of the High Court earlier Friday. In filing the administrative petitions, Drexel essentially sought the court's guidance in ascribing priorities to creditors or claimants against its operations. Peat Marwick said its job would be ``to ensure that all commitments'' with the three Drexel units ``are honored in full'' and that Drexel's clients are ``totally unaffected by events occurring in other parts of the group.'' James Furlong, a Drexel senior vice president in charge of European-based equities trading, said his division was in talks with three major institutions about the possibility of the division's sale. He said he had no doubt that the staff would stay together. Furlong's staff of 60 trades in U.S. stocks and related products. Drexel's non-U.S. stock trading business was curtailed last year. The heads of Drexel's several European-based operations held discussions in London for much of Friday, Furlong said. Strategies emerging from the meetings suggest the divisions will attempt to market themselves individually to prospective buyers, he said. For equities, the first option was to find a buyer for the whole of the equities business outside the United States, comprising both European and Asian operations with a total staff of 300, he said. The second option was to find a buyer for the European sales staff alone. Furlong said that three institutions so far have shown interest in this plan. There so far have been no resignations or defections from the European team and morale was good, Furlong said. On Thursday, the Bank of England announced a special settlements arrangement for foreign exchange trades involving Drexel in London to prevent liquidity problems. Also Thursday, the London Clearing House, which is responsible for clearing operations on the London Metal Exchange, International Petroleum Exchange and several other markets, declared Drexel in default of all its commodities futures business.

DOC.HEAD: Crop Futures Close Lower on Profit-Taking, Slack Exports
DOC.TEXT: Grain and soybean futures prices closed slightly lower Friday on the Chicago Board of Trade, largely reflecting profit-taking as traders evened up their positions ahead of the long weekend. DOC.HEAD: Reader Outrage Gets Globe To Pull Changes
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs 9th graf, `More than...' to make clear that ombudsman did not speak in interview. Also moving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: A few short years after new Coke fizzled on the marketplace, The Boston Globe is admitting that it, too, underestimated human resistance to change. After the newspaper altered the format of its TV listings last summer, its editors were deluged with calls and letters from readers criticizing the changes. This week, as the paper reintroduces the new old version of its TV Week, it is taking to the airwaves with a series of tongue-in-cheek advertisements, hoping to win back the disgruntled. ``It's a story about being misunderstood, and having the guts to overcome it ... about being unwanted and unloved, and finding the strength to change,'' the ad's narrator says. ```Refreshingly simple,' says the Boston Globe,'' the ad continues. ``The Boston Globe calls it `This year's best revival.' And the Boston Globe raves, `Now you can read it.''' Last June, the Globe altered the format of its weekly TV listings to cut a few pages. The move, which saved ``a few hundred thousand dollars,'' was part of a general belt-tightening, as newspapers everywhere confronted lagging revenues, Globe spokesman Richard Gulla said Friday. The earlier format featured a horizontal grid of shows scheduled for prime time, as well as a `rolling log' that listed in narrative form the day's schedule, with blurbs for some of the movies. After the changes, listings for the entire day were compiled in a vertical grid, with the names of the channels heading the columns. The type was smaller, there was no rolling log and no blurbs explained the shows. ``Readers went bananas,'' Gulla said. More than 3,000 called in to express their outrage. Many readers who called said the main reason they bought the Sunday Globe was for the old TV Week, reported Robert L. Kierstead, the paper's ombudsman. He wrote that one Boston man told him: ``If it wasn't broken, why did you have to fix it?'' ``Part of what it shows you is how much TV is a part of people's lives,'' Gulla said. In October, the Globe put a questionnaire in a Sunday edition, circulation 800,000, asking readers what they thought of the changes. Over 37,000 responded in 17 days and nearly 90 percent of them said they were not happy, Gulla said. ``It certainly was a mistake on our part,'' he said. ``We didn't recognize how near and dear this was to people's hearts.'' The Globe could have used a lesson from executives at the Coca-Cola Co. In 1985, when the Atlanta-based company introduced new Coke and stopped making the old formula, ``there was a consumer outcry,'' said a Coke spokesman. ``Consumers were very specific and aggressive about telling us that they wanted the old formula,'' said spokesman Randy Donaldson. Three months later, old Coke was back on the shelves, this time under the guise of Coca-Cola Classic. Unfortunately for the Globe, they couldn't simply release the old product in a new can. It took eight months of surveys and focus groups before the first edition of the new, old TV listings returned to the newsstand. And like Coke Classic, the new product is markedly similar to that of eight months ago. ``People were telling us `Don't mess with my TV book'' and we heard them loud and clear,'' Gulla said. ``Rather than continue to irritate the readers, we went back.'' Distributing the survey and launching the focus groups cost the paper ``less than $20,000,'' Gulla said. That did not include the cost of staff time spent on the project, or those advertisers or readers that may have left the paper over the issue, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Animation, Surprise Endings Score Big with Ad Watchers in 1989
DOC.TEXT: Advertising that used animated characters ranging from dancing raisins to a drumming rabbit scored well when consumers were asked to pick the best commercials of 1989, a research firm said Friday. Ads with surprise endings or unusual twists, such as cats that appear to have human voices, also did well, according to the survey by Video Storyboard Tests Inc. Celebrities touting products were not as popular, continuing a slump of several years, said Video Storyboard President David Vadehra. ``Some advertisers feel that is still one of the easiest ways to get attention,'' he said. But he said the 1989 survey results, based on interviews with 24,000 consumers across the country, indicated TV viewers are tuning those ads out. Topping the firm's 11th annual survey results were commercials from McDonald's Corp., the nation's biggest fast-food restaurant chain. The Oak Brook, Ill.-based company's advertised promotions last year that included tie-ins with the movies ``The Little Mermaid'' and ``All Dogs Go to Heaven.'' Vadehra said the commercials that consumers cited most often from McDonald's were one called ``First Love'' that showed a young boy bidding goodbye to the girl he met at McDonald's as he and his family move to another neighborhood and another ad in which people recited the menu in a rap song. Second were ads for Pepsi and Diet Pepsi, many of which contained celebrities. But Vadehra said the Pepsi ad consumers cited most often featured monkeys who get the right soft drink from the vending machine for the researcher studying their behavior. The California Raisin ads featuring a claymation version of entertainer Michael Jackson placed third. The campaign slipped somewhat after ranking first in each of the past two years. Commercials for Energizer batteries featuring a pink toy rabbit that played a drum and showed up without warning in ads for other products came in fourth for the year. Vadehra said the ad was unusual in that it not only captured attention but ``made the point that the battery goes on and on.'' Rounding out the top five was the campaign for Isuzu cars and trucks that featured an Isuzu spokesman riding by a competitor's lot and encouraging buyers to ask the dealer how his vehicles stacked up to Isuzus. Ads for Bud Light beer came in sixth, followed by ads for Coca-Cola soft drinks including appearances by entertainer George Michael and actor Art Carney and by commercials for Miller Lite beer. Commercials for Infiniti cars, which for months featured scenes of nature, a narrator talking about values and the senses but nary a shot of the new car, finished ninth. The ads were widely attacked in the trade press, but Vadehra said consumers liked them because they were so different from other car commercials. A woman from Florida told interviewers an Inifinit ad was ``a heady commercial'' that made her ``do a lot of thinking and visualizing.'' A woman from Chicago said, ``It was very subtle and stil grabs you and makes you think about the car that is not there.'' Nike placed 10th with its commercials that included one featuring baseball and football star Bo Jackson and a host of athletes who attested that ``Bo knows'' other sports. Vadehra said consumers liked the ad because the athletes never specifically pushed Nike shoes, appearing instead to be encouraging them simply to be active. Among other best-liked ads from 1989 were a commercial for Friskies pet food that showed a cat running around the house looking for a meal as the sound of a race car engine played in the background and an ad for Nine Lives pet food that showed kittens who appeared to be calling for dinner with human voices. Vadehra said advertisers like to use animated characters because they are safer than using celebrities, whose real-life problems can sometimes reflect poorly on products they tout. He said the characteristics of animated characters are sometimes better known than those of real people, an advantage that advertisers can exploit.

But analysts said traders remained leery of chasing after the recent upswing in stock prices. Fears persist that a rise in worldwide interest rates so far in 1990 might have increased the chances of a recession and a continuing slump in corporate profits.

DOC.HEAD: Employees at Swank Beverly Hills Office Pack Up Their Belongings
With AM-Drexel, Bjt
LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: Securities traders at the Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. division where the explosive junk-bond market of the 1980s got its start packed their belongings Friday and rued the loss of their jobs, their company and former leader Michael Milken. Employees hurriedly entered the Wilshire Boulevard headquarters, packed boxes, consoled colleagues and talked of other jobs. Drexel's parent company filed for bankruptcy protection this week in New York after defaulting on $100 million in short-term debt and failing to raise financing to prevent further defaults. Drexel blamed its demise on a capital shortage created in part by a decline in the junk-bond market. An erosion of confidence in the firm also hurt. Many of the departing employees refused to talk with reporters Friday on short, final walks to or from a parking garage dotted with Mercedes-Benzes and Jaguars. One man, briefcase in hand, walked past a small group of reporters. ``Bunch of vultures hanging over a dead body,'' he uttered, shaking his head slightly and refusing comment. Others took the time to note the end of an era. ``There are some tears today. We all regard it as a real shame and a tragedy,'' said John E. Oden, director of institutional placement in Drexel's real estate division. ``I feel like it could have been prevented.'' Oden said many Drexel employees continued to hold Milken in high regard and viewed his prosecution by former U.S. Attorney Rudolph Giuliani as the beginning of the end. The junk-bond division was drastically altered when Milken got into criminal trouble. He quit the firm last June, but had been working only part-time for close to a year. He and partners still own the headquarters building. ``We could have used Mike Milken,'' Oden said. ``I think he could have had a positive impact and would have helped us get down the road.'' He added that Drexel's payment of fines and restitution for securities trading violations also did the firm grave harm. A total of $500 million of $650 million has been paid. Employees were on the telephones early Friday, as they usually are. But instead of their normal duties, they were selling positions in securities and pursuing work. ``I'm just going to let people know I'm available,'' Oden said. ``Life goes on. You can't get down.'' Four men walked into the building, coffee in hand. ``You know of any jobs?'' a couple asked. Oden and others said they were still reeling from the news of Drexel's folding. ``It was a definite shock. People didn't see it coming,'' said Andy Gumaer, a division vice president in the Beverly Hills office. ``What Michael did was a positive thing,'' Gumaer said. ``The truth is, in hindsight, maybe the firm should have stood behind Michael Milken. A lot of people feel that way. ``In hindsight, you have to wonder whether we could have called the bluff of Giuliani, and not have pleaded guilty ....'' Gumaer and others said employees were forming small groups to collectively look for work and some were considering going into business independently. Gumaer said he personally hoped to get back into the liquidation firm that he helped run before he joined Drexel three years ago. ``I would love to get this account,'' he said, gazing at the building that became home to Drexel's high-yield division in 1978.

DOC.HEAD: Bank's Future in Jeopardy Despite Asset Sales
DOC.TEXT: While Bank of New England Corp. desperately tries to improve its health by selling assets and eliminating thousands of workers, those steps might not save the bank from the growing ills of bad real estate loans, analysts said Friday. ``They are probably not far behind Drexel,'' said Virginia Adair, a banking analyst with Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., the Wall Street investment firm that filed for bankruptcy this week over junk bond losses. Since last month, when Bank of New England said its 1989 losses should exceed $1 billion, the bank has tried to stop the hemorrhaging. The bank is near the halfway point in a plan to sell $6 billion in assets, and Marcia Ryan, a company spokeswoman, said Friday the bank expects to lay off about 2,000 employees. The timing of the layoffs is not final, and they do not include other payroll cuts the bank will implement through attrition and the sale of assets, Ryan said. ``I think it's stable and improving,'' she said, referring to the bank's condition. But analysts were more cautious. They say the sagging New England economy, which has contributed to the bank's mounting pile of troubled loans, could decline further and drag down the bank. ``They appear to be right on target with their plan, but you wish they weren't there in the first place,'' said Gerard Cassidy, an analyst with Tucker Anthony Inc. Bank of New England is expected to report its 1989 financial results next week. At the same time, Ryan said, the bank should disclose details of a consent order, negotiated with the federal government, that will describe steps the bank will take to fix its finances. Analysts predict Bank of New England, which employs about 17,500 people, eventually will cut its payroll to around 13,000. The bank's assets, which totaled $31.5 billion last year, should shrink by about one-third by the time the sales are completed. Before the bank took its tumble, it rose to become the second-largest bank holding company in New England, behind Bank of Boston Corp., and the 15th largest nationwide. Much of the growth came through aggressive real estate lending during a construction boom in the mid-1980s. But when the real estate market declined during an economic downturn, the credit losses mounted. The bank has come under intense scrutiny by federal regulators, and in the last several weeks, the board of directors has forced out the bank's chairman, Walter J. Connolly, and other senior executives. Analysts say the heavy presence of the federal government is reflected in the bank's delay in releasing its financial results and plans for the consent order. ``The decisions about the future are being decided on by the management with the regulators,'' Adair said, describing the bank as being under ``de facto'' control of the government. For the moment, the bank's priority is to avoid running out of money, analysts said. Depositors have withdrawn millions of dollars, and more money is expected to flow from the bank as certificates of deposit, which were bought before the bad news surfaced, reach maturity. Because of this cash crunch, the bank has been forced to borrow money from the Federal Reserve Bank of Boston. The Federal Reserve does not identify borrowers, but the agency's Boston bank has loaned out more than $900 million, and analysts say Bank of New England appears to have received most of the money. But even if the bank emerges from the cash crisis by completing the sale of assets, Cassidy said the next issue will be, ``What are they left with?'' The bank will have a higher concentration of poor loans, since they will be balanced against a smaller base of good assets, analysts said. James Moynihan, senior vice president of Advest Inc. in Boston, said the bank possibly could segregate the troubled loans in a single subsidiary and bring in specialists to deal with them. The sound assets could be pulled together in a ``good bank,'' he said, that can be run ``like a good bank and compete.'' But until Bank of New England gets its house in order, Moynihan said, ``it's clearly a day-by-day situation.''

DOC.HEAD: Bond Prices Finish Little Changed
DOC.TEXT: Bond prices finished little changed Friday after a sluggish pre-holiday session and inconclusive evidence on the direction of the economy. The closely watched 30-year Treasury issue fell 1-16 point, or about 60 cents for every $1,000 in face value. Its yield, which rises when the price declines, inched up to 8.46 percent from 8.45 percent late Thursday. Trading in the government bond markets ended at about 2 p.m., several hours earlier than normal as traders got a head start on the three-day weekend that will mark Monday's observance of the Presidents Day holiday. The government reported Friday that the U.S. trade deficit fell to $7.17 billion in December, down from $10.29 billion in November. The deficit narrowed to $108.58 billion last year, the smallest yearly imbalance since 1984. Elliott Platt, director of economic research at Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Securities Corp., said many analysts had expected a deficit of $9 billion for December. But he said the market failed to react to the report despite the possibility that a smaller deficit suggests added strength in the economy, normally a negative development for bond prices. In a separate report, the Federal Reserve said industrial production fell 1.2 percent in January following a revised 0.2 percent gain in output a month earlier. Analysts said the market failed to react to this report either. William Sullivan Jr., who follows the credit markets for Dean Witter Reynolds Inc., said the report was distorted by unusually warm weather in January that cut the need for production of electricity for heating and by an anticipated decline in auto production. Sullivan said that by adjusting for those two special factors, industrial production would have been up slightly. He said traders also are worried that interest rates are going to rise in Japan and West Germany, luring investors to securities in those countries rather than to dollar-denominated securities. In the secondary market for Treasury securities, prices of short-term government issues finished unchanged, intermediate maturities were unchanged to 1-32 point lower, and long-term issues slipped as much as 1-16 point, according to figures provided by Telerate Inc., a financial information service. The movement of a point is equivalent to a change of $10 in the price of a bond with a $1,000 face value. The Shearson Lehman Hutton Daily Treasury Bond Index, which measures price movements on all outstanding Treasury issues with maturities of a year or longer, slipped 0.17 to 1,160.29. In the tax-exempt market, the Bond Buyer index of 40 actively traded municipal bonds rose 1-32 point to 92 3-16. The average yield to maturity held steady at 7.39 percent. Yields on three-month Treasury bills fell to 7.92 percent as the discount dropped 2 basis points to 7.67 percent. Yields on six-month bills fell to 8.06 percent as the discount lost 1 basis point to 7.65 percent. Yields on one-year bills held at 8.08 percent as the discount remained at 7.52 percent. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point. The yield is the annualized return on an investment in a Treasury bill. The discount is the percentage that bills are selling below the face value, which is paid at maturity. The federal funds rate, the interest rate banks charge each other on overnight loans, was quoted at 8 3-16 percent, down from 8] percent late Thursday.

DOC.HEAD: Precede LONDON
Dollar Falls; Gold Recoups Losses
DOC.TEXT: The dollar took a nosedive Friday despite an encouraging report on the U.S. trade deficit. Gold prices moved higher, recouping their losses from the previous session. On the New York Commodity Exchange, gold rose $4.70 to close at $417.10 a troy ounce. Republic National Bank of New York later quoted a bid of $417.25 a troy ounce, up $4.25. The dollar opened on a strong note ahead of the government's merchandise trade report for December, which showed an impressive 30 percent drop in the deficit, to $7.17 billion from $10.29 billion in November. While the figure was far better than expected, traders focused on the fact that imports were down 5.9 percent, which they interpreted as an indication that consumer spending is slackening. ``It was seen as showing underlying weakness in the economy,'' said Stephen Flanagan, a vice president at Manufacturers Hanover Trust Co. The dollar's inability to extend the gains it posted in the previous session ``brought back all the underlying bearishness in the market,'' Flanagan said. A dealer with Bank of America in London said the ``fundamental situation for the dollar is still down. ... If the dollar doesn't rally on a $7.1 billion deficit, then it's in some trouble.'' The currency took another hit with the release of a separate government report that showed industrial production in January slipped 1.2 percent. Traders said the decline was much larger than expected. ``It reinforced the weakness in the economy that people picked out of the trade report,'' Flanagan said. Trading slowed considerably by midday as many dealers left early ahead of the three-day weekend. Most U.S. currency trading operations will be closed on Monday for the Presidents Day holiday. In Tokyo, the dollar closed at 144.80 yen, up 0.35 yen from Thursday's close. Later in London, it was quoted at 144.10 yen. In New York the dollar closed at 144.13 yen, down from 144.78 yen Thursday. In London, the British pound rose to $1.6953 from $1.6936 late Thursday. In New York it cost $1.6972 to buy one pound, more expensive than Thursday's $1.6855. Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Thursday, included: 1.6758 West German marks, down from 1.6935; 1.4910 Swiss francs, down from 1.5075; 5.6950 French francs, down from 5.7580; 1,243.25 Italian lire, down from 1,258.50; and 1.1998 Canadian dollars, down from 1.2041. Other late dollar rates in Europe, compared with late Thursday, included: 1.6794 West German marks, down from 1.6805; 1.4930 Swiss francs, down from 1.4950; 5.7045 French francs, down from 5.7130; 1.8915 Dutch guilders, down from 1.8940; 1,246.00 Italian lire, down from 1,248.00; and 1.1997 Canadian dollars, down from 1.2060. Gold prices were mostly higher. In London the metal rose to a late bid price of $416.65 a troy ounce from $415.50 bid late Thursday. In Zurich, the metal rose to a closing bid of $416.50 from $415.75. But in Hong Kong, gold dropped $2.64 an ounce to close at $412.69. Silver prices rose. DOC.HEAD: First Boston To ``Phase Out'' Bond Futures Business
DOC.TEXT: First Boston Corp. said Friday it was eliminating its bond futures brokerage business for customers on the Chicago Board of Trade and Chicago Mercantile Exchange and laying off 29 employees. The private New York-based investment bank said it will continue trading listed futures for its own account on the two exchanges. ``We will be phasing out in an orderly fashion so customers can unwind their futures positions and-or transfer accounts to other brokers,'' said First Boston spokesman Fred Garcia. First Boston said the decision was made after a six-month ``strategic review'' of all its businesses. The company would not disclose the number of customers or futures contracts involved. Both exchanges declined comment. The move will affect 29 employees in New York, Chicago, Los Angeles and Tokyo, who were notified on Friday, Garcia said. First Boston will retain two of nine current seats on the Board of Trade and at least one of seven on the Merc. In a prepared statement, futures Managing Director Robert S. Cohen said changes in the futures market in the last 12 years prompted the decision which ``was unrelated to events in any other financial markets.'' ``First Boston's ability to provide value-added service for our customers has diminished given the breadth of readily-accessible information and analytics and the overcapacity in the brokerage community,'' Cohen said. The securities brokerage industry has slumped since the 1987 stock market crash. Several brokerages have pared down their businesses and laid off hundreds of workers. This week, the parent of one of the nation's largest brokerages, Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., announced it had filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection. First Boston announced 200 layoffs last spring in what Garcia called part of the overcapacity after the stock market crash of 1987. In January 1989, First Boston merged with its London-based sister company Financiere Credit Suisse-First Boston in a $1.1 billion deal. The combined entity, which is privately held, is called CS First Boston Inc. The merger capped a difficult two-year period during which First Boston lost about $100 million in trading risky options on Treasury bonds and another $50 million in trading mortgage-backed securities.

DOC.HEAD: Industrial Production Falls in January
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 14th graf, `Reflecting the ...,' to include reference that January rate was lowest since October 1987. Also moving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: Industrial production took its biggest plunge in nearly four years last month, the government said Friday, but analysts cited temporary factors for the 1.2 percent drop and said output should resume its sluggish growth. The Federal Reserve said the production slump was the steepest since output plummeted 1.3 percent in March 1986. But it attributed the decrease to a drop in energy use due to abnormally warm weather and to temporary layoffs in the automobile industry to correct bloated inventories. ``If you take energy and autos out, the index was up 0.2 percent,'' said Michael K. Evans, head of a Washington economic forecasting firm bearing his name. ``The figures are more commensurate with the `soft-landing' scenario for the economy _ that is, slow growth _ than with the possibility that we're actually heading into a recession,'' said Gordon Richards, economic policy director for the National Association of Manufacturers. Priscilla Trumbull, an economist with the WEFA Group in Bala Cynwyd, Pa., agreed, saying, ``Outside of those areas, production basically was moving very slowly upward and that's what we've been seeing for the last three to four months.'' The Fed said utility output, which rose 6.3 percent during December's bitter cold, reversed itself in January and fell 10.7 percent. According to the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration, January temperatures were the warmest for that month since the government began keeping records 96 years ago. December was the fourth coldest on record. ``The output of motor vehicles was curtailed drastically,'' the department said, as ``automobile assemblies plunged to a 4.1 million unit annual rate from a 6.2 million unit rate in December.'' As a result, manufacturing production, which represents 84 percent of industrial output, was off 0.9 percent last month. But, Ms. Trumbull said, many of the laid-off workers have returned to production lines ``and we'll probably see an uptick'' in February's report. Durable goods manufacturing, which includes autos and other big-ticket items expected to last more than three years, was down 1.7 percent. Non-durable goods manufacturing, on the other hand, rose 0.2 percent. Mining production was up 2.1 percent after falling 2 percent in December because of the cold weather. The changes meant the industrial production index in January stood at 140.9 percent of its 1977 base, down from 142.5 percent a month earlier. Reflecting the decline in output, the Fed's report Friday on the operating rate of the nation's factories, mines and utilities also dipped 1.2 percentage point to 81.9 percent last month. It was the lowest since a similar 81.9 percent rate in October 1987 that followed an 81.1 percent rate a month earlier. The rate had remained steady at 83.1 percent during the last three months of 1989. Analysts generally consider an operating rate of 85 percent or above as an indication of inflationary pressures so, while indicating a weak economy, it could be interpreted as good news for consumers. The manufacturing-plant operating rate in January also slipped to 81.9 percent, from 82.9 percent in December. The rate had peaked at 84.7 percent in January 1989. The rate at factories producing durable goods fell from 80.9 percent to 79.4 percent. ``Operating rates for auto and truck assembly facilities dropped to levels near their 1982 recession lows,'' the department said. The utility operating rate fell from 86.4 percent to 77.1 percent in part because utilization at power plants dropped about 10 percentage points because of the weather, the department said. The rate at factories producing non-durable goods fell 0.1 percentage point to 85.6 percent. The operating rate at mines was down 0.8 percentage point to 84.7 percent.
