The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks dropped .64 to 183.75. Standard & Poor's industrial index fell 2.70 to 383.81, and S&P's 500-stock composite index was down 2.17 at 332.72. The NASDAQ composite index for the over-the-counter market slipped .60 to 429.01. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index closed at 358.77, down .83.

DOC.HEAD: Copper Futures Surge on Supply Drop, Stronger Economy Signs
DOC.TEXT: Copper futures prices soared Friday on New York's Commodity Exchange amid positive economic signals and signs of dwindling copper supplies. On other commodity markets, precious metal futures advanced; petroleum futures slipped; livestock and meat futures were mixed; and grains and soybeans retreated. Copper futures settled unchanged to 4.35 cents higher with the contract for spot delivery up 4.35 cents at $1.1285 a pound and the more actively traded March contract up 4.3 cents at $1.1135 a pound. Traders bid up prices going into the close despite the fact that the market will be closed Monday for Presidents Day. Traders usually are cautious heading into a three-day weekend. Signs of shrinking copper stocks provided the strongest upward pressure. After two days of unchanged levels, the Commodity Exchange reported a 90-ton drawdown in registered warehouse stocks Thursday to a 16-month-low of 3,629 tons. After the close of trading Friday, the Comex reported a much sharper daily drop in warehouse stocks, down 609 tons to 3,020 tons. Analysts said much of the copper withdrawn from warehouses Friday appeared to be headed for the Far East. Thursday's stocks report came on the heels of a government report that January housing starts were running at a record-high annual pace. That news was bullish for copper since copper wire and tubing are used heavily in home construction. The housing-starts surprise was followed Friday by the government's report that the nation closed out 1989 with a $108.6 billion trade deficit, the smallest in five years. The good economic news contrasted sharply with recent perceptions of a recession in the making. And as the economy strengthens, so does demand for copper by the manufacturing and construction industries. ``I think some of the recent economic data has suggested that we could run into problems with copper supplies,'' said Randolph Donney, a research analyst with the commodities brokerage Elders Futures Inc. Precious metal futures strengthened as the dollar weakened against other major currencies. Gold futures rose $4.60 to $5.50 on the Comex with February settling at $417.10 a troy ounce; silver futures were 0.9 cent to 1.1 cents higher with March at $5.34 a troy ounce. On the New York Mercantile Exchange, platinum futures settled 10 cents lower to $2.50 higher with April at $525.40 a troy ounce. Petroleum futures weakened on the New York Merc amid profit-taking after five straight days of gains in the crude oil and heating oil markets. West Texas Intermediate crude settled 20 cents to 42 cents lower with March at $22.42 a barrel; heating oil was .95 cent to 1.17 cents lower with March at 57.48 cents a gallon; unleaded gasoline was .40 cent to .75 cent lower with March at 59.99 cents a gallon. On the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, cattle futures ended mixed and pork futures finished lower ahead of the Agriculture Department's monthly cattle-on-feed report for the seven largest cattle-producing states. The report showed a 7 percent increase from a year ago in the number of cattle being fed for slaughter as of Feb. 1, compared with traders' expectations for about a 4 percent increase. Some analysts predicted cattle futures prices would drop sharply Tuesday in reaction to the report. Live cattle settled .10 cent lower to .28 cent higher with February at 79.77 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .05 cent to .23 cent higher with March at 82.17 cents a pound; live hogs were .10 cent to .40 cent lower with February at 49.52 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were .70 cent to 1.58 cents lower with February at 49.85 cents a pound. On the Chicago Board of Trade, wheat futures settled } cent to 2\ cents lower with March at $3.84 a bushel; corn futures were } cent to 1{ cents lower with March at $2.41\ a bushel; oats were 2 cents to 2\ cents lower with March at $1.38\ a bushel; soybeans were 1\ cents to 2{ cents lower with March at $5.69} a bushel.

DOC.HEAD: Oil Futures Slump
DOC.TEXT: Energy futures prices slumped in subdued trading Friday on the New York Mercantile Exchange, pressured by profit-taking and warm weather in the Northeast. The March contract for West Texas Intermediate, the main grade of U.S. crude oil, fell 42 cents to $22.42 a 42-gallon barrel. April crude ended at $22.25 a barrel, down 18 cents, and May crude fell 20 cents to $22.04 a barrel. Among refined products, wholesale unleaded gasoline for March delivery fell 0.65 cent to 59.99 cents a gallon. April declined 0.71 cent to 60.93 cents a gallon and May dropped 0.75 cent to 64.90 cents. No. 2 heating oil for delivery in March ended at 57.48 cents a gallon, down 1.17 cents. April finished down 1.15 cents at 56.81 cents and May heating oil lost 0.97 cent to 55.87 cents. Energy analysts said trading was light ahead of Monday's Presidents Day holiday as warm weather in the Northeastern states and profit-taking helped dampen prices. ``Warm weather hit the heating oil market and that led the market lower,'' said Peter Beutel, an analyst for Elders Futures Inc. Profit-taking followed Thursday's price rise after news that a volcano eruption in Alaska might disrupt oil shipments. Although a 34,000-barrel terminal was temporarily evacuated after the eruption of Mount Redoubt, no major interference was reported.

DOC.HEAD: Soft Drink Company Announces Dividend Increase, Proposed Stock Split
DOC.TEXT: The Coca-Cola Co. said it was boosting its quarterly dividend by 18 percent _ its largest increase in 30 years _ and recommending a a 2-for-1 stock split. The dividend increase _ from 34 cents to 40 cents _ marks the 28th consecutive year the Atlanta-based company has raised its dividend. It is payable April 1 to stockholders of record March 15. Stockholders are to vote on the stock split at their April 18 annual meeting. Additional shares would be distributed May 11 to stockholders of record May 1. Roberto Goizueta, chairman and chief executive, said the twin announcement ``reflects the fundamental strength of our global soft drink business and our optimism for its future growth.'' Analyst Lee Wilder of Robinson-Humphrey Co. in Atlanta said he expects Coca-Cola dividends to increase at least 15 percent annually over the next several years, in line with expected earnings increases. Meanwhile, analysts said the stock split will make the company's stock more affordable for individual investors. Coke's shares rose $2.37{ on the New York Stock Exchange Thursday to $69.50. Coca-Cola's last previous stock split was a 3-for-1 deal in 1986. It has 336 million shares outstanding among 100,000 shareholders worldwide.

DOC.HEAD: Over And Out At Drexel
With AM-Drexel, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: After leaving Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. on Friday for the last time, Christine Karpeles put her arms around several co-workers and announced loudly to camera crews, ``We're going to Disneyland.'' But her misty eyes betrayed the smile on her face as she mimicked the sports heroes who are paid to shout the same promotional phrase after winning a championship. For most of the 5,300 employees of the collapsed securities giant, this was their worst day. In letters to thousands of workers let go Friday, the company said it had failed despite ``Herculean efforts to obtain additional capital.'' Drexel's parent company filed for bankruptcy court protection Tuesday and is liquidating its operations. By the dozens, employees who hours earlier were told they were fired were emerging from its doors in the heart of the financial district with pained expressions. ``I was crying because it's sad,'' Karpeles, 21, of New York said after waving goodbye to the building. ``This is just the beginning. The industry is falling apart. Everybody is going to be hurt by this,'' said the secretary in corporate finance. ``It felt like a wake,'' said Judy Finn, who pushed a shopping cart full of $350 worth of computer equipment for her daughter, Debbie, who was fired as a supervisory analyst in the research department. The company offered employees computer equipment and other odds and ends at bargain prices on the last day. ``My daughter's unemployed. I'm very sad,'' she said. The younger Finn said she saw no irony in a button _ ``Junk Bonds Keep America Fit'' _ which she wore on her blouse. ``It had a great spirit,'' she said of Drexel. It was pride for the company that kept most of the executives and analysts from talking to about a dozen reporters, who drew angry glances from some workers outside Drexel's doors, said analyst Ken Haim, 26, the only one who would talk among about 60 men in suits and ties who left Drexel over a two-hour period. ``People seemed to feel more sadness that the company was gone than for their own plights,'' Haim said. He said many workers blame the press for fanning the flames of distrust for the company after its leader, Michael Milken, was indicted on fraud and racketeering charges last year. Milken was widely credited with raising the company to fame and billion-dollar profits through his role in the corporate takeover craze financed by risky high-yield bonds. One man walked out of the building loudly cursing Rudolph Giuliani, the former federal prosecutor who led the investigation that resulted in criminal charges against Milken and Drexel. But another analyst who asked that his name not be used blamed the downfall on ``some management mistakes made in the last year or so.'' ``It's a terrible thing. It didn't have to happen,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Profit Sharing for Big Three Way Down
DOC.TEXT: Employees of the nation's Big Three automakers will feel the financial pinch that's squeezing their companies as they watch their profit-sharing checks shrivel or, in Chrysler Corp.'s case, disappear. The automakers reported 1989 earnings this week, including the base for profit-sharing calculations _ earnings on their U.S. operations. After all the arithmetic is done, the Big Three will spend 93.7 percent less on profit-sharing this year than they did last year. ``They'd rather make the money, I'm sure, and pay it out,'' said auto analyst Joseph Phillippi if Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc. in New York. Chrysler said Tuesday it made $359 million during 1989, but that included a $309 million one-time gain from the sale of stock in Mitsubishi Motors Corp. and a one-time, $557 million charge for closing two plants and other matters. In sum, the nation's No. 3 automaker didn't make enough money to trigger profit-sharing formulas for hourly and some salaried employees or bonus provisions for upper-level white-collar workers. About 443,000 of GM's hourly and salaried workers will get $50 each in profit-sharing, the company said Thursday. The world's largest automaker declined to say specifically how much it made in the United States, other than to say only that GM was profitable in the market. Friday, Ford Motor Co. announced that about 150,000 of its hourly and salaried workers would receive profit-sharing checks of about $1,025 each next month. Ford said it earned $1.1 billion in the United States last year. Last year, GM workers received $265 each in profit-sharing, Chrysler employees got $720 apiece and eligible Ford workers received $2,800 each. While Ford's payments this year are the largest among the Big Three, they don't match what Honda's employees received in November. Each of the 8,800 employees at the four Ohio plants operated by Honda of America Manufacturing Inc. received an average $1,600 in ``bonus-sharing'' payments, said spokeswoman Sharon Van Winkle. The payments are based on worldwide profits from all operations of the Japanese automaker. There are no profit-sharing provisions for manufacturing employees at the U.S. factories of Toyota Motor Corp., Mazda Motor Corp. and Nissan Motor Co. Ltd., all of Japan. Nor are there profit-sharing programs at the GM-Toyota venture in Fremont, Calif., called New United Motor Manufacturing Inc., or the Chrysler-Mitsubishi Diamond-Star Motors Corp. plant in Normal, Ill. In all, the Big Three will spend about $40 million in profit-sharing payments this year, compared with the $604.1 million they laid out last year. The decrease could affect contract talks between the United Auto Workers union and the Big Three automakers. Negotiations are expected to begin in July. The contracts expire at midnight Sept. 14. ``Ford obviously is in a decidedly advantageous position on a labor relations standpoint as a result of this,'' Phillippi said. UAW President Owen Bieber said Tuesday that although there would be no profit-sharing for Chrysler hourly employees, ``at least there will be some equality of sacrifice and Chrysler executives will have to go without bonuses as well.'' There may be a problem at GM, Phillippi said. ``The problem GM is going to have is the hourly guys get $50 and the executive bonus pool group is probably going to get a pretty sizeable check,'' he said. ``It's only going to make sitting down at the bargaining table rather sticky.''

DOC.HEAD: Nielsen Picked to Measure Cable TV Viewership in Europe
DOC.TEXT: Dun & Bradstreet Corp.'s A.C. Nielsen subsidiary said Friday it has been selected to measure the cable television audience across 11 European countries. Nielsen, which is based in Northbrook, Ill., said it was selected over two other audience-measurement companies, Audits of Great Britain and Britain's RSL, for the contract awarded by Pan-European Television Audience Research. Terms were not disclosed. Nielsen said its operations in Great Britain will direct the project, which will collect viewing information from 3,500 households representing the European cable TV audience of 15-20 million households. It said it plans to publish the first results in August. Nielsen said the industry group making the award was composed of the British Broadcasting Corp., Turner Broadcasting System's Cable News Network, the Italian state television service RAI, News Corp. Ltd.'s Sky Television and two German-language satellite channels, among others. The services are delivered via satellite to cable households throughout Europe. Krus Benson of Sky Television, the chairman of the industry group, was quoted as saying the group was ``looking to achieve a consistently high standard of information throughout 11 countries.'' The countries involved in the measurement system are West Germany, the Netherlands, Belgium, Switzerland, Austria, Norway, Sweden, Denmark, Finland, Great Britain and Ireland. Nielsen said the contract fits with its plans to deliver comprehensive integrated information on both a country-by-country basis and across national borders within Europe. Nielsen has been measuring U.S. television audiences for 40 years. It also measures TV audiences in nine other countries.

DOC.HEAD: SEC Accuses Bolar Pharmaceutical of Fraud
DOC.TEXT: The Securities and Exchange Commission filed fraud charges Friday against Bolar Pharmaceutical Co., accusing the beleaguered generic drug manufacturer of making false and misleading disclosure statements. The SEC, in a complaint filed at U.S. District Court in Washington, accused Bolar of making misleading and inadequate disclosure to the investing public about an agreement with the Food and Drug Administration to suspend shipment of some of its drugs. The SEC action, the second against Bolar in as many months, also named former Bolar President Robert Shulman. Last month, the SEC suspended trading in Bolar's securities for 10 days. The SEC accused Bolar and Shulman of violating the anti-fraud provisions of federal securities law, which requires prompt and truthful disclosure of significant events regarding a company. The civil complaint sought a court order barring Bolar and Shulman from further alleged violations. The complaint alleged that Bolar failed to disclose that it reached an agreement with the Food and Drug Administration earlier this month to suspend shipment temporarily of all of its products until at least Feb. 6. Bolar agreed to the temporary shipment suspension ``pending an agreement with the FDA to indefinitely withdraw its narrow-range therapeutic drugs with the potential for serious physical harm,'' the SEC alleged, adding ``These facts were not disclosed to investors until Feb. 8, after trading in the securities of Bolar was halted on the American Stock Exchange.'' Between the time the 10-day trading suspension ended Feb. 5 _ when Bolar stock was trading a $10.75 a share _ until trading on the AMEX was halted Feb. 7, 2.27 million shares of Bolar stock were traded and the price rose to $13.12 per share, according to the SEC. The Copaigue, N.Y.-based generic drug maker said Friday it had no comment on the SEC suit. On Jan. 23, the SEC suspended trading of Bolar securities for 10 days after allegations that the company falsified safety claims about a high blood pressure drug. That suspension came after a House subcommittee disclosed a letter from Bolar's attorneys that indicated Bolar apparently falsified documents about safety tests for its generic version of a popular anti-hypertension drug, Dyazide. Dyazide is a widely prescribed high blood pressure medication made by SmithKline Beecham. There is no FDA allegation against that drug. In August, the FDA said it would seek to remove Bolar's version of Dyazide, claiming the drug maker may have misrepresented documentation and safety data. Bolar disputed the allegations. However, the House Energy and Commerce Committee's subcommittee on oversight and investigation disclosed a letter from attorneys for Bolar that said the company appeared to have used false documents to fight government action against its generic form of Dyazide.

Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. fired thousands of workers and doled out slim severance packages as the Wall Street wonder of the 1980s headed into oblivion. The bulk of Drexel's 5,300 employees were turned loose Friday into a slumping securities industry that already has witnessed tens of thousands of layoffs since the 1987 stock market crash. Drexel workers, some tearful, carried boxes and wheeled shopping carts filled with computer equipment bought at a discount from the firm as they left the headquarters in lower Manhattan.

A surprisingly large 30 percent trade-balance improvement in December allowed the nation to close out 1989 with a $108.6 billion deficit, the smallest in five years, the government said. Private economists noted, however, that while U.S. exports hit an all-time high last year, so did imports, driven upward by America's growing dependence on foreign oil. Some economists forecast Friday that the deficit this year will worsen as consumers continue to buy imported products and the foreign oil bill rises.

Industrial production took its biggest plunge in nearly four years last month, the government said, but analysts cited temporary factors for the 1.2 percent drop. The Federal Reserve said Friday the production slump was the steepest since output plummeted 1.3 percent in March 1986. But it attributed the decrease to a drop in energy use due to abnormally warm weather and to temporary layoffs in the automobile industry to correct bloated inventories.

Regulators seized Franklin Savings Association of Ottawa, Kan., the state's largest thrift and one of the few S&Ls to participate heavily in the futures markets. To protect depositors, the Office of Thrift Supervision said Friday it was turning the institution over to the Resolution Trust Corp. With $11.4 billion in assets at the end of December, it was the largest thrift in Kansas. It was the 21st biggest S&L in the nation, according to Sheshunoff Information Services Inc. of Austin, Texas.

While Bank of New England Corp. scrambles to improve its health by selling assets and eliminating thousands of jobs, those steps might not save the bank from the growing ills of bad real estate loans, analysts say. ``They are probably not far behind Drexel,'' said Virginia Adair, a banking analyst with Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., the Wall Street investment firm that filed for bankruptcy this week over junk bond losses. The bank is near the halfway point in a plan to sell $6 billion in assets, and Marcia Ryan, a company spokeswoman, said Friday the bank expects to lay off about 2,000 employees.

Employees of the nation's Big Three automakers will feel the financial pinch that's squeezing their companies as they watch their profit-sharing checks shrivel or, in Chrysler Corp.'s case, disappear. The automakers reported 1989 earnings this week, including the base for profit-sharing calculations _ earnings on their U.S. operations. After all the arithmetic is done, the Big Three will spend 93.7 percent less on profit-sharing this year than they did last year.

First Boston Corp. said it was eliminating its bond futures brokerage business for customers on the Chicago Board of Trade and Chicago Mercantile Exchange and laying off 29 employees. The private New York-based investment bank said Friday it will continue trading listed futures for its own account on the two exchanges.

Western officials considered pleas for cash and credit from five East European countries that shed Communist rule and now want to embrace free-market economies. The representatives of 24 Western nations took no immediate action Friday on the litany of requests, leaving it up to a meeting in early June of foreign ministers. East Germany, Czechoslovakia, Bulgaria, Yugoslavia and Romania are seeking the same sort of Western assistance that was given to Poland and Hungary, two nations that led the remarkable string of anti-Communist revolts last year.

Advertising that used animated characters ranging from dancing raisins to a drumming toy rabbit scored well when consumers were asked to pick the best commercials of 1989, a research firm said. Commercials from McDonald's topped the list compiled and released Friday by Video Storyboard Tests Inc., a consumer research firm based in New York. Second were ads for Pepsi products followed by California Raisin ads featuring a claymation version of entertainer Michael Jackson.

The stock market was mixed Friday, as the Dow Jones average of 30 industrials dropped 13.96 to 2,635.59, finishing the week with a net loss of 12.61 points. Bond prices finished little changed. The dollar took a nosedive as traders interpreted trade figures to show consumer spending was sowing. Copper futures prices soared; precious metal futures advanced; petroleum futures slipped; livestock and meat futures were mixed; and grains and soybeans retreated.

DOC.HEAD: FDIC Sues Drexel, Shearson Over Alleged Fraud Scheme
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS penultimate graf to CORRECT spelling of Shearson spokesman's name.
DOC.TEXT: Regulators said Friday they filed suit seeking more than $500 million from Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., the parent of Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc. and others over an alleged fraud scheme that led to the failure of a Texas savings institution. The Federal Deposit Insurance Corp. alleges that five former salesmen at Drexel, whose parent filed for bankruptcy this week, and the now-defunct E.F. Hutton & Co., which was absorbed by Shearson, helped put together a scheme to defraud Guaranty Federal Savings and Loan Association of Dallas. The agency, which provides deposit insurance for banks and S&Ls, seeks $129.2 million in actual damages and $387.6 million in punitive damages. The suit was filed Wednesday in U.S. District Court in Dallas. A Shearson spokesman disputed the allegations and said the company would seek to have the suit dismissed. A Drexel spokesman did not immediately return a call seeking comment. The suit alleges that the sales representatives helped two former chairmen of Guaranty Federal, Paul Sau-Ki Cheng and Simon Edward Heath, divert profits from government securities trading into trusts and corporations controlled by the two. ``The central purpose of the fraud scheme was to divert federally-insured deposits to shore up a takeover attempt by Cheng and Heath of U.S. Home Corp., a large publicly traded home building company,'' the FDIC said. At the time, Drexel was U.S. Home's investment banker. The suit says personnel from Drexel's Beverly Hills, Calif., office ``advised and encouraged'' Heath and Cheng to attempt the takeover. The acquisition failed, resulting in a loss of $68.5 million to Guaranty Federal but profits of $49.6 million to brokers and $11.1 million to trusts controlled by Heath and Cheng, the FDIC said. Guaranty Federal, with $2 billion in assets, failed in September 1988. Heath and Cheng are charged in an unrelated criminal indictment with defrauding the S&L. The defendants in the FDIC suit are Drexel, Shearson Lehman Hutton Holdings Inc. as successor to E.F. Hutton, Heath, Cheng, the five former salesmen, and two trusts and three corporations controlled by Heath and Cheng. Shearson spokesman Steve Faigen said there is ``absolutely no evidence of wrongdoing or merit to the allegations. The claim for damages is preposterous and we will seek to have the suit dismissed promptly.'' Phone numbers for the other defendants could not be found immediately.

DOC.HEAD: Air Wisconsin Buys Part of Denver-based Airline
DOC.TEXT: Air Wisconsin has signed a letter of intent to acquire Denver-based Aspen Airways Inc., which operates feeder routes for United Airlines as United Express, officials announced Friday. William Geenen, Air Wisconsin's vice president for finance, said the acquisition would be operated as a separate business and not be folded into Air Wisconsin as was Mississippi Valley when that airline was purchased in 1985. The move will represent Air Wisconsin's first venture into operating a subsidiary airline. Aspen is a 35-year-old, family-controlled airline operating primarily between Aspen and Denver. It also connects a number of smaller communities with Denver and seasonally flies ski charter trips from Chicago, Dallas and Los Angeles to Aspen. Aspen operates a fleet of four BAe-146 jets and 10 48-passenger Convair 580 turboprops. Air Wisconsin officials say that company will only receive the four BAe-146 jets and will operate the Aspen-Denver routes and seasonal Aspen service from Chicago, Los Angeles and Dallas. A majority of the stock in Aspen Airways is owned by the Donald Ringsby family. Mesa Airlines of Farmington, N.M., purchased the Convairs and other routes and will operate them under the Mesa corporate name, but also fly as United Express.

DOC.NOTE: $adv18
For release Sunday Feb. 18
DOC.HEAD: Did Threat of Racketeering Indictment Cinch Drexel Demise?
DOC.TEXT: Late in 1988, former U.S. Attorney Rudolph Giuliani gave Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. a choice: Plead guilty to securities crimes or face indictment on racketeering charges. ``It was like he put a gun in the middle of the table and said, `I can shoot you, or you can shoot yourself,''' said a Drexel junk-bond executive who quit last year after 20 years at the firm. Many on Wall Street _ not only defenders of the investment Goliath _ believe Drexel's fate was determined not last week when it defaulted on $100 million in debt but in December 1988 when it agreed to admit criminal behavior in six transactions and pay $650 million in penalties. Prosecution under the Racketeer Influenced and Corrupt Organizations act threatened Drexel with pretrial asset seizures that likely would have put the firm out of business on the spot. By pleading guilty in the government's insider trading sweep, Drexel gained the right to keep peddling junk bonds, underwriting stock and arranging mergers. It avoided the lengthy public ordeal of a trial and further erosion of investor confidence. But it was forced to sever ties with junk bond dynamo Michael Milken, who led the firm's rapid rise in the 1980s to the pinnacle of Wall Street. It agreed to disembowel some profitable operations and permit microscope scrutiny by federal regulators that shackled some businesses. If Giuliani's threat was no more than a bluff by a publicity-friendly prosecutor (who went on to run unsuccessfully for mayor), then Drexel is no more and 5,000 people are losing their jobs without proof that crimes were committed. ``Without a judge and a jury, as soon as they brought RICO charges they killed Drexel,'' a top executive at a rival Wall Street firm said last week. ``They just chose a slow death instead of a fast one.'' Off Wall Street, former prosecutors, regulators and legal experts said the theory of government culpability in Drexel's demise is an attempt to turn the perpetrator into a victim. The pursuit of Drexel may have been aggressive but the firm admitted to the crimes alleged and the government's case was strong, they said. ``Do the best-paid and most articulate defense attorneys advise clients to plead guilty and pay $650 million in fines in response to an empty threat?'' said Michael Goldsmith, a RICO expert and law professor at Brigham Young University. ``When you're indicted for fraud that's going to affect your business,'' he said. ``Surely these companies aren't suggesting they shouldn't be indicted for fraud?'' After settling last year, Drexel halved its work force, dumped businesses and restructured top management in an effort to compete as a medium-sized firm. But without Milken leading the firm's Beverly Hills, Calif., junk bond division, Drexel's pre-eminence in the lucrative field began to falter, and some clients steered clear because of its tarnished reputation. ``The assessment at the commission was that if it could not operate in an honest fashion it should not operate,'' said David Ruder, the Securities and Exchange Commssion chairman during the Drexel case. ``The (SEC) complaint is a very strong indictment of the way they did business there,'' he said. ``Our effort was to reform that operation. There was always some doubt about whether once reformed it would work.'' In filing for bankruptcy protection last week, Drexel's parent said it was hurt by a capital shortage partly created by a decline in the high-yield bond market Milken helped create. Analysts said that pointed out problems in relying on one product to sustain a financial services business. As Drexel's problems came to a head, government regulators refused to step in and ask banks to provide Drexel with enough money to keep it alive. Officials in Washington said they determined that Drexel's elimination would not have a serious impact on the nation's financial markets. ``I think it was clear from the outset of the investigation that (Drexel) might not survive because the investigation went to the heart of their business,'' said former SEC enforcement director Gary Lynch, who spearheaded the Drexel probe. ``The settlement ... gave them every chance at survivial,'' he said. ``Unfortunately for the firm there was a general deterioration in the junk market that obviously hurt them.'' In addition, Drexel insiders say that the firm embarked on several shaky deals in the post-Milken era that bore the sign of ``quantity not quality'' and further eroded its reputation. A general slump in the securities industry didn't help either. Milken has been charged in a 98-count racketeering and fraud indictment in connection with Drexel's underlying crimes _ as well as others _ but has yet to go on trial. His friends claim that if he is acquitted, then Drexel's passing was for naught since he was the supposed architect of Drexel's crimes. The theory of government blame holds sway with many Drexel employees, who remained loyal to the firm and defensive to the outside world in the face of the scandals. ``We were really screwed by the government,'' Ken Haim, a 26-year-old Drexel debt analyst, said after he was fired on Friday. Detractors claim the government was on a witch hunt in its ballyhooed crackdown on white-collar crime. The Wall Street Journal, a forceful critic of the RICO law, said in an editorial last week that ``it's now clear that the collapse of Drexel was decided in the prosecutorial hothouse of the late 1980s.'' ``Most notable was Mr. Giuliani's decision to not merely bring traditional charges against Mr. Milken and Drexel, but to use RICO,'' the Journal said. ``It didn't matter that the RICO law was designed by Congress explicitly for the Mafia or that this would somehow morally equate investment banking with loan sharking and murder.'' But Goldmsith said: ``To a degree it relects Wall Street's bias against RICO. I suppose the fear that they have is, `There but for the grace of God go I.'''
DOC.NOTE: End advance for Sunday Feb. 18

DOC.HEAD: Hong Kong Concern Countersues Cummins Engine
DOC.TEXT: A Hong Kong investment concern battling to win a seat on the board of Cummins Engine Co. has countersued the Indiana diesel engine maker, documents disclosed Friday. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission in Washington, Industrial Equity (Pacific) Ltd., said it sued Cummins Thursday at federal court in Indianapolis. The lawsuit named Cummins and six of its directors, including chairman and chief executive officer Henry B. Schacht. It claimed that the six ``manage Cummins not for the benefit of its shareholders and its other corporate constituencies, but to enhance their own personal power and prestige.'' Cummins sued IEP, which holds a 14.9 percent stake in the Columbus, Ind.-based manufacturer, seeking to force IEP to sell its 1.9 million shares of Cummins stock. Cummins launched its lawsuit after IEP sought representation on the Cummins board. In its countersuit, which sought to overturn Cummins' poison-pill, antitake over defense, IEP, the Hong Kong arm of New Zealand's Brierley Investments Ltd., charged that inside directors ``have gone to extraordinary lengths to deter investment by any large shareholder who might exercise independent judgment or ask questions.'' There was no answer at Cummins headquarters when called for comment late Friday.

DOC.HEAD: Federal Regulators Take Over Largest Thrift in Kansas
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 1 graf after 7th graf pvs, `However, the ...,' to ADD analyst comment. SUBS 11th graf pvs, `Franklin and ...,' to CORRECT amount of deferred losses to $119 million sted $200 million. ADDS 6 grafs with background, quotes. A shorter version moved on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: Franklin comment

Regulators on Friday seized Franklin Savings Association of Ottawa, Kan., the state's largest thrift and one of the few S&Ls to participate heavily in the futures markets. To protect depositors, the Office of Thrift Supervision said it was turning the institution over to the Resolution Trust Corp. ``Franklin was operating in an unsafe and unsound condition likely to cause insolvency or a substantial dissipation of assets,'' the thrift office said. With $11.4 billion in assets at the end of December, it was the largest thrift in Kansas. It was the 21st biggest S&L in the nation, according to Sheshunoff Information Services Inc. of Austin, Texas. Franklin has $4.7 billion in 154,423 deposit accounts. Regulators said its nine branches would remain open and all deposits would be protected up to the $100,000 insurance limit. The institution specialized in a complex financial strategy in which it accepted high-rate deposits from Wall Street brokers and invested them in mortgage-backed securities, using futures contracts to protect itself from swings in interest rates. However, the thrift office said the strategy didn't work and the S&L was hit hard by a change in interest rates. ``Frankly I'm very suprised. Their entire strategy was based on protecting Franklin from interest rate risk and they had a very sophisticated system for doing that,'' said Henry Peltz, an analyst with Keefe, Bruyette and Woods in New York. The announcement came one day after the publicly traded S&L disclosed that regulators were conducting what it called a routine examination of its operations. Franklin Vice Chairman John Scowcroft had assured reporters that the thrift was not in danger of becoming insolvent. Franklin was seized under a provision of the S&L law enacted last August that permits regulators to step in to prevent an institution from dissipating its assets or engaging in unsafe and unsound practices, thrift office spokesman William Fulwider said. Although Franklin met its net worth requirement as of Dec. 31, regulators ordered it to book further losses that would deplete all of its tangible capital and saw no reasonable prospect that it could raise the capital, Fulwider said. Franklin and regulators were involved in an accounting dispute centering on the treatment of $119 million in deferred losses from the futures market, which the institution planned to take over five years. If a heavy loss depressed Franklin's net worth below regulatory requirements, the thrift had an agreement with zero-coupon bond holders that would trigger an even larger reduction in net worth. On Thursday, Franklin reported a net profit of $3 million, or 8 cents a share, in its second quarter ended Dec. 31, compared with a loss of $21.5 million in the same quarter of 1988. It also announced a management shakeup in which William J. Marshall was named president and chief executive officer, replacing Duane H. Hall. The RTC said it appointed John Carr as Franklin's managing agent. He is the former chief executive officer of Gibraltar Savings of Beverly Hills, Calif. The agency also is hiring two firms, Hyperion Capital Management Inc. and Ranieri Wilson & Co. Inc., to advise it on how to handle Franklin's securities and futures portfolio. Founded in 1889 as the Ottawa Mutual Loan and Savings Association, Franklin mounted a rapid-growth strategy that relied excessively on high-cost deposits from money brokers, the thrift office said. As of Dec. 31, 70 percent of its deposits came from brokers. ``Their problem was they had a very high interest expense, one of the highest in the business,'' said Kenneth H. Thomas, a financial institutions analyst in Miami. He noted that the S&L also had a big junk bond portfolio _ $247 million at the end of September, the 11th largest in the country. Franklin's parent firm, Franklin Savings Corp., owns 92 percent of thrift's stock, while 5.5 percent of the stock is traded publicly in the over-the-counter market. Franklin officials declined to comment on the seizure, directing questions to the institution's government managers.

DOC.HEAD: Vestron Names Potential Candidate for Merger
DOC.TEXT: Vestron Inc., a film and video company whose credits include ``Dirty Dancing'' and ``Hamburger Hill,'' said Friday it was discussing a possible merger with LIVE Entertainment Inc., a Los Angeles-based video and music entertainment company. Vestron confirmed discussions over a non-cash merger in which LIVE would buy all of Vestron's assets or securities in exchange for a package of LIVE equity securities. It said Tuesday it was considering a proposal from an unidentified party. LIVE is an entertainment software distributor with anticipated 1989 revenue of $450 million, up from $352 million in 1988, said company spokeswoman Vicki Greenleaf. It owns International Video Entertainment, a home video distributor in Los Angeles; Strawberries record stores of Milford, Mass.; and Lieberman Enterprises, a Minneapolis-based services firm for the retail industry. Vestron, which had $335 million in sales in 1988, reported a nine-month net loss of $87.8 million last year, compared to net income of $18.9 million in the same 1988 period. The company owns Vestron Video, a domestic videocassette distributor; Video Store, a retail video outlet; and Vestron International Group, which distributes videocassettes abroad, said John McInerney of Abernathy-MacGregor Group, Vestron's investor relations consultant. Another division, Vestron Pictures, began in January 1986 as an offshoot of Vestron Video, which at the time was the country's largest independent videocassette distributor. Its completed or near-finished films include ``Little Monsters,'' starring Fred Savage, ``Fear'' with Ally Sheedy, and ``Blue Steel'' with Jamie Lee Curtis. The division shut down in August because of a cash-flow strain caused when Security Pacific National Bank decided to end an agreement to provide a six-year, $100 million line of credit, McInerney said. He said Security Pacific agreed to provide the credit line Aug. 10, 1988, and withdrew from the deal on Oct. 21, 1988. Vestron officials have filed suit alleging breach of contract.

DOC.HEAD: AT&T To Phase Out Five Data Processing Centers
DOC.TEXT: Five of AT&T's 12 national data processing offices will be phased out over the next 18 months as part of a cost-cutting plan, resulting in the loss of 1,000 jobs, the company said Friday. The move continues a cutback in the information management services division of American Telephone & Telegraph Co. begun three years ago. That division has shrunk from 7,700 workers to 7,400 since 1987, not including the latest cuts, the company said. AT&T said it would try to offer transfers or early retirement to the workers affected. AT&T said it expects to save about $70 million a year when the division has been fully consolidated into seven offices. The offices to be closed are in Hamilton Township, N.J., Cincinnati, Greensboro, N.C., Oakton, Va., and Fairhaven, Mass. The remaining offices are in Denver, Kansas City, Mo., Mesa, Ariz., Orlando, Fla., Bridgewater, N.J., and Knightsbridge, N.J.

DOC.HEAD: Bass Buyout Offer for St. Petersburg Newspaper Rejected
DOC.TEXT: A $270 million buyout offer for the company that publishes the St. Petersburg Times, one of the South's most prominent newspapers, was flatly rejected Friday by trustees who told an investor group led by Texas billionaire Robert M. Bass that the newspaper was not for sale. The Bass group responded immediately by saying the fight with the Times wasn't over. Trustees of the Poynter Institute, a journalism school that owns controlling stock in Times Publishing Co., voted unanimously to turn down the bid made last month. The company publishes the newspaper and Congressional Quarterly. ``The trustees carefully considered the institute's educational purpose and concluded it was better to own a newspaper than a stack of Treasury bills,'' said Andrew Barnes, chairman of the board of trustees and editor, president and chief executive of the newspaper. ``The institute's ownership interest in the Times is not for sale,'' Barnes said. The institute was set up by the late Nelson Poynter who ran the paper for 30 years before his death in 1978. ``In light of previous statements by Mr. Barnes and his unique capacity to make decisions for both the Times Publishing Co. and the institute, this announcement is not unexpected,'' said David Bonderman, a general partner and spokesman for the Texas investors. Through a complicated ownership plan the not-for-profit school ultimately is the majority stockholder of the newspaper. Some shares are owned by Poynter's widow, Marion, who endorsed the institute's action, calling it the only decision that could have been made. ``Nelson spent the better part of a lifetime assembling defenses against assaults such as these,'' Mrs. Poynter said. ``Just because the attacks have become more sophisticated and the weapons gold-plated there is no reason to give up the battle for independence, integrity and commitment to the larger community.'' The Bass group, which bought a minority stake in the company from disgruntled Poynter heirs in mid-1988, offered $270 million _ $90,000 for each of 3,000 shares of common stock. The partnership controls 200 shares _ or 40 percent _ of the voting stock which earns 5.7 percent of the company's dividends. In another action, the Bass group has filed suit in federal court for a bigger share of the dividends, which they claim aren't fairly distributed in breach of fiduciary trust to stockholders. ``As fiduciaries for all of the common shareholders, the Board of Times Publishing simply cannot pay dividends of $3.7 million per year on preferred stock owned by only one of the common shareholders when the company can redeem the preferred stock at any time for $318,000,'' Bonderman said. ``The issue remains, and we will, of course, continue to pursue its resolution by whatever means are available to us,'' Bonderman said.

DOC.HEAD: Black Investors Settle Baltimore Cable TV Set-Aside Dispute
DOC.TEXT: Two black investors, who claimed a cable television company failed to live up to a minority set-aside clause in its agreement with the city, have agreed to a settlement that could be worth $100 million. United Cable Television Corp. of Baltimore agreed to the settlement Monday, midway through a trial brought by the two investors. The plaintiffs contended that the cable company blocked them and other minority investors from obtaining a 25 percent ownership interest in the franchise as required by the special set-aside provision of the original franchise won from the city. The two investors, Clarence Elder, a Baltimore businessman, and O. Patrick Scott, a Prince George's County public school art teacher, will receive an immediate $8.7 million lump-sum payment. In addition, United Cable will transfer to them more than 2,100 units, or shares, in United's investment partnership that underwrites the cable system. Those units, in addition to 311 they already own, could be worth up to $92.3 million by 1995 if Scott and Elder decide to sell them that year, according to court estimates cited by attorneys for Scott and Elder. United Cable officials put the total settlement figure at about $50 million. By whatever measure, ``the result is a great one,'' said Stephen Snyder, chief attorney for Scott and Elder. Under the settlement, approved by Baltimore Circuit Judge Hilary Caplan, Snyder's Baltimore law firm, Snyder, Mehlman and Wais, will receive 40 percent of the cash and stock paid out to Scott and Elder. In agreeing to the settlement, United Cable acknowledged no wrongdoing. ``It was a business dispute, and that's the way we looked at it from the beginning,'' said John Neal, a vice president of United Artists Entertainment Co., the Denver-based parent of United Cable. Elder and Scott claimed in their lawsuit that United Cable resorted to various subterfuges to limit minority ownership interest in the franchise to about 3.5 percent, rather than the 25 percent required by the city. Neal said the ownership issue was ``clouded'' by varying interpretations of the franchise agreement and by ``the inability (of black investors) to raise the money in the full amount for their 25 percent interest.''

DOC.HEAD: Steel Imports Down, Exports Up in 1989
DOC.TEXT: Steel imports declined in 1989 and exports rose substantially, an industry group reported Friday. The American Iron and Steel Institute said both figures reflect the greater competitiveness of American steel in the domestic and world markets. The group cited production efficiencies in the U.S. industry and continuous strong demand for steel in the world market. According to the group's compilation of U.S. Commerce Department figures, imports of steel-mill products last year were 17.3 million net tons. That marks a decrease from the 20.9 million tons imported in 1988. Steel exports totalled 4.6 million tons in 1989, which was up from the 2.1 million tons exported the previous year, the group said. The 1989 export figure was the highest since a steel boom year in 1974, the institute said. The post-World War II high for exports was 7.1 million tons in 1970.

DOC.HEAD: Nordstrom Stock Falls As Company Faces Labor Orders, Lower Revenues
DOC.TEXT: Hit with a double-whammy of lower revenue projections and an order by the state of Washington to stop breaking wage laws, Nordstrom Inc. stock fell 9.2 percent Friday, from $32.50 to $29.50 per share. The retail chain announced Thursday that its fourth-quarter earnings, to be released in a few days, will be lower than earnings for the same period a year earlier. Also Thursday, the state Department of Labor and Industries ordered Nordstrom to pay two years' worth of unpaid overtime to its hourly employees in Washington state, a decision that eventually could affect all 30,000 employees of the department store operator nationwide. Ruling on a complaint filed by Locals 1001 and 367, United Food and Commercial Workers in Seattle and Tacoma, the state labor department found that Nordstrom violated the state Minimum Wage Act. Nordstrom could be liable for $40 million in claims and penalties in Washington state alone, and for $300 million in California, Local 1001 president Joe Peterson said Friday at a news conference. The union did not immediately provide projections for possible claims in other states. Peterson said a class-action suit on behalf of Nordstrom employees nationwide would be filed against the chain if it doesn't comply with the state order. Bruce Nordstrom, co-chairman of the company's board of directors, said in a Friday news release: ``We will be reviewing our record-keeping procedures and making any necessary back-pay adjustments for those Washington employees who may be affected by the department's findings. ``However, comments by the union representatives about the financial impact of those pay adjustments are purely speculative and we believe greatly overstated.'' According to the labor department and the union, Nordstrom consistently encourages employees to volunteer their time for such activities as attending company meetings, preparing paperwork and inventory, and making customer deliveries. The department ordered Nordstrom to start proper record-keeping for the hours its employees works and offer back pay to those who have put in unpaid overtime. ``Nordstrom is doing a disservice to its reputation, employees and stockholders by continuing to deny that they have a culture ... that requires employees to work without pay,'' Peterson said Friday. The alleged practice forces employees to work unpaid hours to improve their sales per hour, he said. Those who don't participate see their hours cut and don't get promoted, he claimed. The technique, he added, gives Nordstrom an unfair competitive advantage. ``Nordstrom has a great reputation for customer service and merchandising. There is no reason why they can't continue to be that but, like other employers, pay their employees,'' he said. Nordsrom spokeswoman Kellie Tormey said Friday that any implication that employees who don't work unpaid overtime aren't promoted is ``absolutely false.'' She also said Nordstrom had always provided employees with extra pay for extra work and if that weren't the case, she asked rhetorically, why did so many employees stay with the company? The union has collected 450 claims for $2.1 million in back pay and expects more now because of the state order, Peterson said. Marcia Raley, who follows Nordstrom for the Dain Bosworth Inc. brokerage in Minneapolis, said she thinks the earnings projection is more responsible for the market decline than the labor department order. However, she said, Nordstrom's response to the order will make a difference in the future. She estimated that Nordstrom's fourth-quarter earnings per share were 48 cents, down from 58 cents a year earlier. Her guess on year-end results is $1.47 a share, down from $1.51 a year earlier. Nordstrom has 60 stores in Washington, California, Oregon, Utah, Virginia and Alaska. It plans 16 more stores in Oregon, California, New Jersey, Illinois, Maryland, Minnesota, Indiana, Connecticut, Massachusetts and New York. The Seattle-based chain, closely held by the Nordstrom family, has prospered in recent years in part because of its reputation for customer service.
